The companies estimate they've spent as much as $6 million on the cleanup, and the state has spent about $175,000, Stokes said. ``It's probably been the largest non-oil cleanup in the state,'' Stokes said. ``I certainly think it's been the most complex, being right in the middle of a town.'' Preliminary results of follow-up soil tests in what were once the most contaminated areas show lead levels below the limit of 1,000 parts per million, Stokes said. Before the cleanup, concentrations were as high as 133,000 ppm. Much of the cleanup has employed large vacuum trucks that can suck up soil several inches deep. The vacuum separates the fine, lead-filled soil from the coarse soil. The ore then is filtered through screens at the terminal and washed into holding ponds, Taylor said. The lead that settles to the bottom will be recovered and the water filtered. ``In the end we'll have a few thousand gallons of clean water and a truckload of lead,'' Taylor said. The residential cleanup, unlike the industrial effort, is optional. Property owners are being offered the services of the vacuum-truck crews to get the lead out of their yards. ``We aren't planning to rip up any sidewalks or even tear up established lawns,'' Stokes said. ``We'll try to target loose soils in places where tracking would be the most significant. ``There hasn't been a whole lot of interest. I think we'll end up with one or two dozen lots where we'll do some work.'' Before the blood test results were announced last fall, DEC officials had considered ordering an indoor cleanup of homes where vacuum cleaner samples had shown high concentrations of lead. That idea was rejected in light of the small health risk. ``It would be too expensive and too disruptive. It wasn't justified,'' Stokes said. Instead the state has told residents to reduce their exposure to the ore by increased handwashing, frequent damp mopping and dusting, and avoiding tracking soil into their homes. Concern over the lead appears to have subsided in Skagway as it prepares for summer, which every year brings thousands of tourists on cruise ships and day excursions from Juneau, 92 miles to the south. A group formed to monitor the cleanup, Get the Lead Out, disbanded last week. And when the state held a public hearing on the spring cleanup plans Wednesday, only about 20 people showed. Lynne Smith, a mother who has lived on and off in Skagway for 13 years, said the group's members were not fully satisfied with the cleanup. ``But we've really gone through a lot in the last year,'' she said, ``so we just have to decide what we will do in our own individual lives as far as protecting our children.''

DOC.HEAD: Berlin Market Draws Poles By The Thousands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with figures on customs violations, further details on sales, SUB 8 grafs for grafs 13-19, `Poles call ... 3,000 zlotys.' Picks up 20th pvs, `Other Poles ...' ^An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Even the Easter holidays didn't stop thousands of Poles from streaming into West Berlin _ some to shop, others to sell goods in a muddy, littered field known as the ``Polish market.'' The influx of Poles to West Berlin, one of the few Western European destinations they can visit without visas, has increased dramatically since the Polish zloty became convertible in January. More than a million Poles have visited since, West Berlin officials say. Many head for the Polish market, a ragtag bazaar near central Potsdamer Platz where Poles sell whatever they can bring from home. They cart to West Berln everything from caviar smuggled out of the Soviet Union to farm fresh eggs and bacon, untaxed cigarettes and Polish vodka. For Poles trying to weather their country's radical transformation from a centrally planned to a free market economy, the bazaar can be a crucial source of income. ``Who knows how long I'll have a job. I'm sure the company will go bust by June,'' said Krzysztof Goral, a bus driver from Poznan, as he tried to sell a pair of mounted deer antlers for 15 marks ($9.30). ``We've got to try to earn while we can,'' said his brother Marek, an electrician, who watched over a pile of chocolates and wooden-handled screwdrivers the brothers also had for sale. The Goral brothers are regulars at the Polish market. Every Friday, they take an evening train on the 205-mile trip to East Berlin. Upon arrival, they stay up all night in order to avoid a hotel bill, then cross into West Berlin to stake out a spot at the market early in the morning. Many other Polish visitors sleep in their cars, tour buses or try to camp in the Zoo train station. Those habits, along with the wide-open trading at the market, appal many Berliners who would like the city government to do something to stop the flow. Poles call it business; Germans call it smuggling and officials have recorded more than 26,000 customs violations so far this year. Officials say the amount of confiscated goods, mostly from Poles, is ``no longer conceivable,'' said the Berlin Morgenpost newspaper. More than 1.5 million cigarettes have been confiscated at the market since January, the newspaper reported. Despite the discomforts of travel and the threat of fines and confiscation, many Poles find the market essential. ``Things are hard in Poland, I've got two kids and no job. I've got to make a living,'' said Stanislaw Neuman of Wroclaw. Neuman lost his job last month as a bus driver as a part of the economic ``shock therapy'' that ended state subsidies and has left more than 200,000 people unemployed since taking effect Jan. 1. His blanket covered with Polish shaving creme, plastic combs, used clothes and hand tools, Neuman hoped to earn a few marks that can be exchanged for zlotys to be spent at home. Although Neuman was selling items for low prices, his mark-ups would make many merchants envious. Among his goods was a comb that he had bought for 1,000 zlotys (about 10 cents); he later sold it for the equivalent of 3,000 zlotys. He also earned 13 marks ($7.75), nearly one-sixth of what he earned each month as a bus driver, for a used pair of high heels sold to a Turkish customer. Other Poles come to buy goods they then sell for a profit back home at one of the thousands of open markets springing up across Poland. But, facing customs restrictions, they may not tell you as much. ``We don't have these kind of things in Poland,'' confided Henryk Stachowicz, a coal miner from Zabrze, pointing proudly to two new electronic keyboards he had just purchased. He said he could get 850,000 zlotys ($89) in Poland for each keyboard, which he purchased for the equivalent of 660,000 zlotys ($69) apiece. Unshaven and dressed in wrinkled clothes, Stachowicz and the other 36 passengers who paid 140,000 zlotys ($14.70) for a round-trip bus ticket, slept in their tour bus in a West Berlin parking lot rather than pay for a hotel. The coal miner denied he planned to resell the keyboards. He also insisted he would never do business at the Polish market. ``Stand there and sell stuff. That's not for me. I have a job. There is just nothing to buy in Poland,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Museum and Director Plead Innocent in Obscenity Case
LaserPhoto CS1
DOC.TEXT: An art gallery and its director pleaded innocent to obscenity charges for exhibiting photos by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. The written pleas were filed Monday in Municipal Court by the Contemporary Arts Center and director Dennis Barrie, who were indicted April 7, the day the exhibit opened in this city that styles itself a scourge against smut. Barrie and the gallery are charged with pandering obscenity and use of a minor in nudity-oriented material, both misdemeanors. Barrie could be jailed for a year and fined $2,000. The gallery could be fined $10,000. Defense attorney H. Louis Sirkin said the case may not go to trial until after the Mapplethorpe exhibit ends its Cincinnati run May 26. A federal judge has barred authorities from confiscating the photos in the meantime. More than 25,000 people have viewed the 175-photo exhibit since it opened. Seven of the photos, depicting naked children and homosexual acts, are singled out in the indictments. An exhibit of the photos in Washington last year prompted Congress to limit funds for the arts after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., declared the photos obscene. Outside the courthouse Monday, about 25 people chanted and waved signs in support of the center. One sign read: ``Myopic Politicians Are Suffocating the People with Backward Social Structures.'' Mapplethorpe died of AIDS in 1989 at age 42.

DOC.HEAD: Freeway Demolition Favored, Despite Chinatown Strike
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: Despite a merchants' strike that turned Chinatown into a virtual ghost town, city supervisors have decided to raze and rebuild an earthquake-damaged freeway rather than take the quicker step of repairing it. The Board of Supervisors voted 6-5 Monday to replace the two-mile, elevated Embarcadero Freeway, which led tourists into Chinatown, North Beach and Fisherman's Wharf before the October quake cracked its concrete towers. The vote was seen as a victory for Mayor Art Agnos, who wants to build a sunken roadway that would cost $120 million and take at least four years. Chinatown merchants had pressed instead for repairs, which state officials said would cost an estimated $32 million and take just six months. Most of Chinatown's 1,200 shops, restaurants and professional offices had shut down Monday afternoon to protest plans to demolish the Embarcadero. The City Hall hearing drew about 1,000 Chinatown residents. ``This is the first time in 205 years the Chinese community has shut down their businesses to protest,'' said protest organizer Rose Pak of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce. The vote brought boos from people in the audience, including many who came to City Hall in chartered buses and wore green T-shirts that read, ``We Love the Embarcadero Freeway.'' Merchants have complained their businesses have suffered since the freeway was closed by the 7.1-magnitude earthquake that shook Northern California on Oct. 17, killing 68 people. Deputy Mayor James Ho estimated business is down by 8 percent; Pak put the drop closer to 30 percent for tourist-dependent businesses and 20 percent for those relying on local residents. The freeway, built in the 1950s, was controversial from the start, with environmentalists contending it was unsightly and split the waterfront from San Francisco's downtown. In opposing demolition, Supervisor Richard Hongisto said neighborhood businesses would suffer during the time it will take to build a new roadway. ``Instead of our favorite Italian or Chinese restaurant, when the freeway finally gets built, you'll find a McDonald's,'' Hongisto said. Agnos vowed to develop a system of streets to route traffic efficiently. He said after the vote that the demolition presented the ``opportunity of a lifetime.'' Supervisor Jim Gonzalez said the city had a chance to ``build one of the most beautiful waterfronts in the history of the United States.'' The Board of Supervisors' vote to ``endorse the concept of a subsurface or surface freeway'' will make a final review of the issue by Aug. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Vargas Llosa Decides Against Quitting Presidential Race
DOC.TEXT: Novelist Mario Vargas Llosa has decided not to withdraw from the presidential runoff against Alfredo Fujimori, the upstart independent who is suddenly favored to win. Saying he is constitutionally required to take part in the second round, Vargas Llosa declared Monday that he will campaign ``fighting for the reforms that our country needs.'' The runoff will probably take place in early June. The celebrated writer, who advocates harsh austerity measures to revive the country's crippled economy, won the most votes in the first round of voting April 8 but was far from the majority needed for election. After his disappointing first-round showing, Vargas Llosa considered pulling out of the race. But he was reported to have been urged to stay in the race by Roman Catholic officials and senior figures in the military. The government is battling a bloody 10-year-old insurgency by Maoist-inspired Shining Path rebels and the military apparently fears Fujimori would not be as forceful a leader as Vargas Llosa. Fujimori, an agronomist who says Vargas Llosa's economic plan would only bring recession, is expected to pick up the votes that had been cast for leftist candidates in the first round. It is believed that Vargas Llosa's association with the wealthy cost him much support. The writer entered the political fray two years ago after leading rallies against President Alan Garcia's attempts to nationalize the country's banks. Fujimori, the descendent of Japanese immigrants and a political unknown when he started the race, has been criticized by Vargas Llosa's center-right Democratic Front coalition for being vague on his plans for Peru. Finally, he is detailing some concrete proposals. In an interview published Monday, Fujimori rejected Vargas Llosa's call to privatize most of Peru's huge companies, which many Peruvians fear would lead to massive layoffs. The candidate also sharply criticized U.S. drug policy in Peru, saying Washington-backed attempts have failed to eradicate coca plants _ the raw material of cocaine. The 51-year-old former rector of Peru's respected National University of Agriculture recommended building railroads and highways into Peru's main coca-producing region so local farmers can more easily get legal produce to markets along the coast. Coca growers ``must be oriented towards other types of cash crops _ rice for example. But for this, highways must be built,'' Fujimori said in the interview in the Lima daily newspaper Pagina Libre. Fujimori was set to announce his official platform at a Monday night press conference, but he canceled at the last minute due to what his wife described as food poisoning. Vargas Llosa's announcement he would stay in the race came an hour later, in a short communique released after meetings with campaign strategists and leaders of his party. In the first round, Vargas Llosa won just 32 percent of the vote after topping 50 percent in February opinion polls. Fujimori won 30 percent. The novelist's coalition also fell well short of capturing a majority in Congress. Vargas Llosa went into seclusion with his family last week to mull over the decision on whether to continue the race. Aides said he was discouraged by the likelihood he would lose the runoff. Equally discouraging, if he won, was the prospect of trying to govern without a congressional majority. Without legislative support, Vargas Llosa would face great problems imposing the harsh austerity measures he advocates. In the Pagina Libre interview, Fujimori said, ``We are not in agreement with the `shock' (program proposed by Vargas Llosa) which would bring a deeper recession, and we are against a recession.'' Fujimori was also quoted as saying he would welcome ``foreign funds and advice'' in the fight against the Shining Path.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down, Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's chief index lost morning gains to inch lower today, while the dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen on expectations of a decline in the U.S. trade deficit. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 1.58 points, or 0.006 percent, ending the day at 28,461.60. The index, which on Monday fell 750.74 points, started lower, regained 349.65 points, and fell back in the afternoon session. Some of the buying in the morning was carried out to prevent the index from falling below 28,000 points, which is seen as a psychological barrier, said a dealer with Nomura Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The stock market is still very sensitive and nervous, although we believe it has bottomed out,'' the dealer said. Traders attributed the afternoon losses to intermittent index-linked selling, including arbitrage, by securities firms. ``Both Japanese and foreign securities firms conducted arbitrage selling from time to time in small amounts throughout the afternoon session,'' said Masayoshi Shimoyama, a senior trader with Nikko Securities Co. Stock traders and analysts have blamed arbitrage sellings for the continuing plunge of the Tokyo stock market since the beginning of this year. Large-scale arbitrage sales in thin trading have a strong impact on the market. The Tokyo Stock Exchange has asked member firms to make a weekly report on the number of shares and the amount of money traded in arbitrage dealings to eliminate uncertainties among investors, stock market officials said Tuesday. Shimoyama said participants gradually withdrew to the sidelines toward the end of the day ahead of the announcement of U.S. trade figures for February slated for Wednesday. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 159.83 yen, up 0.41 yen from Monday's close of 159.42 yen. The currency opened at 159.71 yen and traded between 159.60 yen and 159.95 yen. The dollar was pushed up during the afternoon session by investors expecting improvements in the U.S. trade balance, dealers said. ``The U.S. trade deficit is expected to be around $8.1 billion from $9.3 billion in January. Some even predict the deficit will be $4-5 billion,'' said Toru Kanai, foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. However, dollar selling for profit-taking prevented the U.S. currency from climbing over the 160-yen level, Kanai said. Uncertainties over developments in Lithuania also prompted dollar buying, because the dollar is believed to be the safest investment in times of emergency, said Masato Hayashi, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on Friday threatened to impose economic sanctions on Lithuania if the rebel Baltic republic refuses to rescind legislation passed since its declaration of independence last month. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds was changing hands at 85.90 points at 4 p.m., up from Monday's close at 85.74. The 119's yield fell to 7.385 percent from 7.415 percent on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Flynn Decides Not to Enter Gubernatorial Race
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Raymond Flynn says he's decided against running for governor out of loyalty to the city of Boston. ``The foremost challenge before us today is the task of building a better future for the children of all our neighborhoods and turning the tide against violence, the illegal drug trade and the despair that affects too many of our citizens,'' the Democrat said in a letter to 1,500 community leaders and advocates Monday. ``To complete this unfinished work, I feel an obligation to continue as mayor of this city.'' Flynn had kept analysts and the public speculating on whether he would seek the state's top office ever since Gov. Michael Dukakis, whose fortunes plummeted after the 1988 presidential campaign, decided against a fourth term 15 months ago. ``I have an obligation to the people of the city of Boston,'' the mayor told the Boston Herald on Monday as he drank beer at a bar after running the Boston Marathon. ``It's an L-word. It's loyalty. I have to stay with them.'' Already seeking the Democratic nomination are John Silber, on leave from his post as president of Boston University; former state Attorney General Francis Bellotti, Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy and state Rep. John Flood. Running for the Republican gubernatorial nomination are former U.S. Attorney William Weld and state House Minority Leader Stephen Pierce. In a general election poll by the Becker Institute last month, Flynn led GOP frontrunner Pierce by 20 points.

DOC.HEAD: French Newspaper: Libya, Not Palestinians, Seized Hostages
DOC.TEXT: A leading newspaper says three hostages released in Lebanon last week were seized in 1986 by Libya's navy, not the following year by Abu-Nidal's Palestinian terrorist group as had been claimed. Monday's front-page article in Le Monde and other similar reports could increase pressure on France to reveal more details about the case. French officials effusively thanked Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi after the release of Jacqueline Valente of France, her Belgian companion Fernand Houtekins and the child born to them in captivity. Critics accused France of cutting a deal for their freedom. The Fatah-Revolutionary Council, Abu Nidal's Libyan-backed group, claimed in November 1987 that it had seized a yacht carrying suspected pro-Israeli spies in the eastern Mediterranean. Aboard were Ms. Valente; two of her daughters, who were freed in 1988; Houtekins and four members of his family. The four members of Houtekins family are still being held while Abu Nidal demands the release of a Palestinian sentenced to life in prison in Belgium for a terrorist attack. Le Monde said in Monday's article that it appeared the boat actually was captured by the Libyan navy in 1986 in waters between Malta and Libya's Gulf of Sidra. It said Gadhafi later asked Abu Nidal's group to claim responsibility. Le Monde gave no specific sources for its report. A 1986 abduction date would explain the mystery surrounding Sophie-Liberte, the daughter of Houtekins and Valente. Reporters who saw the girl after her release generally agreed she looked and acted like a 4-year-old. Le Monde said its version of the capture would also explain a few comments by the freed hostages, who have declined to answer questions about their abduction and captivity. An aide to Abu Nidal claimed the hostages were held in Lebanon throughout their captivity, and they were released April 10 in Lebanon. But Le Monde noted that Houtekins _ walking to freedom at the French Embassy in Beirut _ said he was ``tired by the voyage,'' suggesting he had made a long journey. Also, Houtekins said they had been kept for a long period in a ``large villa'' _ which Le Monde said was ``unthinkable in the hell of Lebanon.'' The week before the hostages were released, Gadhafi publicly appealed for them to be set free. Immediately after their release, Gadhafi was thanked by President Francois Mitterrand and praised as a ``humanitarian'' by Foreign Minister Roland Dumas. Le Monde said there were no firm rules for governments in dealing with hostage cases but asked: ``At what point does a state have the right to enter into this hellish game if it must support the most shameful of lies for the enormous benefit of criminals.'' The newspaper Le Figaro reported last week the possibility that the freed hostages were seized by Libya, earlier than previously reported. The hostages held by Abu Nidal's group are considered separate from the 18 Westerners held in Lebanon. Most of them are believed to be held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem groups. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Garbo Gets Her Way; Funeral Services Will be Private
DOC.TEXT: As enigmatic in death as she was in life, Greta Garbo will be buried privately, the question of who will inherit her fortune unclear. The New York Post reported today that the actress died a rich woman but left no will. Officials at New York Hospital _ where the husky-voiced actress died Sunday at age 84 _ said Monday that funeral services would be private. ``Private means private and everyone should respect her wishes,'' said longtime friend and neighbor Ben Buttenweiser. ``It makes sense that she would have wanted it that way, otherwise you'd need the whole, entire United States Army on hand to keep everybody out.'' Hospital spokeswoman Myrna Manners said Garbo had been a kidney dialysis patient, but at the family's request she released no other information. The medical examiner's office told the Post that Garbo's body would be cremated. Garbo starred in 26 films in 17 years. In 1941, at age 36, she quit Hollywood, spending the rest of her life in shuttered and fenced residences in France, Switzerland and Manhattan, where she lived in an East Side high-rise. Her frugal ways and good financial advice built the star's holdings into a fortune, according to the Post, which reported she owned several buildings in Beverly Hills, an extensive art collection and her East Side co-op. Her only relative is her niece, Grae Reisfeld of Passaic, N.J., who also fiercely guards her privacy, the Post said. The Swedish beauty's sculpted face and husky voice made her an international star and one of the world's most famous recluses, living by her most famous line, ``I vant to be alone.'' However, she was not a shut-in but took long, solitary walks around town in a slouch hat and dark glasses. ``She'd get up in the morning and go out walking. She loved to window shop. ... The surprising thing is that she wasn't recognized more frequently,'' playwright Garson Kanin told the Daily News. He remembers her telling him, ``People in New York really don't bother you at all. When I go home to Sweden, everybody stares and asks for autographs. In New York, it's easy to be anonymous.'' Born Lovisa Gustafsson in Stockholm, Garbo made her screen debut in 1923. She made 12 silent films before uttering her first words in the 1930 movie ``Anna Christie'': ``Gimme a visky, ginger ale on the side. And don't be stingy, baby.'' ``She was always a living, unreachable myth ... the founder of a religious order called cinema,'' said Italian film director Federico Fellini. ``She gave cinema the sacredness of Mass.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain Falls From South to Northeast, Snow in Upper Michigan
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in a broad swath today from Missouri to New York, and thunderstorms rattled Oklahoma. While much of the nation enjoyed fair weather, rain fell early today from St. Louis to Buffalo, N.Y., and storms enveloped Oklahoma and parts of Arkansas, Missouri and the Texas Panhandle. Snow fell in northern Michigan, where four inches were dumped Monday on Sault Ste. Marie. Temperatures dipped early today to 30 degrees in Sault Ste. Marie, 29 in Minneapolis-St. Paul and 21 in Rapid City, S.D. A cold front drifted southward, bringing gusty winds and colder temperatures. Today's forecast called for showers running in a band from Arizona to southern Oregon, from New Mexico to Maine and across Washington state. Thunderstorms were predicted from Texas to West Virginia. A record temperature for April 16 was broken at Pocatello, Idaho, where the mercury touched 80, up from the previous high of 79 in 1936. The high temperature in the Lower 48 states Monday was 94 at Midland, Texas. DOC.HEAD: At Least 33 Killed In Easter Black Factional Fighting
By BARRY RENFREW
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: At least 33 people were killed and dozens hurt in vicious black factional fighting over the Easter holiday despite stepped up efforts by security forces to end unrest, authorities said today. The latest unrest came as President F.W. de Klerk was expected to make a major speech in Parliament today on further steps to dismantle apartheid. Conservative opposition groups said they would resist any attempt by the government to repeal apartheid legislation. Police said most of the fighting was in Natal province, where rival Zulu factions battled with guns and knives and set fire to homes and cars in clashes over the four-day holiday weekend. Among violent incidents police reported, a man and two women were taken from their home Monday near Port Shepstone in Natal and hacked to death by a mob that then burned the bodies. A soldier and a police officer were killed in separate incidents during the weekend when security forces attempted to intervene in clashes in Natal, police said. Three police officers were hurt Monday when they were stoned by a mob. The government moved military reinforcements into Natal in an attempt to stem the factional fighting, which has claimed hundreds of lives in the region in recent weeks. Military patrols blocked roads and guarded black townships. Govermment officials, who declined to be named, said de Klerk would today outline plans to dismantle major apartheid laws, including legislation restricting use of public facilities along racial lines. The government wanted to present steps on ending apartheid before the start of talks next month with the African National Congress. The two sides are to try to clear the way for full-scale negotiations on ending white-minority rule. South African newspapers reported today that the government hopes steps on reducing apartheid will boost international support for South Africa and lead to the end or reduction of economic sanctions. De Klerk, who has promised to end white-minority rule and share political power with blacks, legalized the ANC and other black opposition groups in February. The president also released Nelson Mandela, who will head the ANC delegation to the May 2 talks in Cape Town. The independent South African Press Association reported today that political prisoners held on Robben Island off Cape Town hope to be freed following the May talks. The ANC is demanding the release of all political prisoners and ending of a state of emergency. The fighting in Natal pits the ANC-allied United Democratic Front against the conservative Inkatha movement. Both groups are anti-apartheid, but differ over plans for a future South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Julie Rivers has a home where the buffalo roam. That's the problem. Her two 900-pound pet buffaloes wandered away Sunday and eluded capture Monday. ``I'm just worried they won't find water,'' Ms. Rivers said. ``They probably will, but I guess I'm worried anyway.'' The male's name is Tatanka and the female is Sheena. Both are 14 months old and stand about 4 feet high. Ms. Rivers got the pair in August. They are affectionate pets, but Ms. Rivers warns: ``I don't want people to get the idea they could play with them. They could charge somebody if they got scared. You need to respect them is all.'' Ms. Rivers had been keeping the beasts behind a 4-foot fence while she looked for a home where the buffalo couldn't roam. ``They're jumpers and they jumped right over it,'' she said. ``Now we know we waited too late.'' Ms. Rivers, her boyfriend and her son tracked the buffalo from the house to a restaurant about five miles away before losing the trail. ``We love them,'' Ms. Rivers said. ``They each have their own personality. It's been very interesting to watch them grow. They're very playful. They run and kick. They've really been a joy.''

DOC.HEAD: Animal-Rights Activist Pleads No Contest to Attempted Murder
DOC.TEXT: An animal-rights activist pleaded no contest to charges she attempted to kill the head of a surgical supply company with a bomb. Under the plea bargain, she will receive one year in prison. Fran Trutt, 33, pleaded no contest Monday to attempted murder, possession of explosives and bomb manufacturing. Trutt, who earlier turned down a plea agreement that did not permit her visits with her four dogs, could have received 20 years in prison on the attempted murder charge alone. She was arrested in 1988 after a remote-controlled pipe bomb was found near the parking space of U.S. Surgical Corp. chairman Leon Hirsch in Norwalk. Defense attorney John Williams said she opted for the plea bargain because the prosecution planned to present tape recorded conversations in which Trutt discussed her sex life and the murder attempt. ``The sex tapes _ I think that's what did it. It was just disgusting,'' he said. The tapes were of telephone conversations between Trutt and a woman hired by U.S. Surgical to befriend Trutt and spy on her, the lawyer said. U.S. Surgical has been criticized by animal-rights activists for its use of anesthetized dogs to train physicians in the use of surgical staples instead of stitches. The dogs are then destroyed. In entering her plea, Trutt maintained her innocence. Instead, she accused Hirsch of murdering dogs. As Superior Court Judge Joette Katz reviewed the charges, Trutt said, ``The one who was guilty of that is Hirsch.'' Animal-rights activists and Trutt claimed she was set up by the company to discredit their movement, which had long criticized U.S. Surgical. In a statement, U.S. Surgical said the case vindicated the company. Activists ``can protest, that they can disagree and they can picket peacefully, but the American system of justice will pursue vigorously those who attempt to force their views on others through violence,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Murderers Hanged to Death in South Korea
DOC.TEXT: Nine prisoners convicted of murder were hanged in Korea today as part of an official campaign to stem rising crime, the Justice Ministry announced. Seven of the prisoners were executed in a Seoul prison, and two in Taegu and Pusan, both south of the capital, officials said. Some had also been convicted of rape. They said the action was intended to show the public that the government is determined to maintain law and order at a time of rising crime. Many South Koreans are fearful about crime, especially murder, rape, and mob activity. The Justice Ministry listed the number of felonies as 7,590 in 1989, up 13.4 percent from 1988. The number in the first quarter of this year rose 8.1 percent from a year ago to 2,198. The last execution was in August 1989, when seven criminals were hanged. With today's executions, 17 criminals remain on death row, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened in early European trading today as traders returned from the four-day Easter holiday weekend. Gold prices fell. Currency dealers in Frankfurt said early trading was quiet as the market attempted to establish a new trend. A speech later today by U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady may help set the tone for this week, said traders in Milan. The dollar was buoyed by the continued weakness of the Japanese yen, and by expectations the U.S. trade deficit for February will have narrowed, they said. The trade figures are to be released Wednesday. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.41 yen to a closing 159.83 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 159.75 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.6816 West German marks, up from 1.6730 _1.4925 Swiss francs, up from 1.4835 _5.6475 French francs, up from 5.6213 _1.8935 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8840 _1,235.50 Italian lire, up from 1,231.50 _1.1700 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1633 In London, the dollar firmed against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6285, compared with $1.6425 late Thursday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $373.75 a troy ounce, down from $375.25 bid late Thursday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $373.85. In Zurich, the bid price was $374.00, down from $375.50 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 81 cents to close at a bid $375.39. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.07 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $5.11.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Supreme Court Rejects Appeals by Louisiana Death Row Inmate
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court has cleared the way for the execution of a nearly retarded man for the 1977 murder of a state trooper. Lifting a stay of execution it granted four months ago, the high court on Monday voted 7-2 to deny the appeals by Dalton Prejean, 30, who has been on death row since 1978, longer than any other inmate in Louisiana. Death penalty opponents have made Prejean's case a cause celebre, saying he should be spared because he was just 17 when he shot Trooper Donald Cleveland and because he has an IQ of 76 and the mental capability of a 13-year-old. No new execution date was set for Prejean, who is at the Louisiana State Penitentiary and was less than eight hours away from the electric chair in November when the high court granted the stay and agreed to consider the case. The Pardon Board voted 3-2 that month to recommend Gov. Buddy Roemer reduce Prejean's sentence to life in prison based on testimony that he had been abused as a child and may have brain damage. Roemer rejected the recommendation. Prejean shot Cleveland twice in the face with a .38-caliber pistol after a routine traffic stop. Six months earlier, Prejean had been released from a reform school, where had served time for killing a cab driver at age 14. Last June, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that the Constitution does not forbit executing murderers who are retarded or were teen-agers at the time of the crime. Prejean's appeal focused largely on whether the judge's instructions to the jury had prevented full consideration of Prejean's mental deficiencies. In refusing to grant clemency last year, Roemer cited the brutal nature of Cleveland's death, noted that Cleveland was a uniformed trooper on duty at the time and said the sentence met all judicial standards for the death penalty. Voting in Prejean's favor Monday were Justices William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall, who oppose capital punishment under all circumstances.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Vows Hair-Trigger Response To Any Israeli Nuclear Attack
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein said in the event of an Israeli nuclear attack, he has instructed his commanders to hit Israel with chemical weapons without waiting for orders, government media reported today. Several newspapers and the Iraqi News Agency said Saddam made the disclosure last week during talks with a group of six visiting U.S. senators led by Sen. Robert Dole, R-Kan. ``I ordered the commanders of air and rocket bases, if they ever hear that Israel hits any base or place in Iraq with an atomic bomb, you have to hit Israel because Israel could hit us while we (the leadership) are holding a meeting in Baghdad,'' Saddam was quoted as saying. ``So you have an advance order to hit back, even in the event that you do not have an order from a top commander, if Israel bombs any base or any Iraqi city,'' the Iraqi media quoted him as saying. Israeli jets using conventional bombs destroyed an unfinished Iraqi nuclear reactor near Baghdad in 1981. Israel claimed the facility was being used to develop atomic weapons, but Iraq denied it. Saddam had earlier announced that in the event of an Israeli attack on Iraqi installations, his nation would retaliate with advanced binary chemical weapons. That announcement came after the arrests in London of several people accused of trying to smuggle nuclear bomb triggers to Iraq. Later, British customs agents impounded Iraq-bound steel tubing in northern England, saying it could be part of a huge gun. After meeting with Saddam, Dole did not give many details of their talks but did say Saddam was seriously worried Israel would launch a pre-emptive strike similar to the one in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Two Americans Among Recipients of Japan Prizes
DOC.TEXT: An American scientist cited as the ``father of artificial intelligence'' and three earthquake researchers, including a U.S. professor, today received the two 1990 Japan Prizes, each worth $315,000. Professor Marvin Minsky of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who has been working on how to make computers learn more by themselves, received his prize in the field of ``technology of integration.'' The other prize, for earth science, was shared by American professor William Jason Morgan of Princeton University, professor Dan Peter McKenzie of Britain's Cambridge University and Xavier Le Pichon, director of the Ecole Normale Superieure in France. The three were cited for their work on the theory that the Earth's crust is made up of rigid tectonic plates that grind against each other, causing earthquakes, volcanic eruptions and the formation of ridges and mountains. The prizes were awarded at ceremonies attended by Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. The non-profit Science and Technology Foundation of Japan, under the direction of the Prime Minister's Office, began awarding the prizes in 1985 to promote applied scientific research of direct benefit to mankind. It has expressed hope that the Japan Prize will become as widely recognized as the Nobel Prize. The foundation said it received 662 recommendations for this year's prizes. The 1991 prizes will be awarded for applied mathematics and imaging techniques in medicine, it added. On Monday, Morgan told a news conference that despite progress in forecasting the location and size of earthquakes, predicting the exact time ``is still pretty much in the future.'' Minsky told reporters that in the next few years a computer ``will be able to watch your eyes and your face and will be able to tell what interests you.'' It might, for example, enlarge whatever the operator is studying on the screen, he said. Minsky said some computers now can recognize spoken words without understanding their meaning. ``In another generation, maybe 10 years, maybe 50, the computer will have more understanding, like a child, and know what words really mean, and then it will be more like talking to another person,'' he said. ``Once that happens, it's impossible to make predictions,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Warns Military Will Defend Socialism
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam's Communist authorities said they are clamping down on dissent and warned that the army stands ready to defend socialism. The warnings indicate that Vietnam is entrenching as movements for democratic reform sweep the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Hanoi Radio said a mass movement had been broadened in all areas to safeguard national security, according to a transcript of the broadcast seen in Bangkok today. This included a ``crackdown on those who seek to undermine political security,'' the radio said. The radio broadcast on Sunday quoted from an editorial published the same day in the Communist Party newspaper Nhan Dan. It said the crackdown was also directed at ``corrupt elements, bribe takers, smugglers, illegal traders and swindlers ... distributors of decadent and reactionary reading materials ... those who instigate and rally forces to oppose the ... policies of our party and state.'' The report gave no specific details of the crackdown. The official Vietnam News Agency on Sunday quoted Vo Chi Cong, the president of the state council and second-ranking member of the Communist Party politburo, as saying ``imperialist and reactionary forces'' were attempting to destabilize Southeast Asia and weaken Vietnam. In a speech to infantry cadets, he said the army and the people would ``protect the purity of Marxism-Leninism (and) defend the party administration and socialism in our country.'' Soviet-backed Vietnam has strongly criticized the political changes in Eastern Europe that it says are the result of a plot by the West to destroy socialism. While emphasizing the leading role of the Communist Party, Hanoi also has stressed the need for reform and has purged what it said were corrupt party members. Earlier this month it announced a major cabinet reshuffle, streamlining a dozen government ministries into three new ones and dissolving other offices. In March the party purged Tran Xuan Bach, a politburo member who had advocated more democratic reforms, saying he had seriously violated party discipline.

DOC.HEAD: 150 Dead in Food Poisoning After Engagement Party
DOC.TEXT: The death toll in a food poisoning outbreak from a marriage engagement party rose to 150 people today and an official said more fatalities were expected, news reports said. Hundreds of people were hospitalized after the feast Sunday in the northern village of Raipura Jungla near Lucknow, capital of the Uttar Pradesh state. At least 80 people were pronounced dead on Monday and 70 more died today, Press Trust of India reported. Hospital spokesmen said the number of deaths could not be estimated because the sick were brought to several hospitals. One government health official said he expected that more people would die. According to a preliminary investigation, a poisonous phosphorous compound apparently contaminated flour used for making puri, a puffy fried bread, and caused the deaths. No reports from Lucknow have suggested foul play. United News of India said the outbreak happened after a ``tilak'' ceremony to celebrate a marriage engagement. A tilak is a decorative dot many Hindus wear on their foreheads on auspicious occasions. During the ceremony, couples exchange rings and feast with their families. There was no indication whether the engaged couple was among the victims. In rural areas, such ceremonies are attended by entire villages, drawing hundreds of people.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Upholds Death Penalty for Murderer
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by a 40-year-old man convicted of killing four people and upheld a High Court death sentence against him. Norio Nagayama was first convicted and sentenced to death by the Tokyo District Court in 1979 for slaying four people during four 1968 robberies. He used a handgun stolen from a U.S. military base in Tokyo. The case has been highly publicized because Nagayama, who was 19 at the time of the crimes, has written at least four award-winning autobiographical novels since his imprisonment in 1969. In 1981, the Tokyo High Court commuted his death sentence to life imprisonment. But after an appeal by prosecutors, the Supreme Court in 1983 ordered a retrial of the case, and four years later the High Court reaffirmed his death sentence. In their appeal to the Supreme Court, defense lawyers argued the death penalty was unconstitutional because it violated Article 36 of the Japanese constitution, which forbids cruel punishment. They also argued Nagayama was young and mentally unstable when he committed the crimes. Four judges, however, unanimously supported the High Court's decision in favor of the death penalty. In two 1968 robbery attempts, Nagayama tried to break into hotels and in both cases killed security guards before fleeing. In two further cases, he killed taxi drivers after robbing them. Japanese authorities are extremely secretive about executions, which occur by hanging, and do not disclose the time of death. Neither the number of people on death row, nor the date of the latest execution are available. By law, an execution must be carried out within six months after a death sentence is finalized. But legal experts say executions are frequently delayed. The death sentence was handed down most recently early last year by the Nagoya District Court in the conviction of a 20-year-old man for killing a young couple in 1988. The case has been appealed to the High Court.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Sending Signals He May Seek A Fourth Term
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry again is accepting donations to the re-election campaign he had put on hold while receiving treatment for substance abuse, his top political aide says. The aide, Anita Bonds, described Barry as a ``potential candidate'' for re-election. But a WJLA-TV television reporter who met with him Monday said, ``The mayor told me he now feels good enough about his recovery from alcohol and chemical addictions to seek a fourth term.'' The station quoted unidentified sources as saying Barry ``is convinced the city and its voters will give him a second chance.'' Ms. Bonds told The Washington Post a formal decision on whether Barry will launch a re-election campaign before his trial could come late this week or next week. She said Barry planned to attend a forum being hosted next week by the American Federation of Government Employees, a powerful labor union in the District whose endorsement is coveted by city candidates. Barry returned to the district a month ago after several weeks of treatment for alcohol and chemical dependencies. He entered treatment after being arrested in a sting operation in which federal authorities allegedly videotaped the mayor smoking crack cocaine in a hotel. Barry was indicted on felony charges of lying to a grand jury about alleged past drug use and on a misdemeanor charge of cocaine possession. His trial is scheduled for June 4. Barry has been acting like a candidate since his return, meeting with neighborhood and civic groups in campaign-style events. But until now he has shied away from formal mayoral campaign forums, at which most of the candidates have criticized the Barry administration. ``Until the mayor were to say he was not going to run, he is not going to lose touch with his constituencies,'' Ms. Bonds told the Post. She said the mayor resumed accepting political donations shortly after his return and has garnered only a few ``small'' donations. Some longtime Barry financial supporters have defected to other candidates or shied away from the race to date. Barry acknowledged in a Post interview over the weekend that he has skipped some of the counseling sessions he promised to attend after returning from treatment. He said he mistakenly believed he could attend church services as an alternative. There already was a crowded Democratic mayoral field before Barry's arrest. While the mayor was in treatment, Walter Fauntroy, the district's delegate to Congress, announced he would seek the Democratic nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Health at Issue in Florida Governor's Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 2 grafs recasts, pickup 3rd pvs bgng ``Every intimate''
DOC.TEXT: Florida's three Democratic gubernatorial candidates plan to release their medical records following the disclosure that one of them, former Sen. Lawton Chiles, is undergoing treatment for depression. Chiles will be opposed in the Sept. 4 primary by Rep. Bill Nelson and state Sen. George Stuart. ``Every intimate detail is open and is fair game,'' Nelson said Monday. ``Every candidate's mental and physical health is a legitimate issue, especially with regard to a race that is for the governor of Florida, since that is so important to the future of Florida.'' Chiles, 60, said last week he is nearing successful completion of prescribed drug therapy for depression. The former senator, who retired in 1988, said he began taking a 25-milligram tablet of Prozac daily late last year. ``I think full disclosure of the medical history and the medical records, as well as Chiles' performance in the next few months, will shed some light on this issue,'' added Nelson, who has requested his medical chart. Chiles planned to get his medical records today from his Tallahassee doctor, according to his son, Lawton M. ``Bud'' Chiles III. Scott Sokol, a spokesman for Stuart, said the state senator's medical records would also be available by the end of the week. Bob Martinez, Florida's second Republican governor since Reconstruction, is seeking a second four-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Should Protect Farmers But Not Crops, U.S. Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Japan need not abandon its farmers for the sake of opening up world trade, but it should end protection of specific crops, a U.S. official said today. Proposals made by Washington at trade talks on agricultural products would permit nations to help their farmers, said U.S. Undersecretary of Agriculture Richard T. Crowder. ``We're not asking countries to give up agricultural support programs. What we're asking is the support of agriculture in ways that do not distort, or minimally distort, trade patterns,'' Crowder told reporters. ``What should be done is to support the income of farmers ... but not support production of a specific crop,'' he said. Crowder said Japan was not alone in its fears of what would happen to farmers in the event of trade liberalization. Nordic nations and Switzerland had voiced similar concerns, he said. But, he said: ``Food security depends not on artificial self-sufficiency but on an open, market-oriented trading environment. ... Food security cannot legitimately be used as a shield against true trade liberalization.'' Japan is seeking exemptions to maintain its virtual ban on imported rice, arguing the stiff barriers guarantee Japan's food supply. Last week, Japan reiterated its opposition to rice imports in an annual paper on agriculture endorsed by the Cabinet. The United States has proposed a phase-out of agricultural trade subsidies and barriers at the Uruguay Round of talks, sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The talks run through December. Crowder, in Tokyo for consultations with Japanese officials, said the United States was prepared to address Japan's concerns. American proposals do not call for quick approach to liberalization, but rather a 10-year transition period to ease the shock of imports, he said. But for liberalization to succeed, all forms of agricultural supports _ export subsidies, import access, internal controls and health regulations _ must be put on the table at once for negotiation, he said. ``None of us are without sin,'' he said, acknowledging U.S. farm supports would also have to be eliminated. Crowder said the U.S. proposal was met with a cold reception, especially from European Community nations. But he said Japan should support trade liberalization across the board. ``Given Japan's prominent place in international trade, we think Japan needs to take a strong leadership role in the GATT negotiations. Japan will benefit significantly from supporting major trade reform,'' Crowder said. The Geneva-based GATT sets rules for international trade.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Post Office Explosion, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0503,0457
DOC.HEAD: Tax Protest Letter Explodes, Injures Postal Worker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to add that package was in a mail hamper, CORRECT name to Berlucchi sted Berlucci. Picks up 11th graf, ``We don't...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Tax Rush
LaserPhoto DT1
DOC.TEXT: An envelope addressed to ``tax thieves'' exploded outside a suburban post office, injuring a postal worker and shutting the office for several hours before the tax deadline. The blast occurred at 8:30 p.m. Monday in a mail hamper placed outside the Royal Oak Post Office to collect tax returns from filers rushing to meet the midnight deadline. ``From the writing on the envelope, there was an indication it was some kind of tax protest,'' U.S. Postal Inspector Fred Van de Putte said. There were no arrests, postal officials said this morning. The envelope, addressed ``To The Tax Thieves,'' contained a Roman candle and a tea bag, Van de Putte said. The tea bag apparently referred to the Boston Tea Party of 1773, the tax protest that helped spark the American Revolution. The envelope also contained an unidentified red fluid and a fuse, fire Capt. Ron Gammon said. Tom Berlucchi, 29, a maintenance employee for 10 years, spotted the envelope smoking in a bin of last-minute tax returns. ``Berlucchi smelled something burning,'' Van de Putte said. ``He pushed aside the other mail and saw a brown, padded envelope.'' Berlucchi was trying to toss the parcel into a nearby puddle when it exploded. Berlucchi was treated for burns on his hands and face and released, William Beaumont Hospital spokeswoman Valerie Mahaczek said. ``We don't know exactly what the explosive device was,'' Gammon said. ``I guess the fluid was supposed to be blood. It flew all over the place.'' Gammon said the department initially was told the explosion was inside the post office, the distribution center for Oakland County. ``When we got there, there were about 20 or 30 tax protesters, but they disappeared fast,'' he said. There was no information linking the protesters to the blast. Patti Hornick, who was dropping off her tax return, said: ``I thought it was a fireworks display or something, it looked like a huge fireworks explosion. We just dropped our taxes in the bin and we saw them working on the injured man.'' The blast did little or no structural damage to the post office, Royal Oak police Lt. Ray Taylor said. Agents of the FBI, federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and state police bomb squad also responded to the explosion, but the investigation was turned over to the Postal Service because it involved mail.

DOC.HEAD: French Judge Orders Ad Company To Display Controversial Posters
DOC.TEXT: A judge today ruled that a movie poster showing a sexually aroused young angel should be allowed in subway stations despite objections by the advertising company that sells the ad space. Judge Marie-Claude Domb said the poster, denounced by some religious groups as obscene, might shock some subway riders. ``But it could just as easily raise a smile,'' she said. Metrobus, which has a monopoly over advertising in the Paris Metro, had argued that it was entitled to reject the poster, advertising a new movie called ``It's Freezing In Hell'' by director Jean-Pierre Mocky. The poster shows a painting of two chubby, smiling young angels with black wings, the female wearing black silk stockings and the male in a state of sexual arousal. In the context of contemporary morality, the judge said, it was unlikely the poster would ``seriously offend the modesty of many people.'' Mocky initiated the court action to force Metrobus to display about 260 copies of the posters from Wednesday through May 2, for a payment of $75,000.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Daily News Eliminates Union Dues Checkoff During Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News has stopped deducting union dues from paychecks of members of 10 unions embroiled in contract talks with the newspaper. The dues deduction, a convenience to the unions, was eliminated Monday by the News, as the unions had expected. The 10 unions, under the umbrella of the Allied Printing Trades Council, are locked in contract talks that are considered decisive for the tabloid's future. Contracts expired March 30. ``We will not be provoked and we will collect our own dues with no problem without the assistance of the Daily News,'' said Deborah Friedman, a spokeswoman for the unions. The News says it must eliminate overstaffing and invest $500 million in new printing plants to become profitable.

DOC.HEAD: Students Clash With Riot Police in Anti-government Protests
DOC.TEXT: Radical students shouting anti-government slogans clashed with riot police in two provincial cities today while in Seoul others rallied to mark a 1960 student uprising, news reports said. About 1,200 students hurled rocks and firebombs in battles with police at two universities in southern Kwangju, an opposition stronghold, the Yonhap News Agency said. Police used tear gas to stop protesters from marching off campus. Similar clashes broke out at another southern city, Sunchun, where 300 students, shouting ``Down with Roh!'' tried to march from their school after a campus rally, it said. Yonhap did not say whether there were any injuries or arrests in the two cities. In Seoul, about 7,000 students rallied at Korea University and proclaimed ``a week of protests'' marking the April 19, 1960, student uprising that toppled South Korea's first government, led by the late President Syngman Rhee. Radical students in all three cities also protested a political merger in January, when President Roh Tae-woo's conservative party joined with two moderate opposition groups, giving Roh's ruling group an overwhelming parliamentary majority. ``Let's crush the three-party merger,'' a student leader in Seoul shouted from beneath a two-story-high banner showing a student walking away from a U.S. flag. The crowd took up the chant. After the rally, the students marched through the campus singing anti-government songs. They did not clash with riot police, who stood by outside the school gate. Fierce fighting lasted for almost two hours at Chonnam University in Kwangju, 150 miles south of Seoul, where 700 students tried to march from the school after a two-hour campus rally. ``Punish Roh Tae-woo!'' and ``Drive out Yankees!'' Yonhap quoted students as shouting. Police, using two armored vehicles equipped with tear gas launchers, sealed off the school's main gate and washed away anti-government slogans painted by students on the pavement, the agency said. At Chosun University, in a different section of the city, about 500 students threw rocks and firebombs, fighting police for more than an hour, Yonhap said. Police responded with tear gas, it said. Also Tuesday, President Roh met with leaders of his ruling party to end a factional feud. Government officials said after the six-hour meeting that Roh and three co-leaders of the party agreed to work toward party unity. They also agreed to continue democratic reforms, the officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Trade Union Council Head Replaced
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet trade union federation, which has come under criticism for kowtowing to the government instead of defending workers' interests, replaced its chairman today, the official news agency Tass said. Stepan Shalayev, 61, who had been chairman of the All Union Central Council of Trade Unions for eight years, asked to retire and was replaced by Deputy Chairman Gennady Yanaev, Tass said. The change comes at a time when labor disputes continue to simmer in the Soviet Union. Hundreds of thousands of coal miners walked out across the country last summer, and strikes are threatened in the oil-rich western Siberian region of Tyumen. The trade union council for decades acted mainly as a distributor of vacation trips, medical care and other benefits rather than as an advocate for better conditions for workers. It also conveyed government and Communist Party directives to workers. Last year, however, criticism mounted against the labor federation, particularly during the coal strikes, when miners complained that if the unions had taken better care of them they wouldn't have felt forced to strike. The council has since made visible efforts to improve its image. A plenum last fall pledged to conduct ``effective social policies'' and urged a price freeze on basic commodities. It also pushed for an end to shortages of dairy products, soap, medicine and notebooks. Today's plenary meeting defined the trade union's role as working toward ``helping the population adjust to a market economy and simultaneously helping the poorer strata'' of society. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has said he is planning soon to introduce radical economic reforms that are expected to include price increases and heighten unemployment. The council proposed a system that would compensate poor people, especially those on fixed incomes, for price hikes. Yanaev, 52, graduated from an agricultural institute and law school, and headed the Soviet Committee of Youth Organizations for 12 years, Tass reported. ``He has won domestic popularity for his parliamentary crusade for workers' social and economic rights and interests,'' the news agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Search Continues for Three Missing Fishermen After One Found
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard searched by air and sea today for three fishermen missing since their boat sank in the Atlantic Ocean last week. A fourth man from the 34-foot fiberglass fishing boat was found Monday drifting in an open wood box about 20 miles east of Hilton Head Island, S.C. Nathan Neesmith, 32, was rescued Monday morning by a passing boat, said Coast Guard Petty Officer 2nd Class Brett Farrell. Neesmith was in serious condition suffering from hypothermia and dehydration in Savannah's Memorial Medical Center, hospital spokeswoman Ronnie Boaen said today. Farrell said Neesmith told his rescuers he was one of four crew members on a commercial fishing boat that sank after it left Darien, Ga., last Wednesday en route to a fishing area off Edisto Beach, S.C. Coast Guard officials do not know exactly when the boat sank or how long the man had floated in the box, which may have been used as an engine cover on the boat, Farrell said. Neesmith probably was able to survive because most of his body was ``up and out'' of the water in the box, Farrell said. Neesmith, who was described by a doctor as ``confused,'' had been able to tell searchers little about what happened. The Coast Guard sent two boats and two helicopters to search for the three other crew members, but no sign of them had been found by early today, Farrell said. He identified the missing men as 23-year-old Billy Joe Neesmith, brother of Nathan Neesmith 18-year-old Keith Wilkes and 23-year-old Franklin Brantley. ``We're still out searching,'' he said. ``We haven't found any significant debris or anything at this point.'' Boaters and commercial fishermen were helping with the search, which was centered about 30 miles east of Hilton Head, Farrell said. Jean Neesmith, an aunt of the Neesmith brothers who was reached by telephone at her Darien home, said the men were commercial fishermen who ``went fishing for snappers for a living.'' She said Billy Joe Neesmith was the captain of the boat, which was owned by a South Carolina man. She said Wilkes is a nephew of the Neesmiths and Brantley is a childhood friend. ``God only knows what happened out there,'' she said. ``We're just hoping they find them alive.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Politician Blames Bhutto for Kashmiri Refugee Problem
DOC.TEXT: A senior opposition politician warned today that Pakistan faces a growing crisis because Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto has encouraged an influx of thousands of Moslem militants from Indian-held Kashmir seeking weapons and training. Abdul Qayyum, president of Pakistan-controlled Azad Kashmir, or Free Kashmir, said Ms. Bhutto's emotional vows of solidarity with the militants had unduly raised their hopes. ``The emotional outbursts of the prime minister herself, saying `your blood is our blood ... Our blood is the same' has very seriously backfired,'' said Qayyum, whose right-of-center All Jammu-Kashmir Moslem Conference Party governs Pakistani-controlled Kashmir. ``They are here. ... Now they are disillusioned,'' he said. Qayyum said fleeing militants have received only food and lodging from Pakistan, but they want more. ``If this repression is not stopped by India, and Pakistan is not able to make India do anything, there will be no third option,'' warned Qayyum, who has been a critic of Ms. Bhutto since she took office 16 months ago. ``Either they (the militants in Pakistan) will turn against Pakistan or they will have to be trained, armed and sent back to recapture their motherland,'' he said in an interview with The Associated Press. Qayyum warned that Pakistan could go ``up in flames'' if the militants turned against Pakistani authorities. A spokesman for Ms. Bhutto dismissed Qayyum's charges. ``There is a trickling in of refugees ... not because of our statements but because of Indian repression,'' said the spokesman who cannot be identified under briefing rules. ``Innocent people are being killed under the guise of being militants.'' At least 270 people have died in India's turbulent state of Jammu-Kashmir since Jan. 20 when Indian troops launched a crackdown on Moslem separatists seeking an independent state. The violence has caused escalating tensions between India and Pakistan. India has accused Pakistan of fomenting unrest in Jammu-Kashmir, an accusation the Islamabad government denies. On Saturday, Indian Prime Minister V.P. Singh accused Pakistan of a military buildup along the border and warned that Indian would not back down from a war with its neighbor. A Pakistani Foreign Ministry official said Singh's remarks indicated that India was trying to provoke a war. The two countries have twice gone to war over Kashmir _ in 1948 and 1965. A cease-fire line monitored by the United Nations divides the Pakistani- and Indian-controlled portions of the disputed valley. The dispute over the Kashmir territory dates back to 1947 when India and Pakistan gained their independence from Britain. The Hindu ruler of Moslem-dominated Kashmir opted for union with India, although other Moslem-majority provinces joined together to form Pakistan. About 64 percent of the 6 million people in Jammu-Kashmir are Moslem. Nationwide, only 12 percent of India's 880 million people are Moslem, while 82 percent are Hindu.

DOC.HEAD: Space Probe Bound for Jupiter Successfully Fires Thrusters
DOC.TEXT: NASA engineers fired the Galileo spacecraft's tiny thrusters almost 1,600 times in a successful four-day maneuver designed to help the space probe reach Jupiter in 1995. The thruster pulses, completed late Thursday, slowed the spacecraft by about 55 mph, said Jim Wilson, spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The next set of maneuvers on the $1.35 billion mission is scheduled for summer, spokesman Bob MacMillin said Monday. The 2.8-ton Galileo was launched by the space shuttle Atlantis on Oct. 18. It flew past Venus on Feb. 9, enabling the planet to act as a ``gravity slingshot'' and help propel the spacecraft on its looping 2.4-billion-mile, six-year journey to Jupiter, the solar system's largest planet. The spacecraft will fly past Earth on Dec. 8 and again on Dec. 8, 1992, in two more ``gravity slingshot'' maneuvers. Galileo will examine Earth, the moon and one or two asteroids before it separates into an orbiter and a small probe in July 1995. They arrive at Jupiter in December 1995. There, the probe will parachute into the atmosphere and make measurements until intense heat and pressure vaporize it. The orbiter will photograph and study Jupiter and its major moons until late 1997, circling the planet instead of flying past it like the Pioneer and Voyager spacecraft.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Proposes Bills to Improve Land Use in Urban Areas
DOC.TEXT: In an effort to make land cheaper for Japanese and more accessible to U.S. companies, the Cabinet today proposed two bills that would promote construction on farmland and urban sites considered underdeveloped. ``This will be a first concrete step'' on land policy to be taken by Japan following Japan-U.S. talks on changing business practices in the two countries, said Nobuyuki Yamazaki, an official of the Construction Ministry's City Planning Divison. The bills are to be submitted to Parliament for approval, he said. The proposals are ``intended to improve the supply of housing and residential land in major city areas by encouraging effective and intensive use of idle land and farmland'' Construction Minister Tamisuke Watanuki told the Cabinet, which approved the proposed legislation. Both proposals are aimed at targeting underutilized land for residential development and at lifting restrictions on residential construction. One would require three major urban areas _ Tokyo, Osaka, in western Japan, and Nagoya, in central Japan to designate priority areas to be developed as residential areas. The other bill would authorize officials to designate idle and underutilized plots of 53,800 square feet or more as areas to be developed for housing. It also would double to 66 feet the maximum height of apartment buildings constructed on land originally used for farming. Yamazaki said a comprehensive national land policy would be compiled afer committees in the government and governing Liberal Democratic Party develop proposals for tax reforms related to land use by this autumn. In an interim report on bilateral structural talks between Japan and the United States issued earlier this month, the Japanese government said it would take steps to increase the supply of housing and residential land. Spiraling land prices and a shortage of inexpensive housing are serious problems in Japan's major cities. U.S. trade negotiators have said that increasing the supply of affordable housing could lead to greater opportunities for foreign firms to sell products and services in Japan. There are now about 71,659 acres of vacant or underutilized plots, excluding farmland, in the Tokyo metropolitan area, according to Construction Ministry estimates. If about 27,181 acres of that land, including former factory sites, were developed for residential use, about 1.8 million new housing units could be built, it says.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Anti-Bias Suits May Be Filed in State Courts
DOC.TEXT: Lawsuits charging employers with violating a key federal anti-bias law may be filed in state as well as federal courts, a unanimous Supreme Court ruled today. The 9-0 ruling upheld a $27,000 award won by a Chicago Ridge, Ill., woman against her trucking company employer, the Yellow Freight System Co. Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the court, said, ``We have no reason to question the presumption that state courts are just as able as federal courts'' to decide claims governed by the federal law. Lawyers for Yellow Freight urged the court to rule that Coleen Donnelly waited too long before filing a lawsuit invoking the law, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 barring on-the-job discrimination. Mrs. Donnelly's lawsuit invoked the federal law within a required 90-day deadline. But the case at that time was in an Illinois state court. Lawyers for Yellow Freight said that does not meet the deadline requirement because, they said, federal courts have exclusive authority to hear Title VII cases. Some federal appeals courts have ruled that such suits must be filed in federal court. But the Chicago-based 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in favor of Mrs. Donnelly, and its decision was upheld today. Mrs. Donnelly applied to Yellow Freight for a job as a dockworker in October 1982. She was told the company was not hiring at the time but was advised she would be the next dockworker hired. When Yellow Freight began hiring dockworkers agains in February 1983, Mrs. Donnelly was told the company still was not hiring. She was hired 18 months later. Mrs. Donnelly in early 1985 filed charges with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, alleging sexual bias in Yellow Freight's delay in hiring her. The commission issued a right-to-sue notice on March 15, 1985, triggering a 90-day deadline for the suit to be filed. Mrs. Donnelly sued in state court before the deadline. But her original lawsuit did not allege a Title VII violation, only a violation of the Illinois Human Rights Act. The suit later was amended to included a claim that Title VII was violated. After Yellow Freight had the case transferred to federal court, Mrs. Donnelly was awarded $27,656 in back pay and interest. The case is Yellow Freight System vs. Donnelly, 89-431.

DOC.HEAD: Feinstein and Van de Kamp Running Even in Latest Poll
DOC.TEXT: Poll results show a very close race between Dianne Feinstein and John Van de Kamp for the Democratic nomination for governor, and both have dropped behind the likely Republic nominee, Sen. Pete Wilson. Feinstein, the former San Francisco mayor, was far behind Van de Kamp, the state attorney general, in a California Poll reading of Democratic voters' preferences last fall. But she surged ahead in another California Poll taken two months ago. In the latest poll results, released Monday, 36 percent of 718 registered Democrats interviewed supported Feinstein, 35 percent backed Van de Kamp. The remaining voters, 29 percent, were undecided. The primary is June 5. Poll taker Mervin Field said an increase in the undecided percentage might have resulted from the candidates' recent television advertisements. ``The candidates have been trying to lift voters out of their lassitude by trying negative advertising. But when both are doing it, the public gets injured,'' Field said. In a sampling of 1,495 registered voters given possible general election matchups, Wilson led Feinstein 46 percent to 38 percent and Van de Kamp by 43 percent to 38 percent. Two months ago, he was about even with Van de Kamp and behind Feinstein. The latest poll is based on interviews conducted in late March and early April. The Field organization says the poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 2.6 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Flutist Galway Ill, Misses Opera Debut
DOC.TEXT: Flutist James Galway missed his operatic debut because he was hospitalized, and his wife stepped in to fill the role. Galway was scheduled to play the lead role in a new production of Rossini's ``The Thieving Magpie'' with the Opera Company of Philadelphia on Monday night. He was hospitalized for an inflammation of the intestinal tract, said Betsy Samuels, spokeswoman for Thomas Jefferson University Hospital. He was in stable condition Monday night. ``There was really no way he could go ahead with the performance,'' said Jane Grey Nemeth, company acting general director. ``He didn't want to cancel.'' Galway's wife, Jeanne Galway, took over the magpie role, a role she was originally slated to play on Friday. The Philadelphia production was the first to use a flute player on stage as the magpie.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Tribesmen Kill 22 People
DOC.TEXT: Rebel tribesmen killed 22 people during night raids on villages in southeastern Bangladesh, the United News of Bangladesh reported today. The deaths occurred during two separate attacks on Monday in the Chittagong Hills in the Bandarban district, 155 miles southeast of Dhaka, the news agency said. The tribesmen are resisting government plans to settle people from the country's plains region in the district. The news agency said 19 people were shot to death in their sleep when the tribesmen opened fire with machine gunes in the village of Sichari. In the second attack, the assailants shot and killed three people in the village of Dabtachari, the news agency said. The tribesmen are campaigning for autonomy for the hill region, their traditional home. More than 4,000 people have died in the 14-year-old bush war. The conflict has forced about 38,000 tribespeople to seek shelter in neighboring India.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says More Study Needed into Causes of Climate Changes
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; editing thruout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called for more study into the causes of climate changes today and was immediately criticized for a go-slow approach on the issue of global warming. The president, receiving only polite applause at the beginning and end of his address, told delegates to an international conference on global warming: ``Environmental policies that ignore the economic factor, the human factor, are destined to failure.'' Bush repeatedly emphasized the link between environmental consequences and economic costs. ``All of us must be certain we preserve our environmental well-being and our economic welfare,'' Bush said. He called these ``two sides of the same coin.'' However, some delegates to the conference criticized the administration's cautious approach to dealing with the so-called greenhouse effect, where pollutants released in the Earth's atmosphere are believed to trap sunlight and lead to warming of the planet. ``Gaps in knowledge must not be used as an excuse for worldwide inaction,'' said West Germany's environmental minister, Klaus Topfer in a statement. He said the White House conference should include debate over what measures might be taken to curb global-warming pollution. Bush told his audience that prominent scientists come down on both sides of the issue _ some claiming that failure to control airborne pollutants can lead to series global warming and others disputing such contentions. ``Where does that leave us?'' Bush asked. ``What we need are facts, the stuff that science is made of.'' The president's remarks opened a two-day White House conference. As expected, Bush avoided making a specific commitment in his remarks. Attending the conference were government environmental, economic and science officials from 18 nations and representatives from several international organizations. ``I know there's a debate raging out there. But I'm confident that this approach that brings all of you together is the way to go,'' Bush said. Bush cited congressional and White House cooperation on compromise clean-air legislation as a sign of a U.S. commitment on cleaning up the environment. He said that the debate over global warming ``often generates more heat than light.''
