Bush, carefully using the phrase ``climate change'' instead of ``global warming,'' told his audience that recognizing the economic realities of the cost of environmental cleanup ``is in the interest of every nation here today.'' Bush said that in developing nations, in particular, curbing pollution is especially difficult. ``In a climate of poverty or persistent economic struggle, protecting the environment becomes a far more difficult challenge.'' He added: ``There is no better ally in service of our environment than strong economies.'' Some of the European delegates have called for industrial nations to make specific commitments on controlling so-called greenhouse pollutants, such as carbon dioxide, but the administration has refused to go that far. The president's science adviser, Allen Bromley, a co-chairman of the conference, recently criticized those who advocate ``slam-dunk solutions'' to global warming when uncertainties remain. The cautious approach taken by the White House has prompted some of the delegates to the conference to complain that the gathering is being used solely to promote the U.S. position on global warming. Conference sources said Monday that both the Dutch and West German governments have complained about the conference agenda because it focuses exclusively on research efforts and does not provide an open give-and-take among delegates on possible response strategies. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl made his displeasure known in a letter to Bush, according to the sources, who asked not to be identified. The Dutch complained in letters to senior White House officials that the participants aren't even given time in open sessions to address policy options other than additional research. ``We want to discuss (a response) policy,'' said Pier Vellinga, a senior member of the Dutch delegation. The Netherlands and several other European countries have favored an immediate commitment by industrial nations to stabilize carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2000. Vellinga said the Europeans have waited eagerly for Bush to convene the conference, which he promised during his 1988 election campaign, but they had expected it to focus on responses as well as research. Senior administration officials have emphasized in recent days that they view the conference as primarily a way to focus on the need for more research into global warming and to address the economic questions posed by the issue. Representatives to the meeting are senior cabinet-level advisers on economics, science and the environment from nations that include the European Community, Japan and Brazil. U.S. environmentalists also chastised Bush for not focusing on pollution control efforts. The Sierra Club called the conference an attempt by the administration to shift the focus away from environmental questions to economic ones. The Sierra Club, which has more than 500,000 members, said Monday it plans to take that message to the public with a series of television advertisemets featuring actors such as William Shatner, John Ritter and Jane Alexander. Some computer models have suggested the Earth could warm by 4 to 9 degrees Fahrenheit over the next 60 years because heat is being trapped by pollution. Other studies, however, questioned whether the warming would be that severe because of uncertainties about the effect of clouds, oceans and other factors.

DOC.HEAD: Watchdog Group Troubled by All-White Jury in Murder Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to Gonzales sted Gonzalez.
DOC.TEXT: A citizen group has doubts whether an all-white jury can deliver justice in the murder trial of a former Houston police officer accused of killing a black woman. Testimony was to begin today in the trial of Alex Gonzales, a white officer charged in the slaying of Ida Lee Delaney. The jury of 12 was selected Monday for the trial, which was moved to Dallas because of publicity. ``They could have gotten that jury makeup in Houston. I don't even know why they came to Dallas to do this,'' said Ada Edwards, an organizer of the Ida Lee Delaney-Byron Gillum Justice Committee. Gillum is a black man killed by police in a separate incident. ``It's not a surprise. I just hope the process will carry itself out and that those people are people who will be willing to hear the entire story,'' Ms. Edwards said. ``The state of Texas is very happy with the jury,'' said prosecutor Don Smyth. ``We think they'll do a fine job. As we've been telling everybody else, this is not a racial case.'' Elsewhere, more than 500 people Monday mourned a black teen-ager fatally shot in the back by a white policeman in Teaneck, N.J. A grand jury was to begin hearing evidence in the case today, a week after Phillip Pannell was killed by an officer responding to reports that the 16-year-old was brandishing a gun. ``No longer will we put up with public officials putting guns in the hands of people untrained to our needs,'' said Theo Bolden, a junior at Teaneck High School, speaking at Pannell's funeral at a Baptist church in Englewood. A call for activism came in a letter from Jesse Jackson saying, ``We must transform confusion into order, fear into hope, death into light.'' Gonzales, 25, is accused of killing Mrs. Delaney, 50, last fall while off duty. Mrs. Delaney and Gillum, 24, were shot within two weeks of each other. The officer suspected of shooting Gillum was not indicted. Mrs. Delaney was driving to work on a freeway when Gonzales and two other off-duty officers chased her in an unmarked car, authorities. After she pulled over, Mrs. Delaney and Gonzales exchanged fire. The defense maintains Mrs. Delaney fired first and Gonzales acted in self-defense. The officers had been attending a birthday party at a nightclub for several hours before the shooting. Hospital records showed Gonzales was intoxicated when he sought treatment for gunshot wounds to the abdomen. Pannell was shot by Officer Gary Spath. Police said that officers believed the teen-ager was reaching for a gun and that a .22-caliber gun was found on the body. Some of the dead boy's friends have said he had a BB pistol instead.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules No Right to Take Peyote as Religious Practice
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 13-17, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today there is no constitutional right to take the hallucinogenic drug peyote as a religious practice. The justices, voting 6-3, said Oregon officials may deny unemployment benefits to two fired drug counselors who ingested small amounts of peyote in Indian religious ceremonies. Justice Antonin Scalia, writing for the court, said the First Amendment does not permit people to break the law in the name of religious freedom. ``We have never held that an individual's religious beliefs excuse him from compliance with an otherwise valid law prohibiting the conduct that the state is free to regulate,'' he said. Oregon's drug laws do not ``regulate religious beliefs, the communication of religious beliefs or the raising of one's children in those beliefs,'' Scalia added. In a strongly worded dissent, Justice Harry A. Blackmun accused the court of treating religious freedom for the first time as a ``luxury'' rather than ``an essential element of liberty.'' Today's ruling is a signal to Indians that religious freedom for unorthodox practices is ``an unfulfilled and hollow promise,'' Blackmun said. He was joined by Justices William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall. Scalia's opinion was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, John Paul Stevens and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor provided the sixth vote to deny the unemployment benefits to the fired drug counselors. But she said in a separate concurring opinion that the five other justices in the majority went too far in limiting religious freedom. O'Connor said after weighing all the factors, she believes Oregon has ``a compelling interest'' in outlawing peyote use. In other action, the court: _ Made it more difficult for employers to withdraw recognition of a labor union representing striking workers after new employees are hired to break the strike. By a 5-4 vote, the justices reinstated a National Labor Relations Board policy against presuming the new employees oppose the union. _ Ruled that lawsuits charging employers with violating a key federal anti-bias law may be filed in state as well as federal courts. The 9-0 ruling upheld a $27,000 award won by a Chicago Ridge, Ill., woman against her trucking company employer, the Yellow Freight System Co. The peyote case was before the nation's highest court for the second time. The justices in 1988 sent it back to the Oregon Supreme Court to determine whether the religious use of peyote was a crime in that state. The justices were seeking that guidance, presumably, because if a state can ban all peyote use outright, it has the power to withhold unemployment benefits for those who use the drug. But the Oregon Supreme Court refused to answer the high court's question, once again ruling that Oregon may not deny unemployment compensation for use of peyote in a religious ceremony. Unlike Oregon, the federal government and most states exempt religious use of peyote from their criminal drug laws. The fired workers in today's case, Galen W. Black and Alfred C. Smith, were counselors with the Douglas County, Ore., Council on Alcohol and Drug Abuse Prevention and Treatment (ADAPT). After each took small amounts of peyote as part of a Native American Church sacrament, they were fired by ADAPT for violating company policy. The rehabilitation program since has changed its policy and now permits employees to use peyote in religious services. Peyote is a cactus ``button'' containing the hallucinogen mescaline. Smith, a Klamath Indian, is a recovered alcoholic who said he has not taken a drink since 1957. Black is not an Indian but converted to the Native American Church. He worked for ADAPT while recovering from drug and alcohol abuse. State officials have not disputed that both men sincerely believe peyote is a part of the church's religious practices. Lawyers for both men said using small quantities of peyote in a church service is comparable to sacramental use of small quantities of wine in Christian religious ceremonies. But state officials said that if peyote is permitted in church ceremonies it will create a wedge for allowing other drugs, such as marijuana, to be used by other religious groups. Oregon officials also argued that creating an exception for peyote would be a violation of constitutionally required separation of church and state. The case is Oregon Employment Division vs. Smith, 88-1213.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Lantos Got Free Office Space From Lobby Firm
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Tom Lantos, a leader of Congress' probe into the Department of Housing and Urban Development, got free office space from a company representing a key figure in the HUD affair, a published report says. The space was provided rent-free by Hill & Knowlton Inc., a major public relations company that is prominent in Washington lobbying, the San Jose Mercury News reported Sunday. The Congressional Human Rights Foundation, a private group headed by Lantos, has used the space since late 1988, the newspaper said. The newspaper said it investigated the foundation and a similarly named, taxpayer-supported organization founded by Lantos. The California Democrat denied that he had violated ethical or financial guidelines. Hill & Knowlton was hired to represent former federal housing commissioner Thomas T. Demery before Congress and the news media after an April 1989 inspector general's report raised suspicions of possible wrongdoing by him at HUD. Lantos' space arrangement with Hill & Knowlton was unknown to the public when on May 8 he ruled that his House subcommittee would not question Demery about important aspects of the inspector general's report. Lantos, 62, a member of the House since 1981, terminated an interview last October and requested that further questions be submitted in writing, the newspaper said. The Mercury News did so March 19. In written responses to those questions, the congressman denied he had violated ethical or financial guidelines. Lantos also said his activities involving Hill & Knowlton and the human rights foundation have not influenced his congressional decision-making. ``The foundation,'' Lantos said, ``is a separate legal entity reflecting the global human rights concerns of many persons, including members of Congress. In no way does it affect my official actions.'' Lantos also is a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Hill & Knowlton did not respond to messages seeking comment. Vice Chairman and Managing Director Frank Mankiewicz told the Mercury News that his firm began providing the free space to Lantos' foundation because, ``We do some pro bono work, and this seemed like a worthy cause.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Sets Guidelines for Awarding Interest Payments
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today set some new guidelines for awarding interest payments to winners of antitrust lawsuits. The 5-4 ruling in a case from New Jersey is a partial victory for both sides in the dispute. The case stems from a suit by the former owners of a New Jersey company who accused Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corp. of illegal monopoly practices. The former owners of Columbia Metal Culvert Co. in Vineland, N.J., which made aluminum drainage pipe, said the company was driven out of business by Kaiser. They sued Kaiser in 1974 and eventually were awarded more than $9.5 million in damages. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last year ruled the ex-owners are entitled to interest on the award from Dec. 2, 1981, until the award was paid by Kaiser on July 3, 1986. The Dec. 2 date is the one on which a federal jury assessed the damages. The Supreme Court today changed that date to Dec. 4, 1981, the date on which the judgment was formally approved by a federal judge. The high court rejected Kaiser's bid to base the interest payments on a period beginning July 1, 1986, when a federal appeals court upheld the damage award. The justices also rejected arguments by the former owners of the New Jersey firm who wanted the operative date set at Aug. 16, 1979, when a federal jury first found Kaiser guilty of antitrust violations. The high court also ordered a lower court to determine the interest rate to be paid based on the prevailing rate on Dec. 4, 1981. The 3rd Circuit court had said the interest should be based on Treasury bill rates. The appeals court had applied the Treasury bill rates retroactively _ since it was not until October 1982 that a federal law mandating the T-bill rate in such cases took effect. The high court today barred such retroactive application of the 1981 law. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote for the court. She was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices John Paul Stevens, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Dissenting were Justices Byron R. White, William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and Harry A. Blackmun. The cases are Kaiser Aluminum vs. Bonjorno, 88-1595, and Bonjorno vs. Kaiser, 88-1771.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Greyhound Driver Held in Bus Shooting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with bomb explosion, picking up 6th graf pvs, `On Monday....'
DOC.TEXT: A striking Greyhound driver was jailed without bail on charges he shot at a bus carrying 30 people, and a small bomb exploded today at a bus depot in northern California. Dennis L. Daniels, 42, was arrested at his home Monday after being indicted on federal charges of damaging the bus March 9 in reckless disregard for the safety of passengers and using a firearm in doing it. Daniels was the fourth person arrested for allegedly shooting at buses since Greyhound's 6,300 drivers and 3,000 maintenence and office workers walked out March 2 over wages and job security at America's only nationwide bus system. Three shots were fired at the bus shortly after midnight from a car on Interstate 71 about 25 miles from Columbus. Neither the driver nor any of the 29 passengers was injured, and the bus continued its Columbus-to-Cincinnati trip. Daniels was held for a bail hearing on Thursday. In northern California, a small bomb exploded early today at the Greyhound bus depot in downtown Redding, the same building where a striking Greyhound driver was killed when crushed by a bus in a March 3 accident. The explosion occurred outside the depot near a maintenance building, and a second bomb was found that did not explode, said Redding Police officer Bill Horton. He said there were no injuries and damage appeared minimal. On Monday, Greyhound spokeswoman Ann Wheat said a bus in Falksville, Ala., was fired on Saturday as it traveled to Birmingham, but the shot missed, and there were no injuries. In Kansas City, maintenence workers found a bullet embedded in the radiator of a bus that arrived from St. Louis, Ms. Wheat said. Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said there have been 31 shooting attacks involving Greyound and seven injuries since the strike began. One person was arrested in Connecticut and two were taken into custody in St. Louis. ``Our overall interest is getting the violence stopped,'' Gravley said. ``If more arrests are made, it may be effective in preventing further violence.'' Talks between the union and company have ceased and Gravley said the company will not resume talks until at least a week passes without violence. The seven-day rule means employees ``are being held hostage by common criminals,'' said union spokesman Jeff Nelson.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors: Bensonhurst Ringleader Bragged He Was Ready to Kill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf, `A second...'' to UPDATE with Fama opening postponed by lawyer's illness. Note language in 5th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The alleged ringleader in the white-on-black slaying of a teen-ager boasted he was going to shoot blacks, a prosecutor charged. But the defense argued the man was falsely accused by a drug-addicted young woman. ``I'll show you she's a contemptible liar. Her mother is a contemptible liar,'' Stephen Murphy screamed at the jury Monday as Keith Mondello went on trial for murder in the slaying Aug. 23 in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst section. Yusuf Hawkins, 16, was shot to death after he and three of his pals, all black, crossed paths with a mob of bat-wielding whites in the mostly Italian-American neighborhood. The four blacks had gone to look at a used car. The slaying raised racial tensions in the city in the middle of a mayoral campaign. Mondello, who did not shoot Hawkins but allegedly assembled the white gang, had ``boasted that he would blow the heads off the nigger bastards,'' Assistant District Attorney James Kohler said. ``It didn't matter what black man. Yusuf Hawkins innocently appeared on the scene, and his fate was sealed,'' the prosecutor said. A second jury sitting in the same courtroom had been scheduled to hear opening statements today in the murder trial of the accused gunman, Joseph Fama, but his lawyer was ill and the opening was postponed. Mondello and Fama, both 19, could receive 25 years to life in prison if convicted. Separate juries will hear testimony against the two defendants, with one panel deciding the fate of Mondello and the other the case against Fama. Six other whites have been charged in the slaying and will be tried later. Murphy asserted his client was falsely accused by Gina Feliciano, a key prosecution witness who he said is a habitual liar and an unreformed drug addict. The lawyer said he would play for the jury a secretly recorded telephone conversation between Miss Feliciano and her sister that ``makes it real clear that the truth has nothing to do with anything.'' A copy of the tape provided to reporters later Monday appeared to shed little new light on the case. Murphy said the girl brought on the entire episode by inviting some black and Hispanic friends to her birthday party in the neighborhood.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Eviction of Jewish Settlers in Old City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with court upholding eviction order. Pickup 2nd graf `Lawmaker Dedi...'; EDITS thereafter to TRIM and CONFORM
DOC.TEXT: A court today upheld an order to evict 150 Jewish settlers who rented church-owned buildings in the Christian quarter of the walled Old City despite protests by Palestinian Christians. The settlement of the Jews under police guard only days before Easter raised tensions in the Old City, where traditionally Moslems, Christians and Jews have lived in separate and jealously guarded neighborhoods. The settlers moved into the 72-room complex last Wednesday and set up the largest Jewish settlement in the Old City, which Israel captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. The settlers said the four buildings were sublet to a Panamanian company, which rented to them. The Greek Orthodox Church contended the rental to the settlers was illegal. Avraham Sochozolsky, a lawyer for the Greek Orthodox Church, said he would next ask police to carry out the eviction order. It was not clear, however, whether the settlers would be evicted immediately from the buildings, which once served as a church hospice. The three-judge panel of the Jerusalem District Court ruled that a stay of the eviction notice granted Friday by a single District Court judge was improperly obtained. The action in effect reinstated the original eviction order issued by a Magistrate's Court. ``The judges have canceled the stay. They (the settlers) must be evicted,'' Sochozolsky said. The lawyers for the settlers said before the decision that they planned to appeal. They left the court just after the ruling and were not available for comment. The decision came after a four-hour, closed-door session presided over by Judge Vardimus Zailer. The panel also included Judge Shalom Brenner, who last Thursday stayed the eviction order. On Monday, a group of Jews who ignited angry protests by moving into the Christian quarter accused Jewish Mayor Teddy Kollek, the Greek Orthodox Church and other critics of being anti-Semitic. Shmuel Evyatar, a spokesman for the Jewish settlers, urged ``everyone in the enlightened world to denounce the horrifying anti-Semitism to which we are witness.'' Also Monday, a legislator said Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is exploiting political uncertainty during the formation of a new government to boost the Jewish presence in the occupied lands. Lawmaker Dedi Zucker of the Citizens Rights Movement told The Associated Press that Shamir has approved preparations for four more settlements. He said Shamir also gave permission for a Jewish residential building in the West Bank city of Nablus and for enlarging the Jewish presence in the West Bank town of Hebron. Zucker said Shamir was pushing the government settlement program at this time because its opponents are now outside his caretaker government. ``Shamir is using the fact that he has nobody to argue with inside the government,'' Zucker said, referring to the left-of-center Labor Party that wants to slow down the pace of settlements. Labor governed jointly with Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, but it left the coalition in a dispute over U.S. peace proposals and then toppled the government on March 15. Shamir spokesman Yossi Ahimeir refused to comment on the specifics of Zucker's charges. ``Mr. Zucker is the one who is acting against the national needs of our state, and I don't want to react to statements by this man,'' Ahimeir said. Since capturing the West Bank and Gaza Strip from Arab neighbors in the 1967 Middle East war, Israel has built 143 settlements, which are home to about 75,000 Jews. About 1.7 million Palestinians live in the occupied lands. The United States has criticized the settlements as an obstacle to peace.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Delay Pushes Back Next Mission
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Columbia will be launched one to two weeks late next month because of the delay in getting the shuttle Discovery off the ground with the Hubble Space Telescope, NASA said today. Columbia originally was scheduled to lift off May 9 carrying an astronomical observatory known as Astro. That date is no longer feasible since Discovery's second launch attempt is not until April 25. ``There's a rule of thumb that we like three weeks between launches,'' said Dick Young, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. NASA wants time to check Discovery following its five-day mission to see if anything needs to be changed before the next shuttle's flight. It will wait until Discovery is launched before setting a new target date for Columbia. Discovery's launch was scrubbed four minutes before liftoff April 10 because of a faulty auxiliary power unit. The mission was postponed 15 days to allow replacement of the power unit and recharging of Hubble's batteries. Discovery remains on the launch pad. The newly installed power unit will be tested for five minutes Wednesday. The $1.5 billion telescope, inside Discovery's sealed payload bay, will not be at risk, NASA said. Hubble's six nickel-hydrogen batteries are undergoing 130 hours of recharging. They will be put back in the telescope on Saturday. The telescope is NASA's most expensive and complex payload. Once in orbit 380 miles high, it will enable astronomers to study stars and galaxies so distant their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years. Columbia was transferred from the orbiter processing facility to the Vehicle Assembly Building on Monday. The move was delayed a few days so technicians could replace a leaking hydraulic part in the shuttle's nose landing gear. NASA plans to roll Columbia out Sunday to the second of the Kennedy Space Center's two shuttle launch pads.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Sued Hospital for Saving His Life Dies
DOC.TEXT: The lawyer for a man who sued a hospital for keeping him alive after he suffered cardiac arrest in 1988, says he expects the lawsuit to continue despite his client's death. Edward H. Winter, 84, died of a stroke Saturday at the Hillebrand Nursing Center, where he had lived since May 1988. Winter's lawyer, William C. Knapp, said Monday he expects family members to try to recover from St. Francis-St. George Hospital the $100,000 cost of Winter's nursing home care and damages for his emotional suffering. Legal and medical ethics experts have said the case could break new ground because hospitals traditionally have not been held liable for saving lives. In the lawsuit filed last year in Hamilton County Common Pleas Court, Winter said that after a May 25, 1988, heart attack, he asked the hospital not to take any special measures to keep him alive. He accused St. Francis-St. George staff members of disregarding his wishes and reviving him after a second heart attack. Two days later, Winter suffered a stroke that left him unable to walk, talk or care for himself. Winter's daughter, Lynn Kroger, said her father suffered mentally and physically after the stroke. St. Francis-St. George Hospital denies any wrongdoing, and contends that Winter didn't make clear to hospital staff that he issued orders not to perform lifesaving measures on him. The hospital says it respects patients' refusal of such treatment. Knapp said the administrator of Winter's estate will decide how much to seek in damages. No administrator has yet been appointed. Funeral services are scheduled for Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Maker of ``Boo Pumpkin'' Recalls Potentially Hazardous Toy
DOC.TEXT: The manufacturer of a Halloween toy cited for potential hazards by a consumer group is recalling the novelty items, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Tuesday. Rhode Island-based Easy Aces, Inc. this week recalled 40,000 of its ``Boo Pumpkin'' toys because, the commission said, parts can break off ``and pose a fatal choking hazard to yung children.'' The two-inch, pumpkin-shaped toys were sold nationwide between August and November 1989. When the pumpkin is squeezed a latex balloon shaped like a ghost pops out and a squeaker sounds. The Americans for Democratic Action Consumer Affairs Committee said in its annual Holiday Toy Safety report in December 1989 that the ``Boo Pumpkin'' presents a choking hazard. The pumpkin was listed among potentially dangerous toys placed near store checkout counters that consumers may buy on impulse while waiting to pay for other items. Noting ``inhalation of balloon parts is a major source of injury and death,'' ADA warned the balloon could come off and tempt a small child to put it in his or her mouth. The CPSC recently began the first step of a three-part rulemaking process that could result in mandatory warning labels for balloons. Consumers should return the toys to the stores where purchased for a full refund, the commission said.

DOC.HEAD: `The Piano Lesson' by August Wilson Opens on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 4 grafs with what other critics said. No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: A ghostly ragtime melody floats through the air at the beginning of August Wilson's ``The Piano Lesson.'' It's a haunting tune that makes the old upright piano in Doaker Charles' Pittsburgh living room in 1936 come alive with memories of a past that is very much a part of the present. Both past and present are the subjects of ``The Piano Lesson,'' a mesmerizing history of one black family that refuses to give up either one. The play won the 1990 Pulitzer Prize for drama last week and deservedly so. ``The Piano Lesson,'' which opened Monday at Broadway's Walter Kerr Theater, is another installment in Wilson's decade-by-decade look at the black experience in American life. And it is Wilson's most accomplished work to date, resonating with a poetry that enhances a strong story and illuminates a half dozen or so expertly drawn characters. That piano dominates Wilson's play _ and the stage. It is the battleground between a brother, Boy Willie, and his sister, Berniece, both of whom want the family heirloom for their own purposes. Berniece wants to keep the piano, a symbol of the Charles family's slave days down South. Boy Willie wants to sell it to buy the land their ancestors worked. The conflict between these grandchildren of slaves is revealed slowly but effectively by Wilson. The playwright is not afraid to take time to set up scenes and develop characters. His persistence pays off. Wilson traces the piano's history from the time Berniece's great-grandmother and her grandfather, then age 9, were sold, to buy the instrument. And how her great-grandfather carved details of their history into its wood, a lasting memory of its high price. Wilson also details how Berniece's father helped steal the piano from its owners _ and lost his life in the process. And how it eventually made its way to Pittsburgh and the home of Berniece's Uncle Doaker. Berniece sees the piano as a symbol of her family's survival. She won't even play it, preferring to let the piano sit as a museum piece in her uncle's living room. Boy Willie sees it as a means to a better life. He's not afraid to use the past to build a better future. The past takes on mythic, even supernatural qualities in the play. In fact, the play ends in an exorcism of the past that pits Boy Willie against the ghosts of the family that once owned his forefathers. It's effectively melodramatic if not entirely convincing. Director Lloyd Richards' best moments are small ones, quiet scenes where the characters reveal their hopes for the future or funny bits, particularly when one scamp of a character tries to fleece another man out of money for a suit. Charles S. Dutton is a towering Boy Willie, both in size and spirit. His Boy Willie is alternately ingratiating and calculating, a man who knows what he wants and won't stop until he gets it. But he is equally matched by the marvelous S. Epatha Merkerson as the resolute Berniece. Her dignified determination is quiet but by no means less effective. There are sharply drawn portraits by the other actors including Rocky Carroll as Boy Willie's naive friend and cohort in crime, Tommy Hollis as Berniece's suitor, Carl Gordon as the strong, dignified Uncle Doaker and particularly Lou Myers as an old reprobate uncle. From ``Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' to ``Fences'' to ``Joe Turner's Come and Gone,'' Wilson demonstrated an ability to create specific universes, filled with real people who speak with their own unique voices. In ``The Piano Lesson,'' these voices make for memorable theater.

What other critics said: Frank Rich, The New York Times: ``The Piano Lesson'' is joyously an African-American play: It has its own spacious poetry, its own sharp angle on a nation's history and its own palpable ghosts that roar right through the upstairs window of the household where the action unfolds. Howard Kissel, the Daily News: In this play, as in ``Joe Turner's Come and Gone,'' Wilson is trying to go beyond the poetic realism of ``Fences,'' into a combination of realism and mysticism. As yet the attempt seems strained, but Wilson's efforts to find mystic depths in the everyday are important, because they may help push the American theater beyond the mingy naturalism in which it seems so hopelessly mired. Clive Barnes, New York Post: ``The Piano Lesson'' ... is a play of magnificent confrontations. ... This is a wonderful play that lights up man. See it, wonder at it, and recognize it.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow to Start Shutting Off Gas Supply to Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8, `In Washington ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Bush comment. Pickup 7th graf `Teresa Juodenienie...'
DOC.TEXT: Soviet officials ordered drastic cuts in natural gas supplies to Lithuania today, putting into force a threatened economic embargo to break the Baltic republic's drive for independence, Lithuanians said. Soviet officials also plan to cut oil and gasoline to the republic on Wednesday, Lithuanian officials said. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had given Lithuania until Sunday to repeal laws enacted since the republic's parliament declared independence March 11. Lithuanian residents had been forming long lines at gasoline stations in recent days to fill up for what they feared might be the last time. ``Implementing the orders of the government of the Soviet Union and those of the state gas concern ... supplies of natural gas ot the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic will be sharply reduced from the 17th of April,'' said a telegram sent by a Soviet gas official to Lithuanian authorities. Rita Dapkus, a spokeswoman for the Lithuanian Supreme Council, confirmed the telegram's text, which was broadcast on the republic's official radio and monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. in London. No official announcement was made immediately in Moscow. President Bush said his administration is studying how to respond if Moscow carries out the threats, but he refused to elaborate. ``We're waiting to see if the Soviet announcements are implemented,'' Bush said. ``Clearly those announcements are contrary to the approach that we have urged and that others have urged upon the Soviet Union. ``We are considering appropriate responses if these threats are implemented,'' Bush said. ``And I'm going to leave it right there.'' Teresa Juodenienie, a secretary for Premier Kazimiera Prunskiene, said in a telephone interview that the Lithuanian government received a telephone warning from the Druzhba, or Friendship, enterprise that supplies oil to Lithuania, saying that deliveries of oil and gasoline will be curtailed beginning Wednesday. She said the telegram announcing the natural gas reduction was sent only to Lithuania's gas authority rather than to the government, and that officials did not immediately know whether the cut already had taken effect and what percentage would be reduced. The news came after Lithuania's Parliament convened today to define a response to Gorbachev's ultimatum threatening an economic blockade. The republic's prime minister sent Gorbachev a telegram on Monday seeking a meeting to negotiate Moscow's objections to laws enacted in the Baltic state promoting its March 11 independence decree. Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said Lithuania's leaders were ready to discuss allowing residents who so desire to remain Soviet citizens and permitting Lithuanians to join the Soviet army if they so choose. She also expressed a willingness to discuss the protection of borders. ``The main goal of negotiations is to realize independence, or how the Soviet Union can get out of this situation and out of Lithuania,'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis was quoted as telling legislators today. The parliamentary session was televised live in Lithuania, said Edwardas Potashinskas of Lithuanian TV, who reported Landsbergis' remarks. Gorbachev on Friday gave Lithuania 48 hours to rescind laws on those issues or face a cutoff of products the Soviet Union supplies to the republic. He described as ``unconstitutional'' such Lithuanian proposals as releasing Lithuanian youth from the annual spring conscription into the Soviet army and introducing the republic's own identity cards. Gorbachev did not specify what supplies could be cut off, but Lithuania depends on the Kremlin for oil, gas, machinery, raw materials, chemicals and automobiles. Gorbachev has refused to meet with Lithuanians unless the republic backs away from its independence declaration and there was no immediate response to the telegram from Prunskiene. In her telegram, Prunskiene said a broad economic boycott would damage both the Soviet and Lithuanian economies. Lithuania's chief of foreign trade, Rimantas Purtulis, told reporters that gas supplies would last a month and oil three to four months, according to Daina Kalendra of the Parliament's press office. Lithuania gets its oil and gas from the Soviet Union at prices much lower than world market prices. The republic has little foreign currency to buy fuel from the West. Some economic sanctions against Lithuania could backfire on the Soviet Union, journalist Vilius Kavaliauskas quoted one official in the leadership as saying. Among them: _ If Moscow embargoed much-needed chemical fertilizers, that will mean less meat and dairy products for the 14 other Soviet republics. _ If a natural gas pipeline were shut down, the Russian district of Kaliningrad wedged between Lithuania and Poland would be hurt. _ A cutoff of supplies for the Drob textile mill would also disrupt deliveries to a Leningrad factory that employs more than 18,000 people. Kavaliauskas said his source said the republic has enough newsprint for four or five days. Western correspondents have been barred by Soviet authorities from Lithuania since last month and the Soviet military has sought to assert its authority in the republic by seizing and beating deserters from the army and parading armored vehicles through the streets. Landsbergis said Monday that the other two Baltic republics, Estonia and Latvia, promised aid in the face of an embargo, but gave no details, Ms. Kalendra reported. The three Baltic states were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Latvia and Estonia also are seeking independence, but moving more cautiously.

DOC.HEAD: Some Bus Drivers Commit An Offense Every Five Minutes
DOC.TEXT: Policemen with video cameras boarded a number of express buses Tuesday and discovered to their horror that some drivers committed an offense every five minutes. The chief police officer of the state of Selangor, Nordin Idris, said after the experiment that some drivers passed other vehicles on bridges. Some of the more reckless drivers overtook six vehicles in a row, he said. Nordin told reporters the buses were driven ``aggressively and violently'' without regard for the safety of passsengers or other motorists. He said police will prosecute the offending drivers for dangerous driving. Nordin said passengers had the right to remind drivers not to drive recklessly and to report them to the Road Transport Department.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Seeks Records of 754 Bank Accounts in Drug Probe
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department today sought records of 754 U.S. bank accounts that it says once contained $400 million in illegal drug profits amassed by Colombian drug lords. The cepartment asked federal judges in Atlanta, New York and Miami to direct 173 banks in 23 states to produce records of the accounts. Prosecutors also sought to freeze 684 accounts, which they said were linked to Eduardo Martinez Romero, who was extradited last September from Colombia to face charges of laundering money for the Medellin cartel. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement that the action was the fourth phase in the Justice Department's longrunning Operation Polar Cap investigation of Colombian cocaine trafficking in this country. The action ``seeks to lift the veil of secrecy over the financial network of these narco-terrorists, including Pablo Escobar and Jorge Ochoa,'' Thornburgh said in a statement. Operation Polar Cap, conducted by the Drug Enforcement Administration and other federal law enforcement agencies, determined that the cartel made $1.2 billion selling cocaine on American streets between 1987 and 1989, officials said. Through a complicated set of wire transfers involving banks in eight foreign countries, $400 million ended up in the banks from which the records are being sought, officials said. Other money was invested in foreign countries or was used to buy supplies and equipment for cocaine production, officials said. Justice Department trial attorney Peter G. Djinis said investigators traced the money ``dollar for dollar'' through banks in Colombia, Panama, Uruguay, Luxembourg, Switzerland, Britain, Canada and Austria. Investigators have been reviewing the bank records for almost a year with the cooperation of the eight foreign governments. Officials said they do not know how much of the $400 million remains in the accounts. But Djinis said the records are expected to help investigators continue their pursuit of the international money trail left by the cocaine dealers. `We think this is going to point fingers in a lot of directions,'' he said, and could help investigators identify additional assets of the Colombian cartel as well as individuals involved in its illegal activities. The Justice Department believes the records will confirm suspicions that the cartel bought real estate in this country, he said. Most of the accounts were located in Miami and New York because many of the people who used them lived in those cities, Djinis said. Many of the accounts were kept in the name of Martinez and others were held for nominees, including the 2-year-old daughter of a member of the cartel. The funds were kept in U.S. banks to finance the purchase of airplanes, equipment and ``to keep up the payroll,'' Djinis said. ``The only way to administer these activities is to have ongoing capital in the U.S,'' he said. There was no evidence the banks in which the accounts were kept were ``anything other than unwitting service providers,'' said David Runkel, the department's chief spokesman. But Djinis said a review of the bank records may lead investigators to a different conclusion. ``We are not ruling out anything,'' he said. Nevertheless, he said, ``we are not at this time suggesting the banks had knowledge and were knowing and willing participants in the return of the funds to the U.S.''

DOC.HEAD: Nordic Council Drops Soviet Visit Because Lithuania Excluded
DOC.TEXT: Officials of the five-nation Nordic Council on Tuesday canceled a visit to the Soviet Union because they were barred from going into Lithuania, the Norwegian news agency NTB reported. The decision appeared to be a rebuke of Moscow's plans to use economic sanctions to force an end to Lithuania's independence drive, said NTB. ``It is a shame that the planned trip cannot be carried out, and it is a shame that the Soviets are subjecting Lithuania to such a hard ride,'' said Bjarne Moerk Eiden, a member of the council leadership. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev invited a delegation from Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland and Iceland to visit the Soviet Union for a week in May. The council requested stops in the Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, but Moscow said a visit to Lithuania would be difficult, NTB said. ``It had to be all the Baltic states, or no tour at all,'' said Anders Talleraas, a Norwegian representative. The three Baltic republic were forcibly annexed by the Kremlin in 1940. Lithuania declared itself independent March 11.

DOC.HEAD: Interim Government Cabinet to be Sworn in Thursday
DOC.TEXT: Nepal's first opposition-led government in almost 30 years will be sworn in this week to rule the Himalayan nation until free elections are held, an opposition leader said today. Prime Minister designate K.P. Bhattarai made the announcement after he and another opposition leader, Ganesh Man Singh, met with King Birendra at the royal palace. The Cabinet will be sworn in on Thursday, he said. Bhattarai said the names of ministers or their portfolios have not been finalized but only two members of the 11-member Cabinet will be appointed by the once all-powerful king. Four members, including the prime minister, will be from the Nepali Congress Party, led by Singh, and three from the United Left Front coalition. The two parties led Nepal's democracy movement, which surged on Feb. 18. There will also be two independents. One minister will be a woman, Left Front chairman Sahana Pradhan, Bhattarai said. The interim government will be Nepal's first opposition government in almost three decades. Elections have yet to be scheduled but on Monday Singh said they would be held by April next year. The Nepali Congress in 1959 formed the country's first democratically elected government, which lasted only 20 months before Birendra's father, King Mahendra, dismissed it, accusing it of corruption and poor administration. Mahendra banned political parties, introduced a new constitution and ruled the country through a rubber stamp government and the partyless Rashtriya Panchayat, or National Assembly. Birendra legalized political parties on April 8 after a people's movement brought the country to a standstill with strikes and demonstrations. On Monday he agreed to dismiss the National Assembly and allow the opposition to lead the interim government. Bhattarai, 65, was Parliament speaker in the 1959-60 government. He was jailed for nine years immediately after Mahendra's action. He spent five more years in jail during different periods for political agitation. Birendra ``was very happy with the proposed Cabinet and told us he wanted to cooperate and help us,'' Bhattarai said. Bhattarai quoted the king as saying his nominees will ``never impede the work you have undertaken. They are there just to smooth operations.'' He said the prime minister will have the freedom to allot portfolios, including those to the king's nominees. Bhattarai will be sworn in by Birendra at the Narayan-hiti royal palace. The prime minister will then administer the oath of office to his Cabinet colleagues at the Singh Durbar where the secretariat is housed. Many of Nepal's 17 million people regard the king as the reincarnation of a Hindu god.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Warns Moscow on Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 3-4 with Bush comments in interview
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today warned Moscow that the United States would make ``appropriate responses'' if the Soviet Union carries out a threat to cut back drastically on natural gas and other fuel supplies to Lithuania. Bush refused to say what steps might be taken. ``We are considering appropriate responses if these threats are implemented,'' Bush said. In an interview Monday with a group of foreign journalists, the president said, ``I want to be sure anything we do is productive. There's been dramatic change in the world and I don't want to inadvertently take some action that would set it back.'' ``And yet, I don't want to be seen as one who is not interested in the peaceful change and in the self-determination for Lithuania,'' Bush said in the interview. A transcript of his remarks was released today. Bush issued his warning after Soviet officials ordered sharp cuts in natural gas supplies to Lithuania and said reductions in oil and gasoline will begin on Wednesday. ``Obviously we are watching the situation very, very closely,'' Bush said, commenting during a picture-taking session in the Oval Office with visiting President Rafael Callejas of Honduras. ``We're waiting to see if the Soviet announcements are implemented,'' Bush said. ``Clearly those announcements are contrary to the approach that we have urged and that others have urged upon the Soviet Union. ``We are considering appropriate responses if these threats are implemented,'' Bush said. ``And I'm going to leave it right there.'' Bush concluded by saying, ``What we need is dialogue, discussion and a peaceful resolution of this great difficulty there.'' The president planned to meet on the subject later in the day with Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, who led a Senate delegation to Moscow last week, and Minority leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. Both lawmakers have criticized the Soviet ultimatum. Dole said Congress might act on its own to retaliate economically against Moscow if it escalated its efforts to block Lithuania's drive toward independence. Mitchell said Gorbachev's threat was contrary to the assurances that he and other senators had received from the Soviet leader in Moscow that force or intimidation would not be used. The president has repeatedly warned that Soviet pressures against Lithuania put U.S.-Soviet relations at risk. At a news conference last Friday, Bush told Moscow that ``now is no time for escalation. It's time for talk.'' He made the comment after Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev set a 48-hour deadline for Lithuania to revoke legislation it had passed since its March 11 declaration of independence, or face cutoff of critical supplies. In recent weeks, high-level U.S. officials have been meeting to consider what steps the administration might take in response to various Soviet actions against Lithuania. Most of the options apparently involve economic measures, such as denying Moscow improved trade status or blocking its entry into international economic organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma Teachers Stage Walkout over Education Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with pickets at Capitol today; number of schools closed today, Oklahoma board closing schools Thursday. CORRECTS quote in 4th graf, `In order...', to day sted week. Picks up 14th graf, `Senate President...'.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Oklahoma teachers abandoned their classrooms to protest the failure of a school funding bill, and union officials called for more teachers to join the walkout today. Many of the teachers picketed at the state Capitol on Monday, and hundreds swarmed the halls, lobbying for the failed $230 million education package. Hundreds returned to the Capitol today to walk a picket line. Some school administrators supported the walkout; others opposed it. The Oklahoma City School Board today oted to used a leftover snow day to allow teachers to join the protest Thursday. Oklahoma City schools _ the second largest district in the state with 38,000 students _ were open Monday. ``In order for us to make this work our numbers need to grow each day,'' Kyle Dahlem, president of the Oklahoma Education Association, said Monday as the union kicked off a five-day teacher walkout. Speaking at the Capitol, Ms. Dahlem called for the closing of more schools throughout the week and demonstrations at the Capitol and local schools. Nancy Jewell, union vice president, estimated that more than 10,000 took part in Monday's protest at the Capitol. Other estimates ranged up from 5,000. The union called the walkout after the Oklahoma Senate failed last week to pass the school bill as an emergency measure, which would have put it into effect immediately. The union today said it thought the strike was gaining strength. Spokeswoman Carla Feeley said 139 of the state's 606 school districts were closed today, down from the more than 145 closed Monday. But she said more teachers from districts that remain open have joined the strike. She estimated that 18,600 teachers, or 60 percent of the union's 31,000 members, are participating in the walkout. The state had 40,052 teachers in the 1988-89 school year. Gov. Henry Bellmon asked Attorney General Robert Henry to go to court if necessary to prevent illegal strike activity. Henry said state law forbidding strikes against school boards did not appear to apply in the case of a walkout to protest legislative action. Bellmon had opposed the strike, although he backs the education package. ``The decision by a significant number of Oklahoma teachers, administrators and school board members to interrupt the educational process is deeply regretted,'' Bellmon said. The Tulsa school district, the largest in the state, was closed Monday and again today. Senate President Pro Tempore Bob Cullison said there were discussions over the weekend about reviving the school bill. The education package _ the end product of an eight-month special session _ provides an additional $212 million in funding for schools, and sponsors said much of the money could be used to upgrade teacher pay. Teachers say their pay ranks 48th in the nation. Under the bill, the minimum pay for a beginning teacher with a bachelor's degree would go from about $15,000 a year to about $24,000 a year. Much of the opposition was stirred by the plan for taxes to support the reforms, including a half-cent increase in the state's 4-cent sales tax and increases in corporate and personal income taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Two Military Jets Collide Near Karlsruhe; 1 Pilot Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with police unable to say whether second pilot was hit by car, second person injured by debris; Picks up last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Two Canadian air force fighter jets collided near this southwestern city today, killing one pilot and showering the area with flaming debris, police said. The second pilot landed in his ejector seat on a busy highway, the A5 autobahn, and his condition was not immediately known. Police spokesman Manfred Frey said he could not confirm earlier reports the pilot was hit by a car. Fire officials and police rushed to put out small fires started by the falling aircraft debris. At least two people on the ground were slightly injured, police said. Much of the debris landed near the train station. ``Luckily, damage (on the ground) was minimal,'' because the area where the planes crashed is not densely populated, a police spokesman said. Baerbel Newman, a spokeswoman for the Canadian air force in Lahr, said the planes crashed at about 4:10 p.m., south of Karlsruhe. She confirmed that one pilot was killed and the second was injured. ``One of them is alive, but in what condition, I don't know,'' she said. Police identified the aircraft as American-made F-18s. They had taken off from a base near Rastatt, about 25 miles southwest of Karlsruhe, police said. The Canadian air force has 48 F-18s at the base south of Karlsruhe.

DOC.HEAD: GAO: Next 50 Years to Bring Bigger Timber Harvests, Fewer Jobs
DOC.TEXT: National timber harvests will increase 55 percent over the next half century but industry employment will fall an average of 27 percent because of saw-mill modernization, the government said Tuesday. The South will feel the greatest effect of the modernization, losing an estimated 36 percent of its timber industry jobs in the next 50 years, the General Accounting Office said. Elsewhere, the report said, employment was expected to fall 26 percent in the Rocky Mountain region, 23 percent in the North and 13 percent on the Pacific Coast. However, the South is expected to post the largest harvest increase over the next five decades _ from about 8 billion cubic feet to nearly 14 billion cubic feet. The North is expected to nearly double its 1986 harvest of 4 billion cubic feet by 2040, while the Pacific Coast and Rocky Mountain regions are forecast to show only slight gains from their 1986 levels, to about 6 billion and 2 billion cubic feet respectively. Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich., requested the GAO report, much of which was presented to lawmakers in testimony before the House Ways and Means Committee last month. The regional statistics and supplemental information were made public this week. Chester Joy, a GAO evaluator, said the projections were based on U.S. policy at the time the study began in October. It does not take into account proposed changes in Pacific Northwest logging in an effort to save the northern spotted owl from extinction. Timber was the nation's No. 1 agricultural crop in 1986, composing about one-fourth of the total value of all major crops. Timber harvesting increased 4 percent from 1986, to 17.6 billion cubic feet in 1988, while the number of acres planted and seeded annually increased 23 percent from 1986, to 3.39 million in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Government Approves Anti-Viral Aid for Kidney Transplant Patients
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday approved a new biological product to help protect kidney transplant patients from a potentially fatal infection. The product, Cytomegalovirus Immune Globulin Intravenous, or CMV-IGIV, contains cytomegalovirus antibodies, giving the patient the ability to fight CMV infections that can be carried by donated kidneys, the FDA said. The virus is common in the United States and is usually harmless. But when it is carried by a donated kidney, transplant patients often are unable to fight its uncontrolled spread to other critical organs because their immune systems have been weakened with drugs to prevent rejection of the new organ. The infections are serious in transplant patients and can be fatal. The new product will enlarge the pool of donated kidneys available to people who have no cytomegalovirus antibodies. People who have been infected with the virus earlier in their lives already have the antibodies necessary to ward off CMV infection and do not need CMV-IGIV, the FDA said. The immune globulin has been available for transplant patients since October 1987 under the FDA's program to investigate new drugs, which allows patients with serious or life-threatening conditions to get experimental drugs. CMV-IGIV has no major side effects, but it has been associated with flushing, chills, muscle cramps, back pain, fever, nausea, vomiting and wheezing in a small number of patients, the FDA said. It should not be given to patients sensitive to immunoglobulin A, the agency said. The product was developed under the FDA's orphan drug program by the Massachusetts Public Health Biologic Laboratories of Jamaica Plain, Mass. The program provides financial incentives to develop therapies for serious but rare diseases. The product is being distributed by the American Red Cross, Northeast Region, which can be contacted in Massachusetts at 617-461-0891.

DOC.HEAD: Court Sends Case Involving Federal Agencies, Unions, Back for Study
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court left unresolved today a conflict between federal agencies and their employees' unions stemming from the government policy of ``contracting out'' _ buying certain goods and services from private businesses. The justices said a dispute between the Internal Revenue Service and a federal employee union should be restudied by a federal appeals court or by the Federal Labor Relations Authority. The FLRA resolves collective bargaining disputes between federal agencies and their employees. By a 6-3 vote, the court struck down a FLRA ruling that would have forced agencies to negotiate with unions over how to resolve contracting-out disputes. Justice Antonin Scalia wrote for the court that the authority wrongly ruled the IRS must negotiate with the National Treasury Employees Union over a contract proposal to submit contracting-out disputes to arbitration. ``We do not lightly overturn the FLRA's construction of the act (the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978) it is charged with administering,'' Scalia said. ``However, we conclude that the FLRA's construction is not reasonable.'' But Scalia said the court was leaving unanswered whether some other legal basis exists for forcing agencies to negotiate over such contract proposals. Justices John Paul Stevens, William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall dissented. The case is IRS vs. FLRA, 88-2123.

DOC.HEAD: Notice of Appeal Filed
DOC.TEXT: The attorney for Joseph Hazelwood has filed notice that the former Exxon Valdez skipper will appeal his conviction on one count of negligent discharge of oil. Hazelwood was acquitted by a Superior Court jury on March 22 of more serious charges that he had been drunk and reckless when the tanker ran aground on a reef in Prince William Sound. The grounding resulted in the nation's worst oil spill. Nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil gushed into the waters and along hundreds of miles of shorelines. The notice off appeal was sent late last week from Fairbanks and arrived at Superior Court on Monday. After the court certifies the notice, defense attorneys have 30 days to file the appeal brief. Dick Madson, a defense attorney based in Fairbanks, said the appeal will argue that Hazelwood was immune from prosecution because of federal and state laws that protect ship captains from prosecution if they immediately report a spill. Hazelwood was ordered to pay $50,000 restitution and to perform 1,000 hours of community service cleaning the waterway.

DOC.HEAD: Kissing Protesters Win
DOC.TEXT: Gay-rights demonstrators kissed, and made up with the owner of a cafe where an employee had asked two women patrons to stop their smooching. Donald Hanigan assured the protesters Monday they would not be discriminated against at his Espresso Royale Cafe and that he wanted their business. The controversy began April 8 when an employee asked two women to refrain from holding hands and kissing as they sat at a window table along State Street near the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus. On Monday, about 125 protesters showed up and exchanged kisses for several minutes. ``You say gays and lesbians cannot show affection here?'' asked Malvene Collins, a spokeswoman for the protesters. ``Why not here but in every other restaurant in Madison?'' An apology was in order, Hanigan told the protesters. ``I regret that this incident ever happened,'' he said. ``I want all of you to come in here every day.''

DOC.HEAD: Housing Starts Continue to Fall
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Housing starts continued to fall in March from their January peak, the government reported Tuesday, but many analysts said the decline had bottomed out. The Commerce Department reported that starts of new homes and apartments fell 9.3 percent last month, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.32 million units _ a pace many analysts said probably would continue. ``We might see levels like we had in March during most of the rest of the year,'' said economist Thomas Holloway of the Mortgage Bankers Association. The drop was the sharpest since a 12.4 percent plunge in January 1989, but was expected after starts jumped 23.2 percent to an annual rate of 1.57 million units during January's record warm weather. They slipped to 1.46 million in February, still well above the level of the last 11 months of 1989 as unusually warm weather continued. ``It isn't so much that housing is plunging as it is a correction in the data to the bulge earlier this year which couldn't be sustained,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for The Boston Co. David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, noted that all of the decline was in single-family homes, which fell 12 percent to an annual rate of 1.02 million units. Nevertheless, Berson added, the March rate ``still is a very good number, better than most months of 1989.'' Single-family starts totaled 1 million last year. On the other hand, multifamily starts gained 0.9 percent to an annual rate of 306,000 _ ``up a tad, but still at an abysmally low number,'' said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. Apartment starts plunged 35.3 percent in February after a 37.1 percent jump the previous month. In addition to the weather, analysts had attributed the January gain to builders wanting to get construction under way before expensive new regulations designed to make apartments more accessible to the handicapped went into effect. Seiders blamed the ``incredible weakness'' in apartment starts on fair housing regulations for the handicapped that he said would add as much as $3,000 to the cost of multifamily units and on a construction credit crunch brought on by the August savings and loan bailout law. The biggest decline in starts was experienced the Northeast, where the real estate industry has been in the doldrums in recent months. They were down 37.8 percent, to 138,000 units, after advancing 32.1 percent in February. ``We though we had seen hopeful signs'' in the Northeast, Seiders said, ``but it clearly was a temporary, weather-based effect. Now it's showing it is the weakest housing component in the country.'' Other declines were posted in the South, down 11.5 percent to 524,000 units, and the West, down 0.5 percent to 376,000 units. The Midwest registered the only gain, up 6.8 percent to 293,000 units. Applications for building permits, often a barometer of future housing activity, fell 7.6 percent after dropping 25.2 percent the previous month. The 1.21 million applications were the lowest since 1.15 million permits were sought in October 1982.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Tuesday by the Supreme Court.
PEYOTE
The court ruled there is no constitutional right to take the hallucinogenic drug peyote as a religious practice. The justices, voting 6-3, said Oregon officials may deny unemployment benefits to two fired drug counselors who ingested small amounts of peyote in Indian religious ceremonies. Justice Antonin Scalia, writing for the court, said the First Amendment does not permit people to break the law in the name of religious freedom. In a strongly worded dissent, Justice Harry A. Blackmun accused the court of treating religious freedom for the first time as a ``luxury'' rather than ``an essential element of liberty.'' The case is Oregon Employment Division vs. Smith, 88-1213.
STRIKES
The court made it more difficult for employers to withdraw recognition of a labor union representing striking workers after new employees are hired to break the strike. By a 5-4 vote, the justices reinstated a National Labor Relations Board policy against presuming the new employees oppose the union. The case is NLRB vs. Curtin Matheson Scientific Inc., 88-1685.
JOB BIAS
The court ruled that lawsuits charging employers with violating a key federal anti-bias law may be filed in state as well as federal courts. The 9-0 ruling upheld a $27,000 award won by a Chicago Ridge, Ill., woman against her trucking company employer, the Yellow Freight System Co. The case is Yellow Freight System vs. Donnelly, 89-431.
ANTITRUST
The court set some new guidelines for awarding interest payments to winners of antitrust lawsuits. The 5-4 ruling in a case from New Jersey stems from a suit by the former owners of Columbia Metal Culvert Co. in Vineland who accused Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corp. of illegal monopoly practices. The cases are Kaiser Aluminum vs. Bonjorno, 88-1595, and Bonjorno vs. Kaiser, 88-1771.

DOC.HEAD: If You Don't Want to Stick Your Neck Out, Pick Red Neckties
DOC.TEXT: They are the staple neckwear of presidents, politicians and power brokers. They brighten drab suits and look great on TV. They are to establishment businessmen what Sansabelt slacks are to golfers. At a time when the variety of men's neckties has never been greater, people are seeing red _ the traditional, risk-free hue for ties, no matter if they come with polka dots, paisleys, prints, patterns, stripes or geometric designs. ``Red is the brightest color that goes with all men's suits in a business environment,'' said tie-designer Alan Flusser, who created the neckwear for Michael Douglas in ``Wall Street,'' the tale of yuppie greed in the 1980s. ``It gives new life to somber, conservative business suits,'' he said. But be advised. Flusser's personal tie rack is devoid of red. The reasoning is similar to what Yogi Berra once said about a nightspot being too popular: ``Nobody goes there anymore. It's too crowded.'' ``Red is too obvious a color,'' said Flusser, whose only concession to red are his luxurious, woven Jacquards in claret, burgundy or bordeaux. But in places like the nation's capital, crimson is red hot in the corridors of power. President Bush favors them. TV anchormen love them, and ABC's Sam Donaldson wears red ties so often they've become a personal trademark. Donald Trump flashes them the same way he runs business _ unblushingly. Some trace red's staying power to the 1988 presidential campaign, when politicians out-did themselves to prove their red-blooded patriotism without sticking their necks out. ``I saw one Democratic debate when all seven of the candidates had a blue suit, white shirt and red tie. It was like a uniform,'' said Bob Beauchamp, fashion editor for Esquire magazine. The necktie is the only part of a man's wardrobe that has no function other than to decorate. The average man owns 30 to 40 ties, although only 10 to 15 of them are worn regularly, according to the Neckware Association of America, a New York-based industry trade group. It said about 95 million are sold each year, and red can be found more than any other color. ``A tie allows room for self-expression,'' said the association's Jerry Anderson. ``It's probably the most noticeable item he wears. It says more about your personality than a suit or a shirt.'' Fashion forecasters note the mainstream tie is widening from 3{ to 3} inches. Some risk-takers are even pushing the 4-inch barrier, Anderson said. And for those who are bloody tired of red, take heart. The latest look is called retro, for retrospective, a back to the future concept that revives the splashy patterns of the Forties and Fifties. ``You've had a conservative look for a number of years,'' Anderson said. ``Men want to look fresh and different. It's time for a change.'' The new look is embodied by hipster Arsenio Hall or the trendy characters on ``L.A. Law'' or ``thirtysomething.'' Bruce Mertz, president of Format Inc., a Chicago company that makes retro ties, has already buried power ties, even the trendy, teal-colored hues. ``If you see a guy wearing a yellow tie, he's really out of fashion. He hasn't bought a new necktie. He's sleeping,'' Mertz told the Chicago Tribune. ``They're gone. Finished. You don't see anybody wearing them.'' Meanwhile, New York tie designer Joseph Abboud would rather be dead than red. ``Men fall into safety zones. They see somebody else wearing red, so they wear it too. They all look like airline pilots,'' said Abboud, who makes ties for NBC's Bryant Gumbel. ``I think we've got to get the politicans to be a little more daring,'' he said. ``Red lacks originality or individuality. It's archaic. It's old news. You run the risk of being extremely boring and repetitive. ``I'm not telling people to wear naked ladies on their tie. But they can be freer and not as regimented. My whole goal is to design ties for a man who's a leader, not a follower, someone willing to step out and be his own man,'' Abboud said. Now, about those black socks.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Prices Rise Sharply in March
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBs 11th-12th grafs pvs, On Wall ... to provide updated Wall Street activity, picks up 13th graf pvs, In the ...
DOC.TEXT: Consumer prices surged an unexpectedly sharp 0.5 percent in March, pushing the inflation rate for the first three months of 1990 to its highest level in almost eight years, the government reported today. The Labor Department blamed last month's increase in the Consumer Price Index in large part on a jump in housing costs and another surge in new clothing prices, although there were widespread increases in a variety of retail areas. The 0.5 percent rise matched February's gain and followed a 1.1 percent increase in January. Private economists were caught by surprise by the brisk March advance, which they termed a disappointing sign that inflation was not slowing as they had hoped. Many analysts had been looking for a modest increase of around 0.2 percent. ``The CPI shows an entrenched, unacceptably high rate of inflation,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``The inflation result was dangerous and potentially devastating for financial markets and the economy.'' Through the first three months of the year, consumer prices have risen at an annual rate of 8.5 percent. That is the fastest quarterly increase since the spring of 1982 and is far above the 4.6 percent price increase for all of 1989. Today's bad inflation news was likely to strengthen the resolve of the Federal Reserve to resist pressures from the Bush administration to lower interest rates. Sinai predicted that if inflation does not retreat soon, the Fed may even begin pushing interest rates upward, something it has not done for over a year, in an effort to dampen price pressures. ``The message is that it may take more pain, more restraint on the economy, to get inflation down to acceptable levels,'' he said. In other economic reports today, the government reported that industrial production rose 0.7 percent in March while the nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 83.3 percent of capacity, an increase of 0.4 percentage point, reflecting a rebound in auto production. However, housing construction fell by 9.3 percent, its second monthly decline and the biggest setback in more than a year. The Commerce Department said new homes and apartments were being built at an annual rate of 1.32 million units in March. On Wall Street, stock prices posted broad declines with traders attributing the weakness to the higher-than-expected inflation figure, which dashed hopes that the Federal Reserve might relent and lower interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was off more than 13 points in early trading but by 1 p.m. had recouped some of the losses and was down by 4.73 points. In the inflation report, housing costs climbed 0.5 percent in March, pushed upward by a sharp 1 percent rise in the cost of owning a home. Homeowners' cost had actually fallen 0.1 percent in February. The advance in housing costs accounted for almost one-half of the overall March increase. Higher clothing costs contributed to more than one-fifth of the increase as apparel prices rose by 1.6 percent, following a record 3.3 percent increase in February. Many economists had been looking for prices to moderate in March, aided by lower food and energy costs. Energy prices were down during the month, dropping by 0.8 percent, pushed lower by falling gasoline prices and another big drop in home heating oil costs. Food prices rose 0.4 percent during the month, slightly better than the 0.5 percent increase in February, as a big drop in fruit and vegetable prices offset increase in other areas. Prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors were up sharply as well in March, climbing 0.7 percent, the fastest increase since a 0.8 percent rise in December. Economists believe this core rate is a better gauge of underlying inflationary pressures. The 8.5 percent annual rate of increase for the first three months of the year was the fastest advance since a 10.1 percent increase in the spring of 1982. Rising food prices accounted for about one-fourth of the price acceleration so far this year. Clothing costs, which rose just 1 percent for all of 1989, were up at an annual rate of 21.4 percent during the first three months of this year. The department gave the following details of the price report: _Fruit and vegetable costs, which had been driven higher by December's killer freeze, retreated slightly in March but prices for meat, poultry, fish and eggs were up by 0.7 percent. _Gasoline prices fell by 1.4 percent, the first decline this year, while heating oil prices dropped by 3.4 percent following a 16.1 percent plunge in February. Fuel oil costs have been on a roller coaster this year, surging 26.9 percent in January in response to unusually cold weather in December. _The 1.6 percent increase in clothing costs was led by a 2.7 percent increase in the cost of women's and children's clothing. Men's clothing costs were up 0.6 percent. The various changes left the Consumer Price Index at 128.7 before seasonal adjustments. That meant that a hypothetical selection of goods and services costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period would have cost $128.70 last month, up from $122.50 a year ago. One reason the 0.5 percent March increase took analysts by surprise was that it followed a more benign report on inflation at the wholesale level. The government reported last Friday that prices one step short of retail actually fell by 0.2 percent in March.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Blast Near Nuclear Plant Kills Woman
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded near a nuclear power plant in western India today, killing a woman, a news agency reported. The blast occurred near the Tarapur power plant, 70 miles north of Bombay on the Indian Ocean, Press Trust of India news agency said. Another bomb-like object was found nearby, it said. No further details were immediately available and there was no claim of responsibility. Federal officials in the Interior Ministry, which overlooks internal security, said security was stepped up today around all important government buildings and installations, including nuclear power plants. The decision came after fire heavily damaged the government's main conference center in New Delhi. United News of India said a Sikh separatist group, Khalistan Liberation Force, claimed responsibility for setting the blaze.

DOC.HEAD: Clashes Rage In Moslem, Christian Sectors of Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Street battles raged Tuesday in the Moslem and Christian sectors of Beirut, sparked by separate power struggles for control of the Shiite Moslem and Maronite Christian communities. Clashes also broke out in the southern port of Sidon between the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army and the leftist Nasserite militia. Police said one Nasserite militiaman was killed and two were wounded. Police said at least seven people were killed and 38 wounded in fighting between rival Shiite Moslem factions using machine guns, assault rifles and grenade launchers in Syrian-policed west Beirut and the city's southern slums. Some of the clashes were in the Hajjaj neighborhood in south Beirut, one block from the barracks believed to be the most frequent prison for 18 Western hostages. It was not known if the fighting affected the captives. The barracks belong to the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, the umbrella group for factions believed to hold most of the hostages. The Shiite clashes later spread to south Lebanon's Iqlim el-Tuffah, or Apple Province, where four people were wounded, according to police. In the Christian sector of east Beirut, troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun and Lebanese Forces militia chieftain Samir Geagea skirmished with mortars and machine guns. No casualties were reported. The rival Maronite Christian factions are fighting for control of the Christian enclave north and east of Beirut. According to police, 875 people have been killed and 2,376 wounded since the Christian battles began Jan. 30.
