The Shiite confrontation pits the fundamentalist Hezbollah against the Syrian-backed, more secular Amal militia. The militias are fighting for control of Lebanon's Shiites. The latest clashes erupted a day after Ali Abu Hassan, an Amal leader, was killed by unidentified assailants in west Beirut. Amal blamed the killing on Hezbollah, which denied the charge. Amal fighters raided west Beirut homes overnight, seizing some Hezbollah members in apparent revenge. Each side blamed the other for the latest round of fighting, which started in west Beirut around 4 a.m. and spread to the southern slums by noon. Prime Minister Salim Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, pleaded with both factions to ``stop fighting immediately and have mercy on the population.'' The Syrian command deployed foot patrols in an effort to disengage the combatants but met with limited success. ``They stop fighting when the Syrian patrol is in an area and resume their war after the patrols leave,'' said a police spokesman. However, he said the Syrians appear ``determined to halt the fighting'' and were bringing in more troops to establish control in the disputed districts. The Syrians control most of Lebanon with about 40,000 troops sent under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. Voice of the Nation, the main Moslem radio station in Lebanon, repeatedly broadcast urgent appeals from hospitals for blood donations and pleas from civilians for a cease-fire. ``Let them go to hell. Why do we have to pay the price for their dirty war?'' said one civilian, Amina Ghandour. Ghandour told the radio station that the fighting had left three floors of her apartment building on fire. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting sporadically for more than two years for leadership of the country's 1.2 million Shiites, Lebanon's largest sect. In the fighting in south Lebanon, police said fighters of the Israeli-allied South Lebanon Army clashed with members of the Nasserite militia, which controls Sidon. The sides battled for three hours in the hills east of Sidon. Also in Sidon, police said an unidentified gunman went berserk, storming into a business office with a submachine gun. The assailant killed three employees and wounded two before killing himself. The motive for the attack was not known.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Mayor Blasts Lack of Drug Funding
DOC.TEXT: Philadelphia Mayor Wilson Goode said Tuesday the federal government has mixed up its priorities by planning to spend billions of dollars more on bailing out the savings and loan industry than on fighting illegal drugs. ``For some reason we can't get the people who list priorities to put this above savings and loans,'' Goode told a House hearing on the narcotics problem. ``The lives of our young people are more important than these buildings and these investors who put money in savings and loans.'' Goode, testifying for the U.S. Conference of Mayors, called for more federal funding to stem demand for narcotics, grants provided directly to city governments and freedom for local officials ``to respond to the drug crisis based upon their own particular experiences and insights.'' He urged a greater emphasis on treatment for drug abusers. He said he visited ``the 25 worst drug corners'' in Philadelphia last year and was repeatedly told by addicts, ``We need some way to get off this train _ I got caught up in this by mistake, and now I need something that works.'' Goode told the Government Operations Committee the $10.2 billion earmarked in recent legislation to fight drugs ``is simply not enough to have a meaningful impact across the entire nation.'' Instead, he said, federal funding should match the amount the government will pay to combat the financial calamities besetting the savings and loan industry. Estimates of that cost have ranged up to $200 billion. He also criticized the idea of legalizing narcotics, a concept that has gained currency in recent months among those who believe that the problem is so overwhelming that a war against it is virtually guaranteed to fail. Goode called it ``a very bad idea that some very smart people are lending their endorsement to.'' He said legalization would flood the nation with narcotics and set an ``inappropriate moral tone.'' ``This would be the worst domestic policy decision that we as a nation could make _ bar none,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Nuclear Regulatory Commission Must Establish Training Guidelines
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission must establish training requirements for workers in the nuclear power industry, an appeals court said today. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said the NRC has circumvented a congressional mandate by failing to adopt regulations called for in a 1983 law. A presidential panel examining the accident at Three Mile Island said inadequate training contributed significantly to the risks posed by nuclear power plants, the court noted in its opinion. The NRC issued a policy statement in 1985 which encourages but does not compel nuclear plant operators to create training programs. The NRC concluded that the best way to get civilian nuclear power plants to improve training was to create a model training code and urge utilities to comply with it voluntarily. Public Citizen, a group founded by Ralph Nader, challenged the NRC's approach in lawsuits in 1986 and 1988. The NRC reconsidered the training issue in 1988 and decided not to impose requirements. ``Congress directed the NRC to create mandatory requirements for civilian nuclear powerplant licensee personnel training programs and ... the commission has failed to do so,'' said the 3-0 decision by chief appeals court judge Patricia Wald. The case was returned to the NRC for further proceedings consistent with the court ruling. The 1983 law, an amendment to the Nuclear Waste Policy Act, says the NRC ``shall establish ... instructional requirements for civilian nuclear powerplant licensee personnel training programs.'' The NRC relied on other language in the amendment which allows the agency to issue ``appropriate ... regulatory guidance.'' The appeals court said that while the term ``regulatory guidance'' is ambiguous, other language mandating the instructional requirements is clear and controls the issue. The NRC and the industry argued that imposing mandatory requirements will make the nuclear power industry less safe because it will choke off the industry's self-regulatory efforts. The argument is that the companies will regard the NRC's requirements as a maximum rather than a minimum level of appropriate training. The NRC and the industry ``must take this argument to the Congress, not to the courts,'' said the appeals panel. Voluntary industry training was under way at the time Congress passed the law and the NRC's model training code ``is exactly what Congress did not want to perpetuate,'' said David Vladeck, an attorney for the Public Citizen Litigation Group.

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Governor Defends Veto of Rape Education Bill
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Tommy G. Thompson defended his veto of a bill requiring public schools to teach students about date rape, saying younger pupils didn't need exposure to such lessons. The bill, passed during the Legislature's winter session, called for instruction three times between the first and 12th grade on how to recognize and prevent sexual assaults, particularly those that can happen with an acquaintance on a date. In vetoing the bill Monday, the governor said he feared it could force teachers to talk about date rape to children between grades one and three. ``I didn't know these students dated,'' he said. Thompson said he also believed the bill duplicated a state law that ``already requires school districts to provide instruction in preventing sexual abuse, of which sexual assault could be argued to be a subcategory.'' He noted that he recently signed a law requiring the University of Wisconsin System and Vocational, Technical and Adult Education System to teach incoming freshmen how to avoid sexual assault. He also expressed concern that a provision in the bill requiring the state to pay a ``sum sufficient'' to cover the lessons would ``give school boards a blank check.'' Milwaukee County Assistant District Attorney John DiMotto, head of his office's sexual assault unit, criticized the veto. Although the schools teach sexual-assault awareness and prevention, DiMotto said, ``there is nothing that specifically addresses the issue of date rape, which can and does affect many youths.'' DiMotto said about 35 percent of the sexual assaults handled by his unit involved acquaintances of the victims. Linda Willsey, committee clerk for state Rep. Barbara Notestein, who sponsored the bill, said the governor was confused about existing law. ``There is a protective behavior statute,'' Ms. Willsey said. ``But it applies to elementary school students only. ... Our concern mainly was with acquaintance rape and sexual assault among teen-agers and high school kids.'' According to Ms. Notestein, about half of the 5,100 sexual assaults reported in Wisconsin in 1987 involved teen-age girls.

DOC.HEAD: One-Third of Senate Candidates Raising Most Money Out-of-State
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 7th graf pvs, bgng, Three candidates ... to make it two candidates; DELETES 9th graf pvs, bgng, The only ...; Revised figures furnished today by the FEC show NO candidate in Colorado has received more than $1 million in out-of-state contributions
DOC.TEXT: One-third of the Senate candidates this year got more money from out-of-state individuals than they did from local contributors, according to the Federal Election Commission. The commission also said Monday that 17 of the 31 incumbent senators seeking re-election raised more individual contributions of at least $200 from out-of-state residents than from state residents. Some non-incumbent candidates also received more $200-plus donations from out-of-state individuals than from state residents, particularly in states where the current senator is not seeking re-election. While it still is early in the campaign, the 23 Senate candidates raising most of their individual contributions from out-of-state are below the number who did in 1988 and 1986. In 1988, 29 of the 66 candidates for 33 Senate seats received more campaign funds through individual contributions of $500 or more from outside than at home. In 1986, 31 of the 68 candidates for 34 seats did the same. The commission cautioned that the data does not include contributions from business, labor and special interest political action committees or PACs. Also not reflected is smaller contributions _ less than $200 per individual last year and less than $500 in the 1987-88 and 1985-86 election cycles. Two incumbent candidates already have raised more than $1 million in large individual donations from outside their states. Leading the pack is incumbent Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., who has raised $1.34 million outside his state or about triple the $462,331 from in-state donors of $200 or more. Close behind is Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., with nearly $1.3 million in large out-of-state contributions compared with $474,569 from New Jersey residents. Former Ku Klux Klansman David Duke has raised three times as much in large contributions from outside Louisiana than inside the state in seeking the Republican nomination to challenge veteran Democratic Sen. Bennett Johnston. But Duke's total campaign receipts of $138,063 are dwarfed by Johnston's campaign chest of nearly $1.3 million. Another state where the incumbent senator is stepping down and large out-of-state contributions are playing a role is New Hampshire. Former Democratic Sen. John Durkin and Republican lawyer Tom Christo have both raised more through $200-plus contributions outside the state than within in bids for their parties' nominations to fill the seat being vacated by Republican Sen. Gordon Humphrey. Other incumbent senators whose large out-of-state contributions _ listed first _ in 1989 exceeded those from within the state _ listed second _ include: Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, $141,696, $30,776; Joseph Biden, D-Del., $511,950, $76,262; Paul Simon, D-Ill., $720,082, $681,681; Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, $635,485, $66,225; William S. Cohen, R-Maine, $273,475; $32,700; John Kerry, D-Mass., $643,144, $556,229; Carl Levin, D-Mich., $964,022, $414,485; Max Baucus, D-Mont., $312,508, $72,148; Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M., $254,998, $233,166; David Boren, D-Okla., $382,454, $377,670; Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., $63,219; $43,080; Albert Gore, D-Tenn., $350,568, $12,723; Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., $512,917, $228,348. Both incumbent Republican Sen. Larry Pressler and Democratic challenger Ted Muenster have raised more money through large individual contributions from outside South Dakota than from the state's residents. Pressler has received $365,521 from the outside compared with large individual donations totaling $20,550 from within it. Muenster has raised $73,400 in large contributions from outside the state compared with $22,550 in similarly sized donations from South Dakota residents.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Frank Announces He Will Seek Re-election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf to CORRECT that Frank is 50, sted 49.
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Barney Frank today announced he will seek re-election, although a congressional ethics committee has yet to release a report on questions surrounding his relationship with a male prostitute. The Democrat initially said he would make a decision after the report was released. But in a statement released by his office, he said the political calendar pushed him to make a decision beforehand. Frank, who in 1987 became the first member of Congress to voluntarily disclose being homosexual, said the report is not yet available and the deadline for nominating petitions is May 8. No other Democrats have announced for the seat. The Republican Party has only been able to field two little-known candidates. Frank, 50, who represents the Fourth Congressional District in suburban Boston, was first elected to his seat in 1980. He has one of the most liberal voting records in Congress. The Washington Times first reported Frank's relationship with a male prostitute last August. It quoted a source as saying that Frank not only hired a prostitute for sex but was aware that a prostitution ring was being run out of his Capitol Hill apartment. Within days, Frank identified Stephen Gobie as the man he hired for $80 in 1985 for sex. He apologized for ``poor judgment'' but denied knowing about the prostitution ring. He said he fired Gobie in 1986 after learning of the ring. On Sept. 11, the House ethics committee voted to conduct a preliminary investigation of Frank. Although Frank had formally sought the investigation, the committee chairman, Rep. Julian Dixon, D-Calif., told reporters that the decision ``was not based on his request,'' but on the panel's own initiative. The Hous ethics committee plans to meet Thursday in a closed session. A committee spokeswoman gave no indication whether Frank's case would be on the agenda.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Haven't Set Date for Cheney Visit
DOC.TEXT: No definite plans have been made for an expected visit to the Soviet Union by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney because the Soviets haven't suggested a date, the Pentagon spokesman said Tuesday. At the end of an October tour of U.S. military facilities, Defense Minister Dimitri Yazov invited Cheney to visit the Soviet Union. There have been ongoing exchanges in recent years between the two nations' military and defense leaders. The trip was expected to occur sometime this summer, but no date has been announced. Last month, the Bush administration called off a scheduled visit to the Soviet Union by Army Chief of Staff Gen. Carl Vuono, calling the trip inappropriate amid the tensions over Lithuania. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams, queried at a briefing about Cheney's invitation, told reporters that no firm date had been offered by the Soviets and that there were no plans for Cheney make such a trip ``on the near horizon.'' However, Williams added, ``We are eager to do so.'' Besides meeting with Cheney at the Pentagon, Yazov visited Camp Pendleton, a Marine training base north of San Diego; Luke Air Force Base in Arizona; and Fort Bragg, home of the Army's 82nd Airborne in Fayetteville, N.C.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Wants Global-Change Studies; Europeans Call for Action
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called for more research ``to sort out the science'' of global warming Tuesday, but ran into a storm of criticism at an international White House conference from Europeans who argued for action. ``Gaps in knowledge must not be used as an excuse for worldwide inaction,'' declared Klaus Topfer, the West German environmental minister. Bush said he hoped the conference, attended by delegates from 19 nations, would prod international research and inject economic issues into the debate over the ``greenhouse'' effect. The president called for resolving some of the scientific uncertainties and economic implications before making a commitment to specific pollution controls to deal with possible gradual warming of the Earth. ``Environmental policies that ignores the economic factors _ the human factors _ are destined to fail,'' he said, maintaining anew that some scientists are in wide disagreement over the impact of manmade pollutants on the temperature of the globe. Many of the European participants, especially the West Germans and the Dutch, said the conference agenda was narrowly arranged to prevent open discussions of policy aimed at dealing with global warming. Topfer suggested the German delegation would pursue such discussions, adding, ``The gravity of the situation requires immediate, determined action.'' Similar views were expressed by members of other delegations, including Dutch and French officials. Discussions about further research and economic considerations should ``not distract us from taking action on carbon dioxide stabilization now,'' Hans Alders, the Dutch environmental minister, told the conference during a closed working session. ``We needed Love Canal before hazardous waste was tackled. We needed a dying River Rhine before waste water was treated. ... My country has decided to learn the lessons from the past and act on global warming now,'' Alders told the delegates, according to a transcript made public by the Dutch delegation. ``I know there's a debate raging out there,'' Bush said in his welcoming remarks to the delegates, all Cabinet-level ministers involved in environmental, economic and science issues. But he said he was confident that more research and examination of economic factors before action to curb ``greenhouse'' pollutants such as carbon dioxide ``is the way to go.'' Scientists, including Bush's own science advisers, generally agree that manmade pollution, especially the release of carbon dioxide from burning of fossil fuels, is causing heat to be trapped and will result in a warming of the globe. Many say the Earth's temperature could increase by as much as 4 degrees to 9 degrees Fahrenheit by the middle of the next century, causing coastal flooding and a shift of weather and agriculture patterns. Environmentalists have urged immediate action by industrial countries to curb carbon dioxide emissions by 20 percent and many of the European countries have called at least for a stabilization of such releases by the year 2000. Such a commitment would require new efforts at energy conservation, development of more fuel efficient automobiles and more efficient use of energy in homes and businesses. Meanwhile, U.S. environmentalists accused Bush on Tuesday of abandoning his leadership responsibilities on the global warming question by not joining the Europeans in a call for firm commitments to reduce global warming pollutants. ``Bush is using the conference as a smoke screen to hide his inaction. He's using economics as a weapon against environmental protection,'' said Daniel Becker of the Sierra Club. Rafe Pomerance, of the World Resources Institute, chided Bush for suggesting that scientists are at opposite poles on the global warming debate. He said there is widespread agreement that the earth will become warmer if pollution curbs are not put into effect. At a luncheon address to the conference, William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, maintained the Bush administration has taken actions to combat global warming. He cited the push to phase out chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, which are another major cause of global warming; a call by Bush to plant 1 billion trees a year, and efforts to toughen federal air pollution laws, as well as a $1 billion global change research effort. But environmentalists maintained the tree planting effort will have scant effect on overall carbon dioxide pollution and that the administration vigorously fought efforts in Congress to require automakers to develop more fuel efficient cars, which would have allowed for significant carbon dioxide reductions by the end of the decade. Federal money to foster energy efficiency and renewable fuels also remains below the levels of a decade ago, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Hazardous Waste at Nuclear Plant Illegally Stored
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS third graf to CORRECT time element.
DOC.TEXT: The Rocky Flats weapons plant stored hazardous waste illegally for a decade by claiming it was being saved for recycling, a federal judge has ruled, apparently making the plant subject to state regulations. ``This takes a big step toward making clear what they can and cannot store and what is and is not hazardous waste,'' said Maggie Fox of the Sierra Club, which sued the U.S. Department of Energy over storage of the material at the plant. The ruling by U.S. District Judge Lewis T. Babcock, which was issued Thursday but did not become publicly known until Monday, does not call for fines or other penalties. But it apparently will force the plant to meet state hazardous-waste regulations on storage of ash and other residue left over from waste incineration. The plant shut down its incinerator last year as part of the lawsuit, but for years it had burned waste tainted with radioactive plutonium. Plant operators had argued that the resulting ash was exempt from state regulation because the plant was storing the material for recycling of the plutonium it contained. Court records showed that plutonium actually was recovered from less than 10 percent of the tons of residue stored. Triggers for nuclear weapons were assembled at the plant, but most of the plant's plutonium-related operations have been shut down since late last year, partly for a seasonal inventory and partly because of technical problems. Energy Department attorneys argued that any ruling designating the residue as regulated waste would jeopardize an agreement with the state over the handling, storage and generation of hazardous waste at the plant. John Haggard, Rocky Flats program coordinator of the Colorado Department of Health, said the ruling strengthens the state's authority to regulate the waste.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Wants 9.9 Percent Increase in Medicare Payments
DOC.TEXT: Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan is recommending a 9.9 percent increase in Medicare payments to physicians for the 1991 fiscal year, his office said Tuesday. The recommendation to Congress is ``a realistic goal for physicians, one consistent with both the prudent practice of medicine and the necessary restraint on cost increases,'' Sullivan said. Medicare payments to physicians have been growing by 12 percent a year in recent years, about double the rate of inflation. Under legislation passed by Congress last year, the secretary must recommend annually a Medicare physician payment target. Congress is to review the recommendation and set a Medicare Volume Performance Standard. If Congress does not act, the law provides for the performance standard to be determined based on a specified formula. The new law changes the way Medicare pays physicians by realigning reimbursement rates, increasing them for family and internal physicians and reducing them for surgeons and other specialized physicians. The performance standard will be the main factor used to determine future annual Medicare fee increases to physicians. The new system of physician payments will be phased in beginning in January 1992. In recommending a physician payment goal, the secretary takes into account such things as general inflation, the increase in the number of Medicare beneficiaries and changes in technology. The 9.9 percent overall rates of increase includes an 8.7 percent growth rate for surgical services and 10.5 percent growth rate for all other physician services.

DOC.HEAD: 25 Percent Rationing Plan Recommended
DOC.TEXT: The San Francisco Water Department, citing low reservoirs, called for mandatory water rationing to cut use by 25 percent for its 2.2 million customers. The department's recommendation Monday proposes the same formula used during the 1988 drought year, based on 1987 usage. ``Anybody who was in the program last time will be getting the same allotment,'' said John Mullane, acting director of the department. The recommendation heads to the Public Utilities Commission next week. If approved, rationing probably would begin May 1, according to Mullane. Mullane, who noted reservoirs are only at 38 percent of capacity, said rationing is necessary to guarantee enough water to get through another dry winter. Supplies also will be cut by 25 percent for the 32 suburban agencies in San Mateo, Santa Clara and Alameda counties that buy water from San Francisco. However, those agencies have the option of creating their own rationing plan. The Santa Clara Valley Water District adopted mandatory rationing that began on April 1. The East Bay Municipal Utility District has turned to voluntary conservation.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Discusses European Issues
DOC.TEXT: President Bush defended the practice of appointing an American general as supreme commander of NATO, saying it underscores the important role the United States plays in preserving peace in Europe. On another European issue, Bush said he had given no thought to dealing with a possible Labor government in Great Britain. He shrugged off polls that indicate British voters have turned against Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Conservative government. Bush was interviewed Monday by four correspondents from newspapers in France, Great Britain and Canada. The White House released the transcript Tuesday. Bush, who will consult Thursday with French President Francois Mitterrand in Key Largo, Fla., was asked if he could envision a French supreme commander of NATO. Although France belongs to the 16-nation alliance, it does not participate in its integrated military structure. ``We're very happy with the present arrangements,'' Bush replied. ``I don't want to have this coming out in a chauvinistic sense, but I think the American people have to feel ... the American presence is wanted.'' Keeping an American in charge of NATO's military command ``contributes to the view that we have an important role to play and the Europeans want us to have an important role to play,'' Bush said. ``I've given no thought to any substantive change in all of this. But if anybody has a different view, I'd be willing to hear it.'' Bush, who last week conferred with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney in Toronto and with Mrs. Thatcher in Bermuda, said he was meeting with Mitterrand in part to ``narrow any differences that might exist'' between France and the United States on the future of NATO. ``It is my conviction that NATO will have a perhaps even more important role to play in the stability of Europe,'' Bush said. Mitterrand ``has a keen interest'' in a role for the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a 35-nation forum spanning both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, Bush said. But he added, ``I know we're not egregiously apart at all.'' Bush sought to brush aside questions about whether he could deal with Britain's Labor party if it ousts the Thatcher government. ``I don't want to get into the bubbling cauldron of domestic politics inside the U.K. right now,'' Bush said. He said he had not ``given any thought to'' dealing with the Labor Party. ``We do have a special relationship (with Britain) and it'll continue, I'm sure'' regardless of who occupies 10 Downing Street, he said. He dismissed Mrs. Thatcher's low standing in polls, citing his own low ratings early in the 1988 campaign and the recent polling fiasco that indicated Daniel Ortega would win Nicaragua's presidential election. ``I'm enough of a politician to know that people can be down one moment and then soaring like an eagle the next,'' Bush said. He called Mrs. Thatcher ``a very courageous, principled leader who fights for her beliefs and has survived many ups and downs.'' Bush refused to express an opinion on Quebec's separatist movement, saying he would ``courageously sit on the sidelines'' on that question. The United States, he said, should not ``involve itself in the internal affairs of Canada.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Shortage of RNs Will Worsen
DOC.TEXT: There will be an adequate supply of physicians and most other health professionals through the end of the century but the shortage of nurses is expected to worsen, the government said Tuesday. The number of registered nurses has grown from 750,000 in 1970 to more than 1.6 million in 1988, according to a report sent to Congress by Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. However, even though the number is expected to continue to increase over the next 15 years, it will not be enough to alleviate the shortages, the report said. Public health experts say the nursing shortage has been caused in part because of population growth and because hospital patients tend to be sicker these days and need more intensive care. In many other health professions, the supply is growing but the rate of growth is expected to slow between 2000 and 2020 because the number of people leaving the workforce will be greater than the number entering, the report said. Minorities, it said, are underrepresented in health professions. Black and Hispanic physicians make up 3 percent each of the total number of doctors although blacks constitute 12 percent of the total U.S. population and Hispanics 7 percent, the report said. Sullivan pointed to Newark, N.J., as an example of the ``geographic maldistribution of health professionals.'' In that city, he said, there are three times as many office-based primary-care physicians per 100,000 people in non-poverty areas as in poverty areas.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pressuring Congress to Enact Central America Aid Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs, statements after meeting; picks up 2nd graf pvs, Administration officials ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush praised Honduras today for a ``productive role'' in bringing about a peace agreement in Nicaragua and voiced strong U.S. support for helping to demobilize and resettle Contra rebels. Administration officials have been waging a heavy lobbying campaign to get Congress to act on the president's $800 million aid package for Central America, calling further delay an affront to U.S. allies in the region. Bush, speaking after a White House meeting with Honduran President Rafael L. Callejas, called the Honduran government ``an inspiring example of the democratic promise that today is spreading throughout the Americas.'' ``The United States applauds Honduras' productive role in achieving a multilateral agreement on the peaceful demobilization and repatriation of the Nicaraguan resistance in conditions of safety for all concerned,'' Bush said. It was a reference to the peace process that ended the war between the U.S.-backed Contras and the marxist Sandinista government. Callejas, calling the 1980s ``a complicated decade for Central America,'' said that the present decade must be one of economic rebuilding. ``It is impossible to have democracy without economic development,'' he said, speaking after Bush during a departure ceremony outside the White House. Both Bush and Callejas praised an economic package being put together by the United States, Japan and international lending organizations to help Honduras refinance some of its huge international debt. The meeting came at a time when the administration has been turning up the heat on Congress to pass its aid package for Nicaragua and Panama. Administration officials say that stalling the aid package beyond the April 25 inauguration of U.S.-backed Nicaraguan President-elect Violeta Chamorro would be a foreign policy embarrassment. It also would be a burden on the government of Honduras, a longtime U.S. ally, the officials say. Many of the Contra rebels the United States hopes to resettle remain in camps in Honduras. Also on the agenda at today's Bush-Callejas meeting was the status of efforts by the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, the United States and Japan to help Honduras ease its large international debt. Addressing a White House audience on Latin American issues Monday, Bush said Congress _ which returns from its Easter-Passover recess on Wednesday _ was wrong to not provide the funds before the break. ``I have pledged to Mrs. Chamorro that the United States government would respond in Nicaragua's hour of need,'' the president said. ``I believe the United States of America has a great deal at stake in the success of Violeta Chamorro, but more so in democracy itself in Nicaragua,'' he added. A senior administration official, briefing reporters at the White House on the condition of anonymity, said: ``It would be a very unfortunate message for the Congress to send to Mrs. Chamorro not to have this on the president's desk by her inauguration.'' ``Time is wasting. To cut this package and reduce it supposedly to help some other part of the world would be a historic mistake,'' the official said. The administration's package, bogged down in Congress, calls for $500 million for Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua. The House increased the package to $2.4 billion, adding money for U.S. projects including food stamps, disaster relief, fighting forest fires and veterans' programs. The Senate has yet to act on the legislation. Many members have called for expanding the package to include more aid for emerging Eastern European democracies. The administration said last week that it would rechannel about $3.6 million in already appropriated funds to help a joint United Nations-Organization of American States team begin demobilizing Contra rebels now encamped in Honduras. However, the senior administration official said, ``There are some 45,000 family members of the resistance who will remain in Honduras as refugees. They want to go home.'' Bush's $300 million request for Nicaragua includes $47 million for resettling Contra fighters and families now in Honduras. ``If that money is not available, the ability of the Central Americans and Mrs. Chamorro to help this process move along is going to be crippled. It would burden Honduras with a burden it should not have at this time. They've been very patient for many years,'' the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Five Countries Develop Nuclear Capability Through Smuggling
DOC.TEXT: Pakistan, India, Brazil, Argentina and Iraq have been able to build or expand nuclear weapons capabilities by smuggling materials from supplier countries, according to a private study released Tuesday. To counter these activities, the report recommends that the United States and other suppliers threaten military and economic sanctions against countries engaging in such operations. Titled ``Nuclear Exports: The Challenge of Control,'' the report was prepared by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, a private research group. It was written by Leonard Spector, a veteran expert on nuclear proliferation, with assistance from Jacqueline Smith. The report said West Germany has been the ``weak link'' in the international export control system and must tighten its export laws. Both India and Pakistan have relied on West German suppliers for their nuclear programs, the report said. Shortly before the report was released, the new head of Brazil's nuclear energy commission, Jose Luis de Carvalho Santana, said Brazil will not build a nuclear bomb. But he declined to say whether it had the technical ability to do so. Argentina has repeatedly proclaimed the right to develop and explode a nuclear device even though experts claim it seems far from being able to achieve that goal. Three weeks ago, Iraq denied any intention of developing nuclear weapons and reaffirmed that denial on Monday. It said devices described by U.S. prosecutors as nuclear warhead detonation capacitors allegedly being smuggled to Baghdad were to be used in a non-nuclear university laser project. In mid-March, British investigators arrested four people they claimed had tried to smuggle these devices to Iraq. President Saddam Hussein has expressed concern in recent days about a possible nuclear attack by Israel against his country. The report lists Israel among countries where there is a ``proliferation concern.'' Of the five countries the report focuses on, it said Iraq's program was far behind those of the other four. The report said in some instances, agents of the five countries have engaged in simple smuggling _ ``for example, by attempting to export commodities without required export licenses or by making blatantly false declarations on export documents.'' In other cases, it said, these agents have been able to minimize any suspect characteristics of the commodities at issue, taking advantage of a relaxed attitude by licensing officials or exploiting gaps in export regulations. If controls had been enforced effectively, Spector said, it is possible ``Pakistan would not be able to manufacture nuclear weapons today, that India's nuclear weapons potential would be a fraction of its current size and that neither Argentina nor Brazil would have facilities capable of producing nuclear weapons material.'' Supplier countries should retaliate against nuclear smuggling by threatening reduced aid, military sales restrictions or economic sanctions, the report said. It recommended that traditional nuclear suppliers ensure rigorous enforcement of their common nuclear export guidelines. Prosecuting individuals involved in nuclear smuggling, while essential, ``neither reaches the source of the problem nor imposes unacceptable costs on nations that seek to undermine the international nuclear control regime,'' the study said. ``Indeed, many of these states continue to enjoy the fruits of their illicit nuclear purchasing operations even after they have been exposed,'' it said. Other recommendations included: _Finding ways to recover illicitly acquired nuclear commodities or to ensure that they do not contribute to nuclear weapons programs. _Publicizing nuclear smuggling operations more frequently. ``The embarrassment of publicity serves at least as a mild sanction against states engaged in such operations and also serves to chastise the commercial firms that aid them,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Twin Commits Suicide at Same Place Her Sister Died
DOC.TEXT: A 22-year-old woman committed suicide by driving her car into the Thames River from a downtown park, almost four years after her twin sister killed herself in the same way in the same place. Michelle A. McDonald drowned Monday, according to Dr. Said Esfahanian, an assistant state medical examiner. Her body was not found until about six hours later, police said. City and federal emergency rescue crews, including eight divers, combed the river. Ms. McDonald's twin sister, Melissa McDonald, then 19, drove her car into the river near the spot on July 29, 1986. Police ruled that death a suicide. Michelle McDonald was obsessed with suicide and always said that when she died she would die as her sister did, according to Deborah Labrie, her roommate. ``I know it preyed on Michelle's mind all of the time,'' Ms. Labrie said.

DOC.HEAD: Former State Democrat Chairman Acquitted in Bribery Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Tuesday acquitted a former state Democratic Party chairman on charges he participated in a scheme to bribe Dominican Republic officials to release seized drug planes. The case against Alfredo Duran went awry in the past month after a co-defendant was revealed to be a Drug Enforcement Administration informant, and a chief prosecution witness turned out to be a lawyer who failed to inform clients he was secretly cooperating with federal investigators. Democratic officials at the time of the November indictment called it a political vendetta by U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, a former Republican state senator whose wife is a Republican congresswoman. On Tuesday, before the defense was to present its case, U.S. District Judge James Kehoe ordered Duran acquitted, saying the government had failed to prove the charges against him were a crime under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. ``I feel that I have been thoroughly vindicated,'' said Duran, 53, who could have faced a maximum five years in prison if convicted. He was state party chairman during 1976-80. His lawyer, Donald Bierman, played down any political angle in the case. ``I think that it was a very poorly thought out prosecution, but I don't personally believe it was political,'' said Bierman. The judge refused a government request to stay the acquittal while prosecutors appealed, and Bierman said the judge's decision in such cases is final. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for Lehtinen, denied any political motivation behind Duran's indictment. She said of the verdict: ``We are disappointed, but we have every faith in the criminal justice system.'' The indictment had charged that Duran took money from attorney Jose Insua and co-defendant Robert Gurin, and was to pass it to retired Dominican Gen. Joaquin Pou, who would see that government officials there released the planes. Gurin pleaded guilty and cooperated with the government, and Pou's aide, Jose Guasch, also later pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to break the corrupt practices act. But Pou jumped bond, fleeing to his homeland and telling the media there he was a DEA informant who was betrayed by the U.S. government. Last week, the judge agreed with the defense that all evidence concerning Pou should be excluded from the case, crippling the prosecution. Insua, in turn, was attacked by the defense because he set up a sting operation against Duran and Pou after becoming involved in another criminal investigation. Attorneys said that was an ethical violation by both Insua and the U.S. attorney's office, because the lawyer's clients were never informed their attorney was working with prosecutors. With much of the evidence excluded, Kehoe ruled that there was no evidence the money had left the United States, as required under the 1977 law, and ordered the acquittal.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Seeks Bank Records in Suspected Drug Laundering
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department on Tuesday sought records of 754 U.S. bank accounts where it said Colombia's Medellin cartel has stashed $400 million from cocaine sales on American streets. The action marks the first time thaAssociated Presst federal authorities traced ``dollar for dollar'' drug money from U.S. street sales that was laundered through foreign accounts and returned to American banks, officials said. The department asked federal judges in Atlanta, Miami and New York to order 173 banks in 22 states and the nation's capital to turn over the records that officials said could yield a wealth of financial information about the cartel. Federal prosecutors also asked an Atlanta judge to freeze 684 accounts linked to Eduardo Martinez Romero, who was extradited in September to face charges he laundered drug money for the cartel. The legal action is likely to produce more information than money, but should help investigators continue theNazi death camps. ``Of course, we know the pictures from home, but it has a different meaning here,'' said cellist Alexander Wedow, 56, who has been with the orchestra for 28 years. ``It goes very deep into your soul. It is a deep sadness,'' said oboe player Hansjoerg Schellenberger, 42. ``This can always happen again. Mankind has this black part in its soul.'' Some musicians said they had been somewhat apprehensive about audience reaction before their first concert, and that they were overwhelmed by the standing ovations after each performance. Among those cheering were several elderly German-born Israelis who are often torn between pride in the culture of their youth and hatred of the Nazis who uprooted them and killed their families. Alfred Frankenstein, 84, who fled Berlin in 1935, said the sounds of Schubert and Brahms brought back the days when he covered the orchestra as a music critic. ``An old man likes to relive the beautiful moments of his youth, and this was one of them. The faces (of the musicians) have changed, but the Berlin Philharmonic remains one of the best orchestras,'' said Frankenstein. The warm welcome is the latest sign that while the Holocaust still shapes Israeli attitudes, there is less sensitivity about old taboos, in part because a new Israeli generation has emerged with no direct experience of Nazi rule. Earlier this year, Gottfried Wagner, the great-grandson of 19th century German composer Richard Wagner, toured Israel to push for the lifting of a boycott on the music of Wagner. He won support from Israel's music establishment, and Ron said Barenboim was trying to put together a Wagner concert with the Israel Philharmonic this fall. Orchestra officials said they were unaware of any such efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Art Curator Ouster Prompts Donor to Pull Collection, Millions
DOC.TEXT: The ouster of a curator at the small but innovative Berkshire Museum has set off a furor, with one donor changing his mind about donating $2 million and his photograph collection. ``I am appalled that the museum could cut a curator so sympatico to the arts,'' Connecticut collector George R. Rinhart said of the dismissal of art curator Debra Balken. Rinhart owns one of the largest private collections of American photographs. It includes more than a million prints dating from the 1830s to the 1960s, including Civil War scenes by Matthew Brady, along with a reference library of at least 20,000 volumes. Museum director Barry Dressel said Monday that Rinhart's threat wasn't as dire as it seemed because he never had received any written guarantees that the bequests were final. ``Basically we have only the word from a donor that ... when he dies in 30 years he is going to leave this collection and an endowment to the museum,'' said Dressel. ``Would we love to have that collection? Sure. But it was a conclusion of the trustees and me that basically there was little to assume,'' he said. However, others have said they also have changed their minds about donations to the museum. Balken could not be reached for comment; she is not listed in directory information. She declined comment earlier to the newspaper. Balken, who came to the Berkshire Museum in 1981, has been praised for bringing exciting exhibitions to the museum and for her expertise in the field of modern and contemporary art. But she also has been criticized for exhibitions that weren't received well by some sections of the community. Last week, museum officials announced that Balken's job had been consolidated in an ``administrative restructuring.'' Trustees said the museum will create an administrative post of director of curatorial programs, and will contract with guest curators for individual exhibits. The decision was made by Dressel and approved unanimously by the 11 trustees present. Rinhart was not at home Tuesday and not available for additional comment. He told The Berkshire Eagle last week he had changed his mind about his intended gifts, including an endowment that could have provided $100,000 annual income. ``I only came out of my turtle shell because of the outrage I feel about the way Debra was treated,'' he said. ``A sensitive, intelligent human being is being treated as an ornament no longer in vogue.'' In the wake of the museum changes, a donor has canceled plans to donate three paintings by 19th century landscape painter George Innes. And Ellsworth Kelly, of Spencertown, N.Y., who has donated work to the museum, said he will not give any more. George Heard Hamilton, professor emeritus of art at Williams College and former director of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, resigned from the Berkshire Museum's collections committee on account of the ouster of Balken. Dressel said the reaction hasn't shaken trustees' conviction they needed to replace Balken. ``We've had virtually no cancellation of membership. Our funders are not unhappy,'' Dressel said. ``The museum is certainly not rocked or sinking by this change.''

DOC.HEAD: Inflation Rate Rising at Fastest Pace Since 1982
DOC.TEXT: Consumer prices, fueled by sharp increases in clothing, housing and medical costs, shot up 0.5 percent in March to push inflation to the highest level since 1982, the government said Tuesday. Private economists saw the unexpectedly brisk advance in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index as a discouraging sign that inflation was not retreating as they had hoped. The inflation rate is ``dangerous and potentially devastating for financial markets and the economy,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. Through the first three months of the year, inflation has risen at an annual rate of 8.5 percent, the fastest quarterly increase since a 10.1 percent increase in the spring of 1982. Part of the surge earlier in the year was attributed to an unusually cold December that froze crops along the Gulf Coast and sent fuel oil prices skyward. But March declines in energy and fruit and vegetable prices were not enough to offset widespread increases elsewhere. The March figures are ``a reminder that inflation is a chronic problem, that it's not going away and it's not getting better,'' said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI-McGraw Hill. While inflation is still expected to slow in coming months, the March figure sent some economists scurrying to revise upward their forecast for the entire year. Some said consumer prices could rise by 5 percent for all of 1990. That would be up from a 4.6 percent increase in 1989 and the highest annual rate since 1981. The bad news on inflation had a negative impact on financial markets, pushing the yields on bond prices up as investors demanded more insurance against inflation threats. Stock prices retreated but recovered somewhat later in the day. In another economic report Tuesday, the government said industrial production rose 0.7 percent in March, reflecting a rebound in auto production. It was the second consecutive strong showing and provided evidence, some analysts said, that the slump in American manufacturing may finally be coming to an end. In a third report, the Commerce Department said that housing construction fell for the second consecutive month, declining by 9.3 percent as new homes and apartments were being built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.32 million units in March. Analysts predicted the 0.5 percent inflation rate in March _ which followed an equal gain of 0.5 percent in February and a 1.1 percent increase in January _ would strengthen the Federal Reserve's resolve not to lower interest rates, despite pressures from the Bush administration. In fact, Sinai said that if inflation does not slow soon, the Federal Reserve might even begin pushing interest rates upward, something it has not done for over a year, in an effort to dampen price pressures. ``The message is that it may take more pain, more restraint on the economy, to get inflation down to acceptable levels,'' he said. Over two-thirds of the March inflation came from rising housing and clothing prices. Housing costs rose by 0.5 percent, the biggest advance since January's 0.7 percent. Clothing costs, which climbed a record 3.3 percent in February, rose 1.6 percent last month as the impact of sharply higher costs for new spring lines continued to be felt. So far this year, clothing prices are up at an annual rate of 21.4 percent, compared to an increase of just 1 percent for all of 1989. Medical costs jumped 0.8 percent last month and have risen 8.6 percent over the past year, the biggest increase of all the major categories. Energy prices were down during the month, dropping by 0.8 percent, pushed lower by a 1.4 percent drop in gasoline pump prices and another big drop in home heating oil costs which continued to retreat after a big spike in January. Food prices rose 0.4 percent during the month, slightly less than the 0.5 percent increase in February, as a big drop in fruit and vegetable prices offset increases in other areas. Prices excluding the volatile food and energy areas were up sharply as well in March, climbing 0.7 percent, the fastest since a 0.8 percent rise in December. Economists believe this core rate is a better gauge of underlying inflationary pressures. The various changes left the Consumer Price Index at 128.7 before seasonal adjustments. That meant that a hypothetical selection of goods and services costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period would have cost $128.70 last month, up from $122.50 a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Ralph David Abernathy Dies at Age 64
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with medical details and reaction, including Martin Luther King III quote. Picks up 5th graf, `The Rev...' Adds byline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY20, NY21, NY22, AX5
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, the right-hand man to Martin Luther King Jr. who was spurned by colleagues after publicly telling of King's infidelity, died today after a three-week hospitalization. He was 64. Abernathy, who complained in his book that aides viewed him only as a glorified pal and bodyguard to King, ``was the unsung hero of the modern civil rights movement,'' said a friend and political ally, state Rep. Tyrone Brooks. ``He never received the recognition he's due.'' Abernathy died at Crawford Long Hospital, which he entered three weeks ago for an electrolytic imbalance. Hospital officials said his heart stopped during a lung scan, and he died while in an operating room. They would not say what surgery Abernathy might have been undergoing. Abernathy was president emeritus of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and pastor of Atlanta's West Hunter Street Baptist Church. He caused a controversy last year when he wrote in his autobiography that King dallied with two women and later fought with a third he had spurned on the night and morning before his 1968 assassination. King's family and many of his colleagues condemned Abernathy following the book's publication. But Tuesday, King's son, a visibly saddened Fulton County Commissioner Martin Luther King III, called Abernathy's death ``certainly a very tragic loss to our nation.'' The Rev. Joseph Lowery, who succeeded Abernathy as president of the SCLC, today called Abernathy ``a faithful servant of the cause of liberty and justice.'' Lowery said he regretted the allegations against King in Abernathy's book, ``nevertheless his record still stands as a stalwart steward in this movement.'' Abernathy, born March 11, 1926, in Linden, Ala., worked in the civil rights movement from its inception in 1955. He stood at King's side through the great battles of the movement and went to jail as often as King did, but Abernathy consistently found himself in King's shadow. In his autobiography, ``And the Walls Came Tumbling Down,'' Abernathy said he felt other King aides saw him as ``no more than an appendage to Martin, someone who served as a part companion, part bodyguard, but who never played an important role in the decisions that affected the direction of the movement.'' Abernathy mentioned in his autobiography that King dallied with various women on April 3, 1968, his last night alive. He became the first of the civil rights inner circle to openly discuss King's alleged marital infidelities, which had been chronicled by several noted biographers. That revelation drew the ire of black leaders who asked Abernathy to retract the passages dealing with King's alleged infidelity and insinuated that Abernathy's memory had been impaired by two strokes and brain surgery. The book controversy tore a hole in the already fragile relationship Abernathy had with his movement colleagues, a relationship that had been rather cool since Abernathy's 1980 endorsement of Ronald Reagan for president. Abernathy supported Jesse Jackson, another former King aide, for president in 1988. Abernathy and King led the Montgomery, Ala., bus boycott in 1955, which launched the civil rights movement. In 1957, the pair founded the SCLC, and Abernathy was King's confidant, counselor and cellmate during the turbulent years before King was shot to death in Memphis, Tenn. It was Abernathy who cradled King's bloody head April 4, 1968, as he lay dying of a bullet wound on the balcony of the Lorraine Motel. He took care of various funeral details for King's widow, Coretta Scott King, and delivered the eulogy at his best friend's funeral. Abernathy said he had no desire to lead the civil rights movement, preferring to leave that role to the more charismatic King. But two days after King's death, Abernathy was SCLC president, leading the Poor People's Campaign, a mass demonstration held in Washington in the summer of 1968. Abernathy was SCLC president for nine years, as the focus of the civil rights movement shifted from voting rights and civil rights to such economic issues as full employment and anti-poverty programs. He resigned from the SCLC in 1977, saying he wanted to devote his time to a campaign for Congress. He was defeated in the Democratic primary. Concentrating on preaching and lecturing, Abernathy also held the title of president with honors of the World Peace Conference headquartered in Helsinki, Finland, and he traveled around the world three times on peace missions. He suffered a stroke in 1983, and underwent brain bypass surgery at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. After he recovered, he returned to preach at West Hunter Street Baptist Church, where he had been pastor since 1961. At a 1985 dinner, he was praised by other civil rights leaders as an ``unsung hero'' of their movement. In 1989, he was handed a telegram, signed by most of his movement contemporaries, which said the accounts about King in his autobiography could ``rob you of your rightful place in history.'' Despite the controversy, Abernathy stood by his account as true. ``I'm not Judas,'' he said. ``I know who I am.'' Abernathy is survived by his wife, Juanita; two sons, Kwame and state Rep. Ralph David Abernathy III; and two daughters, Juandalynn and Donzaleigh.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd item to CORRECT inauguration year in 3rd graf to 1989 sted 1988
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle will make Indianapolis 500 history when he serves as grand marshal for the race parade May 26. Quayle, an Indiana native, will be the first sitting vice president to lead the 104-unit parade. ``Parades are not what a president or vice president would normally do, something they aren't always invited to,'' said Ray Yonkus, special agent in charge of the Secret Service in Indianapolis. He said Monday he assumed Quayle's last parade was at the 1989 inauguration. ``There's only so much you can do with a parade crowd because it is open to the public, so it gives you extra headaches,'' Yonkus said. He declined to say how many officers would be needed to protect Quayle. The vice president, his wife, Marilyn, and their children, Tucker, Benjamin, and Corinne, are expected to spend three days in the city. The Quayles also attended last year's Indianapolis 500.

DOC.HEAD: Frank Announces For Re-Election in Advance of Ethics Report
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Barney Frank, whose personal and political life was rocked last year by disclosure of his relationship with a male prostitute, announced Tuesday he will seek re-election. The Democrat had intended to wait until the House ethics committee released a report about questions surrounding his involvement with prostitute Stephen Gobie, but said the election calendar pushed him to act sooner. Frank must file nominating petitions by May 8. ``People may decide to run or not run based on what I do. So I thought it was only fair to let people know that,'' Frank said. Frank, 50, said he also concluded his effectiveness as a congressmen had not been hurt by the relationship with Gobie that he said ended in 1986. The relationship, which included Frank hiring Gobie as a personal aide after paying him for sex, was revealed in August by The Washington Times. The story also quoted sources as saying Frank was aware Gobie ran a prostitution ring from his Washington apartment, an allegation Frank has vigorously denied. ``I did some things that were dumb. I was also accused of some things that weren't true. I had to figure out whether the combination of that was going to damage my effectiveness,'' Frank said. ``Obviously my judgment is that it has not.'' Frank, who in 1987 became the first member of Congress to voluntarily disclose being homosexual, said his major concern was how his congressional colleagues viewed him and his ability to continue with the job. ``My sense is none of them think I deserve a Nobel Prize for judgment for what I did five years ago, but I think they have given me a chance to establish what did and didn't happen,'' Frank said. ``Based on that, I don't think my ability to fight for the things I care about has been damaged.'' Alexander Tennant, executive director of the Massachusetts Republican Party, accused Frank of breaking his word by announcing for re-election before the ethics committee reported. ``He is just disregarding a commitment he made to the public,'' Tennant said. ``It was all a charade. He had every intention of running from day one.'' Tennant accused Frank of abuse of power because Frank has acknowledged writing to Virginia parole authorities on behalf of Gobie. No other Democrats have announced for the seat, the Fourth Congressional District in suburban Boston. Two little-known Republicans, Jim Nuzzo, a physician, and John Soto, a telephone company accountant, have announced their candidacies.

DOC.HEAD: Members of Afghanistan's Ruling Party Executed For Coup Role
DOC.TEXT: Two senior members of Afghanistan's ruling party have been executed for their alleged role in last month's bloody coup attempt, Western diplomats said Tuesday. Ghulam Astagir Panjshiri and Saleh Mohammad Zeary were expelled from the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan and the powerful Politburo shortly after the failed March 6 coup, the diplomats said on condition of anonymity. The diplomats said information from the Afghan capital of Kabul indicated the men were put to death but the date was not immediately clear. The executions could not be independently confirmed. Shaw Nawaz Tanai, Afghanistan's former defense minister and architect of the attempted coup, has been hiding at a guerrilla base inside Afghanistan, according to guerrilla sources and diplomats. Tanai, once a fierce opponent of the U.S.-backed guerrillas, defected after troops loyal to President Najib crushed the mutineers. He joined the most radical of the seven guerrilla groups based in Pakistan, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar's Hezb-i-Islami. The Afghan government has arrested 600 people in connection with the failed coup, diplomats said. The latest arrests included the chiefs of police in Jalalabad and Khost, both in eastern Afghanistan, the chairman of Kabul University and chairman of the Afghan Academy of Sciences, the diplomats said. The diplomats also said Najib had appointed a new ambassador to the Soviet Union, Mohammad Daod Rasmyar, fanning speculation about the disappearance of former ambassador Sayed Mohammad Gulabzoi, a long-time enemy of Najib's. Diplomats and guerrilla leaders had expected Tanai's coup attempt would trigger mass defections within the Afghan army, particularly among the Khalqs. Najib belongs to the rival Parchams. ``There just haven't been the defections,'' said one diplomat. Meanwhile, diplomats said Afghan soldiers pushed through several guerrilla positions in Afghanistan's eastern Logar Province, recapturing several posts and establishing new ones. The guerrillas, fighting the Soviet-backed government for 12 years, are bankrolled by the United States and Saudi Arabia, but regularly complain of weapons' shortages. One Western diplomat said there appeared to be a genuine shortage of ammunition in Logar because of heavy fighting. Washington annually ships about $700 million worth of military supplies to the mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors. Moscow has been sending between $3 billion and $5 billion in weapons and food to the Kabul government since withdrawing its troops early last year after a decade-long occupation, Western diplomats said.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills Woman; Eight Bombs Found on Train Tracks
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in a western state Tuesday and killed one woman, and authorities found eight bombs on a railroad track in northern India, news reports said. Officials said security was stepped up nationwide. The incidents came a day after fire heavily damaged the government's main convention center in New Delhi. Sikh separatists claimed reponsibility for the blaze. The Press Trust of India news agency said Tuesday's bomb blast occurred at Palghar, six miles from the Tarapur nuclear power plant, in western Maharastra state. One woman was killed. Another bomb-like object was found nearby. Both bombs were concealed in tin cases the size of a loaf of bread. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the blast. The 420-megawatt Tarapur plant is 70 miles north of Bombay on the Indian Ocean. Safety workers found and dismantled eight bombs on a train track near the Hindu holy city of Mathura, 90 miles of southeast of New Delhi, Press Trust of India reported. PTI, quoting a senior police official, said the bombs were planted on the railroad track to blow up the Marudhar Express train, which carries an estimated 1,600 passengers. The train carries many Hindu pilgrims to Mathura. Federal officials in the Interior Ministry, which overlooks internal security, said security was increased around all important government buildings and installations, including nuclear power plants. They did not elaborate. The fire in the government's main conference center in New Delhi was extinguished Tuesday, nearly 17 hours after it was first noticed, fire department sources said. Two firefighters were reported injured. The five-story building in the heart of New Delhi, venue of the summit meeting of non-aligned nations in 1983 and several other important international conferences, was badly damaged. United News of India said a Sikh militant group, Khalistan Liberation Force, claimed responsibility for the fire. Sikh militants in Punjab are campaigning for an independent Sikh nation. At least 607 deaths in the rich farming state this year have been blamed on the militants. Sikhs make up 2 percent of India's 880 million people, but they are in slight majority in their home state of Punjab. They claim they are discriminated by Hindus, the country's religious majority accounting for 82 percent of the people.

DOC.HEAD: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Division Settles with SEC
DOC.TEXT: A New York-based securities firm agreed to pay $5.6 million to customers for stock sold in partial tender offers without prior client approval, federal officials said Tuesday. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. and a managing director, Michael Dreitlein, agreed to settle _ without admitting or denying wrongdoing _ an administrative action alleging they violated Securities and Exchange Commission anti-fraud and record-keeping rules. The action, brought by the SEC's New York Regional Office, the firm's Pershing Division of making $4.3 million in tender offer profits from the ``unauthorized and undisclosed'' sale of shares from customer accounts. A tender offer is an offer to buy a corporation's shares _ often as a means of acquiring the concern _ usually at a premium price. According to the SEC, the division, then directed by Dreitlein, tendered shares belonging to customers who had not given any instructions to do so. The shares were later replaced, usually with stock bought at a lower price after the tender offer. DLJ kept any profits from the difference between the sale and repurchase price. The alleged activity, known as overtendering, took place between January 1982 and April 1988, according to the SEC. ``Securities transactions are predicated on trust. DLJ misused that trust when it confiscated customers' securities for its benefit,'' said Martin A. Kuperberg, the SEC's associate regional administrator in New York. As part of the settlement with the SEC, DLJ agreed to pay $4.3 million plus interest for a total of $5.6 million to customers whose shares were used in the overtendering.

DOC.HEAD: Court Orders NRC Training Requirements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with reaction, detail, inserting new 4th graf and adding 3 grafs at end
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission must set up training requirements for nuclear power plant workers, a federal appeals court said Tuesday. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said the NRC had circumvented a 1983 change in the Nuclear Waste Policy Act. The NRC issued a policy statement in 1985 that encourages, but does not compel, nuclear plant operators to create training programs. The NRC concluded that the best way to get civilian nuclear power plants to improve training was to create a model training code and urge utilities to voluntarily comply. The NRC ended up endorsing industry-written training procedures. And utility companies with nuclear power plants are successfully meeting those standards, said Angie Howard of the Institute of Nuclear Power Operations, an industry group. Public Citizen, a group founded by Ralph Nader, filed lawsuits in 1986 and 1988 challenging the NRC's approach. The NRC looked again at the training issue in 1988 and decided not to impose requirements, relying on language in the amendment that allows the agency to issue ``appropriate ... regulatory guidance.'' The term ``regulatory guidance'' is ambiguous, but the language mandating the instructional requirements is clear and controls the issue, Chief Judge Patricia Wald wrote. ``Whatever the commission's regulatory guidance is, it must establish instructional requirements, and non-mandatory suggestions fail to do this,'' she wrote in the 3-0 decision. ``When Congress gives an agency its marching orders, the agency must obey all of them, not merely some.'' Wald noted that a presidential panel examining the accident at Three Mile Island said inadequate training contributed significantly to the risks posed by nuclear power plants. The NRC and utilities argued that imposing mandatory requirements would make the nuclear power industry less safe because it would choke off the industry's self-regulatory efforts. Companies could regard the NRC's requirements as a maximum rather than a minimum level of appropriate training, the agency said. The NRC and the industry ``must take this argument to the Congress, not to the courts,'' said the appeals panel. Voluntary industry training was under way when Congress passed the law and the NRC's model training code ``is exactly what Congress did not want to perpetuate,'' said David Vladeck, an attorney for the Public Citizen Litigation Group. In the NRC's inspections of specific sites, ``we have had concerns about the effectiveness of training,'' said Susan Shankman of the federal agency's office of nuclear reactor regulation. Monitoring is continuing. The training programs in place now ``are superb'' and the court ruling probably won't have an impact on them, said Joe Colvin, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Nuclear Management and Resources Council, a utility industry group. ``I can't argue that there won't be any increased enforcement'' action by the NRC as a result of the court case, but ``we don't view that as a major'' problem, said Colvin.

DOC.HEAD: Benjamin Franklin Bequest Comes of Age and Everyone Wants Piece of Pie
DOC.TEXT: Benjamin Franklin died 200 years ago Tuesday, and according to his will that means it's now time to spend the 1,000 pounds sterling he bequeathed to Massachusetts and Pennsylvania. The pennies saved are now worth about $4.5 million, and requests for a cut are pouring in from as far away as London. Franklin died in Philadelphia on April 17, 1790, at age 84. In his will, he gave 1,000 pounds sterling to Massachusetts and the city of Boston, and an equal sum to the state of Pennsylvania and the city of Philadelphia. The dollar did not become the official U.S. currency until 1792. The money came from what Franklin earned during his tenure as president of the commonwealth of Pennsylvania, 1785-87. He believed that politicians should not be paid for serving the public. Franklin specified in his will that on the 100th anniversary of his death a part of the two trusts be used for training young people, but at that time several interested parties sued for access to the money. A Massachusetts court resolved the dispute there by setting up a board of managers to control the money until the 200th anniversary. The managers ultimately decided to build a technical school, the Franklin Institute in Boston. A similar arrangement in Pennsylvania benefited the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia, a science museum. The Massachusetts group did considerably better in investing its share, with the fund now worth about $4.5 million. Pennsylvania's 1,000 pounds is now worth $2 million. Because Franklin's trust was not set up for more than a year after he died, current litigation seeks to put a date on when the money will be released to the cities and states. Officials estimated it would be 1991 before the recipients see their share. Then comes the question of what to do with the money. ``In keeping with Franklin's legacy we'd like to use the fund to help the young people of Boston with job training for their careers. This way, we're investing in the future of Boston,'' said Bob Consalvo, Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn's operations manager. Philadelphia Mayor W. Wilson Goode issued a statement citing Franklin's hope that the money aid students. He said the money should go to city high school students or recent graduates who need financial aid, especially in pursuit of a trade. Susan Kaplan, a spokeswoman for Gov. Michael Dukakis, said Massachusetts' plan for the trust had not been determined. Pennsylvania Gov. Robert P. Casey's office also said there were no firm plans for that state's share. Consalvo said requests for money from the fund have come from as far away as London, where a group called Friends of the Franklin House want $1.5 million to renovate the early American's home there. Another bid for the funds has come from Boston's Franklin Institute, which gives financial aid and technical training to Boston youth. ``We feel Franklin's memory would be better served if the trust would be used for the Institute,'' said Richard P. D'Onofrio, vice president of the institute. ``That's our cry _ continue the legacy.'' In Pennsylvania, Rod Snyder, a spokesman for the governor's budget office, said Philadelphia's Franklin Institute would be the likely recipient of the money, although some legislators there have suggested it be used to promote the arts. It also has been suggested that Boston use the funds to combat the rising crime rates among young people. ``It will fit in nicely with the city's Safe Neighborhoods Plan. We believe that through good jobs and careers you can replace the drugs and violence that influence our youth,'' Consalvo said.

DOC.HEAD: Winning Design For Free Speech Monument: Free Space
DOC.TEXT: A mostly invisible sculpture that its creator says suggests the idea of ``free space'' has been chosen to commemorate the Free Speech Movement of the 1960s. The winning design, picked in a nationwide contest, consists of a 6-inch circular patch of earth that sits within a 6-foot granite ring. The viewer is asked to visualize concentric columns of air rising from the circles. Along the low granite ring, which will be several inches wide, an inscription will read: ``This soil and the air space extending above it shall not be a part of any nation and shall not be subject to any entity's jurisdiction.'' The winning artist, Mark A. Brest van Kempen, was announced Monday by Peter Selz, professor emeritus of art history at the University of California at Berkeley and chairman of the Berkeley Art Project, a group of about 100 faculty members that sponsored the search. The Free Speech Movement was born on the UC-Berkeley campus in 1964. Brest van Kempen, a 28-year-old graduate student at the San Francisco Art Institute, described his mostly invisible design as ``apolitical'' and said his idea was to dedicate the ``free space'' to the right of all humans to speak freely. He plans to devote more than half the $70,000 prize money toward getting special legislation to declare the space free of national boundaries. Brest van Kempen's work is to be displayed on the campus' Sproul Plaza, pending approval from the university _ which remains uncertain. In a letter in January, UC-Berkeley Chancellor Ira Michael Heyman expressed misgivings about honoring the Free Speech Movement, saying it had been viewed by many in the community ``with negative or mixed emotions.'' The movement challenged the university's rules against political activity on campus. The demonstrations sparked a wave of protests that made armed camps of the nation's colleges before the 1960s were over. Veterans of the movement, along with UC-Berkeley faculty and students and representatives of the city, chose the winner from among five finalists.

DOC.HEAD: Industrial Production Up Strongly Second Month
With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The nation's industrial production gained 0.7 percent in March, the government said Tuesday, in a second consecutive strong showing that led analysts to suggest the manufacturing ``recession'' may have ended. ``We may have been through the worst of the slowdown,'' said Thomas Runiewicz, an industrial analyst with the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``I think you'll hear less talk of recession from the pessimists for a while.'' March's advance followed an even stronger 0.8 percent increase a month earlier. Both gains reflected increases in the output of automobiles, the Federal Reserve reported. ``The other major contributor to the overall production increase in March was utility output, which increased markedly as temperatures were more normal after an unseasonably warm January and February,'' the Fed said. ``Elsewhere, production was little changed, on balance, in March.'' Production had plummeted 1.3 percent in January because of the effect of the weather on utility output and of layoffs in the automobile industry as automakers trimmed bloated inventories. ``The suggestion is that the bottom has been reached in the industrial sector weakness and the issue raised is whether, in light of such high inflation, the industrial sector now may be too strong,'' remarked Allen Sinai, chief economist for The Boston Co.
