In another report Tuesday, the Labor Department said consumer prices jumped 0.5 percent in March, pushing the inflation rate for the first three months of 1990 to its highest level in almost eight years. Evelina Tainer, senior economist for First National Bank of Chicago, also said she believes the slowdown in manufacturing reached bottom in the fourth quarter of 1989, but added the industrial sector still is ``not showing particular strength.'' Industrial production at manufacturing plants making both durable and non-durable goods rose 0.3 percent in March on top of a 1.1 percent gain a month earlier. Durable manufacturing was up 0.9 percent after jumping 1.7 percent in February. Non-durable manufacturing was down 0.4 percent in March after inching up 0.2 percent a month earlier. Output at mines rose 0.6 percent last month after dropping 1.6 percent in February. Reflecting the return to relatively normal weather, utility output jumped 6.1 percent in March after falling 1.2 percent in February. The Fed said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities _ which usually move in tandem with industrial production _ advanced 0.4 percentage point to 83.3 percent last month. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels.

DOC.HEAD: United States Criticizes Malaysia Over Boat People
DOC.TEXT: The United States criticized Malaysia on Tuesday for turning away Vietnamese boat people, saying the policy was responsible for the death of four people. The United States ``has vigorously protested the denial of first asylum to Vietnamese at all appropriate levels of the Malaysian government,'' said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. Malaysia and other South Asian countries agreed last summer to grant asylum to Vietnamese fleeing their homeland. Under the agreement, those arriving before March 14, 1989, would be screened to determine which were entitled to refugee status and which were economic migrants. Malaysia denies it has turned away Vietnamese but says it is worried about being stuck with migrants who are not accepted by the United States and other western countries as refugees. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has reported that at least 4,000 asylum seekers from Vietnam arrived in Indonesia after being ``redirected'' by Malaysian authorities, Tutwiler said. ``We are deeply distressed that four Vietnamese have perished as a result of Malaysian actions,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Launch May Be Moved Up a Day
DOC.TEXT: Discovery's launch next week with the Hubble Space Telescope may be moved up a day if a new power unit tests well and the change doesn't hamper preparations for the next shuttle mission, NASA said Tuesday. The second attempt to launch Discovery is scheduled for April 25, 15 days after the first attempt was scrubbed because of a faulty auxiliary power unit. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said the delay has pushed back the launch of space shuttle Columbia to at least mid-May. Columbia originally was scheduled to lift off May 9 on a nine-day mission to scan space with a $100 million observatory called Astro. NASA said it will wait until after Discovery is launched with the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, the agency's most valuable payload, before setting a new target date for Columbia. ``We're required to inspect the hardware of the previous mission before we fly the next one,'' said NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone. For now, she said, ``Things are going well. We're not tracking any serious problems on either of them.'' Hubble will not be at risk inside Discovery's sealed payload bay when the new power unit is fired up for five minutes Wednesday, said NASA spokesman George Diller. The unit is one of three that pressurize the shuttle's hydraulic system, which is used to move wing and rudder surfaces and in the ship's braking and steering systems. Each APU must work properly before a shuttle can be launched. Contamination sensors removed from the cargo bay over the weekend showed no evidence of additional dust or debris on the telescope's 94-inch mirror, the finest ever made, Diller said. ``It's as clean as a whistle,'' he said. Hubble's six nickel-hydrogen batteries are undergoing 130 hours of recharging at a laboratory in the Vehicle Assembly Building. They will be put back in the telescope Saturday. The batteries will power Hubble from the time it is disconnected from Discovery's power system until its energy-collecting solar panels are deployed 380 miles above Earth. Once in orbit, the telescope will enable astronomers to study stars and galaxies so distant their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years. Because of preparations for Discovery are going so smoothly, NASA is considering advancing the mission to Tuesday, said NASA spokesman Ed Campion. ``Test of the APU is the long pole in the tent,'' Campion said. ``If that goes well, they'll poll each of the (launch) team members and ask how their work is going, their ability to support an advance in the launch date. If they all say they can, then we probably would move up the date.'' The decision, expected Wednesday, also will depend on whether a change interferes with work preparing Columbia's payload for launch, Diller said. The agency plans to roll Columbia out Sunday to the second of the Kennedy Space Center's two shuttle launch pads. Columbia was transferred from the orbiter processing facility to the Vehicle Assembly Building on Monday. The move was delayed three days so technicians could replace a leaking hydraulic part in the shuttle's nose landing gear.

DOC.HEAD: French Quarter Residents Suing to Turn Down Jazz Bands' Volume
LaserPhoto NU2
DOC.TEXT: Tourists love the brass bands that blare out Dixieland music all day long in the French Quarter's Jackson Square, but merchants and residents in the heart of the jazz citadel are suing to turn down the volume. Their lawsuit, filed Monday, says the music is causing ``headaches, stress, buzzing in the eardrums, loss of sleep, nervousness, irritability, mental and emotional turmoil.'' ``It would be like somebody putting two or three big, huge brass bands below your window where you live or where you work all day every day,'' lawyer and shop owner Luke Fontana said Tuesday. Jackson Square is considered by many the heart of the French Quarter _ the oldest section of the city. The Mississippi River runs along one boundary of the square. The other boundaries are formed by St. Louis Cathedral and other historic buildings housing museums, shops, bars and apartments. Stone sidewalks and a black iron fence form a perimeter around a small, grassy, tree-shaded park, at the center of which is a statue of Andrew Jackson on horseback. Tourists flock to the square in good weather. Many have their portraits painted or caricatures done by street artists who set up shop on the sidewalks. Others gather around the brass bands and throw money into the musicians' hats or empty instrument cases. Music has been part of the scene for years, but Brad Thoren, one of the artists involved in the lawsuit, said that in the past couple of years too many musicians have been playing too loudly, too often. He's concerned that the excessive noise could damage the hearing of those exposed to it every day. ``You have to shout to your customer to be heard. That is a hazard. That's a proven fact,'' he said. Noise ordinances that could solve the problem already are on the books, Fontana said. The lawsuit would make the police do more to enforce them. New Orleans Civil Court Judge Richard Ganucheau set a hearing on the lawsuit for April 27. ``Every musician that's on the street is going to be there,'' said Anthony ``Tuba Fats'' Lacen, leader of the six-piece Chosen Few Jazz Band that regularly plays the square. Lacen said New Orleans, still suffering from an economic slowdown that hit in the early 1980s, needs all the tourist dollars it can get, and restricting the musicians could drive away tourists. ``If they're not interested in keeping our city alive, then what are they doing here?'' Lacen asked. Thoren said the problem isn't so much professionals like Lacen. It's youngsters who don't play very well to begin with, playing in makeshift bands on weekends and afternoons after school. With the growing number of musicians, there is growing competition for tourist attention and money, said Lee Tucker, an artist and French Quarter resident. ``The street performers themselves have been competing against each other and the way they eliminate the competition is to play louder,'' said Tucker. Fontana is sensitive to the argument that tourists like the Dixieland bands. But there is more than tourism at stake, he said. Blaring brass bands lend nothing to the centuries-old architecture and charm of the quarter, he said. And reducing the number of musicians won't chase tourists away, he added. ``The quality of life is the intrinsic economic core of the community,'' said Fontana. ``And that is where the money is in the long run.'' Caught in the middle is Capt. George Bourgeois, commander of the Police Department's Vieux Carre division. Bourgeois said he has too few men trained in the use of sound measuring equipment to enforce the loudness provision of the noise ordinance. And the department's legal counsel has advised against enforcement of a law forbidding the playing of an instrument that is clearly audible more than 50 feet away.

DOC.HEAD: Johnny Carson Sued By First Wife
DOC.TEXT: Johnny Carson's first wife said Tuesday she is living in a small hotel with no job and wants a judge to force the television host to increase her annual alimony from $13,500 to $120,000. Joan ``Jody'' Carson, 63, said she hasn't spoken to the father of her three sons in ``many, many, many years'' and recent attempts to reach him have been unsuccessful. ``He's quite unavailable,'' she said in a telephone interview from the office of her attorney, matrimonial lawyer Raoul Felder. ``He won't really talk to me at all.'' Carson married his high-school sweetheart in 1949. A postnuptial agreement called for Mrs. Carson to receive $15,000 a year plus 15 percent of Carson's earnings over $100,000, Felder said. They divorced in 1963. When Mrs. Carson remarried in 1970, she signed a new agreement giving her $13,500 annually as well as certain bonuses that ended in 1979. That marriage ended in 1973. Mrs. Carson, who was Carson's assistant in his magic act at the University of Nebraska, said she is living off her savings in a small midtown Manhattan residential hotel. ``I'm like many women of my age with no way of earning a living,'' she said. ``I don't want to get rich. ... I am simply forced into this situation.'' Mrs. Carson said she is not close with her three sons, ages 41, 39 and 38. She said they each receive $50,000 a year from Carson. Felder said a private detective served ``The Tonight Show'' host with court papers Friday in Los Angeles. He is to respond by May 1 in a state court in Manhattan. ``It's really a relatively modest figure,'' Felder said of the $120,000 request. ``This is not an Ivana Trump case.'' Carson, 64, reportedly earns $40 million a year. According to the syndicated television program, ``A Current Affair,'' which reported on the lawsuit Monday, Carson pays his second wife, Joanne, $75,000 a year. His third wife, Joanna, won a $27 million lump-sum settlement. He is currently wed to Alex Maas. Carson's attorney did not return a phone call Tuesday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Congressman Introducing Wetlands Bill
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Charles Bennett, D-Fla., said Tuesday that he will introduce a bill this week with the most comprehensive wetlands policy yet sent to Congress. He said the bill follows President Bush's policy of no overall net loss in wetlands and would restore and create such areas. It is supported by the National Wildlife Federation and former New Jersey Gov. Thomas Kean, who chaired a national committee that evaluated wetland policies and made recommendations to the Environmental Protection Agency. Bennett said the bill makes improvements on the agreement reached last year between the Army Corps of Engineers and the EPA over wetlands. That agreement originally was applauded by environmentalists but met with such opposition from developers that it was modified. Bennett said that even though he calls his bill the Wetlands No Net Loss Act of 1990, it doesn't call for discontinuation of development. ``However, it does mean that every attempt should be made to direct growth away from wetlands where possible, and to minimize the effects on wetlands where avoidance is not possible,'' he said. He said the legislation provides clear definitions of wetlands and would settle conflicts between state and federal jurisdictions.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Acknowledges Anti-Semitism Of Some Visiting Writers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs `The tour ...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Jewish Committee official. Picks up 5th graf pvs `A Russian ...'
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Tuesday that some Russian writers on an officially sponsored tour of the United States hold anti-Semitic views. Spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler called their views abhorrent and said one purpose of the tour, funded by the U.S. Information Agency, was to educate the writers about ``how the United States works as a multiethnic society based on individual freedoms.'' The U.S. official, reading from a prepared statement, added, ``Bringing them here does not signal that we approve or sanction their views.'' The tour prompted a complaint from the American Jewish Committee. ``It's naive to believe such people can be converted overnight,'' said David Harris, director of its Washington office. ``We are giving the group undue exposure by bringing them to the United States at American taxpayer expense,'' he said. ``And I am concerned we are dignifying and legitimizing this group, which can only strengthen their hand when they return to the USSR.'' Harris, in an interview, called the group both anti-Semitic and anti-reformist. ``Someone here did not do their homework,'' he said. A Russian Jewish emigre whose studies of anti-Semitic writers were used by the committee, Semyon Reznick, said some writers in the group ``exuded the myth of a Jewish-Zionist conspiracy, an old Russian hatred'' in their work. Frank S. Johnson Jr., a spokesman for the U.S. Information Agency, said, ``I don't know that they are anti-Semitic; I don't know that they are not, either. ... We feel very strongly that pluralism in this country is worth talking about and observing.'' But Ms. Tutwiler, asked if some of the Russians might have anti-Semitic views, replied: ``My understanding is that some of the people do hold those views. But our opinion, as you know, is that we bring all types of groups here, and it is not a sanction or endorsement of those views, at all.'' She said Secretary of State James A. Baker III had raised the issue of growing anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in their last two rounds of meetings. Ms. Tutwiler said perestroika, the reconstruction policy of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, should bring more tolerance, not intolerance. Emigre Reznick singled out Stanislav Kunyaev as a ``big fish'' of anti-Semitic writers in the group. As editor of Nash Sovremenik (Our Contemporary), Kunyaev wrote an article praising the long-discredited ``Protocols of the Elders of Zion'' as ``written by very clever people who understand the history of mankind.'' The protocols purport to be an account of a meeting of Jewish leaders plotting to control the world. Adolf Hitler in Germany and Czarist rulers in Russia used the fictitious documents to stir up anti-Jewish sentiments to murderous levels. Another writer in the Russian group, Olveg Mikhaylov, has written of the late 18th century Russian writer Gavril Gerzhavin as a ``victim of a Jewish plot,'' Reznik said. Johnson of the USIA said the writers were selected by public affairs and cultural affairs officers of the U.S. Embassy in Moscow who were seeking to bring conservative Russian nationalists to the United States. State's Tutwiler said: ``The purpose of these programs is to bring people to the United States so they can see how our society works. The goal of these programs is an educational goal, teaching people about the United States. We bring people with a wide range of opinions to the United States, including some with whom we thoroughly disagree and whose views we find abhorrent.''

DOC.HEAD: Feds Trying to Deport Sheik's Son
DOC.TEXT: A flamboyant Saudi Arabian who promised to donate $1 million for animal rights shelters in Minnesota was being sought Tuesday by federal officials who say he entered the country on a bogus visa. ``We're still looking for him,'' Thomas Schiltgen, acting district director at the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service in St. Paul, said of Mohammad al-Fassi. Schiltgen declined further comment for fear of jeopardizing the investigation. Mark Cangemi, assistant district director of investigations at the INS office, said al-Fassi, the son of a sheik, arrived in Miami in September 1989 claiming to represent the Saudi government on official business. ``And that's not correct. He doesn't, he hasn't and he won't,'' Cangemi said. An arrest warrant has been issued for al-Fassi who, if caught, will face deportation proceedings, Cangemi said. But it may be too late. Cangemi said al-Fassi has not been seen in Minnesota since the middle of last week, and authorities say he may have left the country. Following negotiations through his lawyer with the INS, al-Fassi failed to turn himself in for questioning by April 13 as he had agreed. An al-Fassi aide at the Radisson Hotel in Minneapolis, where al-Fassi had been staying, refused comment Monday. Al-Fassi, 33, is the son of Sheik Shamsuddin al-Fassi, a Saudi Arabian religious leader who underwent a kidney transplant at the University of Minnesota Hospital last month. His entourage, including his son, has been in Minneapolis for weeks. Last week, aides for the younger al-Fassi gave Minnesota animal rights activist Lori Peterson a symbolic check for $1 million for shelters. Peterson, a University of Minnesota law student, had contacted al-Fassi after hearing that he loved animals. But last Wednesday, al-Fassi was charged in Florida's Dade County with cruelty to animals, according to Joe Torregrosa, an inspector with the Greater Miami Humane Society. The previous day, Torregrosa said, the society had found 32 cats, many sick and dehydrated, at al-Fassi's Miami Beach mansion. Peterson said Sunday that an aide to al-Fassi had given her $1,000 in cash for adoption fees she paid at the Minneapolis Animal Control pound on Saturday. In a cover story in People magazine in May 1983, former aides to the al-Fassi family chronicled the marriage and expensive divorce of the younger al-Fassi and his lavish lifestyle in Europe, the Middle East, Florida and Los Angeles. When al-Fassi was a teen-ager, his older sister was a mistress of Prince Turki bin Abdul Aziz, brother of future Saudi King Fahd, the story said. Al-Fassi became the royal prince's accountant. The press attache at the Saudi Arabian embassy in Washington, D.C., did not return a call regarding al-Fassi. ``He is a private citizen and we don't give out information on private citizens,'' said the attache's secretary.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral Arrangements Completed for Garbo
DOC.TEXT: Funeral services for actress Greta Garbo were conducted quickly and quietly Tuesday at a funeral home, completed with the same mystery that shrouded her life and her death. Garbo's body was taken to the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home in Manhattan. All the arrangements were handled there on Tuesday, a funeral director confirmed. But the funeral parlor _ like the hospital where she died Sunday _ refused to provide any additional information at the request of her family. Garbo spent much of the last 49 years of her life in seclusion, shunning the spotlight for a solitary life. The medical examiner's office told the New York Post that Garbo's body would be cremated, but the funeral home would not confirm that. Her remains may be buried in a family grave in Stockholm, the Swedish newspaper Expressen reported Tuesday. The newspaper quoted Garbo's only surviving relative, niece Grae Reisfeld, as saying it was her aunt's wish to be buried in Sweden. Expressen quoted Ms. Reisfeld, of Passaic, N.J., as saying the cause of death was cardiac arrest. ``The heart could not take any more and there were complications,'' Ms. Reisfeld was quoted as saying. Garbo, 84, died at New York Hospital in Manhattan. Any burial will be private, her family said. New York Hospital spokeswoman Myrna Manners confirmed Garbo had been a kidney dialysis patient at the hospital, but released no other medical information at the request of Garbo's family. The family also requested that in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to The Rogosin Institute. Garbo underwent dialysis at the non-profit institute, which is affiliated with New York Hospital. The Daily News on Tuesday reported that Garbo received dialysis three times a week for the past several months, getting six hours of treatment every Monday, Wednesday and Friday. The paper also said quoted an unidentified Garbo acquaintance as saying that the legendary film star had one bottle of vodka and two bottles of scotch per week delivered to her Manhattan apartment during the months before her death. Garbo starred in 26 films in 17 years before quitting the Hollywood scene in 1941. Garbo who was born in Stockholm, made her screen debut in 1923. After 12 silent films, she delivered her first on-screen sentence in the 1930 movie ``Anna Christie'': ``Gimme a visky, ginger ale on the side. And don't be stingy, baby.'' She became a U.S. citizen in 1951 and spent the rest of her life in seclusion, moving between France, Switzerland and Manhattan. She lived in an East 52nd Street high rise where doormen were constantly shooing fans away. Garbo died wealthy, although the Post said it is unclear who will inherit her estate since she left no will. She owned several buildings in Beverly Hills, an extensive art collection and her East Side co-op, the Post said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Threatens Marcos Supporters With Contempt
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the fraud trial of Imelda Marcos threatened supporters of the former Philippine first lady with contempt on Tuesday for hissing and groaning during the cross-examination of a government witness. Judge John F. Keenan, red-faced and angry, stood up at the bench and said to the courtroom at large, ``I don't know who started that, but you make one more noise and you're out of here.'' Keenan threatened to hold anyone involved in a future outburst in contempt of court. ``This is not Shea Stadium or Yankee Stadium, or Madison Square Garden,'' the judge said. ``You don't cheer for one side or another.'' The brief, noisy reaction came as Mrs. Marcos' attorney, Gerald Spence, elicited from the witness, Dr. Angelita Reyes, that she mistakenly testified that she signed an FBI affidavit in 1988, instead of the correct date in 1986. The Philippine dermatologist was called to testify about documents she helped take from the Malacanang Palace in Manila on Feb. 28, 1986, three days after Mrs. Marcos' husband, Ferdinand, was ousted as president in a popular revolt and they fled to Hawaii. Several of those documents were admitted into evidence, including the purchase contract for a Wall Street office building and bank records that showed Mrs. Marcos used the pseudonym ``Jane Ryan'' in an account at the Swiss Credit Bank in Zurich. The U.S. government intends to use the documents in its effort to prove that Mrs. Marcos and her late husband used millions of dollars embezzled from their homeland's treasury to finance her lavish lifestyle and the purchase of four New York properties, including the building at 40 Wall St. Reyes returned to the stand after a week's break for the Jewish and Easter holidays. She had testified April 9 that she went to the palace with her neighbor Margarita ``Ting Ting'' Cojuangco, the sister-in-law of the then-new President Corazon Aquino. Spence sought Tuesday to show Dr. Reyes' friendship with Mrs. Aquino, her former schoolmate, motivated her to testify for the prosecution. Reyes said she only wanted to tell the truth, not to help either side win the case. ``It is my duty,'' she said. ``To whom, Mrs. Aquino?'' Spence asked. ``No, sir,'' she replied.

DOC.HEAD: Buglary Suspect Killed by Booby-Trap Shotgun
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 14-15 pvs, ``The tenant ... with seven grafs to UPDATE with comment from neighbor of warehouse owner; picks up final graf.
DOC.TEXT: A burglary suspect was killed when he broke into a warehouse and tripped a booby-trapped shotgun, police said. Authorities said three youths with the teen-ager said they were looking for adventure. Michael McComb, 19, was shot in the chest at the warehouse Saturday night while leading three juveniles in what police called a burglary attempt. Police said a shotgun was propped up inside the warehouse and attached to a trip wire. The downtown warehouse, leased to Philip Connaghan of suburban Arvada, had been burglarized eight times since 1987, with shop tools targeted each time. The handyman lost more than $7,000 in tools in a burglary last July. The warehouse also housed vehicle parts, acetylene torches and camper shells. Connaghan, who was out of town and spoke once to authorities by telephone, has denied any knowledge of the booby trap, according to police. Connaghan could not be reached Tuesday. A call to his home was answered by a person who refused to give a name and said Connaghan was not home. A city ordinance prohibits the setting of booby traps at businesses, and violators can face misdemeanor charges, said city assistant district attorney Chuck Lepley. He said the ordinance was enacted because booby traps can backfire and injure the innocent. In cases where someone dies, whoever set the booby trap can be charged with murder, said Lepley. The three youths were arrested Saturday night and were booked for investigation of burglary and released to their parents. ``These kids are talking about going out and exploring. They call it `exploring and adventuring,''' said police Sgt. Doug Hildebrant. ``It's almost like a game. They were in it for the excitement.'' City District Attorney Norm Early said Colorado's ``Make My Day'' law, which allows householders to use deadly force to defend themselves, probably does not apply. The law was nicknamed after a line from a Clint Eastwood movie. ``You just cannot go around intentionally taking someone's life to protect property,'' the district attorney said Monday. ``The property must be a dwelling, and the person who does the shooting must be present.'' The Colorado Supreme Court ruled defendants must prove they were in danger when they used deadly force against intruders. Connaghan said previously he had tried almost everything to keep out burglars, but they just kept breaking in. He parked vehicles in front of the doors, and burglars towed them out of the way and broke in. He put up fence topped with three strips of barbed wire and they still got in. Less than three weeks ago, someone hooked a chain to a large bay door, attached it to a vehicle and ripped the door off its hinges. A guard dog Connaghan bought reportedly ran away. Kevin Corbin, owner of the Skyline Cafe where Connaghan stopped for coffee, said he offered Connaghan some advice: ``Phil, if it was my restaurant they were hitting, I'd sit here with a gun and make sure I was never robbed again.'' Connaghan had his own plan. He welded the second bay door shut and ran rods through the concrete walls. Connaghan said that if someone tried to take down the door this time, they'd have to take down the entire building, according to Corbin. In Florida in 1986, a Liberty City discount store owner rigged an electrical booby trap to deter burglars, and the trap electrocuted a burglary suspect. The Dade County grand jury refused to indict the store owner, saying he had not meant to kill, only to shock.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pledges Speedy Contra Camp Demobilization
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Recasts top 5 grafs to CORRECT that Aronson made comments about dismantling camps, NOT Bush
DOC.TEXT: The Contra rebels are quickly demobilizing, but it is doubtful they will all lay down their weapons by the time Daniel Ortega steps down as president of Nicaragua April 25 even though their camps should be dismantled by then, a top U.S. official said Tuesday. ``Demobilization as agreed to seems to be proceding on schedule,'' and moving toward dismantling of the Contra camps along the Honduran border by next week, Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson told reporters following President Bush's meeting with visiting Honduran President Rafael Callejas. Honduras has pressed for the rebels' speedy repatriation. Aronson said it is unlikely all the Contras will surrender their weapons by the time incoming presideent Violeta Chamorro takes over from Ortega. ``The time frame is moving along faster than people anticipated'' for demobilizing the rebel forces,'' Aronson said. ``The camps should be dismantled in Honduras before the inauguration. Those Contras have turned in their weapons or are in the process of turning in their weapons ... you need to work out a process whereby arms can be laid down with confidence and a sense of security.'' Under peace accords reached by the five presidents of the region, the Contras are to demobilize into security zones inside Nicaragua and disarm under U.N. supervision. ``Clearly the entire demobilization will not have taken place by April 25th,'' Aronson said. ``President Ortega knows that,'' he said in reference to Ortega's demand Monday that complete disarmament take place so a peaceful transition can occur. At the State Department, spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the administration expects ``a complete orderly transfer of power'' next week. She added, ``The Sandinistas rhetorical statements, such as those made recently, are unhelpful to the transition process.'' ``There can be no legitimate reason or international support for conditioning this transfer.'' Vice President Dan Quayle will lead the U.S. delegation to Mrs. Chamorro's inaugural. Among other members of the delegation, according to an administration source, will be the president's son, Jeb Bush, Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind. and Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn. Aronson said that 3,000 to 5,000 Contra fighters remain in the Honduran camps, down from a peak of 12,000. In addition, the camps house 40,000 family members and Honduras is home to about 125,000 refugees who have fled Nicaragua, Aronson said. Pressed by Honduras for economic and trade assistance, the United States is preparing a bridge loan to help Honduras with its $247 million foreign debt, Aronson said following the visit. He said that the exact amount of the U.S. loan is not decided yet and that it will be part of a package that also includes new international lending, with participation by Japan and other countries. Bush, after his Oval Office meeting with Callejas, lauded the role Honduras played in the Central American peace process that led to the Feb. 25 Nicaraguan elections and the end of the decade-long Contra war. ``We support this process and will work to ensure humanitarian assistance to those in need in both Nicaragua and Honduras as they return to their homes, their families and their jobs, and play a vital role in helping Nicaragua establish lasting democratic institutions,'' Bush said. Aronson said the two presidents had discussed concerns involving Nicaragua, in particular the longstanding desire by Honduras to rid itself of the border camps housing the U.S.-backed Contras. ``He obviously is hopeful the process will move'' toward repatriation, Aronson said, describing Callejas as optimistic about the matter. Bush's $47 million Contra aid package includes $33 million for repatriation of the Contras and their families, plus money to go to the U.N. refugee commission for resettlement of the refugee families.

DOC.HEAD: Law Enforcement Officials Say Terrorism Continues to Rise
DOC.TEXT: The number of terrorist acts around the world rose 17 percent to 4,368 last year, and it will only get worse, the FBI's chief bomb technician said Tuesday at a conference on airport security. ``The numbers just keep going up, and we don't see anything that's going to negate that trend,'' including multimillion-dollar bomb detection systems, said Robert Quigley, the head of the agency's Bomb Data Center. The number of incidents last year was up from 3,734 in 1988, Quigley said. There were 1,930 bombings last year, compared with 1,622 in 1988. One of the worst incidents of terrorism was in December 1988, when a bomb said to be concealed as a radio felled Pan AM Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. All 259 people on board, as well as 11 people on the ground, were killed. Quigley was among bomb and security experts meeting at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to discuss the status of airport safety. Raymond Salazar, director of civil aviation security for the Federal Aviation Administration, said the only way to combat terrorism is through cooperation. ``We'll never be 100 percent (effective),'' Salazar said. ``In preventing criminal acts, your major obstacle is the mind of the person who is trying to do you harm,'' and that person will always be a half-step ahead. However, terrorists won't win if local governments, law enforcement and intelligence work together, Salazar said. The arsenal against terrorists now includes automated explosive detection systems developed by the FAA, Salazar said. He estimated the FAA spent about $60 million over 10 years to develop the systems, which use thermal-neutron analysis. The system is being used at New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport and at the Miami International Airport. Others are planned for Dulles International Airport near Washington, D.C., and at airports in England and West Germany, Salazar said. About 200 systems will be deployed in 40 airports worldwide within the next two years, he said. Critics say the new systems are ``too large, too slow, like trying to stuff an elephant into a horse's stall,'' Salazar said. ``To these critics I say, you have to start somewhere. You can't wait for perfect while you have good available.'' About 1.2 billion passengers are screened in the United States a year, or about 2,300 a minute, Salazar said. About 1.25 billion pieces of carry-on luggage are screened annually, he said. ``That means find the hijacker, find the bomb in about four to six seconds per person per article or less,'' he said. These constraints are dictated by the passenger, he said. ``It's `Keep me safe, but please don't make it inconvenient.'''

DOC.HEAD: N.H. House Fails to Override Veto of Abortion Rights Bill
DOC.TEXT: The state House on Tuesday failed to override Gov. Judd Gregg's veto of an abortion rights bill that the governor said was too liberal. The bill would have given women the right to unrestricted abortions until the fetus could live outside the womb. Supporters had argued that the bill essentially put into law what is current practice. The 215-157 vote fell 33 short of the two-thirds needed for override. Chances had been bleak that lawmakers would override the veto, but abortion-rights advocates held out hope that more sympathizers than opponents would be present for the showdown. House rules base the number of votes needed to override on those present and voting, not the entire membership. Two previous House votes approved the legislation by comfortable margins, but short of the two-thirds to override. ``I really don't think the majority of the people in this state support letting New Hampshire have the most liberal abortion law in the nation,'' the governor said after the vote. Rep. Stephanie Micklon, one of the bill's sponsors, called it patronizing and bizarre that New Hampshire refuses to make motorcyclists wear helmets or drivers wear seat belts and allows people to buy assault rifles under the mantle of freedom of choice, but hasn't given abortion rights to women. ``All these people may make very personal choices but the women of New Hampshire,'' she said. The bill also would have allowed abortions after fetal viability to protect the life or health of the mother or if the fetus has a life-threatening physical or congenital abnormality. It would repeal three unenforced anti-abortion statutes enacted in 1848. If the House had voted to override, the bill would have gone back to the Senate for an override vote. The Senate originally passed the bill 14-10, two shy of two-thirds. In his veto message, Gregg argued that the bill would authorize abortion for ``convenience, sex selection, as a form of birth control and with or without parental notification or consent in the case of a minor.'' Abortion-rights proponents had hoped to put the principles of the 1973 U.S. Supreme Court ruling legalizing abortions into state law in case the federal court turns greater regulatory control over abortion to the states.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Rally in Support of Anti-Corruption Prosecutors
LaserPhoto MOSB4
DOC.TEXT: Soviets rallied Tuesday by the tens of thousands in Moscow and Leningrad in support of two embattled prosecutors whose anti-corruption probe has become a lightning rod for popular resentment of Communist Party privilege. About 10,000 people gathered in the shadow of Moscow's Kremlin and journalists said at least as many met in front of the former czarist Winter Palace in Leningrad as the Supreme Soviet parliament in Moscow considered lifting the legislative immunity of the two, Telman Gdlyan and Nikolai Ivanov. ``Gdlyan and Ivanov are our conscience!'' read signs carried by the Moscow crowd.``The fate of Gdlyan and Ivanov is the fate of democracy. Protect them!'' The two gained fame uncovering a trail of bribery and corruption in Uzbekistan that led to the son-in-law of the late President Leonid I. Brezhev. Populist communist leader Boris N. Yeltsin criticized as incomplete a nearly yearlong investigation of Gdlyan and Ivanov by a legislative committee, and urged the legislators to keep their immunity intact. ``If today we lift parliamentary immunity from these two deputies tomorrow the same could happen to others, because some of us as people's deputies are already feeling pressure from many sides,'' Yeltsin said. He said the Communist Party Politburo dallied for months in 1986 on a request by the prosecutors to open an investigation targeting a former leader of the Soviet Central Asian republic of Uzbekistan. The Supreme Soviet made no decision Tuesday and was expected to continue its debate on Wednesday. Gdlyan and Ivanov did not attend the session. They reportedly were in the Armenian republic, where they were nominated for vacant Congress posts in the event they are stripped of the legislative seats they now hold. Ivanov also has tied the name of conservative Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev to his corruption probe. The Tass news agency said the two in a newspaper article accused Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of ``turning a blind eye to the mafia.'' Soviet officials accused the two of abusing their power and making unjustified public accusations against senior leaders in an effort to increase their popularity. Riding a wave of popularity, Ivanov was elected to the national Congress of People's Deputies from Leningrad and Gdlyan was elected from Moscow last March. They cannot be charged with abusing their power unless the Supreme Soviet strips them of legislative immunity. The two prosecutors were taken off their cases, and on Feb. 21 were expelled from the Communist Party. They and their supporters portray the actions as a move by party officials to protect themselves by curbing the investigation. Leningrad journalist Maxim Korzhov said a crowd marching to Leningrad's Palace Square carried a portrait of Gorbachev with the word ``Resign!'' scrawled over it in black. He estimated the Leningrad crowd at 200,000. A Western journalist on the scene reckoned it at 100,000. Neither estimate could be confirmed. Crowd members chanted ``Gorbachev resign!'' and ``Down with the KGB!'' Korzhov reported. Korzhov said about 30 Leningrad factories were hit by a one-hour warning strike against lifting immunity for the prosecutors. Speakers at the Tuesday night rally appealed for a citywide strike if the Supreme Soviet moves against the prosecutors. Tass quoted Soviet national prosecutor Alexander Sukharev as saying Gdlyan and Ivanov are guilty of detaining 50 people illegally for periods of up to several years. They also were accused of threatening detainees and their families to obtain statements. The KGB secret police chief, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, also spoke to parliament about the issue. He called the prosecutors' handling of several cases ``a typical case example of political and penal adventurism,'' Tass said. ``One gets the impression that they are now doing everything to evade responsibility for what they did.''

Important dates in the life of the rev. Ralph David Abernathy: March 11, 1926: David Abernathy is born in Linden, Ala., grandson of slaves and 10th of 12 children of William and Louiverny Abernathy. A sister later calls him ``Ralph David,'' after a teacher she admires, and Abernathy eventually lists his new name on his military records. 1944: Abernathy is drafted, and joins an all-black Army unit with white officers. September 1945: Abernathy, having passed the high school equivalency test, enrolls at Alabama State College, where he becomes class president. 1948: Named pastor of Montgomery's First Baptist Church. 1950: Awarded diploma from Alabama State. 1954: Begins friendship with Martin Luther King Jr., a young Atlanta minister named pastor at Montgomery's Dexter Avenue Baptist Church. Aug. 31, 1954: Marries Juanita Jones of Uniontown, Ala. 1955: King and Abernathy begin planning how they might bring an end to segregation in Montgomery. They lead the Montgomery bus boycott. January 1957: Abernathy's Montgomery home is bombed. 1957: King and Abernathy found the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, with King as president. Abernathy remains King's chief aide for the next 11 years. 1961: Abernathy becomes pastor of Atlanta's West Hunter Street Baptist Church. 1965: King tabs Abernathy to become his successor at SCLC, when the time comes. April 4, 1968: King is assassinated in Memphis, Tenn. April 6, 1968: Abernathy takes over as SCLC president. 1977: The civil rights movement is a shadow of what it was before King's death and Abernathy has been under pressure for months from other SCLC leaders. He resigns as SCLC president and announces a Democratic race for the congressional seat of Andrew Young, a movement colleague who became U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations. Abernathy loses. The Rev. oseph Lowery becomes SCLC president. 1980: Abernathy, along with veteran movement activist Hosea Williams, endorses Republican Ronald Reagan for president over incumbent Democrat Jimmy Carter of Georgia, to give the black struggle ``new meaning.'' He is widely criticized by other movement veterans. January 1983: Abernathy suffers a serious stroke. March 1983: Undergoes brain surgery for a blocked cerebral artery. 1984: Abernathy, spurning Reagan, endorses the Democratic presidential candidacy of Jesse Jackson. June 1986: Abernathy suffers an apparent second stroke. April 1989: Abernathy finishes his autobiography, ``And The Walls Came Tumbling Down.'' October 1989: The autobiography is published. Abernathy is almost immediately denounced by many of the remaining movement leaders _ including Jackson, Young and Lowery _ for a brief passage in which he writes of King's alleged infidelity and his dalliances with women on the night before his murder. March 23, 1990: Abernathy is hospitalized following a bout of nausea, and treated for a sodium imbalance. April 17, 1990: Still hospitalized, Abernathy suffers a heart attack and dies at age 64.

DOC.HEAD: British Firm Frets It May Have Supplied Iraq With Gun Component
DOC.TEXT: A British steelmaker said Tuesday it is afraid it may have been duped into supplying Iraq with a recoil mechanism for a giant gun. Walter Somers Ltd. of Birmingham issued a statement as Customs agents resumed a major investigation into the seizure of eight steel tubes bound for Iraq that were manufactured by rival company Sheffield Forgemasters. Customs officials say the tubes could be used as part of a huge artillery piece. Forgemasters says the tubes were part of a petrochemical installation. On Sunday, Forgemasters denied the eight tubes could be joined together as part of a towering gun to attack Iraq's Middle East enemies or launch satellites. Walter Somers, a subsidiary of Eagle Trust, said engineers were concerned that hydraulic equipment Walter Somers shipped to Iraq last October could be used as part of a heavy-duty shock absorber, possibly a hydraulic recoil mechanism in a huge gun. ``Our engineers are now wondering whether they have been misled up the garden path by the Iraqis,'' Eagle Trust Chairman David James said in a statement. Customs officials seized documents last week from Walter Somers, which had previously manufactured pipes for Iraq, and from Sheffield Forgemasters. ``The Customs investigation was very appropriate, and we are concerned to establish the facts,'' James said. ``We think it is in the interests of the international community as well as a national responsibility.'' He said the company refused to ship a component Iraq first inquired about last October and then sent an urgent order for in early April. ``Re-evaluated in the light of subsequent events and publicity, there was concern that the component described in the order might be used as a positioning or aiming device'' for a gigantic weapon, he said. The company notified the Department of Trade and Industry of its concern on April 9. The department declined comment Tuesday. James said the component in the $131,000 order was designed to resemble a 60-degree segment of a circle, with an arc about 25 feet across. ``It was intended to be laid flat on the ground as a means of positioning or maneuvering a large pipe,'' he said. ``I can't think of any technology where you would want to maneuver a pipe of that size. It was to have been fabricated in a number of pieces and the sections welded.'' James said Walter Somers decided to re-examine its contracts with Iraq following the murder in Brussels on March 22 of American ballistics expert Gerald Bull. He said Bull and his company, Space Research Corp. of Brussels, acted as agents for various Iraqi orders and was the source of technical data and drawings related to them. Belgian police said the 62-year-old Canadian-born U.S. citizen was shot twice in the head, that the gunman used a silencer, and the motive was not robbery because $20,000 was found in the victim's pockets. In a statement Monday, Forgemasters' lawyer Stuart Benson said the company's contract with Iraq involved Bull's Space Research Corp., which had designed a satellite launch system. Customs seized eight forged steel tubes bound for Iraq on April 12. Forgemasters said it agreed to supply 52 sections of the steel tubing for a petrochemical plant and delivered 44 to the Ministry of Industry and Minerals in Baghdad. Walter Somers said Iraq had asked it to bid for a contract for pipes like those seized, but that the company did not have the factory capacity. James said he believed the order went to Forgemasters. Walter Somers believed until now that its orders from Iraq were for Iraq's petrochemical industry, exports licensed by the Department of Trade and Industry, James said. Its previous orders with Iraq were worth about $3.1 million, including the $90,000 hydraulic equipment deal last October, he said. On March 28, British Customs officers arrested five people at Heathrow Airport and seized 40 U.S.-made components for nuclear bomb triggers that were being shipped to Iraq. One of those arrested was deported, one was released and three await trial.

DOC.HEAD: Jane's Reports Ethnic Clashes in Soviet Military
DOC.TEXT: The ethnic tensions in the Soviet Union have spread to the military, causing problems recruiting soldiers from areas of unrest, Jane's Defense Weekly said Tuesday. The authoritative magazine said many ethnic groups were reticent to join the armed forces and nationalist cliques within the military caused fights and disciplinary problems. ``The multi-ethnic mix of the Soviet armed forces is increasingly in doubt as the military finds itself trapped between nationalist pressures within and outside its ranks,'' Jane's reported. Since nationilist protests began in December 1986 in Kazakhstan, ethnic riots have occured in the Soviet republics of Azerbaijan, Armenia, Georgia, Uzbekistan and the Baltic states of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia. Initially, protests focused on assigning ethnic draftees outside their own republics, but Jane's said it now includes recruitment boycotts. Jane's quoted Ground Forces Commander-in-Chief Gen. Valentin Varennikov as warning the military ``cannot and does not remain aloof from (the people's) concerns, problems and misfortunes.'' The British magazine, which has wide contacts in military matters, also quoted a report in the Soviet army newspaper, Krasnaya Zvezda, which said the Azeri Popular Front in Azerbaijan had told its members not to evade conscription but to join the army and learn combat skills ``for the struggle to free Azerbaijan.'' ``The army is proving no more successful than the (Communist) party in managing tensions,'' Jane's said. In Lithuania, since the republic declared independence on March 11, the republic's legislature halted spring conscription and many ethnic Lithuanian soldiers deserted.

DOC.HEAD: Anthony Hope Tapped For Regulatory Commission
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Tuesday he will name Anthony J. Hope as chairman of the National Indian Gaming Commission. Hope, of Washington, is senior vice president of Mutual of Omaha and United of Omaha Insurance companies. His term as chairman will run three years. The commission regulates bingo and other gambling on Indian reservations.

DOC.HEAD: Record Chill On Northern Plains
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures dipped to record lows Tuesday across the northern Plains, and rain and snow were scattered from the Southwest to New England. Severe storms late Monday and early Tuesday did scattered damage in parts of Oklahoma and Arkansas. Record lows were 18 degrees at Rapid City, S.D., and 10 at Valentine, Neb., while both Sioux Falls and Yankton, S.D., tied their records of 19. The cold front that marked the edge of lower temperatures continued to move to the southeast. About noon, Harrisburg, Pa., cooled from 60 to 50 degrees in half an hour when the cold front passed. At midday, rain extended across much of New England, southeastern New York state, northeastern to southwestern Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Kentucky, Tennessee, eastern Arkansas and northwestern Mississippi. Rain changed to snow at higher elevations of the central Appalachians. Snow also was scattered over northwestern New York state, eastern and northern Lower Michigan and eastern Upper Michigan, Scattered showers fell over the central Texas coast, northwestern and west-central Texas, central New Mexico, and along the southern coast of California. Snow was scattered over the mountains of northwestern Arizona. Light rain also fell along the northern Pacific Coast. Freezing rain was scattered from southeastern Wyoming into north-central Colorado. Winds stronger than 90 mph plowed across central Oklahoma overnight, uprooting trees, damaging buildings and knocking out power to about 45,000 people. No injuries were reported. Most power was restored to customers Tuesday morning, said Dave Raybern, media relations spokesman for Oklahoma Gas & Electric. A 92-mph gust at Will Rogers Airport in Oklahoma City was the strongest on record there, the National Weather Service said. Hail 2{ inches in diameter fell in Chandler, Okla. Overnight thunderstorms accompanied by high wind and large hail also knocked out some windows and damaged some roofs in northwestern Arkansas, the weather service said. Some areas got more than 2 inches of rain. ``We don't have any reports of injuries, but there has been lots of property damage,'' said police Cpl. Mark Howell of Rogers, Ark. ``I can confirm that there are some roofs blown off businesses, some neon signs have been blown away and a tree was blown over on a residence.'' In Arkansas, hail the size of golf balls hammered Bella Vista, Lincoln, West Fork, Prairie Grove and an area just west of Huntsville, the weather service said. A 10-minute spurt of three-quarter-inch hail covered the ground in Bentonville. In Utah, wind gusted during the night from 70 to 90 mph over Davis and Weber counties, and to 60 mph across Cache and Box Elder counties. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 23 degrees at the Air Force Academy at Colorado Springs, Colo., to 89 at Avon Park, Fla. Tuesday's low in the Lower 48 states was the record 10 degrees at Valentine, Neb.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Assassinate Ex-Social Security Minister, Dump Body on Beach
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to indicate shooting occurred Tuesday, ADDS killing of three rural officials Monday, that Aprista Party is left of center.
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas on Tuesday shot to death the former director of the Peruvian Social Security Institute and dumped his body on a beach 20 miles south of Lima, police said. Officials said Felipe Santiago Salaverry's body, riddled with four shots, was found near a sports club on the beach. Leaflets found near Salaverry's body indicated he was killed by the Shining Path, a radical Maoist-inspired guerrilla group that began its insurgency 10 years ago in the Andean highlands. More than 18,000 people have been killed since their uprising began, most in the mountains but more recently in Lima. Last year, as chief of the government's Social Security Institute, Salaverry successfully faced down dozens of retirees demonstrating for hikes in their social security payments. A member of the governing left-of-center Aprista Party, Salaverry was a congressman from the northern Andean department of Cajamarca from 1980-85. Before dawn Monday, Shining Path guerrillas also killed three rural officials in an attack near Cuzco, 355 miles southeast of the capital Lima, police said. Police said the rebels seized control of Laio, 55 miles southeast of Cuzco, and forced villagers to witness a mock trial of the mayor, the justice of peace and the district governor, a representative of the central government. The guerrillas then shot the men in the back of the head. In other violence, a former Aprista mayor of Chiquian was shot to death by Shining Path guerrillas Monday night. Chiquian, in Ancash department, is 130 miles north of the Lima.

DOC.HEAD: University of Portland Names President
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. David T. Tyson, vice president of student affairs at the University of Notre Dame, was named Tuesday as the 18th president of the University of Portland. Tyson, 41, has been vice president at Notre Dame since 1984. He previously served as executive assistant to then-president Rev. Theodore Hesburgh. Tyson has a bachelor's degree in sociology, a master's degree in theology and a doctorate in higher education administration. He has served on the Notre Dame faculty since 1980. Tyson will succeed the Rev. Thomas Oddo, who died in an auto accident last October. Oddo had been president of the Roman Catholic university since 1983. Arthur Schulte Jr., acting president at the University of Portland since October, will resume his position as executive and financial vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Seeks Bank Records in Suspected Drug Laundering
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf: ``The order,'' to include reference to Escobar, SUBS 5th graf: ``The department also,'' with one graf bgng: ``Based on,'' to CORRECT that department plans to seek, sted sought, additional court orders in Miami and New York, SUBS 17th graf: ``The accounts,'' to CORRECT that child's name appeared in Panamanian sted U.S. bank records
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Drug Assets-List
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department disclosed Tuesday it won a court order for records of 754 U.S. bank accounts where it said Colombia's Medellin cartel stashed $400 million from cocaine sales on American streets The action marks the first time that federal authorities traced ``dollar for dollar'' drug money from U.S. street sales that was laundered through foreign accounts and returned to American banks, officials said. The department obtained a court order in Atlanta directing 173 banks in 22 states and the nation's capital to turn over the records that officials said could yield a wealth of financial information about the cartel. The order signed Monday by a federal judge in Atlanta also directed banks to freeze 684 accounts linked to Eduardo Martinez Romero, who was extradited in September to face charges he laundered drug money for the cartel, or others charged in the case, including reputed cartel leader Pablo Escobar. Based on information contained in the records, the Justice Department plans to seek similar court orders in Miami and New York against other accounts, officials said. The legal action is likely to produce more information than money, but should help investigators continue their pursuit along the global money trail left by the cocaine dealers, said Peter G. Djinis, a Justice Department trial attorney. ``We think this is going to point fingers in a lot of directions,'' he said. ``We're getting closer and we'll eventually catch up'' to the money. Agents for the Drug Enforcement Administration, the Internal Revenue Service and the U.S. Customs Service participating in the long-running ``Operation Polar Cap'' probe of the Colombian cartel traced the money through eight foreign countries. The investigation determined that the cartel amassed $1.2 billion from selling cocaine in the United States between 1987 and early 1989. The funds were deposited in American banks and transferred overseas. Some of the money was invested in foreign countries or used to buy equipment and supplies for cocaine production, officials said. An estimated $350 million was wired back to U.S. banks and deposited with $50 million that was left behind. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said the department's action ``seeks to lift the veil of secrecy over the financial network of these narco-terrorists.'' Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said the money was traced through banks in Colombia, Panama, Uruguay, Luxembourg, Switzerland, Britain, Canada and Austria. The review of the bank records, obtained with the cooperation of the foreign countries, began almost a year ago, officials said. In Miami, U.S. Customs Commissioner Carol Hallett said the bank accounts could not have been traced without the help of Panama. ``We have been working very closely with the government of Panama,'' she said. Djinis said officials don't know how much of the $400 million is still in the accounts. The records could also confirm suspicions that the cartel bought U.S. real estate, he said. The accounts were listed under the names of Martinez or other people, Djinis said. The 2-year-old son of a cartel member was listed as the holder of a Panamanian bank account, officials said. The cartel needed money in American bank accounts ``to keep up the payroll'' and buy such equipment as aircraft for the shipment of cocaine, Djinis said. ``The only way to administer these activities is to have ongoing capital in the U.S,'' he said. In one case, money was drawn from an account to buy an American-made airplane, which was flown to Colombia to pick up a load of cocaine. The plane made a crash landing in Canada with its cargo intact, Djinis said. ``We are not at this time suggesting the banks had knowledge and were knowing and willing participants in the return of the funds to the U.S.'' Djinis said. But ``we are not ruling out anything.'' Bank officials suspicious of the large cash deposits reported their concerns to federal law enforcement authorities, Djinis said. The investigation is only one of a number of large-scale probes of money laundering, said a law enforcement official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The official said there are as many as 10 other investigations under way.

DOC.HEAD: Lava Flow Threatens More Homes
DOC.TEXT: A lava flow from Kilauea Volcano has re-entered a rural subdivision and was threatening Tuesday to take more homes in its path, authorities said. The lava was building up early Tuesday against a 4-foot-high stone wall at the boundary of a vacant lot in the Kalapana Gardens subdivision, according to Hawaii County Civil Defense spokesman Bruce Butts. A house which escaped being overrun by another flow on April 2 is just 80 yards on the other side of the wall, Butts said. If the flow continues, the house probably will be destroyed, after the lava spills over the wall, he said. Another house sits about 50 or 60 yards from the nearest house, and four or five others are in the vicinity, he said. About 25 or 30 families were ordered to evacuate. Residents of remaining homes in the subdivision remain on alert. Lava flows have destroyed 80 homes and caused more than $20 million in damage since the eruption began more than seven years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands More Join Striking Teachers
DOC.TEXT: Oklahoma's teacher strike spread Tuesday with thousands more planning to join later in the week, and teachers continued to picket the state Capitol demanding increased funding for education. At least one school board voted to close schools to allow its teachers to join the protest. About 60 percent of the state's teachers, or about 20,000, were of the job on the second day of the strike, said the Oklahoma Education Association, the teacher union that called for the walkout. That was up from about 16,000 Monday. ``We think it's growing,'' said Sandy Garrett, education secretary in Gov. Henry Bellmon's Cabinet. ``We're hearing from more and more schools that are going to be closed the rest of the week.'' Ms. Garrett estimated that the walkout had affected about 60 percent, or 343,200, of the state's 572,000 students. Teachers are venting their frustration over the Legislature's failure after an eight-month special session to enact a $230 million school reform and tax plan that contains funds for increased teacher salaries. The education package calls for raising the money by increasing sales and personal and corporate income taxes. It mandates $1,500-per-year increases in teachers' minimum salary schedules over the next four years, eventually boosting that from the present $15,000 a year to about $24,000. The OEA says Oklahoma teachers rank 48th in teacher pay among the states, making an average $22,000 a year, far less than the national average of $29,648. Officials in Oklahoma City and other municipalities not yet participating in the walkout decided Tuesday to close schools later in the week to allow their teachers to join those on the picket lines. The Oklahoma City School Board voted to use one of its ``snow days'' on Thursday to allow the closing of schools. Oklahoma City has about 2,200 teachers. That announcement brought a round of cheers from those picketing at the Capitol. The majority of Oklahoma City teachers are not affiliated with the OEA and officials of their union, the American Federation of Teachers, initially balked at joining the walkout. In Tulsa, Superintendent Bruce Howell canceled schools for the rest of the week because of the prospects of ``an emergency jeopardizing the health and safety of children.'' A decision had been made earlier to close Tulsa schools only on Monday and Tuesday. But Howell said about 80 percent of teachers indicated they would not be in class Wednesday. Officials estimated that 8,000 to 10,000 people walked picket lines at the Capitol on Tuesday. Karla Feeley, OEA communications director and a spokeswoman for the Department of Education, estimated there were 35,000 non-supervisory teachers in the state. The education agency said an earlier figure of 40,052 teachers includedsome principals and other school personnel. The OEA says it represents about 31,000 teachers. The education bill stalled on the Senate calendar last week when leaders were unable to get the two-thirds majority needed to attach an emergency clause, which would have made the measure take effect immediately. Senate President Pro Tempore Bob Cullison said there were discussions in Tulsa over the weekend on a possible alternate tax package more legislators might support. But he said there was no firm indication the deadlock can be broken.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Says He Will Present Minority Government Next Week
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres said Tuesday he will present a minority government for parliamentary approval next week, Israel television reported. Last week, Peres tried to present a majority government but his efforts collapsed when two last-minute defections from an ultra-Orthodox party prevented him from securing the necessary 61 votes in the 120-member parliament. Under Israeli law, Peres can form a government with less than 61 seats if his party has the support of more legislators than any other coalition and no party can muster a majority. Peres did not say which other parties would join his government _ every Israeli government since its founding in 1948 has been a coalition _ or how many seats it would have. Israel's two major parties, Peres' left-leaning Labor and acting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud, each have the support of almost 60 legislators. But their ability to produce a majority has depended on small religious parties and defectors who have proven unstable in their support. Peres' statement comes almost a month after he was designated by President Chaim Herzog to form Israel's next government. Peres said he will still trying to form a majority government. Both Peres and Shamir have been placing their hopes on the support of the ultra-Orthodox Shas, or Sephardic Torah Guardian, party, which has now become a powerbroker of sorts with its five members in parliament. The spiritual mentor of Shas, Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, is scheduled to meet with both Peres and Shamir on Wednesday to decide which party he will recommend supporting, the television said. Peres has been trying to put together a coalition with left-wing, Arab and ultra-Orthodox parties since Labor engineered the collapse of the national unity government on March 15 after the Likud refused to accept a U.S. peace proposal. On March 20, Herzog gave him three weeks to form a new government, but Peres was granted a two-week extension when his efforts collapsed.

DOC.HEAD: Sean Connery Defies Physician, Chats With Royals
DOC.TEXT: Sean Connery defied his doctor's orders Tuesday and engaged in some small talk with Prince Charles and Princess Diana. The 59-year-old star of James Bond thrillers and Oscar award-winner for ``The Untouchables'' is recovering from surgery on his vocal chords and had been ordered to maintain absolute silence. But at the premiere of his new film, ``The Hunt for Red October,'' Connery chatted and joked with the heir to the British throne and his wife and gave the couple presents for their sons, Princes William and Harry. ``I feel fine,'' said the Scottish-born actor. ``I have had a checkup and everything was in order.''

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Against Barney Frank
DOC.TEXT: A District of Columbia judge has dismissed a lawsuit against Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., alleging that Frank's relationship with a male prostitute amounted to a public nuisance, Frank's office said Tuesday. The suit alleged that Frank was aware his Capitol Hill apartment was being used by Stephen Gobie for his prostitution business. Superior Court Judge Harold Cushenberry dismissed the suit on the grounds that the plaintiffs had no right to bring it and that any alleged nuisance was clearly not continuing. The one-page decision, dated April 10, was released by Frank's office Tuesday as Frank, in Boston, was announcing his candidacy for a sixth term. The suit was filed two ministers of Washington churches, the Rev. Cleveland B. Sparrow Sr. and the Rev. John G. Martin. It was financially backed by the Conservative Caucus, which has long opposed many of Frank's liberal views. John F. Banzhaf III, a law professor at George Washington University and a legal gadfly who has pressed a number of high-profile cases in Washington, helped prepare it. Frank has admitted paying Gobie for sexual favors and hiring him as a personal aide. Attorneys for Frank argued that Frank was unaware of Gobie's prostitution business; that Frank fired Gobie as soon as he found out; that Frank no longer lived in the Capitol Hill apartment and that the plaintiffs lacked legal standing to sue Frank. In his one-page order, Cushenberry wrote that he ``concluded that an ongoing statutory violation is required'' to seek an injunction against Frank blocking the alleged nuisance and that the plaintiffs ``have failed to allege the `special damage' that must be pleaded in order for a private party to prosecute a public nuisance claim.'' Banzhaf tried an unusual legal tactic in which, technically, the suit was being brought by the United States government. ``What I tried to do was use a very unusual and heretofore untested statute to deal with an unusual situation,'' Banzhaf said. ``In that area, it's very difficult to predict what the court will do and it's not unusual not to win.'' Banzhaff has said he would explore other avenues to bring a case against Frank.

DOC.HEAD: Bride Sentenced for Stealing Her Wedding Dress
DOC.TEXT: A bride who wore a stolen gown and hat to her wedding was sentenced to 30 days in jail and ordered to pay for the dress, officials said. Theresa Knight, 20, of Oelwein was sentenced Monday to pay court costs and $482 to the bridal shop for the dress. She also was given a 150-day suspended sentence. The gown was taken from a bridal shop in this northeastern Iowa town during the busy Christmas shopping season, police said.

DOC.HEAD: President Mourns Abernathy Death
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Tuesday night he and his wife mourned the death of the Rev. Ralph Abernathy, whome he called a ``tireless campaigner for justice.'' Here is the text of the president's statement.

Barbara and I were deeply saddened to learn of the death of the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy. In recalling Ralph Abernathy's life, we inevitably recall the great campaigns for civil rights for black Americans in which he played such a significant part. From his father's farm in Alabama, he joined the ministry and became pastor of the First Baptist Church in Montgomery. Responding to Rosa Parks' refusal to sit in the back of a segregated bus, he and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., began the Montgomery Improvement Association to insure the success of the boycott which led in turn to the desegregation of buses in that city. Later, he and Dr. King organized the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, of which he originally served as secretary-treasurer. Throughout, Rev. Abernathy was committed to the principle of non-violence. As he said, ``Violence is the weapon of the weak, and non-violence is the weapon of the strong.'' Barbara and I join with all Americans to mourn the passing of the Rev. Ralph Abernathy, a great leader in the struggle for civil rights for all Americans and a tireless campaigner for justice.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania: Oil, Gas Cutbacks to Begin Wednesday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with energy minister says oil and gas cutbacks expected early Wednesday, quotes, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos VIL1,2
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian officials expect Moscow to begin cutbacks of oil and natural gas supplies early Wednesday to enforce Mikhail S. Gorbachev's threatened economic embargo on the wayward republic, local sources said. Lithuanian Energy Minister Leonas Asmantas told a news conference late Tuesday the republic received unofficial information crude oil supplies would be reduced about 7 a.m. Wednesday (Tuesday midnight EDT) and that natural gas supplies would be scaled back too, said official spokesmen and Western journalists on the scene. Asmantas was quoted as saying gas supplies might be cut 50 percent. Premier Kazimiera Prunskiene told Lithuanians to view the move as the ``beginning of liberty,'' because it signified Moscow's recognition of Lithuania as a separate entity from the Soviet Union, said one Western journalist, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mrs. Prunskiene said Lithuania had been contacted by U.S. and Canadian petroleum companies who ``are inclined to come to our rescue,'' but did not specify which companies or how they could deliver supplies. Asmantas said he had no official word, but believed _ based on Moscow sources _ that the cuts would occur imminently. Worried Lithuanians flooded the government in Vilnius with phone calls Tuesday. Last Friday, Gorbachev threatened to impose an embargo of key goods and raw materials unless Lithuania rescinded within 48 hours several laws meant to back up its March 11 declaration of independence. Moscow would demand hard currency from Lithuania for supplies of materials the Soviet Union sells abroad for convertible currency, the Soviet president said. Oil and gas are the Soviet Union's biggest earners of foreign currency. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis on Tuesday called the republic's decisions ``irreversible'' and said an economic embargo will only strengthen the resolve of the 3.8 million Lithuanians. ``I hope it will consolidate our people in our peaceful struggle,'' Landsbergis said in a broadcast interview. Lithuanian gas officials received a telegram from the acting general director of the Soviet Union's western gas network saying: ``Implementing the orders of the government of the Soviet Union and those of the state gas concern ... supplies of natural gas to the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic will be sharply reduced from the 17th of Apri.'' Sources in the capital, Vilnius, said the republic was receiving its full supply of natural gas late Tuesday night. However, the Western journalist quoted gas officials as saying they regarded the telegram received late Monday as 24-hour advance notice the supply would be reduced, and they expected a cut to begin overnight. Nearly all Western journalists were forced by the Soviet government to leave Lithuania last month, though a few remain. Lithuanian officials are discussing shifting some oil and gas from industrial production to use in homes and hospitals if the cuts occur, but so far have not publicly discussed a conservation program. Lithuania uses 18.5 million cubic meters of natural gas a day, including 1.1 million cubic meters for homes. President Bush said in Washington the United States was considering ``appropriate responses'' if supplies are cut. But he also said he does not want to damage superpower relations. Italy's foreign minister, Gianni De Michelis, met Gorbachev on Tuesday and quoted him as saying he had to uphold the Soviet constitution but was still looking for a peaceful way out of the dispute ``without abrupt moves.'' De Michelis told Italian journalists that Gorbachev complained the Lithuanians discussed a law on the republic's official language for six months, but debated independence for only half a night. At the United Nations in New York, Nadia Younes, the spokeswoman for Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, said Tuesday he considers the Lithuanian issue to be ``strictly an internal affair'' of the Soviet Union. Hundreds of Bulgarian protesters chanted ``Leave Lithuania alone!'' as they rallied Tuesday in front of the Soviet Embassy in Sofia, the Bulgarian capital, in the first anti-Soviet protest there in memory. Gorbachev says Lithuanian independence can be discussed only within the framework of Soviet law. A law passed this month would let republics secede if they gain approval of two-thirds of their residents in a referendum and wait a maximum of five years. The Kremlin forcibly annexed Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia in 1940. Tass news agency quoted Landsbergis as saying, in opening Tuesday's discussion in the Lithuanian Supreme Council legislature, that Lithuania's pro-independence moves were ``irreversible,'' but that the republic ``will search for a dialogue by all possible means, through various channels.'' Landsbergis asked Bush to make it clear to Gorbachev an economic embargo on Lithuania would be an act of aggression, but he declined to say if he thought Bush should cancel a planned Washington summit with Gorbachev in June. In a Tuesday interview from Vilnius with Cable News Network, Landsbergis also said he expects to receive supplies from neighboring Soviet republics and even from Scandinavia, but was worried the Soviet navy may interfere. Speaker Alexandras Abisalas read the gas supply telegram to Lithuanian lawmakers, who met to discuss a response to Gorbachev's ultimatum. Tass said Gorbachev's message caused a sharp legislative debate between deputies who found it full of threats and others who want to compromise. No decision was reached Tuesday on an official response. The agency quoted Landsbergis as saying an embargo on Lithuania would result in economic losses for other Soviet republics. Lithuania produces about twice the milk and meat it needs. It produces many of the country's small electronic appliances and all of its household electric meters. Lithuanian journalists quoted officials as saying Monday that the republic had enough natural gas to last about two weeks. The officials warned that an embargo would throw ethnic Russian factory workers out of work and affect the Kaliningrad area of the Russian republic as well. Viktoras Barmuskas, a spokesman for the information bureau of the Supreme Council legislature, quoted Energy Minister Asmantas as saying Lithuania's oil refinery at Mazhiekiai would be entitled to demand compensation in hard currency for lost production. Asmantas said the plant produces 12 million tons of oil products a year valued at $800 million, with only a quarter of the output used in Lithuania and the rest sent to other parts of the Soviet Union.. On Monday, Mrs. Prunskiene sent a reply to Gorbachev, asking for a meeting to clarify the threat of an economic blockade. In his message, Gorbachev had singled out Lithuanian moves to curtail the spring draft into the Soviet Army, give residents Lithuanian identity cards and what he said were seize the property of the Communist Party on Lithuanian territory.

DOC.HEAD: Crowd Marks Six Months Since Quake
LaserPhoto FX3
DOC.TEXT: A small crowd turned out for a rally Tuesday to mark the six months that have passed since an earthquake battered the San Francisco Bay area, leaving 68 people dead. About 150 people gathered a few yards from the ruined Embarcadero Freeway and mingled around tables with displays on earthquake safety. ``You've got to have a foot-long wrench to shut down the gas meter when an earthquake hits,'' a hard-hatted Pacific Gas & Electric Co. worker explained to an elderly woman. The event marked the 15 seconds of terror that struck at 5:04 p.m. on Oct. 17.
