In addition to the toll on lives, the earthquake, centered 80 miles to the south, destroyed or damaged about 15,000 homes and left the Embarcadero Freeway, sometimes called the Chinatown Freeway, cracked and useless. The city has tentatively voted in favor of tearing down the freeway. In one terrible crash of steel and concrete, an elevated section of Interstate 880 in Oakland collapsed, killing 42 people. A mile away, a 50-foot section of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge collapsed, bringing chaos to the entire bay freeway system for a month. On Tuesday, volunteers handed out pamphlets and disaster checklists, and showed pictures of the destruction from San Francisco south to Watsonville. They explained what people could do when the next earthquake strikes. The St. Francis Hook & Ladder Society, a club for firefighting buffs, proudly displayed a long-retired, 30-year-old pumper truck that was pressed into duty the night of the disaster. ``We actually jump-started this rig, loaded some hoses and stuff and fought fires and made calls for two days starting October 17,'' said city firefighter Steve Van Dyke.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Recommends Namibia U.N. Membership
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council unanimously recommended Tuesday that Namibia become the United Nations' 160th member. ``Namibia's birth has been protracted and difficult,'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering told the council. ``But it now appears that the star under which she comes into the world shines brightly.'' The Republic of Namibia will be formally admitted when the General Assembly votes Monday at the opening of a special session to promote economic growth in the developing world. Its membership is expected to be accepted by acclamation and Namibia will take its seat and participate Monday in the special session. Namibia, Africa's last colony, won its freedom from South Africa last month. The United Nations made Namibia's freedom a major cause for many years and monitored its transition to independence and its free elections. Security Council President Tesfaye Tadesse, the Ethiopian ambassador, said Namibia's admission will be a milestone in African history and the culmination of decades of work by the United Nations. ``Namibia's admission will be a tribute to the courage and sacrifice of the Namibian people. They have waged a long struggle for self-determination and independence,'' he said. Nations are admitted to the United Nations upon recommendation by the 15-member Security Council and a two-thirds vote by the General Assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor Moved by Ambulance to Medical Center
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from Miss Taylor dispelling rumors that she has AIDS and doctor's diagnosis of pneumonia; picks up 11th graf pvs, `Miss Taylor's...'
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor, hospitalized for a week with a persistent fever and sinus infection, has been transferred by ambulance to a larger hospital for treatment of pneumonia, her doctor said Tuesday. ``I would like to dispel the plethora of rumors that have been circulating that I have an AIDS-related condition,'' Miss Taylor, 58, said in a statement released by her New York City-based publicist, Chen Sam. ``I feel it is important that people should not be afraid to be tested for AIDS. ``I have an annual physical and have been tested for the disease and the test results are negative,'' Miss Taylor said. The actress entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 10 for what was reported as ``a severe sinus infection.'' She was expected to be released Saturday, but her condition worsened and she was moved Monday to St. John's Hospital and Health Center five miles away. ``In conducting further tests on Elizabeth Taylor, her results reveal her to be suffering from pneumonia,'' Miss Taylor's physician, Dr. Patricia Murray, said in the same statement. ``She is currently being treated intravenously with antibiotics and will remain hospitalized,'' said Murray, an infectious disease specialist. Miss Taylor's whereabouts had been a mystery for several days. She is registered at St. John's under the favored alias of ``Beth Warner.'' Her most recent husband was Sen. John Warner, R-Va. Miss Taylor has been plagued with health problems for years, particularly recurring back troubles from the filming of the 1945 movie ``National Velvet,'' when she fell off a horse. In 1983, Miss Taylor entered the Betty Ford Clinic in Rancho Mirage to deal with alcohol and drug abuse problems.

DOC.HEAD: Two Pioneers in Modern Physical Chemistry Share Welch Award
DOC.TEXT: A pioneer in physical organic chemistry from Harvard University and another from the California Institute of Technology will share the 1990 Welch Award in Chemistry and a $250,000 prize, a foundation announced Tuesday. William von Eggers Doering, 72, of Harvard and John D. Roberts, 71, of Caltech are the first pair to receive the honor presented annually since 1972 to a major figure in chemistry. ``These two men have been primary intellectual forces over more than four decades in a development that represents one of the great advances in the history of science _ the creation of modern physical organic chemistry,'' said Jack S. Josey, president of the Houston-based Welch Foundation. Each man will be presented with a gold medal and his $125,000 share of the prize at a Houston banquet Oct. 22. Doering, a Fort Worth native, is a professor emeritus of chemistry at Harvard, where he has been a professor since 1967. He is known by contemporary chemists for his work on how hydrocarbon molecules change under various conditions, particularly different temperatures. Roberts, a Log Angeles native, is institute professor emeritus of chemistry at Caltech. He is best known for pioneering the use of nuclear magnetic resonance techniques to analyze the structure of chemical compounds. His NMR technique is considered one of the most widely used tools in chemistry today and was the forerunner of magnetic resonance imaging in medicine.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Order to Evict Jewish Settlers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with District Court rejecting second appeal, ordering eviction, 23 wounded in Gaza, CLARIFIES that demonstration not in reaction to court decision. EDITS to TRIM
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto JRL3, JRL4
DOC.TEXT: A Jerusalem District Court panel on Tuesday upheld an order to evict 150 Jewish settlers whose move into the Arab Christian quarter of the Old City has fueled anti-Israeli protests. The settlers immediately appealed the decision, but it was rejected by the same District Court in a hearing before a single judge. In that hearing, Judge Ruth Orr ordered the settlers to evacuate the building by Wednesday morning, army radio said. Jerusalem Police spokesman Uzi Sandori said police were studying the court decision. The settlers said they plan to appeal the eviction order to the Supreme Court. They also said they would not resist police attempts to evict them. ``Of course we will not resist the police,'' said one settler who identified himself as Doki. ``But there is no reason for them to come tomorrow.'' Early Tuesday, a three-judge panel of the District Court conferred nearly four hours behind closed doors before issuing a ruling that accused the settlers' lawyers of ``an improper use of procedures, to say the least'' The judges ruled that a stay of the eviction notice granted Friday by a single District Court judge was improperly obtained. ``We invalidate it,'' the judges wrote. They took the unusual step of assessing court costs of $5,000 to the settlers' lawyers, apparently for attempting to thwart the Israeli legal system. Judge Vardimus Zailer presided over the three-judge panel, which also included Judge Shalom Brenner, who on Friday stayed the eviction order. The ruling said the settlers' lawyers, in asking Brenner for a stay, had failed to mention another judge turned down a separate request for a stay hours earlier. ``The judges have canceled the stay. They (the settlers) must be evicted,'' said Avraham Sochozolsky, a lawyer for the Greek Orthodox Church. Yacov Levine, a spokesman for the settlers group, said their lawyers sought a new District Court hearing late Tuesday to argue that the building was rented legally. At that five-hour hearing, Judge Orr rejected the settler appeal and ordered their eviction. The settler move into the complex has raised tensions in the old walled city, which is divided into ethnic quarters that are home to about 50,000 Moslems, 7,000 Christians and 4,000 Jews. Early Tuesday, several dozen Palestinian women and masked youths demonstrated inside the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, venerated as the site of Christ's burial and regarded by many as Christianity's holiest shrine. Visiting pilgrims and tourists stared as 40 to 50 protesters waved Palestinian flags and chanted ``PLO! PLO!'' and ``Israel no! Palestine yes!'' inside the dark church. It was the first time Arabs had staged a protest inside the church since the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip began 28 months ago. A week ago, the ultra-Orthodox Jews moved into a 72-room complex near the church under heavy police guard, saying they wanted to establish the first Jewish presence in the Christian Quarter since 1936. The Greek Orthodox Church, which owns the property, said a tenant in the four 100-year-old buildings illegally worked out a lease with the Jews. The church sued to have the Jewish settlers removed. The establishment of Neot David, which is Hebrew for ``Dwellings of David,'' was the largest and most significant settlement of Jews outside the Jewish quarter. Previously, two Jewish seminaries were set up in the Moslem Quarter and about 40 Jewish families took up residence in the area, including former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon. Sharon has visited Neot David daily to show support for the settlement. In a visit to the settlement and Greek Orthodox Church headquarters Tuesday, Religious Affairs Minister Zevulen Hammer urged both Christians and Jews ``not to blow things out of proportion.'' ``They (the settlers) did not take over some church and did not throw someone out of some place but used a site that was a hotel ... that happens to be in the Christian quarter,'' he said. In the occupied Gaza Strip Tuesday, Israeli troops opened fire on stone-throwing demonstrators, wounding 23 Palestinians, hospital officials said. The army confirmed 21 of the wounded. Since the start of the uprising, at least 673 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. Another 207 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israel, and 43 Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Church Leader Says High Court Ruling Shows Misunderstanding of Indians
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Indian church leader said Tuesday the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling that peyote use in religious ceremonies isn't protected by the Constitution is an example of how little society understands Indians. Peyote is not a recreational drug used by participants to get high, said Emerson Jackson, a peyote priest and president of the Native American Church of North America. ``We have been doing this all these years before the Constitution was here. I don't see why we can't continue,'' he said in a telephone interview from Albuquerque, N.M. The high court ruled 6-3 that Oregon officials may deny unemployment benefits to two fired drug counselors who took small amounts of peyote, a cactus ``button'' containing the hallucinogen mescaline, in Indian religious ceremonies. Alfred Smith and Galen Black were denied the benefits because they violated their employers' rules by using the illegal drug in Native American Church ceremonies. Oregon Attorney General Dave Frohnmayer said the ruling involved whether the men were entitled to a government benefit, not whether they'd committed a crime. Frohnmayer said the court was making it clear that in terms of religious freedom, the Constitution ``is written in terms of what the government cannot do to the individual, not in terms of what individuals can extract from government.'' ``The court said the state is not compelled to make exemptions for religious use of drugs but said it could if it wished,'' he said. ``We have always insisted the state is not required to pay people for using illegal substances no matter what their religious beliefs might be.'' Jackson said that wine, used as a sacrament in many religious ceremonies, is more toxic habit-forming than peyote. Jackson, a Navajo Indian, also said he is waiting for a change of administration in Oregon so that a centuries-old ritual can continue. ``This is just the beginning,'' he said. ``Perhaps there will be a time when their administration will be more favorable to how the Indian worships. The attorney general is not going to stay there forever.'' Lenora Begay, spokeswoman for the Navajo Tribe in Washington, D.C., denounced the ruling. ``To punish individuals because of their religious beliefs is beyond comprehension and ... an act of extreme ignorance,'' she said. Ellen Lowe, spokeswoman for Ecumenical Ministries of Oregon, said the ministries disagreed with the court's ruling. ``We see it as an infringement on what we have long felt to be First Amendment rights for freedom of religion,'' she said. ``For those of us in majority faiths, there are some exceptions we have taken for granted.'' She cited serving wine to minors during church ceremonies as an example. The Native American Church is an umbrella group for 70 chapters of the church in Western states.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Rioters Reportedly Using Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Officials believe the seven rioters holding out at Strangeways Prison are using drugs from the jail pharmacy, a Home Office spokesman said Tuesday. One convict nearly fell off the roof Tuesday, 17th day of the uprising, as he shouted and lobbed slates at a security video camera mounted on a wall below. ``Judging by his face and eyes, he seems to have been using drugs. And he was standing there pretending to inject himself,'' said the spokesman, who was not identified in keeping with British custom. He said the inmates controlled the pharmacy, but never had the prison hospital, where most of the prison's drugs are stored. The spokesman said no negotiations have taken place since three prisoners surrendered Monday, suffering from food poisoning. There have been no fresh supplies in the Victorian jail since the mutiny began on April 1. More than 1,500 prisoners rioted at the overcrowded prison, badly damaging the buildings. Most surrendered in the first days but a hard core remained on the loose. On Sunday, prisoners held up a sign saying they would continue their standoff for another week. Inmates stockpiled food before the riot but there is no refrigeration in the wing they are occupying.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Dissident Says Underground Resistence Includes Soldiers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Chai Ling comments on resistance, freedom, CORRECTS name of dissident organization. Picks up 7th pvs, `According to...'
DOC.TEXT: The Chinese student dissident leader who fled to France after 10 months in hiding said Tuesday that underground resistance groups exist throughout China and include soldiers and government workers. Chai Ling and her husband, Feng Congde, escaped three weeks ago from China, where they had been on the run from authorities. Both were on the wanted list of 21 students who led demonstrations last spring for greater political freedom. In an interview Tuesday with the French television network TF1, Miss Chai said the Chinese underground spirited them out of the country to safety in the West. She declined to give details. ``We can say there exist in China a certain number of resistance organizations, some bigger and more important than others,'' said Miss Chai, speaking in Chinese translated into French. ``Certain ones are formed by students, by workers, by intellectuals,'' she said. ``In some of these groups you'll find soldiers, members of the government and cadres.'' Miss Chai, who turned 24 Saturday, wore a blue sweater and showed no sign of the fatigue apparent in an interview broadcast by a Taiwan television station April 2. ``I didn't celebrate by birthday, but I have really tasted liberty'' since arriving in Paris, she said. ``Many of my colleagues will not taste this freedom. That makes me very sad.'' Miss Chai, a graduate student at Beijing Normal University when she in effect took over the student-led democracy movement in Beijing last June, will give her first public news conference Wednesday at the Arche de la Defense, the ultramodern skyscraper outside Paris. Earlier Tuesday, organizers announced they are planning rock concerts in Paris, New York, Hong Kong, Taipei, Prague and Sao Paulo on June 3 to commemorate the anniversary of the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing. The concerts were announced at a news conference called by the Front for a Democratic China, a Paris-based dissident group, and by the French news magazine Actuel. They said some top musicians would record a special version of John Lennon's song ``Imagine'' in conjunction with the anniversary. No further details were disclosed. The federation and the magazine are among the sponsors of ``A Boat for China,'' which is sending a radio-equipped ship to the Far East to transmit pro-democracy broadcasts into China. Representatives of the federation and the magazine repeated claims first made Monday that the ship has been the target of surveillance and harassment by Chinese officials since it left France a month ago. According to the sponsors, the 260-foot Goddess of Democracy is now heading across the Indian Ocean to Singapore after being held up in Djibouti, on the Horn of Africa, for 10 days. The 1,200-ton ship _ a former British oceanographic vessel _ is equipped with two radio studios and a television studio. Its crew hopes to begin broadcasting music and news into China from international waters by the end of April. Chinese diplomats have formally protested to the French government about the boat, but were told there was no official French involvement in the project. France rejected a Chinese request to restrict news coverage of the operation. Robert Menard, a spokesman for a press freedom advocacy group called Reporters Without Borders, said Tuesday that Chinese officials had threatened to deny visas to some French television journalists if they reported about the radio ship. But FR-3, one of the TV channels mentioned by Menard, said it had received no such threats.

The Justice Department told the Supreme Court Tuesday that a 1989 federal law banning flag burning is constitutional because it outlaws ``violent assault'' on the symbol of the nation's ``shared experiences.'' Unlike a Texas flag-burning statute that the high court overturned last year, the Flag Protection Act of 1989 expresses ``the depth of the national interest in protecting the flag'' the department said in brief supporting the new statute. The law, passed in response to the high court's ruling in the Texas case, represents ``the considered judgment of Congress _ as opposed to that of a single state legislature,'' the department argued. ``Congress, the president _ the nation's elected representatives _ have now spoken with one voice: the physical integrity of the flag of the United States, as the unique symbol of the nation, merits protection not accorded other national emblems,'' the department said. In deciding whether the law is constitutional, the justices should consider that Congress also studied this question, making a ``legislative determination that the American flag is a unique national symbol deserving special protection consistent with applicable First Amendment limitations.'' The government's brief was filed to appeal the dismissal of misdemeanor criminal charges against demonstrators who burned flags outside the U.S. Capitol and in Seattle last fall to test the new law. The previous federal statute banned destruction of or damage to the flag ``with contempt,'' similar to the provision in a Texas statute found unconstitutional on free-speech grounds by the Supreme Court. The new law simply dropped any reference to the state of mind of the person doing the action. Nonetheless, federal judges in the District of Columbia and in Seattle held that flag burning under the new law was still political speech protected by the First Amendment. ``Flag burning is, by its nature, a physical, violent assault on the most deeply shared experiences of the American people, including the sacrifices of our fellow citizens in defense of the nation and the preservation of liberty,'' the department said in the brief by Solicitor General Kenneth W. Starr. The law does not violate the First Amendment because it does not restrict debate about the flag; it merely prohibits physical attacks on the national symbol, the department said. ``It is the physical assault and accompanying violation of the flag's physical integrity _ not robust and uninhibited debate _ that occasion the injury that our society should not be called upon to bear,'' the brief said. The high court should treat flag burning the same way it views obscene or defamatory speech, the Justice Department said, citing a list of cases in which the high court upheld prohibitions on child pornography or speech that incited violence or illegal activity.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 11th graf bgng: ``I know xxx to UPDATE with later comments by U.S. and Europeans.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Wants Global-Change Studies; Europeans Call for Action
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called for more research ``to sort out the science'' of global warming Tuesday, but ran into a storm of criticism at an international White House conference from Europeans who argued for action. ``Gaps in knowledge must not be used as an excuse for worldwide inaction,'' declared Klaus Topfer, the West German environmental minister. Bush said he hoped the conference, attended by delegates from 19 nations, would prod international research and inject economic issues into the debate over the ``greenhouse'' effect. The president called for resolving some of the scientific uncertainties and economic implications before making a commitment to specific pollution controls to deal with possible gradual warming of the Earth. ``Environmental policies that ignores the economic factors _ the human factors _ are destined to fail,'' he said, maintaining anew that some scientists are in wide disagreement over the impact of manmade pollutants on the temperature of the globe. Many of the European participants, especially the West Germans and the Dutch, said the conference agenda was narrowly arranged to prevent open discussions of policy aimed at dealing with global warming. Topfer suggested the German delegation would pursue such discussions, adding, ``The gravity of the situation requires immediate, determined action.'' Similar views were expressed by members of other delegations, including Dutch and French officials. Discussions about further research and economic considerations should ``not distract us from taking action on carbon dioxide stabilization now,'' Hans Alders, the Dutch environmental minister, told the conference during a closed working session. ``We needed Love Canal before hazardous waste was tackled. We needed a dying River Rhine before waste water was treated. ... My country has decided to learn the lessons from the past and act on global warming now,'' Alders told the delegates, according to a transcript made public by the Dutch delegation. ``I know there's a debate raging out there,'' Bush said in his welcoming remarks to the delegates, all Cabinet-level ministers involved in environmental, economic and science issues. But he said he was confident that more research and examination of economic factors before action to curb ``greenhouse'' pollutants such as carbon dioxide ``is the way to go.'' At back-to-back news conferences later in the day, senior White House officials and leaders of the European Community sought to play down the extent of the discord at the conference and said the day's sessions had produced considerable ``common ground'' on the need for additional scientific and economic research. ``We didn't come here to argue with the United States or anybody else,'' said Padraig Flynn, environment minister for the European Council, a branch of the European Community. Allan Bromley, the president's science adviser and a co-chairman of the conference, told reporters that Bush ``does not feel in any sense that research should be a substitute for action.'' And Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers and also a conference co-chairman, maintained the discord was ``very narrowly confined to a few delegations.'' Scientists, including Bush's own science adviser, generally agree that manmade pollution, especially the release of carbon dioxide from burning of fossil fuels, is causing heat to be trapped and will result in a warming of the globe. Many say the Earth's temperature could increase by as much as 4 degrees to 9 degrees Fahrenheit by the middle of the next century, causing coastal flooding and a shift of weather and agriculture patterns. Environmentalists have urged immediate action by industrial countries to curb carbon dioxide emissions by 20 percent and many of the European countries have called at least for a stabilization of such releases by the year 2000. Such a commitment would require new efforts at energy conservation, development of more fuel efficient automobiles and more efficient use of energy in homes and businesses. Meanwhile, U.S. environmentalists accused Bush on Tuesday of abandoning his leadership responsibilities on the global warming question by not joining the Europeans in a call for firm commitments to reduce global warming pollutants. ``Bush is using the conference as a smoke screen to hide his inaction. He's using economics as a weapon against environmental protection,'' said Daniel Becker of the Sierra Club. Rafe Pomerance, of the World Resources Institute, chided Bush for suggesting that scientists are at opposite poles on the global warming debate. He said there is widespread agreement that the earth will become warmer if pollution curbs are not put into effect. At a luncheon address to the conference, William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, maintained the Bush administration has taken actions to combat global warming. He cited the push to phase out chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, which are another major cause of global warming; a call by Bush to plant 1 billion trees a year, and efforts to toughen federal air pollution laws, as well as a $1 billion global change research effort. But environmentalists maintained the tree planting effort will have scant effect on overall carbon dioxide pollution and that the administration vigorously fought efforts in Congress to require automakers to develop more fuel efficient cars, which would have allowed for significant carbon dioxide reductions by the end of the decade. Federal money to foster energy efficiency and renewable fuels also remains below the levels of a decade ago, they said.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany's Largest Bank Announces Joint Venture in EGermany
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's largest commercial bank announced plans Tuesday to set up a joint banking venture in East Germany as the first Western institution to take a stake in the former Communist nation. The joint venture by Deutsche Bank and East German partner, Deutsche Kreditbank AG, would make it a leading financial force in East Germany when the powerful West German mark becomes legal tender in both German states this year. Deutsche Bank said in the announcement that Kreditbank, the commercial banking arm of East Germany's central bank, will help set up a branch network in East Germany. On April 1, East Germany introduced a Western-style commercial banking system, but so far hasn't granted banking licenses to West German or other foreign banks. Under Communist regime, the central Staatsbank had a monopoly on all major financial transactions in East Germany, including commercial and central bank activities. But last month, the Staatsbank spun off its commercial banking activities into Deutsche Kreditbank, now temporarily owned by a public trustee agency. The joint venture is a ``contribution to the establishment of an efficient banking system in East Germany,'' Deutsche Bank said in the statement. ``This is a precondition for a successful restructuring of the East German economy.'' No financial or other details were disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Given Choice Between Karl-Marx-Stadt or Chemnitz
DOC.TEXT: KARL-MARX-STADT, East Germany (AP) _ Like nearly every other communist in East Germany, Karl Marx may get the boot too. Thirty-seven years after Chemnitz became Karl-Marx-Stadt by a Communist government decree to honor the spiritual father of Communism, city voters are getting the chance to switch the name back again. Conceding to popular pressure for a referendum on the matter, city officials earlier this month sent ballots to the 234,000 inhabitants over age 18. If a majority places a cross in front of Chemnitz on the ballot, the city council will ask the newly elected democratic government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere to reverse the 1953 decision. The ballots, marked ``referendum town hall,'' must be returned by Friday and will be publicly counted April 23. The final result will be published three days later. Frank Werner Heine, one of the organizers of the popular initiative, is confident about the outcome. He told the East German news agency ADN Tuesday the citizen's movement had received overwhelming backing for a referendum when the idea was floated last November shortly after a peaceful revolution reversed four decades of Communist rule. ``In the following weeks we had 50,000 letters, the majority of which were in favor of Chemnitz,'' he said. On May 5, 1953, the Communist Party Central Committee deleted Chemnitz from the map. East German history books say the decision was in honor of the ``glorious traditions of the workers' movement and the achievements of all workers in the city and region of Chemnitz.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged With Killing, Dismembering Daughter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note Contents.
DOC.TEXT: A man bludgeoned his daughter with a tire iron, then dismembered her body and boiled parts on the kitchen stove, police said Tuesday. Police on Tuesday found the dismembered body of Carol DiGregorio, 38, in the apartment she shared with her father, John DiGregorio, 60. Some of her body parts had been skinned and boiled, and the head was stuffed in the refrigerator in this town just northeast of Philadelphia. District Attorney Alan Rubenstein called the Easter Sunday slaying ``one of the most bizarre crimes anyone has ever encountered. It was shocking. ``He methodically sliced the skin from her body,'' Rubenstein said. DiGregorio was charged with murder and abuse of a corpse, authorities said. Rubenstein said DiGregorio told authorities he bludgeoned his daughter after she threatened him with a knife. The argument concerned a problem with the kitchen garbage disposal and was one of a series of violent disputes between the two in recent years, the Philadelphia Daily News quoted unidentified investigators as saying. Police went to the apartment early Tuesday after receiving a telephone call from DiGregorio's son-in-law, Daniel Bechurch of Atco, N.J., who reported his wife's father told him about the killing. Police said that when police arrived, DiGregorio told them, ``You're going to arrest me. I killed my daughter.'' District Justice Catherine Ritter ordered DiGregorio held without bail for a hearing next Tuesday. Rubenstein said DiGregorio told police he had struck his daughter ``four or five times'' with a tire iron he'd been using to fix the garbage disposal. After the woman fell on a couch, the district attorney said, DiGregorio ``dragged her into the bathroom, cut off her clothing and cut up her body, using a large knife and a hacksaw. Then he cooked parts on the kitchen stove.'' Rubenstein said the tools used to dismember the body were found in the apartment, and that DiGregorio showed police where he'd placed the body parts.

DOC.HEAD: Gun Club Organizing Prairie Dog Shooting Contest
DOC.TEXT: Animal rights groups are outraged over a gun club's plan to hold a prairie dog shooting contest and award prizes for the best shots on the critters that ranchers consider serious pests. Marksmanship enthusiasts from Idaho, Texas, Kansas, Oklahoma, Wyoming and Colorado already are calling in for registration forms for the July 14-15 event, billed as the ``Top Dog World Championship Prairie Dog Shoot.'' Teams killing the most prairie dogs at the greatest distances will be eligible for top prizes, including imported hunting rifles worth more than $1,300. Participation will be limited to 50 teams of two people each. Each team will pay $100. Residents of the area in western Colorado complain that prairie dogs multiply rapidly and create burrows in which cattle can break their legs. They also damage irrigation systems in a state where water is at a premium. Supporter Stan Austin said the event around the communities of Nucla and Naturita will upset some people. But he said nearby Moab, Utah, has its Jeep Weekend, Telluride has its Jazz Festival, Durango has a bike race and local folks figured they needed to offer something different to snare tourists. Fred Bellmire, a member of the Naturita town board, said he has received a couple of complaints about the prairie dog shoot. But he said the event would be good for the local tourism economy, which now relies on hunters showing up during deer and elk season. ``The thought that tourists would find it amusing to see animals killed is a pretty sick one,'' said Katharine Thalberg, director of the Aspen Society for Animal Rights. ``We may be down to picket, I don't know,'' said Thalberg, who led a recent campaign against animal furs in Aspen. Chris Bishop, of Prairie Dog Rescue Inc., called the event ``all pretty sickening in my opinion.'' Since August, he said, the group has moved 997 unwanted prairie dogs from the Denver metropolitan area to places ``where they are welcome, wanted and needed.'' Bishop said prairie dogs are photographed by countless tourists as they stand curiously atop their burrows and they are a main component of the prairie ecosystem. They provide a food base for endangered black-footed ferrets as well as badgers, eagles and coyotes, Bishop said, and their abandoned burrows often provide shelter to other animals. Mike Mehew, of the Ten Ring Gun Club which is sponsoring the event, said there are too many prairie dogs to count and said if they aren't shot during the competition, they'll be poisoned. Mehew said the carcasses of the animals will be left on the prairie. ``I never ate one,'' Mehew said. ``We will just leave them.''

DOC.HEAD: FAA Gives Preliminary Approval to Noise Reduction Plan
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration has given preliminary approval to a $60 million to $70 million noise-reduction plan for residents near the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. Under the plan, about 5,800 homes and a number of schools and public buildings would be eligible for soundproofing subsidies, buyouts or home-sale guarantees, airport officials said Monday. Final approval of the plan won't come until the Metropolitan Airports Commission makes a final, more detailed proposal to the FAA later this year, said Nigel Finney, a commission official. The commission hopes to begin insulating a few homes in the summer of 1991, Finney said. Certain residents who have difficulty selling their homes because of airport noise would be eligible for a federal buyout option, or purchase agreement, under part of the program. If the commission were to buy a home that was not selling, it would be insulated and returned to the market, Finney said. The FAA has determined that 18,544 people near the airport are subjected to 24-hour noise levels that average 65 decibels or higher. The commission, which began work on a noise compatibility study in 1984, estimates that soundproofing and buyouts would cost $60 million to $70 million. Federal grants would pay for 80 percent, and the remaining 20 percent would be paid by Northwest Airlines, the airport's major carrier, and other airport tenants, according to Finney.

DOC.HEAD: Major Quake Strikes Area of Recent Ethnic Unrest
DOC.TEXT:
An earthquake measuring 6.4 on the Richter scale on Tuesday struck China's far western border with the Soviet Union, an area affected by ethnic unrest in recent weeks. The State Seismological Bureau said the quake hit West Wuqia in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region at 10:59 a.m. Tuesday, the official Xinhua News Agency reported Wednesday. The report said the bazaar city of Kashgar and surrounding areas were affected, but details of damage were unknown. The Xinjiang regional seismic bureau has sent seismologists to investigate, it said. West Wuqia is just west of Kashgar, about 60 miles from the Soviet border. The Richter scale gauges energy released by an earthquake as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A magnitude of 6.0 is considered a major quake. The area where the quake hit is between the Taklimakan Desert and the Pamir mountains, which has peaks over 23,000 feet. Kashgar and other areas of southwest Xinjiang have been closed to foreign travelers and journalists following reports earlier this month of serious unrest involving Moslem ethnic groups. Unconfirmed reports say dozens of people have been killed.
Local sources said troops were dispatched to Kashgar and two other cities on April 6 to quell rioting linked to longstanding strains between Chinese authorities and the Turkic-speaking Moslems of Xinjiang.

DOC.HEAD: Temblors Hits Southern California, Eastern Indiana
DOC.TEXT: Aftershocks from February's earthquake shook a wide area of Southern California Tuesday, and a small temblor hit rural, eastern Indiana, but no damages or injuries were reported in either state. California residents from Los Angeles to the Mojave Desert felt a 4.6-magnitude jolt at 3:32 p.m. Centered three miles west of Upland, the quake followed a trio of minor earthquakes under the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains earlier in the day, scientists at the California Institute of Technology said. ``It appears to be on the San Antonio Canyon fault,'' said Hall Daily, a Caltech spokesman in Pasadena. ``What the seismologists say is it seems to be extending the aftershock zone to the southwest.'' ``It was the usual rolling,'' said Gloria Kelley, a switchboard operator for the city of Upland. Still, she added, ``I don't think you could ever get used to this.'' The tremors were aftershocks of the damaging magnitude-5.5 earthquake that rocked Southern California on Feb. 28, said Caltech spokesman Robert Finn. The day's aftershocks began with a 3.4 temblor at 1:47 a.m. centered six miles northwest of Upland. That was followed by a 3.3 quake at 7:12 a.m. and a 2.6 aftershock at 7:19 a.m., both three miles west of Upland, Finn said. Two aftershocks measuring 3.4 and 2.4 occurred five miles northwest of Upland early Monday. Upland is in western San Bernardino County, 40 miles east of Los Angeles. The Feb. 28 earthquake caused an estimated $10.4 million in damage, according to the state Office of Emergency Services. Indiana's Tuesday morning quake shook buildings, rattled windows and woke up residents, but caused no damage, Jay County authorities said. ``Usually an earthquake of this size is only felt over a small area,'' said Michael Hamburger, seismologist and geology professor at Indiana University. Seismology stations throughout the Midwest recorded the quake at 5:28 a.m., Hamburger said. He put the quake's magnitude at 2.5 to 3 on the Richter scale and its epicenter in eastern Jay County, about 65 miles northeast of Indianapolis. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage and 5 considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Asks For Report on Arrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, bgng: Thronburgh was xxx to CORRECT spelling of Ixtapa.
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Tuesday he had asked for a full report on the arrest of a Mexican physician accused of helping murder a U.S. drug agent in Mexico. Thornburgh said he asked the Drug Enforcement Administration to file the report after learning Monday of news accounts that the agency had offered a bounty in Mexico for the capture of the physician, Humberto Alvarez Machain. DEA spokeman Frank Shults disputed those reports, including one that the agency planned to pay a reward for the capture of Machain, a Guadalajara gynecologist who was indicted Jan. 31 on federal charges of participating in the 1985 murder of Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena. NBC and Time Magazine both reported last weekend that Alvaraz was captured by bounty hunters. Time also reported that DEA planned to pay a bounty of more than $100,000 to the captors. ``There was no reward offered, period,'' Shults said. ``We don't have bounties, the guy was arrested in El Paso on April 3rd and arraigned on April 10th.'' But Shults declined to describe the circumstances of Alvarez's arrest. Thornburgh was asked about the case during a briefing of foreign journalists the day before he is scheduled to go to Ixtapa, Mexico for an Organization of American States three-day conference on hemispheric drug enforcement. The attorney general said he couldn't comment on the reports about Alvarez's arrest because he didn't know the facts. Justice Department spokesman David Runkel denied that Thornburgh's request for the report was an indication that the attorney general lacked confidence in DEA's handling of the matter. ``He just wants to get the facts,'' Runkel said. Mexican authorities are generally reluctant to extradite Mexican nationals wanted by U.S. authorities. In a string of court rulings, including a recent Supreme Court decision, federal judges have held that the kidnapping of U.S. fugitives on foreign soil to bring them to justice does not violate American law. Nothwithstanding those rulings, Shults said DEA does not offer bounties for the kidnaping of fugitives. Charges against 18 people accused of participating in the kidnaping or murder of Camarena and his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, have strained U.S.-Mexican relations. The Jan. 31 indictment returned in Los Angeles contained the latest round of charges in the case. Besides Alvarez, it named Manuel Ibarra Herrera, former director of the Mexican Federal Judicial Police, and Miguel Aldana Ibarra, former head of the Mexican office of Interpol, the international law-enforcement agency.

DOC.HEAD: Police Storm Hideout, Save Kidnapped Girls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES 15th graf, `Patrizia's kidnapping' because Casela was released previously, not Tuesday. Picks up 16th graf, `At least...'
DOC.TEXT: A police SWAT team burst into a seaside hideout in northern Italy Tuesday night and freed the 8-year-old daughter of a leading sportswear manufacturer, ending a 78-day kidnapping ordeal that touched all of Italy. Officials said Patrizia Tacchella was in good condition and was being reunited with her parents in Verona. Three kidnappers were arrested. Authorities said members of an elite police commando unit stormed the kidnappers' villa in Santa Margherita Ligure, a small town near Genoa on Italy's fashionable Ligurian coast. Interior Minister Antonio Gava said no shots were fired and no one was injured. The girl's father, Imerio Tacchella, co-owner of the Carrera jeans and sportswear firm, said no ransom was paid. News reports have said the kidnappers demanded up to $16 million. Patrizia was abducted Jan. 29 as she walked by herself to a supermarket near her Verona home to buy candy. Gava gave few details, but Italian news agencies said police broke down the door and found the girl sitting in a chair, wearing jeans and a red sweat shirt. Only one kidnapper was in the villa and he was arrested without resisting, the reports said. The two other men showed up a short time later and were apprehended. ANSA news agency said a gun was found in the villa. ``At first Patrizia was frightened but she told us that when she saw the uniforms she knew she had been saved,'' ANSA quoted one commando as saying. An outpouring of sympathy for the family came from all over the country following the abduction. The Verona bishop, Giuseppe Amari, offered himself as a hostage in exchange for the girl. Pope John Paul II sent a message of solidarity. The girl told investigators Tuesday night that she had been held in the villa the past few days. It was not immediately known where else the kidnappers kept her during the 11 weeks. After being taken to a nearby police station, Patrizia asked for a soft drink and was given an Easter egg as a present. She spoke by telephone with her mother. ``Patrizia said she was fine and didn't seem particularly scared or upset,'' her father told reporters. ``She said she had seen me on TV many times.'' Italian media identified the three men arrested as being from the Turin area, also in northern Italy. At least five Italians remain in the hands of kidnappers. The latest victim, Rocco Surace, a 35-year-old storeowner, was abducted in Calabria last Thursday. Patrizia's father appeared often on television to plead for his daughter's release. A photo of the bespectacled Patrizia ran regularly in newspapers and appeared on TV news programs. A popular program on missing persons, ``Chi L'Ha Visto?'' dedicated hours to her case, taking telephone calls from viewers who thought they might have clues to her whereabouts. On Tuesday night, thousands of residents gathered outside the Tacchella residence to welcome Patrizia home. ``What kept us going these 78 days were faith and hope,'' Imerio Tacchella told reporters. ``The solidarity shown by people, the postcards sent to the president, the banners in the stadiums and all the other initiatives meant so much to us.'' The SWAT team, officially called the Special Intervention Group, was formed 10 years ago to deal with kidnappings, hijackings, prison riots and terrorist-related cases. It is similar to Special Weapons and Tactics police teams in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Leader Ralph David Abernathy Dead at 64
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 11-12, `King's son ...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Corretta Scott King and Benjamin Hooks; picks up 13th graf pvs, ``Abernathy was pastor ...'; minor editing to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY20, NY21, NY22, AX5
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, who created the civil rights movement with Martin Luther King Jr. but decades later enraged the slain leader's supporters by writing about his alleged infidelity, died Tuesday. Abernathy, who had cradled the fallen King's bloodied head after he was struck down by a bullet in 1968, was 64. Abernathy's heart stopped while he was being prepared for a lung scan at Crawford Long Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Tisha Burland. ``What they were trying to do was detect if there was a blood clot in the lungs ... but they never got to see,'' Ms. Burland said. Abernathy was taken to an operating room, but he was pronounced dead there at 12:10 p.m. before doctors could begin emergency life support surgery, she said. Ms. Burland quoted Dr. Kenneth Scheidt, a nuclear medicine specialist who was present for the scheduled lung scan, as saying the test never began and could not have contributed to Abernathy's death. Abernathy had been in the hospital since last month for treatment of a sodium deficiency. He had suffered strokes in 1983 and 1986. Abernathy spent his last months under bitter criticism from his colleagues for passages in his 1989 autobiography, ``And The Walls Came Tumbling Down.'' He wrote that King had spent time with two women and had a violent argument with one in the 24 hours before his 1968 assassination. But the Rev. Joseph Lowery, who succeeded Abernathy as president of the Southern Christian Leadership Council, described Abernathy on Tuesday as ``a faithful servant of the cause of liberty and justice.'' ``I extend my love and support to his family,'' he said. ``I salute you Ralph (for) a life of great achievement and merit,'' Coretta Scott King said in a statement from Harare, Zimbabwe, where she was attending celebrations of that country's 10th anniversary of independence. ``When our home was bombed and our lives were threatened, he was there,'' she said. ``His strength as a tactician and a counselor to Martin during our struggle has been eloquently recorded in Martin's own writings and in the annals of the American civil rights movement.'' King's son, Fulton County Commissioner Martin Luther King III, called Abernathy's death ``a very tragic loss to our nation.'' ``I know firsthand of the sacrifices he made for the civil rights movement, and that should never be forgotten,'' said Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``His total life and passion was his support of Martin Luther King,'' said former Mayor Andrew Young, another key King aide in the movement. Young said that if Abernathy had a weakness, ``it was trying to fill Martin Luther King Jr.'s shoes after his death, and that was an impossible task.'' State Sen. Arthur Langford, who visited Abernathy's family Tuesday night, said the family would probably not make a statement until Wednesday. Abernathy was pastor of Atlanta's West Hunter Street Baptist Church and president emeritus of the SCLC, which he founded with King in 1957 as a vehicle for the movement they began with the 1955 bus boycott in Montgomery, Ala. Abernathy had said he had no desire to lead the movement, preferring to leave that role to the more charismatic King. But two days after King's assassination, the remaining aides picked him as SCLC president, according to King's wishes. He was SCLC president for nine years, as the focus of the movement shifted from voting rights and civil rights to economic issues like employment and anti-poverty programs. He left the SCLC presidency in 1977, when he resigned to run for Congress. He was defeated in the Democratic primary. In 1980, he supported Ronald Reagan in his presidential bid. Abernathy suffered a stroke in 1983 and underwent brain bypass surgery at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. After he recovered, he returned to preach at West Hunter, where he had been pastor since 1961, and backed Jesse Jackson in his 1984 presidential bid. When Abernathy mentioned King's relationships with women in his book, he became the first of King's inner circle to do so, even though the matter had been chronicled by several noted biographers. Black leaders asked Abernathy to retract the passages, and insinuated that his memory had been impaired by the strokes and brain surgery. But Abernathy, whom King praised as his closest friend and confidant, insisted the accounts were true. Abernathy, born March 11, 1926, in Linden, Ala., was King's right-hand man for 13 years, sharing jail cells with him, traveling with him and advising him. ``We were known as the civil rights twins,'' Abernathy once recalled. ``We always sought to complement each other. I never tried to be a copy of him and he never tried to be a copy of me.'' It was Abernathy who comforted King as he lay dying of a bullet wound on the balcony of the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, Tenn., on April 4, 1968. He took care of various funeral details for Mrs. King, and delivered the eulogy. Although he worked helped found the civil rights movement, stood at King's side through the great battles and went to jail as often as King did, Abernathy consistently found himself in King's shadow. And it bothered him. In a 1986 interview, he lamented that once, when he visited a school in Connecticut, ``not a single student knew who I was.'' In his autobiography, Abernathy said he felt other King aides saw him as ``no more than an appendage to Martin, someone who served as a part companion, part bodyguard, but who never played an important role in the decisions that affected the direction of the movement.'' The book uproar tore a hole in the already fragile relationship Abernathy had with his movement colleagues, a relationship that had been rather cool after Abernathy's endorsement of Reagan. At a 1985 dinner, he was praised by top black leaders as an ``unsung hero'' of the civil rights movement. Four years later, he was handed a telegram, signed by most of his movement contemporaries, that said the accounts about King in his autobiography could ``rob you of your rightful place in history.'' Hosea Williams, who also endorsed Reagan, branded his longtime friend a ``Judas'' for writing about King's relationships with women. Abernathy never took back his allegations. ``I'm not Judas,'' he said. ``I know who I am.'' Abernathy is survived by his wife, Juanita; two sons, Kwame and state Rep. Ralph David Abernathy III; and two daughters, Juandalynn and Donzaleigh.

DOC.HEAD: NLRB Upheld In Refusing to Assume That Strikebreakers Are Anti-Union
DOC.TEXT: The National Labor Relations Board does not have to asssume that strikebreakers oppose union representation, the Supreme Court ruled Tuesday. By a 5-4 vote, the high court overturned an appeals court in a Texas case and upheld the board's policy of refusing to make a presumption of anti-union views by strikebreakers. Curtin Matheson Scientific Inc. was hit by a labor strike in 1979 by workers at its Houston warehouse after a contract expired and the company locked out the 27 Teamsters union members who worked there. Five of the 27 workers crossed the picket line when the strike began. The company 12 days later hired 29 new employees to replace the remaining 22 strikers. When the union later offered to end the strike under terms previously offered by management, Curtin Matheson management withdrew the offer along with its recognition of the Teamsters as the employees' bargaining agent. The federal labor board in 1987 ruled that the company illegally withdrew its union recognition. The board said the company acted without adequate reason to believe the Teamsters lacked support from a majority of the plant's workers. Upholding that position, and returning the case to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, Justice Thurgood Marshal wrote for the majority Tuesday: ``Replacements may in some circumstances desire union representation despite their willingness to cross the picket line. ... In addition, a replacement, like a non-striker or a strike crossover, may disagree with the purpose or strategy of the particular strike and refuse to support that strike while still wanting that union's representation at the bargaining table.'' Joining Marshall were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices William J. Brennan, Byron R. White and John Paul Stevens. Justices Harry A. Blackmun, Antonin Scalia, Sandra Day O'Connor and Anthony M. Kennedy dissented.

DOC.HEAD: State To Seek Court Order Halting Church Shelter Construction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th graf pvs, `The order...' to UPDATE with comment from church; picks up 7th graf pvs, `Officials have...'; SUBS 17th graf, `Church spokesman...' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: Health officials said Tuesday they will ask a judge to order a religious sect to halt construction on a fallout shelter where more than 30,000 gallons of fuel has leaked from buried tanks. David Niss, an attorney with the Department of Health and Environmental Sciences, said after a meeting in Helena with Gov. Stan Stephens and state regulators that the state will seek a court order this week. The 31,000 gallons of diesel fuel and gasoline leaked from three of 35 buried tanks at the fallout shelter complex of the Church Universal and Triumphant, a New Age religious sect that warns of the possibility of imminent catastrophe. Niss said the court order would cover both the main shelter complex at Corwin Springs, five miles north of Yellowstone National Park, and about 45 smaller fallout shelters at the church-owned subdivision of Glastonbury near Emigrant, Mont., about 20 miles to the north. He said the state also will issue an emergency administrative order requiring the church to empty, remove and inspect all 35 underground storage tanks at the Corwin Springs site. The order will direct the church to turn over all information on how every storage tank on church property was installed, Niss said. ``We believe that we've done everything that we were asked by the state to do, and we will continue to do it,'' said church spokesman Murray Steinman. ``Our essential message is we're going to cooperate, cooperate, cooperate.'' Officials have said they believe the church's decision to bury the tanks during the winter resulted in ruptures as the frozen ground began to thaw and shift. The governor said he shared those concerns. ``If all tanks were improperly installed in one area, it's a reasonable assumption that the same method was used at other sites,'' Stephens said. The spill brought members of a U.S. Environmental Protection Agency emergency response team from Denver and Helena to monitor the cleanup at the church's headquarters on a mountain ranch on the northern boundary of the nation's oldest national park. But state fisheries experts said Tuesday that Mol Heron Creek, an important spawning area for Yellowstone cutthroat trout, apparently has escaped long-term damage so far. Only a small amount of diesel fuel reached the stream last Friday and since then no new traces have been found in the water, said Glenn Phillips, pollution control biologist for the Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks. Phillips said the fuel didn't kill any fish but did wipe out about 70 percent of the aquatic insects for about a quarter-mile downstream. Insects upstream from the spill probably will soon re-colonize the affected area, he said. The insects, including caddis and mayflies, are a critical food source for both spawning trout and the resident fish population in the creek that empties into the Yellowstone River, he explained. ``If we can keep more contaminants out of the stream, we can probably save the fishery,'' said K.L. Cool, department director. The church installed the underground tanks for 634,500 gallons of gasoline and diesel fuel as part of a 750-person fallout-shelter complex it is completing at its Corwin Springs headquarters. Church officials said they're committed to cleaning up the spilled fuel and will excavate and inspect all 35 tanks. Workers were pumping out tanks and loading the fuel into trucks to be taken as far away as Salt Lake City. Steinman said 146,500 gallons of fuel had been pumped from the storage tanks as of Monday night, and an additional 40,000 was to be removed by late Tuesday. ``No one wants a repeat of this situation,'' said Steinman. ``Everything that can be done is being done.'' The group owns about 30,000 acres in southern Montana's Park County. Local officials estimate 2,000 to 3,000 church members live in the scenic mountain valley. The church said nobody is living in the fallout shelters. State officials earlier this year reopened an environmental review of church developments near Corwin Springs, saying the church concealed construction of the shelter complex during the original review a year ago. Reporters still have not been allowed by the church to view the fallout shelter site or the spill cleanup.

DOC.HEAD: Bullet Found in Greyhound Bus Radiator, Bomb Explodes at Depot
DOC.TEXT: A small homemade bomb made of dry ice and water exploded harmlessly Tuesday near the downtown Greyhound bus depot in Redding, Calif., where a striking Greyhound driver was killed in a bus accident March 3. In Kansas City, Mo., authorities were trying to determine when and where a bullet found in a bus's radiator might have been fired, a company official said. The bullet was discovered Monday afternoon after the bus arrived in Kansas City from St. Louis. A security employee found the bullet while inspecting the bus, said Claude Adams, Greyhound's area general manager in Kansas City. ``You would have had to be looking for it to find it,'' Adams said. He said the bullet entered the radiator at the rear of the bus through a vent. The only external indication was a bent wire on the vent screen. Greyhound has reported numerous incidents of violence since 6,300 drivers and 3,000 maintenence and office workers went on strike March 2 over wages and job security at America's only nationwide bus company. The minor explosion in the northern California city of Redding occurred at 1:22 a.m. on the far side of a maintenance building from the depot, said police spokesman Bill Horton. The device, fashioned from a plastic soda pop bottle, caused no injuries and no visible damage to the concrete block exterior. The blast occurred when the mixture of water and dry ice inside the bottle created pressure enough to shatter the container. A second identical homemade bomb that did not explode was found nearby, authorities said. A bomb expert from the Shasta County Sheriff's Department punched a hole in the bottle and released the gas pressure building up inside. In the March 3 accident, 59-year-old Robert Waterhouse was crushed when he was hit by a bus driven by a replacement driver. Investigators ruled the death an accident. Police said they had no evidence linking the explosion to the strike. Talks between the union and company have ceased and the company says it will not resume talks until at least a week passes without violence.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Canadian Jets Collide, Killing Pilot, Showering City With Debris
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with crash occurring at 9,800 feet, pilots on training mission. Picks up 18th pvs, `Police identified...'
DOC.TEXT: Two Canadian fighter jets collided over this southwestern German city during the early evening rush hour Tuesday, killing one of the pilots and showering sections of Karlsruhe with flaming debris, officials said. The second pilot suffered two broken heels after he ejected from the single-seat F-18 and parachuted onto a busy highway, and at least two people on the ground were also hurt, police and Canadian authorities said. Officials earlier said the pilot landed on the highway in his ejection seat, but police corrected that to say the pilot parachuted after bailing out of the cockpit. Reports that the pilot was struck by a car on the A5 autobahn proved inaccurate, officials said. Maj. John Paul Macdonald, spokesman for Canadian Forces in Lahr, said the planes collided at about 9,800 feet while on a training mission. Burning debris, ripped from the Canadian Air Force F-18s during the collision, rained down on many Karlsruhe streets, with West German television quoting witnesses as saying the engine of one jet smashed into a building near a gas station. ``We were lucky it wasn't worse, because the crash occurred during rush hour,'' police spokesman Manfred Frey said. West German television said the ejection-seat parachute of the pilot who died apparently failed to open after the 4:10 p.m. collision. The television reports showed badly damaged cars that had been struck by aircraft debris while parked in Karlsruhe. ``Debris was spread across many kilometers (miles),'' said the ZDF television network. The two wrecked aircraft crashed in areas that were sparsely settled, setting off small brush fires, police said. Fire officials and police rushed to extinguish the blazes. Chunks of an aircraft engine struck the ground in front of a busy train station in this city of 285,000 residents, officials said. ``Luckily, damage (on the ground) was minimal,'' said a police spokesman. ZDF said there were initial reports of exploding ammunition at the sites where the two planes came down. But Canadian air force officials said there were no munitions on board the craft. Macdonald said the planes crashed south of Karlsruhe. In Canada, the father of the victim told Canadian Press that his son, Capt. Timothy Kirk Leuty, 30, was nearing the end of his 3{-year stint in West Germany as a member of the 439th Squadron based in Baden-Soellingen. ``We were really looking forward to his coming home,'' Stan Leuty said from his home in Meaford, Ontario. ``He was due to leave in June and he was going to be based in Cold Lake, Alberta, when he got back.'' The other pilot, Capt. Reginald deCoste, 35, of Jonquiere, Quebec, ejected safely and landed on a highway, breaking both heels. He was listed in good condition in an area hospital, Macdonald said. Police identified the aircraft as American-made. They had taken off from Baden-Soellingen Air Base near Rastatt, about 25 miles southwest of Karlsruhe, police said. The Canadian Air Force has 48 F-18s at the base. Thousands of Canadian soldiers are stationed in West Germany as part of a multinational NATO force. They routinely take part in Allied military manuevers, including air training. The crash was bound to rekindle a debate over the dozens of military training flights criss-crossing West Germany's skies each day. The debate picked up steam after a series of deadly crashes in 1988. More recently, West Germans have said they would like to see the training missions sharply curtailed as East-West relations improve.

DOC.HEAD: Cubans, Soviets Sign Agreements, No Cut in Sugar Trade
DOC.TEXT: Cuba and the Soviet Union signed agreements Tuesday calling for an 8.7 percent increase in trade and no cuts in Cuba's important sugar exports, the official news agency Prensa Latina reported. Prensa Latina said in a dispatch monitored in Mexico City that the agreements call for about $14.2 billion in trade this year between the two nations. Previous trade figures were not given. A high-level Soviet delegation has been in Havana since Thursday to negotiate the accords. Cuban Vice President Rafael Rodriguez told the official Cuban news service that the agreements signify an ``advance and consolidation of relations.'' Some news reports have suggested the Soviets intended to impose harsh conditions on Cuba, whose hard-line leadership is opposed to economic and political reform. ``This campaign has dissipated like foam because the relations maintained during these days confirm the friendship and the unalterable principles that govern relations between the Soviet Union and Cuba,'' Rodriguez was quoted as saying. The agreements signed by Rodriguez and Leonid Abalkin, Soviet vice president and head of the delegation, cover energy, grain, spare parts, food and prime materials, Prensa Latina said. Cuba will maintain the amounts of sugar, nickel and citrus fruit that it sends to the Soviets and will also begin supplying them with medicine and medical equipment, Prensa Latina said. The report did not specify quantities or prices. Cuba depends on the Soviet Union for 70 percent of its foreign trade, investment in major industrial projects and other economic help. In 1989, the Soviet Union bought more than half of Cuba's sugar production, or 4.5 million tons, Prensa Latina has said. Other purchases included nickel, cobalt and citrus that accounted for 40 percent of the Soviet supply. Cuba is a holdout to the economic and political reforms that have been sweeping the Soviet bloc. As his allies in Eastern Europe have fallen to reform-minded governments, Cuban President Fidel Castro has steadfastly kept a hard-line position.

DOC.HEAD: International Press Group Protests Turkish Coverage Law
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute protested on Tuesday to the Turkish government about its news coverage restrictions on the Kurdish unrest in southeastern Turkey. Institute director Peter Galliner said he sent a message to Turkish President Turgut Ozal urging his government ``to immediately repeal this harsh legislation which effectively abolishes press freedom in the region.'' Turkish newspapers were banned last week from printing stories or analyses that might harm military operations in the 11 southeastern provinces where Kurdish guerrillas have been fighting for an independent Kurdistan. About 2,500 civilians, guerrillas and security forces have died in the clashes tied to the drive for independence by the Kurdish Labor Party, a Marxist group that has camps in neighboring Syria, Iraq and Iran. According to the institute, the new regulations are targeted against what authorities describe as publications that ``give distorted information about activities in the region'' as well as ``false reports and comments'' about the Kurdish insurrection. The independent institute, with offices in London and Zurich, claims representation of leading publishers and editors in more than 60 countries. ``It is a gross violation of basic and internationally recognized human rights and therefore can only do irreparable damage to the reputation of Turkey throughout the world,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Medfly Spraying Ordered in California, One Fly Found in Florida
DOC.TEXT: California's agriculture chief Tuesday ordered Medfly spraying in a commercial agricultural region for the first time, and officials in Florida plan to set traps after one of the crop-destroying insects was found in a net. Southern California is seriously infested by the Mediterranean fruit fly, and spraying is taking place over more than 400 square miles of Los Angeles, Orange and now Riverside counties. On Monday, a third Medfly was found in San Bernardino County and a male Medfly was discovered near Florida's Miami International Airport. The Medfly in California raised particular concern because it signaled the insect's first direct threat against a Southern California commercial agricultural region. In addition to the pesticide spray order, state Food and Agriculture Director Henry Voss filed a request for a previously announced quarantine on crops grown over 84 square miles of Riverside County. The quarantine, the first on commercial crops in this infestation, would prohibit transportation out of the area of fruits and vegetables that have not been fumigated against the Medfly. Fumigated crops can be sold in the United States, but some foreign countries, most notably Japan, won't buy treated fruits and vegetables, said Larry Cooper, spokesman for the state Medfly Project. ``The Mediterranean fruit fly is considered to be one of the most serious agricultural pests in the world,'' said Richard Clark, director of the Miami Medfly Project. ``It's known to attack over 250 different types of fruits and vegetables.'' The last Medfly discovered in Florida was found in 1988. It turned out to be the sole one found, Clark said. Workers plan to add about 1,700 traps to some 3,000 already in Dade County. The traps will be checked daily for any of the pests, Clark said. Eggs from the adult female Medfly hatch into larvae, which feed on fruit and vegetables. The insect originated in Africa and spread to the South Pacific and Central America, scientists say. It was discovered in Florida in 1929 and has been eradicated from the state several times by spraying infested areas.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Burned Waste Residue Needed Permits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `The Energy ...,' to ADD that Rockwell fired as plant operator last December.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge sided with an environmental group in ruling that the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant violated federal laws for a decade by storing residue from incinerated plutonium-tainted waste without a permit. Government officials said the ruling shouldn't cause any immediate changes at the plant or affect plans for Rocky Flats to resume plutonium processing operations later this year. At issue in the Sierra Club's lawsuit was whether residue from the burning of plutonium-tainted rags, trash and solvents required a federal permit. U.S. District Judge Lewis T. Babcock ruled that it does. In the ruling issued last week and distributed by the Sierra Club on Monday, Babcock said that since November 1980 the Department of Energy ``has been obligated, but has failed'' to apply for a key environmental permit for residue wastes at Rocky Flats, which makes plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons. The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act prohibits the treatment, storage or disposal of hazarous wastes without a permit from the U.S. Environmental Agency or a state authorized to grant the permit, Babcock said in the ruling. ``This takes a big step toward making clear what they can and cannot store and what is and is not hazardous waste,'' said Maggie Fox of the Sierra Club. ``They basically incinerated materials under the guise of recycling when it was a waste-disposal technique.'' Babcock's ruling probably will have no effect on federal decisions to resume plutonium operations at Rocky Flats, which has been shut down for several months while the plant tries to meet environmental and safety guidelines, said Department of Energy spokeswoman Cathy Kaliniak. ``Right now, we are on track and proceeding through the agreement we reached with the state,'' said Kaliniak. The Energy Department and the state signed an agreement on the issue last November. The plant is operated by EG&G Inc. for the Energy Department, which took control of the plant away from longtime plant operator Rockwell International Corp. last December. John Haggard, director of the Colorado Department of Health's Rocky Flats program, said Tuesday the ruling will have little effect on the state's regulation of the plant's waste disposal. Rocky Flats stores 1,250 cubic yards of radioactive residue at the plant 16 miles northwest of Denver without a permit. Most of the residue is from an incinerator used to burn the disputed waste, which was shut down last August as a result of the lawsuit. Plant officials have argued for years that the residue was exempt for environmental regulations because it was being stored to recycle radioactive plutonium from the ash. But court records show that plutonium actually was recovered from less than 10 percent of the residue. The Sierra Club said the ruling means Rocky Flats now is storing more radioactive waste than Colorado legally allows. State and federal officials had agreed Rocky Flats would store no more than 1,601 cubic yards of waste consisting of plutonium mixed with other hazardous substances such as industrial solvents. Rocky Flats now has 1,094 cubic yards of the waste. Sierra Club attorney Adam Babich said Babcock's ruling means mixed waste and the residue from burning are essentially the same under the law. He said when the two waste sources are combined, Rocky Flats has 2,344 cubic yards, far more than the 1,601-cubic-yard limit. But Fred Dowsett of the state health department said the two wastes cannot be added together. He said the agreement the state reached with the Energy Deparment last November calls for residue wastes to be treated as a separate issue. Babcock said in his ruling that the DOE-state agreement was ``indefinite in many respects.'' He noted that the agreement allows the DOE, not the state health department, to define which are residue wastes. ``This may be an agreement to agree which is really no agreement at all,'' Babcock wrote. ``Second, the deadlines are flexible. Indeed, there is no deadline for compliance.''

DOC.HEAD: Columbia, S.C., Mayor Unseated in Runoff
DOC.TEXT: A former county councilman unseated incumbent Mayor T. Patton Adams in a runoff Tuesday, gaining 57 percent of the vote. With all 50 precincts reporting, unofficial results showed lawyer Bob Coble with 7,963 votes to 6,072 for Adams. The Richland County councilman and Adams were forced into a runoff after both failed to receive more than 50 percent of the vote in the April 3 non-partisian election. Coble was the top vote-getter of four candidates in that election, receiving 6,122 votes, or 47.1 percent of the ballots cast. Adams, mayor since 1986, got 5,411 votes, or 41.6 percent. Two other candidates earned a total of 1,475 votes, or 11.3 percent. Adams and Coble spent about $250,000 campaigning for the part-time, $17,000-a-year job as mayor of the state capital. Adams' campaign platform emphasized stablizing property taxes, promoting growth, revitalizing decaying neighborhoods, expanding the city's water and sewer system and developing a convention center. Coble, who served as a Richland County councilman from 1985 to 1988, promised to devote more resources to neighborhood parks and recreational programs and hire 70 more police officers in the next five years. Columbia, population 93,000, is South Carolina's largest city.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity to Hold First Congress in Nine Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 12 `In an' to CORRECT spelling of gov't newspaper to Rzeczpospolita. Picks up 13th pvs, `Walesa said...'
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity is holding its first congress in nine years, but what should be a triumphant occasion comes at a time when the once-outlawed trade union and its leader find their popularity dropping. The union's second national congress, which opens Thursday, is taking place amid the backdrop of the dramatic changes that have swept away Communist regimes throughout Eastern Europe. The six-day congress is being held just a year after Solidarity regained its legal status April 17, 1989, following months of negotiations between the opposition and Poland's then-Communist government. The union had been outlawed after the December 1981 imposition of martial law. The union now has friends throughout Eastern Europe, but its popularity at home has apparently diminished because of harsh austerity measures introduced by the new Solidarity-led government. A poll released Tuesday by the pro-Solidarity newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reflected a dramatic shift. Walesa's approval rating dropped from 90 percent in November to 56 percent in March, and support for Solidarity fell from 78 percent to 47 percent during the same period, according to the poll taken by the government-run Opinion Research Center. ``In comparison to November, when the public mood was at its highest, all those who owed their support to the general faith and trust in Solidarity have lost some of it,'' Gazeta Wyborcza said. Walesa, the shipyard electrician who won the Nobel Peace Prize for his leadership of Solidarity, is expected to win re-election as union chairman, although he is likely to face at least token opposition in the voting Saturday. ``Walesa is an institution. As chairman of the union he automatically strengthens its power and position,'' Lech Kaczynski, a presidium member of the union's National Executive Commission, told a news conference last week. A critical issue facing the delegates is whether the union should largely confine itself to bread-and-butter issues defending workers' interests, or get more involved in politics. One issue likely to emerge during the congress is whether to create a Solidarity-linked political party. In an interview published Monday in the government newspaper Rzeczpospolita, Walesa said his chief goal for Solidarity is ``turning it into a trade union'' and opening up the political arena to other forces. Walesa said he wants to distance the union from the Solidarity-backed government led by Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a former union journalist and adviser.
