The congress will provide the union's first opportunity to pass collective judgment on the Mazowiecki government's economic reform program. It includes austerity measures that are bringing unemployment to workers in state-run industries. They are the same people who created Solidarity during nationwide strikes in August 1980. The government has lifted price controls, cut subsidies to industries and forced unprofitable factories to close as part of its program to transform the centrally controlled socialist system to a market-driven capitalist economy. While a recent government report shows the inflation rate dropped from 78.6 percent for January to 4.7 percent for March. Unemployment rose from 56,000 in January to 267,000 at the end of March. Solidarity-backed candidates won overwhelmingly in June parliamentary elections. That cleared the way for setting up the East bloc's first non-Communist government in August. But as a trade union, Solidarity has lagged in signing up members. The union has registered 2.2 million members since regaining its legal status, or only about one-fifth of the 10-million membership Solidarity claimed when it held its first congress in 1981. That first congress took place amid a barrage of hostile propaganda from Poland's Communist authorities and the governments of neighboring Soviet bloc countries. Solidarity at that time was the East bloc's only independent trade union and was engaged in a struggle with the ruling Polish Communist Party. The party was secretly gearing up for the imposition of military rule two months later. Most of the delegates spent Christmas in internment camps. When the 487 delegates assemble this time in the same Olivia Sports Hall in the Baltic port of Gdansk, Solidarity's birthplace, they will be joined by Mazowiecki and other government and parliamentary leaders from the union's ranks. Also present will be independent trade unionists from other East European countries that in the past year have also rejected one-party Communist rule. Solidarity leaders say the congress represents the end of the union's rebuilding phase. Delegates were chosen in local and regional union elections that began last fall. Last week, Walesa indicated he planned to run for president of Poland, but quickly retracted the statement. Referring Monday in Rzeczpospolita to complaints he is using the union office as a stepping stone to the presidency, Walesa replied, ``It would be well if the president were to come from the bottom and if he is with Solidarity in his heart.'' But he added that he is not actively seeking the office.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Settlement Reached Between Firm, Families of 15 Dead Students
DOC.TEXT: A bottler has agreed to pay $67.5 million to settle claims in the deaths of 15 students whose school bus was knocked into a water-filled pit by a Coca-Cola truck last September, a newspaper reported Tuesday. Under the agreement, Valley Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Inc. would pay each victims' family monthly payments for the rest of their lives that would total $4.5 million, the McAllen Monitor said. ``We have an agreement in principle,'' the Monitor quoted an unidentified attorney as saying. ``It's just a matter of taking this before a court for approval and I don't see a problem with that.'' The accident occurred Sept. 21, 1989, in the south Texas town of Alton. Twenty-one students died and 60 were injured when the truck struck the bus. It was the state's worst school bus accident. Attorney Morris Atlas, who assisted in the negotiations, declined to comment on reports of a settlement, the newspaper said. Atlas did not return phone calls to The Associated Press. ``There's not anything I can talk about relating to any negotiations,'' said Ramon Garcia, an attorney who represents the families of three students who died and several of the injured. ``We have been negotiating for some time now,'' Garcia said. The soft-drink company agreed two months ago to pay $1.5 million in a structured settlement with a family of one of the dead students. It is the only wrongful death settlement in the case to date. Cases filed on behalf of three of the injured students have been settled for $250,000 each.

DOC.HEAD: Sony To Build TV Picture Tube Plant In Factory Abandoned By Volkswagen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Masaaki Morite ...' to ADD detail that lease is from state. Inserts 1 graf after 6th graf, `The shutdown ...' to UPDATE with state forgiving VW loan; picks up 7th graf pvs: `Sony estimates ...' A longer version moved on the business wire.
DOC.TEXT: Sony Corp. announced Tuesday it would invest $300 million to renovate part of a mothballed Volkswagen assembly plant to produce television picture tubes and, eventually, high-definition TVs. The move, a major expansion aimed at bringing the Japanese electronic giant's U.S. manufacturing capability closer to its suppliers, comes at a time of increasing competition and friction between the United States and foreign business. State and federal lawmakers praised the move as an opportunity not only to bring more jobs to the semi-rural western Pennsylvania area but also to help chip away at the huge U.S. trade deficit with Japan. Masaaki Morita, chairman of Sony Corp. of America, said the lease from the state of the 600-acre parcel 45 miles southeast of Pittsburgh was ``one of the largest single investments that Sony has made in a factory'' and ``a major investment in Sony's future, with impact beyond the region and the U.S. market.'' Weak sales forced the closing of the Volkswagen of America Inc. plant in July 1988. The shutdown caused layoffs of about 2,500 workers and hard feelings among state and local officials who arranged a $70 million loan to the West German automaker for completing the facility and related roads and railways. At its peak in 1980, the plant employed 5,700 people. To take over the sprawling factory, the state is forgiving $40 million still owed by VW from a $70 million loan taken from the state in 1976 to complete a partially built Chrysler Corp. plant, train workers and build a railroad spur and highway, Gov. Robert P. Casey said. Sony estimates about 1,000 jobs, mainly in higher-skilled fields such as engineering, will be created over the next three years by its sixth U.S. plant. Morita said Sony, which already has a picture-tube plant in San Diego, decided to locate in Pennsylvania to be closer to key suppliers and markets in the central and eastern United States. ``We believe we must make the product in the market where we sell it,'' he said. ``Sony's TV business in the United States is growing while at the same time the market trend is toward larger and larger screen sizes.'' Other recent U.S. manufacturing ventures by Sony include the acquisition of a semiconductor chip production plant in San Antonio from Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and the production of laser video discs through an Indiana-based subsidiary. Sony hopes to begin producing 32-inch TV tubes by the end of 1992 for domestic and export sales. It aims to manufacture about 1 million tubes within the first year of production and 1.5 million in the next two years, officials said. High-definition television sets, which feature exceptionally clear pictures, also will be made at the plant after the U.S. government formulates HDTV standards in 1993, said Kunitake Ando, president of Sony Engineering and Manufacturing of America. Pennsylvania agreed to provide Sony with $23.5 million in low-interest loans and job-training grants to develop half of the 1,200-acre site. The company also plans to lease two additional parcels of 200 acres each for the possible development of an additional plant within the next five years. Sony also can sublease the sites to companies such as glass and cabinet makers involved in the production of other television components. U.S. Sen. John Heinz III, R-Pa., said Sony's decision to locate in Pennsylvania advances efforts to reduce trade friction between the United States and Japan. He said he promised Morita's brother, Akio, Sony's chairman and chief executive officer, ``that a direct investment by Sony here in this area, one that created jobs, would be seen not only as a positive step in reducing that trade imbalance, but would be applauded and welcomed enthusiastically.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Break Alleged Heroin Ring
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Tuesday arrested the reputed ringleader and most of the 18 suspected members of a drug ring that smuggled heroin from Nigeria into Baltimore, officials said. The raids in Baltimore, Washington, Rome and Sao Paulo, Brazil, capped a yearlong investigation, the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration said in a statement. More than 200 federal, state and local drug agents arrested suspects named in 18 federal indictments unsealed earlier in the day, the DEA said. Most of the 18 suspects were under arrest by mid-afternoon, including reputed ringleader Linwood R. ``Rudy'' Williams, 36, who was arrested at his Baltimore home, the agency said. Other suspects included Williams' brother, Jackie Glen Williams; his nephew, Namond Earl Williams; and his cousin, Gerald Bernard Gray. All were charged with conspiracy to distribute heroin and cocaine. Agents seized $250,000 in cash, one kilo of nearly pure heroin valued at $150,000 and another of cocaine valued at $25,000. Also seized were several vehicles, including a 1984 Ferrari, a Jaguar and four Mercedes Benz automobiles. Agents also confiscated two rifles, nine handguns, antique silver and other jewelry, a fur coat and drug paraphernalia. The heroin originated in Nigeria and was shipped through various foreign cities to New York, where it was then transported to Baltimore, a DEA spokesman said. The operation may have brought 110 pounds of heroin, or about 20,000 street doses, into Baltimore in the past year, authorities said. Officers from the DEA, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and the IRS took part in the raids, executing 27 search warrants, DEA spokesman Mario Perez said. The Williams group allegedly began in April 1989 and operated throughout Baltimore, the spokesman said. Williams was aquitted last year on charges of heroin possession, assault and resisting arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors View Tape of Mondello Account of Bensonhurst Attack
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in a racial attack case on Tuesday watched a 42-second television interview in which the alleged ringleader of a white gang says the mob assembled to protect their turf. In the videotape broadcast on WABC-TV five days after the Aug. 23 killing of Yusuf Hawkins, Keith Mondello said the whites gathered to battle a gang of blacks they believed were coming looking for trouble in their mostly white Brooklyn neighborhood. ``I was told that 25 blacks were coming to beat me and my friends up,'' Mondello said. ``The only reason baseball bats were on the scene was because we wanted to protect ourselves. And we didn't know if they were going to be armed.'' Mondello denied knowing that one of the whites was carrying a gun and said the attack was not racially motivated. ``No matter what color they were, if someone was coming to beat my friends up we would do anything to protect ourselves,'' Mondello said. Prosecutors said they played the taped interview to show the 19-year-old defendant was a liar who had changed his account of the attack. ``I don't buy that wide-eyed innocence that's on the tape,'' Paul Burns, an assistant district attorney, said outside the courtroom. ``Take a look at what he said to the police and what he said on the tape.'' After his arrest, Mondello told investigators that before the attack a man identified only as ``Frank'' put an object in his car that Mondello soon learned was a gun. ``I opened the door and saw it was a gun that he put in my car,'' Mondello told detectives. ``I picked it up and gave it back to him. We all then went to the schoolyard.'' A few minutes after they went to the schoolyard, ``Joey Fama yelled from the corner, `They're here, black kids are here,''' Mondello told the investigators. The whites surrounded Hawkins and his three friends, all black. Within seconds, prosecutors say, Fama stepped from the mob and fired four shots, hitting Hawkins in the chest. Mondello and Fama are charged with second-degree murder and other crimes. If convicted, they face 25 years to life in prison. Two juries were impaneled to hear the trials of the two men, one for Mondello and one for Fama. Opening arguments in the Fama's trial were postponed a second day because his defense lawyer, David DePetris, was ill with the flu.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Jams Radio Marti
DOC.TEXT: Cuba, escalating its resistance to U.S. government-sponsored broadcasting, jammed Radio Marti early Tuesday for the first time since TV Marti went on the air. Cuba continued to jam the late-night test signal of TV Marti, which began broadcasting March 27. ``We're pretty sure they jammed (Radio Marti) just during the time TV Marti was on the air,'' said Antonio Navarro, acting director of both services for the Voice of America. In a communique monitored in Miami, Cuba denounced Radio Marti as ``an instrument of psychological war and disinformation'' aimed at overthrowing Fidel Castro's regime, according to a story published in Wednesday's Miami Herald. The Cuban government has said that TV Marti, its signal sent from an antenna aboard a balloon off the south Florida coast, constitutes an aggressive action and violates Cuban sovereignty. In a speech earlier this month, Castro implied that one of the moves under consideration in retaliation to the TV Marti broadcasts would involve Radio Marti. He also has threatened to retaliate by interfering with American broadcast signals in Florida. Radio Marti, which sends news and entertainment to Cuban listeners, has been broadcasting relatively free of interference since going on the air in 1985. Both the radio and television stations are named after 19th century Cuban independence hero Jose Marti.

Smuggling operations are helping Pakistan, India, Argentina, Brazil and Iraq to build or expand nuclear weapons capabilities, a research organization reported today. To deter such countries from continuing these practices, the report recommended that the United States and other supplier countries threaten to penalize them with economic and military sanctions. Titled ``Nuclear Exports: The Challenge of Control,'' the report was prepared by the private Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. There was no immediate comment from any of the embassies whose governments were mentioned in the report.

The legal dance through the justice system is over for students in this Ozarks hamlet who want to cut the rug at their school but can't because of a 100-year-old ban on high-steppin'. The U.S. Supreme Court decision Monday left intact the school board's no-dancing rule. Opponents of the ban plan no appeal. The best they can hope for is to elect school board members who are pro-dancing, said Howard Fox, one of 21 students and parents who had sued four years ago in an attempt to overturn the rule. The current board members ``are not going to be there forever,'' Fox said. ``Ultimately we will dance on their graves, figuratively.''

A solid majority of Brazilians support the government's crash economic plan, which has brought inflation down from a record 5,000 percent but also cost hundreds of thousands of people their jobs. ``I couldn't go on the way it was before. With inflation down, I've got at least a little bit of money in my pocket,'' said Denilson Goncalves, who sells baked goods on the street of a middle-class neighborhood in Rio. Goncalves' views were reflected in a public opinion poll conducted last week in Brazil's 10 largest cities that indicated 71 percent approval. Conducted by the prominent Folha de Sao Paulo newspaper, it surveyed 5,291 people and had a 2 percent margin of error. But support for the plan has dropped 10 percent from a similar survey conducted three weeks ago, reflecting a growing concern over a rapid rise in unemployment.

Homeowners' gardens and yards in the Gold Rush town of Skagway will be vacuumed this month in a high-tech spring cleaning aimed at removing lead from the soil. The work, which starts this week, is the final step in one of Alaska's most expensive pollution cleanups. Extremely high levels of lead were discovered in 1988 in the soil in Skagway, a shipping port for lead and zinc ore for decades. But fears that the 700 residents were threatened by lead poisoning were eased by the results of blood tests conducted by the state. State health officials concluded the lead posed no significant threat. Blood lead levels in virtually all the residents tested were below average. Officials explained that Skagway's lead is in a raw form, which is not as easily absorbed into the body as processed lead.

Two of Washington's most famous landmarks, the Lincoln and Jefferson memorials, are slowly crumbling under the ravaging effects of water seepage, air pollution, littering tourists and a pesky little bug called the midge, experts say. Private consultants hired by the National Park Service say the most glaring problem was found at the 68-year-old Lincoln Memorial, where dripping rainwater has caused deterioration of huge concrete slabs that support a broad cobblestone walkway and the grassy terrace surrounding the building. At the Jefferson Memorial, completed in 1943, cracks have been detected in the concrete shell of the inner dome. Officials also are worried that the main plaza and marble steps may be sliding gradually into the waters of the Tidal Basin. The Park Service said none of the problems is serious enough to require immediate attention or pose a safety hazard to visitors.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to CORRECT number sequence; an add to this package will move when the following briefs are available: MOSCOW _ Lithuania; CHICAGO _ Alcoholism Gene; JERUSALEM _ Israel-Settlers; ATLANTA _ Obit-Abernathy.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush warned Tuesday of ``appropriate responses'' in retaliation for Moscow's announced cuts in fuel supplies to Lithuania, but he also said he did not want to damage superpower relations. ``I want to be sure anything we do is productive,'' Bush said. ``There's been dramatic change in the world and I don't want to inadvertently take some action that would set it back.'' Meanwhile, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., were invited to the White House to meet with Bush about increased tensions in Lithuania. Lawmakers have warned that Congress might act on its own with economic pressure against Moscow if the Soviets escalate efforts to block Lithuania's drive for independence.

The radicals running the Moscow city council discussed getting rid of the giant bust of Lenin from their meeting hall Tuesday, then spent their lunch hour at an anti-corruption rally next to Red Square. That was only the beginning for the new dominant force in city hall, which wants to turn the capital of communism into an experimental economic zone where the free market reigns and foreign cash flows freely. ``We'll be trying to bring in a program of the privatization of the economy,'' said Lev Balashov, a member of the Democratic Russia bloc that took control of more than 60 percent of the 495 council seats in an election in March. The key figure in the economic revolution brewing in this city of 9 million is Gavriil Popov, an outspoken economist and lawmaker whom the council is expected to elect mayor Wednesday.

Consumer prices, fueled by sharp increases in clothing, housing and medical costs, shot up 0.5 percent in March to push inflation to the highest level since 1982, the government said Tuesday. Private economists saw the unexpectedly brisk advance in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index as a discouraging sign that inflation was not retreating as they had hoped. The inflation rate is ``dangerous and potentially devastating for financial markets and the economy,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. Through the first three months of the year, inflation has risen at an annual rate of 8.5 percent, the fastest quarterly increase since a 10.1 percent increase in the spring of 1982.

The Supreme Court said Tuesday there is no constitutional right to take illegal drugs, such as peyote, for religious reasons. Dissenting justices said the 6-3 ruling permits religious oppression of Indians and perhaps others with unorthodox views. The court ruled that Oregon officials may deny unemployment benefits to two fired drug counselors who took small amounts of peyote, a cactus ``button'' containing the hallucinogen mescaline, in Indian religious ceremonies. Justice Antonin Scalia, writing for the court, said it ``would be courting anarchy'' to let a few do what is illegal for everyone else.

President Bush called for more research ``to sort out the science'' of global warming Tuesday, but ran into a storm of criticism at an international White House conference from Europeans who argued for action. ``Gaps in knowledge must not be used as an excuse for worldwide inaction,'' declared Klaus Topfer, the West German environmental minister. Bush said he hoped the conference, attended by delegates from 19 nations, would prod international research and inject economic issues into the debate over the ``greenhouse'' effect. The president called for resolving some of the scientific uncertainties and economic implications before making a commitment to specific pollution controls to deal with possible gradual warming of the Earth.

Experts are almost evenly divided about whether the federal government is taking too much money away from cancer, heart disease and other medical studies to support AIDS research, according to a survey by the Office of Technology Assessment. The OTA survey, released Tuesday, said most of the experts also believe AIDS research ``has made many important contributions to advances in the biomedical and behavioral sciences'' and that virtually every medical speciality has benefited, to some degree, from money spent on AIDS studies. Federal spending for treatment and prevention of acquired immune deficiency syndrome totals about $2.9 billion for the fiscal year that ends this October. Research into the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS, is about $1.16 billion. ``Critics of rising expenditures on HIV disease point out that HIV funding has exceeded funding for heart disease and rivals funding for cancer, despite the much greater number of deaths from these latter diseases,'' the OTA report said. It said about 10 percent of the total National Institutes of Health 1990 budget goes to HIV funding.

The Berlin Philharmonic, touring the Jewish state for the first time, is finding that applause is drowning out the voices of protest from Holocaust survivors who remember the days when the orchestra entertained Adolf Hitler. The seven-concert tour was sold out from the onset, the latest sign that with the passage of time, cultural symbols once associated with the Nazis are gradually being accepted in Israel. The visit by the Berlin Philharmonic, under the direction of Israeli guest conductor Daniel Barenboim, climaxes Wednesday night in Tel Aviv with a joint concert with the Israeli Philharmonic Orchestra led by Zubin Mehta. ``Twenty years ago, this visit would not have been possible. But people now have the courage to separate between what happened during World War II and the high standards of this orchestra,'' said Chanoch Ron, music critic of the daily Yediot Ahronot.

The Kremlin said it was tightening the tap on Lithuania's natural gas supply Tuesday and may cut oil and gasoline to the Baltic republic for refusing to rescind pro-independence laws, Lithuanian leaders said. But Lithuania's president called the republic's decisions ``irreversible'' and said an economic embargo will only strengthen the resolve of Lithuanians. ``I hope it will consolidate our people in our peaceful struggle,'' Vytautas Landsbergis said in a broadcast interview. No change was immediately noticeable in natural gas used to heat homes and fuel kitchens in Lithuania. But worried Lithuanians flooded the government in Vilnius with phone calls.

The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, who created the civil rights movement with Martin Luther King Jr. but decades later enraged the slain leader's supporters by writing about his alleged infidelity, died Tuesday. Abernathy, who had cradled the fallen King's bloodied head after he was struck down by a bullet in 1968, was 64. Abernathy's heart stopped while he was being prepared for a lung scan at Crawford Long Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Tisha Burland. Abernathy was taken to an operating room, but he was pronounced dead there at 12:10 p.m. before doctors could begin emergency life support surgery, she said.

Researchers say they have pinpointed for the first time a gene that may make people prone to alcoholism, adding weight to the argument that alcoholism is a disease and not a moral weakness. Government scientists called the finding ``provocative and promising,'' even if it requires more study, but a leading investigator in the field declared it was impossible to say an ``alcohol gene'' had been identified. The researchers reported in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association that they found a particular gene on a chromosome previously linked with alcoholism to be far more common in alcoholics than in non-alcoholics. If verified, the finding would represent the first specific identification of a genetic root for alcoholism. Alcoholism, which afflicts an estimated 18 million Americans, tends to run in families, and previous studies of families and of adopted twins have suggested that environment and genetic factors contribute to the disorder.

A Jerusalem District Court panel on Tuesday upheld an order to evict 150 Jewish settlers from the Arab Christian quarter of the Old City, fueling anti-Israeli protests. The settlers immediately appealed the decision. Several dozen Palestinian women and masked youths demonstrated inside the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, venerated as the site of Christ's burial and regarded by many as Christianity's holiest shrine. Visiting pilgrims and tourists stared as 40 to 50 protesters waved Palestinian flags and chanted ``PLO! PLO!'' and ``Israel no! Palestine yes!'' inside the dark church.

Benjamin Franklin died 200 years ago Tuesday, and according to his will that means it's now time to spend the 1,000 pounds sterling he bequeathed to Massachusetts and Pennsylvania. The pennies saved are now worth about $4.5 million in Massachusetts and $2 million in Pennsylvania, and requests for a cut are pouring in from as far away as London. Franklin died in Philadelphia on April 17, 1790, at age 84. In his will, he gave 1,000 pounds sterling to Massachusetts and the city of Boston, and an equal sum to the state of Pennsylvania and the city of Philadelphia. The dollar did not become the official U.S. currency until 1792. The money came from what Franklin earned during his tenure as president of the commonwealth of Pennsylvania, 1785-87. He believed that politicians should not be paid for serving the public.

DOC.HEAD: Forn Release Thurs PMs, April 26 and Thereafter
Serial Killer Film Finally Reaching Theaters After Tortuous Journey
DOC.TEXT: John McNaughton calls his film ``Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer'' a ``cautionary tale.'' But the Ratings Board said caution wasn't enough and gave it an X-rating. Now ``Serial Killer'' is reaching a few of the country's movie screens after a tortuous five-year journey. Because of the X-rating, which means moviegoers under 17 can not be admitted, only a handful of theaters will exhibit the film and few newspapers will accept ads. Yet the film has earned decent reviews for mainstream critics. John McNaughton, 50, is a quiet-spoken Chicago filmmaker who left his ad agency business to tour with a carnival, then returned to pursue his longtime interest in video and film. He was making commercials when he was approached by Waleed and Malik Ali to make a horror film for their MPI Home Video. McNaughton readily agreed. As he was searching for a subject, he met his friend Richard Fire, a Chicago playwright. ``Here, look at this,'' said Fire, playing the tape of an interview on ABC's ``20@20'' with Texas mass murderer Henry Lee Lucas. ``It took about 30 seconds for it to sink in: `My God, this is true deep horror that this guy could go out and do those things.' One of the things that got through to me was that Henry had this low-key charm in the way he talked. He had the ability to be charming in his own strange way and had the ability to get close enough to people to slaughter them,'' McNaughton said. Fire and McNaughton wrote the script, closely following the Lucas case. For the vital role of the murderer, the director chose Michael Rooker, an outgoing family man who was painting houses while hunting for acting jobs. He has since appeared in ``Eight Men Out,'' ``Mississippi Burning'' and ``Music Box.'' ``Henry'' was filmed in Chicago during a four-week period in late 1985. The budget: $100,000. ``The original intent of the film was for home-video release only,'' says McNaughton. ``Those of us on the film were keeping our fingers crossed that it would turn out well enough to get a theatrical release.'' The Ali brothers sent the film to a number of distributors. No interest. McNaughton began his own campaign, showing it in 1986 at the Chicago Film Festival where it stirred good comment. Vestron Co. people saw the film at a New York screening and made an offer. ``Vestron was very healthy at the time, and they were ready to send it to theaters and home video,'' says McNaughton. But the company's lawyers became skittish about the depiction of real-life figures, and the deal evaporated. Meanwhile, McNaughton was hired to direct ``The Borrower'' for Atlantic Releasing, which also took on ``Henry'' in late 1987. ``Then the MPAA gave it an X-rating, and Atlantic walked away from the deal,'' he said. ``I think Atlantic was going to take it into 400 to 600 theaters. The marketability because of the X-rating is cut down to maybe 25 to 30 theaters, maybe one art-house per city. So it becomes commercially unviable for a company like Atlantic.'' The objection of the Ratings Board of the Motion Picture Association was to the excessive violence. McNaughton could see no way to make cuts in an already tightly edited film. ``Often a film is like a house of cards: pull out one and the house collapses,'' he said. ``Henry'' reverted to MPI, where a marketer became enthused and lined up screenings with film societies and film festivals. The glowing reviews attracted a small distributor, Filmcat, based in Las Vegas. McNaughton has been on the road to attract attention to his movie, since films and TV ads are unavailable. While in Los Angeles, he has been talking to major companies about future projects. ``We'll see what happens,'' he said cautiously. ``Under the concept of `heat' as it's practiced in this town, I should have a month or so of heat. I hope it develops into paying work, which is what I sorely need at this moment.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Thurs April 26

DOC.HEAD: Terrorizing Homeowners
DOC.TEXT: According to legend and song, home used to be sweet, and it still can be if you are able to withstand the pressure. It's constant. The latest terrorizer of the homeowner, and of renters too, is the telemarketer, often a bank or an insurance agent, who believes the dinner hour is the time to make a telephone sales pitch. The audacity of such sales people is magnified many times when you consider how difficult it is to sell anything to someone who left a plate of roast beef or chicken on the table and who probably still has some in the mouth. They try, however, and presumably they occasionally succeed, due to the law of numbers. But they can create havoc in the home, befouling the ideal of it being a place of rest, relaxation, security, peace and love. By the million and one standards of insurers, there is no home or person in America adequately insured for accident, ill health, life, property. By brokerage-house standards, none is properly invested in stocks either. While you might find yourself adequately prepared to ward off the pitches, they leave you with doubts, the nagging kind, the guilty kind that erode your resistance and set you up for an eventual collapse and purchase. While telemarketers are occasional interruptions, there are constant ones too. Rarely is the homeowner safely guarded against hearing or reading about rising interest rates, collapsing home prices and forced sales. You might say that alleged studies supporting such contentions are a staple of some academics, that they sometimes come from Wall Street analysts who might understand stocks but not houses, and that they always find a media outlet. Many of them are poorly done, including one by a Harvard University professor and his assistant, who forecast a long, steady decline in prices of existing homes, but whose methodology has been demonstrated as naive. Why is the homeowner the focus of so much attention? Because homeowners have money and worries. Money can buy the goods, and worry about protecting the house can be a very good sales opener. There is no limit to the problems that can be created and the solutions offered. You found a leak. You say it's insignificant? No leak is insignificant. Slowly and without letup it is doing damage inside your wall, unseen until it suddenly erupts in a cascade of destruction. Plumbers will tell you so. Maybe, you think, you should fill up the fuel oil tank you buried in the backyard. Prices might be lower in summer. You said buried? Is it metal? How do you know its not rusting? And befouling your well? Better check the well. If you live in the city, better check your water anyway. Sure, you might find strange chemicals there, but they can be taken care of reasonably, give or take a few hundred dollars. There is no retreat from these problems. They must be faced, even if you think you can hide from them. You might go out on the lawn, pictured on grass seed boxes as a serene place, but you know you will find work to be done. Besides, have you considered all the chemical you've dumped on that lawn? And that more and more rashes and respiratory problems are being reported? And that you could get Lyme Disease? You may try retreating to the cellar, but you've heard there could be radon gas there. The attic? What if you find termites at home? Wouldn't it be better if you just didn't know? You could, if you wish, climb to the roof and meditate. Nobody is likely to bother you there, except perhaps a neighbor who calls the authorities. Aside from that, how do you know it's safe up there? The reason for the question is that there's that fire-retardant plywood, you know, that some builders used on roofs, and the word is that some of it deteriorates and crumbles under the least pressure. How can you be sure it won't just dump you down into the living room, amid all those other problems? Home _ what a terrifying place.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Wednesday, April 18.

For Release Tuesday AMs, April 24, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Crime Increasing in Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: Two thieves shot Yeh Yung-chuan to death, in front of other investors, as he left the trading floor of a brokerage house with nearly $100,000. Crime has come to Taiwan on the heels of affluence. Yeh, a 32-year-old accountant, turned to run when the men stopped him. They shot him once in the back and once in the head, took his 2.5 million Taiwan dollars and fled on a motorcycle parked outside. Such brutal crimes are becoming common. Wealthy businessmen hire guards and use bulletproof cars. ``Taiwan is not safe anymore,'' said Rebecca Yen, a 28-year-old employee of a trading company. ``Most of my friends plan to emo Australia, New Zealand and Canada. Tai estimated that about 40,000 Taiwanese left in 1989, up from 30,000 in 1988. Luxury cars, seen as invitations to kidnapping and robbery, no longer are in demand. Eric Fang, assistant sales manager of the largest Mercedes-Benz agency, said his company sold only 290 cars in December, down from the 1988 monthly average of 650, and predicted a drop in sales of 15 percent for 1990. ``Many businessmen have postponed purchases because they do not want to drive the `dangerous cars','' he said. Authorities report a dramatic increase in smuggled guns from China. Police said they seized 687 Chinese-made shotguns last year, up from 57 in 1988. Official statistics say smuggled Chinese guns were used in 91 killings in 1987, including those of four policemen. Premier Lee Huan has proclaimed 1990 ``Anti-Crime Year'' and proposed that gun possession, now punishable by 10 years in prison, be made a capital crime. Thousands of inexpensive guns are believed to be in the hands of gangsters. Some legislators say the only way to stop the influx from the mainland is for the government to hold direct talks with Beijing. The ruling Nationalists fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Communists, and still refuse to negotiate directly with the Beijing government. Lin Chia-cheng, a sociology professor at Soochow University, believes one reason for the crime wave is ``the widened gap between the rich and the poor.'' Taiwan's export-led economic boom has made its per capita gross national product the fourth highest in Asia, but good fortune has not been shared equally. The income of the top 20 percent is nearly five times that of the bottom 20 percent. People also seem more inclined to seek quick riches than to work for a better life. Stock speculation has been the favored tactic, but many have turned to crime. ``Traditional values have faded,'' Lin said. ``Fewer people believe in hard work and saving. Most envy those who have gotten wealthy fast from speculating, and some think it is all right to get money from those rich people.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, April 24

DOC.HEAD: Latin American Banks: Great Rewards, Great Risks
DOC.TEXT: Many Latin American banks pay high returns, but the risks are just as great. Money doubled every month in Brazil _ until March, when the government froze all accounts. Such uncertainty is one reason Latin Americans are believed to have more than $200 billion in Switzerland, the Bahamas, Miami and elsewhere. Latin leaders are encouraging citizens to bring their money home, but bitter memories and recent government actions bode ill for success. On his first day in office last month, President Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil put an 18-month freeze on $115 billion in personal and corporate checking, savings and money market accounts and bank certificates of deposit. He said the drastic ``liquidity reduction'' was needed to halt annual inflation of 4,853 percent in Latin America's largest country. Argentina, Mexico, Bolivia, Peru and Chile have decreed economic plans that disrupted the lives of ordinary savers and, for the most part, frustrated government efforts to persuade citizens to invest in their own countries. Brazil's policy allows withdrawls of up to $1,200 from checking and savings accounts and $600 or 20 percent of the balance, whichever is greater, for money-market accounts, mutual funds and CDs. Collor de Mello said he was after ``big speculators,'' but millions of middle class Brazilians saw their plans for new cars or down payments on homes suddenly canceled. ``There's no doubt that the measures seriously affected people's confidence in the local savings and banking system,'' said consultant Carlos Geraldo Langoni, a former Central Bank president. ``They furthered the belief that, for Latin Americans, the only real financial protection is the U.S. dollar or some other strong currency,'' he said in an interview. ``On the other hand, Brazil could not go on with four-digit inflation. If the new economic plan meets with total success, maybe it will erase the trauma.'' Clarice Pechman, a leading expert on foreign exchange, estimates Brazilians have more than $40 billion outside the country. Brazilians, traditionally easygoing, have tried to make the best of things. Jokes have sprung up, as they often do in tough times. When an alligator was discovered in a pond at the Quinta da Boa Vista park in Rio, residents named it Zelia because of its ``big bite.'' The economy minister, who announced the freezing of accounts, is Zelia Cardoso de Mello, no relation to the president. The government said the restrictions applied only to new cruzados, the money that existed before Mar. 16. It promised nothing would happen to cruzeiros, the currency introduced on that date, and urged people to open cruzeiro accounts. A branch manager of Bradesco, a large private bank, said: ``Are you kidding? All people want to do is take their money out.'' He asked that his name not be used. In Argentina, the government seized about $1.5 billion worth of seven-day, high-interest bank CDs in January and converted them to 10-year government bonds. Argentines who don't want to wait until 2000 to get their money back can sell the bonds for cash, but they get only about 30 percent of the face value. ``They robbed me,'' said Raul Tucci, who owns a small Buenos Aires furniture factory. He was in line at his bank, which offered free cups of coffee to its angry customers. ``I owe money for wood I bought, Tucci said. ``I can't pay it. I have to close the factory and lay off my 50 workers. Who wants coffee? I want my money.'' Pedro Gianbaggi, a businessman, said: ``Never again will I put my money in a bank.'' He was allowed to withdraw only 1 million australs, about $500, from his blocked certificates of deposit. Lucia Lattuada said the government bonds were ``good only for papering the wall.'' In 1982, Mexico forcibly converted about $10 billion in U.S. dollar accounts to pesos, then devalued the peso by 30 percent. ``It was horrible,'' said Donna Rojinsky, a U.S. Embassy spokeswoman. Many Mexicans decided it wasn't safe to keep their money at home. Those near the border opened accounts on the American side or invested in Texas real estate. Unofficial estimates say Mexicans have $100 billion outside the country, but up to $3.5 billion is said to have returned since President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, a free-marketeer, took office in December 1988. Peso bank accounts now pay interest of 20 percent a year, higher than the inflation rate. Bolivia converted dollar accounts to bolivianos, the local currency, in the 1980s and claimed no one lost anything. That argument was based on the official exchange rate, but bolivianos officially worth a dollar brought only 10 cents on the street. Bolivian private savings, too, went abroad. President Alan Garcia of Peru ordered $900 million in dollar accounts converted to Peruvian soles in 1985 and the money quickly lost value to inflation, which reached four digits by 1987. Small depositors suffered most, because the rich had taken their money out of the country. After the Chilean military coup of 1973, Gen. Augusto Pinochet's government limited withdrawals from savings accounts to $200, but the restriction lasted only two years. Inflation declined and people were allowed to get their money back. Uruguay, which permits foreigners to hold dollar accounts, is an exception to the general rule of banking uncertainty. Of the estimated $60 billion in Argentine funds held outside the country, about $2 billion is thought to be in neighboring Uruguay. Residents of Buenos Aires can visit their money by taking a 30-minute flight or a slightly longer hovercraft ride. Antonio Erman Gonzalez, Argentina's economy minister, said at an April meeting of the Inter-American Development Bank: ``If domestic savings go abroad, it makes it more difficult for Latin American countries to attract foreign investment. The foreigners see the locals taking all their money out of the country.'' Inconsistent government policy has been a major factor in creating the distrust. Under former President Jose Sarney, Brazil allowed private banks to offer numbered, or ``bearer,'' money market accounts. Those accounts invested heavily in Treasury bills and notes, in part financing the government's inflationary spending. The idea was that nameless, high-interest accounts would be an alternative to keeping money in Switzerland or elsewhere. Hours after taking office in March, Collor de Mello outlawed all bearer accounts.
