DOC.HEAD: Adv for Weekend Editions, April 21-22

DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. reported a better-than-expected 9 percent jump in first-quarter earnings over a year ago. The world's biggest computer company said Monday that continued worldwide demand for its product line resulted in stronger revenue and higher profits. For the three months ended March 31, IBM earned $1.03 billion, or $1.81 per share, compared with $950 million, or $1.61 a share, in 1989. Revenue rose 11 percent to $14.18 billion from $12.73 billion.

The Bush administration is allowing South African iron and steel into the United States despite a 1986 economic sanction designed to force an end to apartheid, the State Department said. Most of the controversial imports are ferroalloys, strategic commodities never intended by Congress to be banned under the law, department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said Monday.

Eastern Airlines' creditors pressed their case for a trustee to run the company, while a federal bankruptcy judge indicated he did not favor a liquidation. The head of the committee representing Eastern's unsecured creditors told a bankruptcy court hearing Monday it had no confidence in the ability of the airline's managers to pull the company out of its financial tailspin.

Two Japanese manufacturing and trading companies agreed to pay $160 million for Dataproducts Corp., a computer printer maker besieged by U.S. and foreign competition and unwanted takeover bids. Dataproducts Chairman Jack C. Davis said Monday that the deal with Hitachi Koki Co. Ltd. and Nissei Sangyo Co. Ltd. will give his company access to advanced laser-printing technology and an entry into new Asian markets. The Japanese companies will benefit from a patented Dataproducts' process that shoots a jet of ink that is solid at room temperature.

The Bush administration is examining ideas for broad changes in the banking system but is months away from deciding on specific proposals, officials said. The Treasury Department has expanded an ongoing study of federal deposit insurance to include a look at restructuring the regulatory bureaucracy and at mixing commercial banking with the insurance and securities industries, officials said Monday.

Chase Manhattan Corp. and Manufacturers Hanover Corp. said their first quarter earnings declined, while another large banking company, J.P. Morgan & Co., reported higher profit than a year ago. All three banks, however, continued to feel the pinch of the Third World debt problem, increasing their reserves against potential loan losses in results released Monday.

Primerica Corp. said its first-quarter earnings rose 62 percent, including a 14.9 percent gain at its Wall Street subsidiary, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Smith Barney on Monday reported a profit of $13.1 million on revenue of $384 million in the quarter ended March 31, up from a profit of $11.4 million on revenue of $291 million in the same 1989 quarter. The gains came during a slump in the securities industry.

The Aluminum Company of America said its earnings plunged 46 percent in the first quarter and blamed the decrease in part on a $36 million decline in results from its Brazilian affiliate. Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum producer, said Monday that earnings also suffered because of reduced shipments of fabricated products and a drop in prices for those items and for ingot.

VMS Realty Partners' eight real estate investment funds reported 1989 net losses, largely because of provisions for possible loan losses that the funds' president indicated could go higher. The funds, which are trying to sever their ties with the troubled parent, had been expected to post losses after establishing or increasing loan loss provisions earlier this year. The losses were reported Monday.

Stock prices closed mixed Monday after the market was unable to hold on to a broad advance prompted by a better-than-expected earnings report from International Business Machines Corp. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 11.26 at 2,763.06 after gaining more than 41 points early in the session, but the number of declining issues slightly outnumbered gainers. Bond prices fell as Japanese investors sold long-term Treasury securities. The dollar rose against major foreign currencies in quiet trading. Crude oil futures prices rallied on the eve of a meeting of three key OPEC ministers over the market's recent steep declines; grain and soybean futures prices advanced; cattle and precious metals futures declined; and pork prices were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Six Months Later, Quake Damage Still Evident But Economy Vibrant
DOC.TEXT: Physical and emotional scars persist six months after the killer earthquake jolted the San Francisco Bay area, but most businesses and residents are back on solid ground. Economic activity has nearly regained its pre-quake level, analysts say, and estimates of the cost of damage caused by the massive temblor have been scaled back. The damage is widespread, nevertheless. The elevated section of Interstate 880 in Oakland, where 42 people died when the road collapsed Oct. 17, has been dismantled while discussions continue about whether to rebuild or reroute it. The similarly elevated Embarcadero Freeway stands forlorn near downtown San Francisco while politicians and business people debate whether it should be replaced or rebuilt. Two sections of busy Highway 101 in San Francisco are under repair, intensifying rush-hour traffic jams, and some small businesses in hard-hit Oakland, Los Gatos, Santa Cruz and Watsonville are still awaiting federal loans for reconstruction and inventory replacement. In downtown Oakland, where many empty buildings are surrounded by chain-link fences, the Emporium department store isn't expected to reopen until August. The store suffered more than $10 million in damage when display windows shattered, stairwells collapsed and the exterior brick facade cracked. Small tremors, shrugged off or barely noticed by the Bay area's six million residents before the 7.1 magnitude quake last fall, now trigger memories of the tragedy that claimed 68 lives and worries about the really big one that geologists say is bound to come. But the region's economy, on the whole, has rebounded vigorously with no evidence of long-term damage. From the computer and chip companies in Silicon Valley to the retail and financial giants in San Francisco, the Bay area remains one of the most vibrant centers of economic activity in the country. Retail business in San Francisco is now about 96 percent of normal, said Deputy Mayor James Ho. That's despite the fact that some hard-hit sections _ Chinatown, North Beach, South of Market, Fisherman's Wharf and the Mission _ continue to suffer. Business in those areas is down from 8 to 18 percent, Ho said. An economic index based on measures of activity in real estate, retailing, services, international trade, manufacturing and tourism for the nine Bay area counties shows the region's economy virtually recovered from the quake by December after a small dip in October and November. The index compiled by Tapan Munroe, an economist with Pacific Gas & Electric Co. in San Francisco, and Walter E. Hoadley, a Hoover Institution senior fellow, showed the overall strength of a diversified economy that had long planned on ways to cope with a big quake. ``The preparedness paid off,'' Munroe said. ``The region fared very well in terms of emergency services.'' Early estimates of $7 billion to $10 billion in damage have been scaled down, but Munroe said the current figure of $5.6 billion from state officials is still too high. Hotel and restaurant owners said their businesses still suffer, though hotel occupancy rates in San Francisco are close to normal even after the post-quake opening of two new large hotels, said Steve Reiser of the accounting firm Pannell Kerr Forster. Passenger arrivals at San Francisco International Airport were off 11.8 percent in October and 4 percent in November from the same months in 1988. But arrivals were up 0.7 percent in December. Fewer travelers from within the United States are coming to San Francisco this year because of higher domestic air fares, but international arrivals are booming, said airport spokesman Ron Wilson. Ray Brady, research director for the Association of Bay Area Governments in Oakland, said the region pulled through the quake so easily because the economy is decentralized. When the Bay Bridge collapse cut traffic in San Francisco, he noted, retail sales went up in the East Bay _ so total retail sales in the region remained constant. Traffic began rolling over the repaired Bay Bridge a month after its partial collapse, and workers are continuing to repair the two closed sections of Highway 101. San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos wants to replace the Embarcadero Freeway, long considered an eyesore, with an underground expressway. The city's Board of Supervisors approved the plan Monday night despite a three-hour strike by Chinatown merchants, who claim that repairing the existing roadway would be cheaper and get business traffic back into the depressed area more quickly.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors' Head Says They've Lost Confidence in Eastern's Management
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Will be led if developments warrant; hearing scheduled to resume at 9 a.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The head of the panel of Eastern Airlines' unsecured creditors says the group has lost confidence in the ability of the airline's managers to pull the company out of its financial troubles. Eastern's unsecured creditors were expected to continue pressing their case today for a trustee to run the company. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland, meanwhile, indicated at a hearing Monday he did not favor a liquidation of the airline. Alan Boyd, chairman of the unsecured creditors' committee, cited Eastern's continuing financial losses and what he called management's inability to forecast results with ``anything close to reality.'' Boyd, chairman of Airbus Industrie of North America, also said at Monday's hearing that Eastern's management had shown itself unable to regain the confidence of the flying public and travel agents since a devastating strike more than a year ago. Airbus, the jet maker owned by a consortium of European nations, is one of Eastern's major suppliers and is owed roughly $100 million by the airline. The creditors' committee wants Lifland to appoint a special trustee to take over the management of Eastern in place of Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp. Eastern's management said appointment of a trustee would doom the airline. The hearing began with a lengthy session last Friday. Eastern also is asking the judge for permission to withdraw $80 million from an escrow account to cover second-quarter operations. Lorenzo and Eastern President Phil Bakes are expected to testify for the company today or later in the week as the hearing continues. Eastern has been attempting to reorganize under bankruptcy court protection from creditors, but several attempted restructuring plans either have failed to win creditor approval or have fallen through. Boyd said creditors objected, among other things, to Eastern's proposal to sell its maintenance facility in Miami for about $100 million because they believed it would remove an integral part of Eastern's operations. Boyd said the committee, which had been supportive of Eastern's previous reorganization proposals, began to change its attitude early this year when the airline proposed cutting debt payments to creditors. The committee lost confidence after Eastern said on March 27 that it no longer could honor an earlier proposal to repay unsecured creditors 50 cents for every dollar owed, Boyd said. The same day, the unsecured creditors passed a resolution to seek a trustee to liquidate Eastern if Texas Air didn't agree to cover the company's losses. Since then, the committee has shifted and said it wants a trustee either to sell the airline as a going concern or in parts. Eastern owes the creditors around $980 million. Preferred shareholders _ who still are seeking to liquidate the airine _ are due $680 million. Bruce Zirinsky, an attorney for Eastern, warned Monday that appointment of a trustee would be ``one more step'' toward the liquidation of Eastern, which he said could have serious financial consequences to creditors. However, Lifland responded that if a trustee were appointed to operate Eastern, it would be someone in the airline industry. A travel agent, appearing as a witness for Eastern, warned that the airline would lose business if a trustee were designated to run it. ``The word trustee would be equated with liquidation and I, for one, would book away from Eastern,'' said Richard Copeland, president of the New York chapter of the American Society of Travel Agents and the head of Hillside Travel Inc. in New York. The pilots, Machinists and flight attendants unions struck Eastern on March 4, 1989, forcing the Miami-based airline into bankruptcy protection five days later. The Machinists union remains on strike. The unions have sought a trustee almost from the outset. They claim Lorenzo has been bleeding Eastern by funneling assets to Texas Air and to Continental Airlines, Eastern's largely non-union sister carrier. A report by court-appointed examiner David I. Shapiro filed in early March suggested Texas Air had victimized Eastern by underpaying for the airline and some of its assets by hundreds of millions of dollars.

DOC.HEAD: VMS Funds Report 1989 Net Losses
DOC.TEXT: More than 100,000 investors hit by losses at eight real estate funds seeking independence from troubled VMS Realty Partners are hoping an audit will bring some good news, an industry analyst says. The funds involved _ five real estate investment trusts and three publicly traded trusts _ reported a total of nearly $260 million in net losses for 1989 on Monday. They were formed as mortgage vehicles to make loans on properties _ mostly commercial _ that were being developed by VMS Realty Partners, one of the nation's largest real estate companies. The company announced in February that it was suspending most payments to creditors and to the eight funds due to severe cash flow problems that analysts said were a sign of the weak real estate syndication business. The funds' financial problems were ``no surprise,'' said Barry Vinocur, editor of the Stanger Register, a monthly financial magazine on real estate investments published in Shrewsbury, N.J. The important news will be the results of an analysis of VMS finances by the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand, Vinocur said. The analysis will study the mortgage loans and underlying collateral of all eight funds to determine what dividends, if any, will be paid by the funds. ``The issue for these investors is really straightforward,'' he said. ``That is, what's the value of the assets that these trusts and partnerships own.'' Investors also want to know ``what is the likelihood that current management can maximize the investment that is there,'' he said. VMS Mortgage Investment Fund reported the biggest loss of the eight, $109.2 million or $2.75 a share, compared with a 1988 net income of $9.5 million, or 73 cents a share. Leonard G. Levine, president of the funds, said in a statement that the losses included provisions for possible loan losses. The funds' independent board of directors ``will continue to seek to realize the maximum amount possible in connection with its mortgage loans,'' he said. VMS Realty has managed assets of more than $9 billion, including high-profile hotels in Florida, California and Hawaii. After the company's February announcement, Levine and four other VMS officers resigned. Levine was appointed chief of the eight funds, which are now managed by an independent board of directors and are seeking new names. These developments followed a management shakeup in November that put Jeffrey J. Park, a former Xerox executive, in charge of VMS. A Xerox subsidiary, Xerox Credit Corp., owns 25 percent of VMS. VMS in November also announced a $110 million writeoff. The other funds andtheir reported 1989 losses are: _VMS Mortgage Investors Limited Partnership ii, $34.7 million, or $2.75 per unit, compared with 1988 net income of $11.9 million or 94 cents a unit _VMS Mortgage Investors Limited Partnership, $32.3 million, or $4.20 a unit, compared with 1988 net income of $10 million, or $1.30 a unit. _VMS Strategic Land Fund II, $27.5 million or $1.43 a share, compared with 1988 net income of $20.6 million or $1.11 a share. _VMS Hotel Investment Fund, $25 million or $2.54 a share, compared with 1988 net income of $7.2 million, or 74 cents a share. _VMS Mortgage Investors Limited Partnership III, $19.4 million, or $1.71 a unit, compared with 1988 net income of $9.6 million, or 86 cents a share. _VMS Strategic Land Trust, $9 million, or 75 cents a share, compared with 1988 net income of $13.1 million, or $1.10 a share. _VMS Short Term Income Trust, $2.7 million, or 39 cents a share, compared with 1988 net income of $7.8 million, or $1.14 a share.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Companies to Buy California Computer Printer Maker
DOC.TEXT: Dataproducts Corp. said a $160 million takeover by two Japanese companies will give the company access to advanced laser-printing technology and an entry into Asian markets. Monday's deal with Hitachi Koki Co. Ltd. and Nissei Sangyo Co. Ltd. marked the end of independence for Dataproducts, a maker of computer printers that had been beseiged by foreign competition and unwanted takeover bids. The buyers, both members of Japan's largest manufacturing group, the Hitachi Group, will benefit in turn from a patented Dataproducts' process that shoots a jet of ink that is solid at room temperature. ``That's believed by most people in the industry to be the technology which will be used to bring low-cost vivid color printing,'' Dataproducts Chairman Jack C. Davis said in a telephone interview. ``This gives all three of us the ability to be strongly positioned,'' said Davis, who will stay on as chairman, reporting to a private board made up of officials of the other companies, under terms of the deal. Hitachi Koki, which makes electrical equipment and power tools, and Nissei Sangyo, which makes machinery and light equipment and has sales offices in 22 countries, agreed to pay $10 per share for Dataproducts. Dataproducts stock shot up $3.25 a share to close at $9.62{ on the American Stock Exchange. Under an agreement approved by Dataproducts' board, a joint venture of the Japanese companies will make a cash tender offer for all of Dataproducts' outstanding shares. ``Dataproducts is an outstanding company,'' Hiroshi Gommori, Hitachi Koki's president, said in a statement. ``We and Nissei Sangyo respect its reputation, technology and management.'' Last year, DPC Acquisition pursued an unsolicited $15-a-share bid for Dataproducts, but Dataproducts rejected it and the deal fell through. DPC was an acquisition group led by John K. Castle, the former chief executive of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, a New York investment banking firm. Dataproducts instead announced its own restructuring, which involved selling its 22-acre headquarters property, paying a special $2-a-share dividend, eliminating 400 U.S. jobs _ a fifth of its domestic work force _ and trying to sell a New England subsidiary that made heavy-duty printers. The company has struggled to update its products with laser technology, cut operating costs and maintain its sales and profit growth. Using engines purchased from Toshiba, Sharp and other Japanese manufacturers, for example, Dataproducts built a machine capable of printing 26 lines per minute. Hitachi Koki, on the other hand, makes printers that can handle up to 135 lines per minute. In its latest earnings report, Dataproducts said it lost $4.1 million, or 21 cents per share, for its third fiscal quarter, compared with a year-earlier profit of $1.6 million, or 8 cents a share. Revenue declined 16 percent from $94.5 million to $79.3 million, the company said in the January report. In the fiscal year ending March 25, 1989, it earned $3.8 million on sales of $353.4 million, down from a $9 million profit a year earlier. Hitachi Koki had sales last year of 109 billion yen, or about $686 million at current exchange rates. Nissei Sangyo's revenues were 482 billion yen, or $3 billion. Davis said he had been talking with representatives of the other companies since the middle of last year, in the middle of the unwelcome takeover bid by DPC. ``The philosophies of the companies are similar in terms of a drive for high-quality products,'' Davis said.

DOC.HEAD: Convenience Store Chain Misses Debt-Interest Payment
DOC.TEXT: Circle K Corp. put a halt on interest payments to bondholders as part of an agreement with its banks that is intended to restructure the ailing convenience store chain's $1.3 billion in debt. Circle K on Monday missed a deadline for an interest payment on $125 million in 12} percent debentures due in 1997, heeding the request of its bankers. Under an agreement in principle announced April 4, bank lenders that have extended nearly $800 million in senior debt to Circle K have the right to determine whether the company can pay interest on subordinated debt. ``The banks have exercised that prerogative at this point,'' said Ray Cox, a spokesman for Circle K. The company operates the nation's second largest convenience store chain with 4,651 stores, and licenses about 1,350 overseas. The agreement is part of a restructuring that could include exchanging some outstanding subordinated debt securities for new bonds, stock or cash. The company plans to file exchange-offer materials with the federal Securities and Exchange Commission before May 15, Cox said. Circle K is considering offering a new bond issue to holders of the 12} percent bonds or 13 percent debentures, both due in 1997, as well as privately held notes, 8\ percent debentures due in 2005 and 7\ percent securities due in 2006. The new issue, about equal to the market value of the existing bonds, would be convertible into a majority of the company's common stock, Cox said. Circle K also is considering giving bondholders an option to receive cash at about market value for their securities. American Financial Corp., the company's largest shareholder and a creditor, tentatively has agreed to buy $100 million of the new bond issue, Cox said. But he said Circle K has not finalized the offer. Under a standstill agreement, American Financial, the bank lenders and holders of $200 million in notes due Oct. 15, 1993, will defer all principal and interest payments on Circle K debt and waive any existing payment defaults. The banks are entitled to judge the company's ability to make interest payments on its debt. The agreement will last until Oct. 31 or the completion of the company's restructuring, whichever is earlier. Cox said Circle K believes it will have sufficient cash to meet daily business obligations during the restructuring. Because of the restructuring, Circle K has not completed sale of 350 stores in the Pacific Northwest. Circle K orginally said it expected to close the sale to PC Venture Ltd. of Canada by April 1. The company also has announced its intention to sell 25 stores in Hawaii to Texaco Refining and Marketing Co. by May 15, but Cox said that deal also may be delayed.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Chairman Holds Peace Luncheon With Challenger
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. Chairman Daniel Tellep held a peace lunch with Harold Simmons, the billionaire Texan who tried but failed to wrest away control of the aerospace company in a proxy battle. Monday's meeting was set up after Simmons received an invitation from Tellep more than two weeks ago, Simmons spokesman Largent Parks said. He called the invitation ``sort of an olive-branch type of thing.'' The lunch followed a reconvening of the company's annual meeting, at which Lockheed revealed the official tally of votes in the proxy battle. Simmons and Tellep had no immediate comment on their luncheon. Tellep offered to hold a series of talks with Simmons and other major Lockheed shareholders after Lockheed's annual meeting March 29. Simmons lost a proxy battle for control of Lockheed's board that culminated at the meeting. Several big institutional shareholders sided with him, though, leading Tellep to make major concessions to big shareholders. Those included a promise to create three new board seats for them. About 120 people, mostly Lockheed workers and retirees, attended Monday's reconvened meeting, which lasted seven minutes at a hotel in Woodland Hills. Tellep thanked them for supporting him. As earlier announced, Simmons' nominees for Lockheed's board were defeated, getting slightly less than 40 percent of the votes, but shareholders rights issues backed by Simmons passed. Those included a recommendation that Lockheed drop its ``poison pill'' provision, which makes it prohibitively expensive for any person or institution to acquire more than 20 percent of Lockheed's shares. Simmons, through his N.L. Industries, owns 18.9 percent of Lockheed's common stock. He paid about $530 million for his shares and has a paper loss to date of about $100 million. Simmons had said he wanted to force Lockheed to concentrate harder on its core businesses. He said he would sell assets from the technology services and electronics systems groups if they could not quickly turn bigger profits. Profits at Lockheed, the nation's sixth-largest military contractor, fell from $624 million in 1988 to $2 million last year. That was chiefly because the company took nearly $500 million in special charges after underestimating the costs of developing several programs, such as a submarine-hunting plane. Lockheed said holders of 82 percent of its stock, 52,685,008 shares of the 63,192,196 shares outstanding, had cast votes. Lockheed's directors got from 57.6 percent to 60.7 percent of the votes. On other issues: _A recommendation that Lockheed adopt confidential voting, one of the issues on which Tellep gave ground, passed by 60 percent. _A bylaw amendment exempting Lockheed from the tough anti-takeover provisions of Delaware law, another measure on which Tellep flip-flopped, passed by 61 percent. Lockheed, with headquarters in the Los Angeles suburb of Calabasas, is incorporated in Delaware. _The recommendation to overturn the ``poison pill'' passed by 54 percent, with 41 percent against and 5 percent abstaining. Excluding shares voted by N.L. Industries, which proposed the measure, it would have lost by a wide margin, Lockheed said. Tellep has refused to give ground on this issue.

DOC.HEAD: Landmark to Sell Kiawah Properties, Along With Others For $967 Million
DOC.TEXT: A California developer will pay $967 million to buy the golf courses, hotel and amenities on Kiawah Island and other properties in California and Florida from Landmark Land Co., a company official said. Gerald G. Barton, president and chairman of Landmark, said the sale is scheduled to be completed in June 1991. The buyer is Irvine, Calif., developer Barry G. Hon and his Palos Verdes Land Holdings Inc. ``It should have very little effect on Kiawah. We're selling the collection of properties instead of piecemealing them,'' Barton said Monday. ``He's acquiring the whole management team. He has the option (of selling them off individually), but I don't think he will.'' Landmark's property will be sold in two phases, Barton said. The first phase of the sale will take place this year, and involves the sale for $497 million of a substantial portion of Landmark's golf, tennis and large-tract development divisions in California. Landmark will finance about 79 percent of the sale. Specifically, Hon will buy Oak Valley, Oak Summit, Greenspot and Moreno Valley Ranch developments together with the Carmel Valley Ranch golf and tennis resort. Kiawah will be sold during the second phase, along with properties in West Palm Beach, Fla.; and Riverside and Placer counties, Calif. The second phase will cost about $470 million, of which Landmark will finance about 76 percent. The sales would leave Landmark with about $400 million in real estate in California, Oklahoma and Louisiana. Most of those properties are expected to be disposed of over the next five years. Landmark, which is based in Carmel, Calif., has received high marks for the beauty and design of its properties, but its fortunes have sagged along with the economies of Oklahoma and Louisiana. Even many of its golf courses, considered among the world's best, have had negative cash flow, said Kenneth Campbell, president of Audit Investments Inc., a Montvale, N.J., investment advisory firm that follows real estate companies. Landmark posted a fourth quarter 1989 loss of $20.5 million, compared with a profit of $16.9 million a year earlier. Hon owns property in Oklahoma, Louisiana and California, and is best known for his 2,743-acre Foothill Ranch development in South Orange County, Calif. Palos Verdes Land Holdings Inc. currently is developing a Ritz Carlton Resort Hotel and golf course as well as custom homes in Rancho Palos Verdes, an exclusive suburb of Los Angeles. Hon is a board member of the South Coast Medical Center, a founder of the Orange County Performing Arts Center and retired chairman of the board of Eldorado Bank. He is a member of the Orange County Transportation Commission Toll Road Task Force and holds a bachelor's degree from the University of Tulsa.

DOC.HEAD: Yamaichi Securities Faces $24 Million Loss
DOC.TEXT: Yamaichi Securities, one of Japan's 17 major securities companies, said Tuesday it faces a loss of $24 million due to one customer's bankruptcy last month. Yamaichi, on orders from a customer late in February, bought 3 million shares _ or one-seventh of the total outstanding _ of Nippon Seisen, a leading wire maker, at the equivalent of about $44 million for delivery in four days. Yamaichi was supposed to receive $70,520 in commission for the transaction, but ``the customer, an institutional investor, failed to settle the transaction and went bankrupt on March 30,'' said Yamaichi spokesman Takao Adachi. Meantime, he said, prices on the Tokyo stock market began to crash and the price of Nippon Seisen's shares plunged to $6.54 a share on Tuesday from $14.65 in February. ``Negotiations for remedy are ongoing. If they fail, the company might bring the case to the court because there's always possibility that manipulation might have been involved in a case like this,'' Adachi said. Manipulation is the act of depressing or raising prices artificially so that they do not represent true value. This is done by creating an appearance of active buying or selling, either alone or in concert with others. The act violates Japan's securities law and is subject to criminal and civil penalties. Adachi said the investor, a company operating coffee shops, had been a good customer for Yamaichi during the last two years, although its earlier investments were made on a smaller scale. No comment was immediately available from Osaka-based Nippon Seisen.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Bills Rates Lowest Since February
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell at the government's weekly auction. The Treasury Department on Monday sold $8.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.71 percent, down from 7.80 percent last week. Another $8.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.75 percent, also down from 7.80 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.65 percent on Feb. 12, and six-month bills averaged 7.70 percent on Feb. 26. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.97 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,805.10 and 8.18 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,608.20. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, was unchanged last week from 8.29 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Last-Minute Tax Filers Rush to Get Their Returns in the Mail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT to Berlucchi sted Berlucci. INSERTS 3 grafs after 13th graf pvs. `I mailed ... to UPDATE with returns destroyed in Norfolk fire; picks up 14th graf pvs: `Demonstrators, mostly ...' A version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Last-minute tax filers trying to beat Uncle Sam's deadline were handed free aspirin in post office lines, while others scrambled for 11th-hour tax shelters. A postal worker was injured by a letter bomb addressed to ``tax thieves.'' Millions of procrastinators produced the usual midnight crowds and traffic jams in cities large and small as Tax Day 1990 drew to a close. An envelope containing a tea bag in apparent reference to the tax protest that helped spark the American Revolution blew up Monday night outside the Royal Oak Post Office in suburban Detroit as workers collected tax returns. The bomb spewed a red liquid. A 29-year-old postal worker, Tom Berlucchi, was treated at a hospital for burns on his hands and face, authorities said. A woman dressed as an aspirin bottle handed out samples at the post office in Chicago, and a Philadelphia radio station blasting rock music from a van gave away stamps. At Twentieth Century Investors Inc. in Kansas City, customers opened more than 130 Individual Retirement Accounts, or IRAs, in three hours. ``We even burned out a fax machine getting applications to clients out of town,'' said Gunnar Hughes, a Twentieth Century spokesman. The Internal Revenue Service did not estimate how many taxpayers waited until the last minute. But the agency predicted about 34 million returns _ more than 30 percent of the 111 million expected this year _ would be filed after April 6. The deadline is usually April 15, but it was a Sunday this year so the IRS delayed it a day. The IRS Form 4868 was one of the most-sought pieces of paper in the nation as an estimated 6 million Americans abandoned hopes of meeting the midnight deadline. Filing a Form 4868, along with a check for estimated taxes owed, extends the deadline to Aug. 15. Michigan Treasurer Robert Bowman was among the late and bleary eyed. ``I always wait until the last minute to do my own taxes because I spend the first three months of the year worrying about everyone else's. But I always get a refund,'' he said. Elliott Swinton, 27, who was among those in line at a copy machine in Philadelphia, said he did his taxes weeks ago but delayed filing them until the last minute. ``We owed money. Why give it to them two months ago?'' he said. A New York City sales representative, 24-year-old Michael Alleyne, balanced his state form on his knees on the steps of the main post office in Manhattan. ``I mailed the federal form at 9:30 and then did the state form out here on the steps,'' he said. ``But at least I had the envelope filled out. I didn't procrastinate that part.'' Dozens of taxpayers in Norfolk, Va., are going to have to do their taxes over because of two mailbox fires discovered Monday that postal inspectors think were deliberately set. Sixty-five tax envelopes were in good enough shape to send on to the IRS, but 37 were too damaged to forward. On several, the name of the taxpayer was destroyed, postal workers said. ``It's all I need,'' said Shirley Evans, when she found out she had to redo her burned tax form. ``I think there's a lot of sick people in the world who do things like that. I have better things to do than set a mailbox on fire.'' Demonstrators, mostly those who oppose the use of tax dollars for defense or nuclear projects or who oppose paying taxes altogether, mingled in post office crowds in Philadelphia, suburban Atlanta and Greenfield, Mass. ``We're here to say our taxes are going to the wrong place ... to defense,'' said Rich Garella, 24, of Philadelphia. ``The people dropping off their taxes here tonight are funding the war in El Salvador. They should be spent on human needs here. There are people sleeping on grates.'' Decatur, Ga., Postmaster Crawford Lovett had 15 or 20 tax protesters in his domain carrying signs against the use of tax dollars to finance nuclear weapons. ``One woman was dressed up like an angel, carrying a `ban the bomb' sign and a huge American flag. Then she walks over to my employee and hands him her tax return,'' Lovett said.

DOC.HEAD: Co-Founder of Company That Became Marriott Dies at 89
DOC.TEXT: Hugh Wilkens Colton, a rancher, lawyer, war hero and co-founder of the company that later became the Marriott Corp., has died. He was 89. Colton died Saturday at his home in Vernal. In 1927, Colton opened a root beer stand in Washington, D.C., with his longtime friend J. Willard Marriott. The partners went on to open three Hot Shoppes Restaurants before Colton sold his interest to Marriott for $5,000. Colton, who graduated from the University of Utah and George Washington Law School, was a commander in the Utah National Guard. He was called to active duty before Pearl Harbor and commanded troops that landed at Normandy on D-day. He achieved the rank of colonel and was awarded military honors of three countries, including the Silver Star with oak leaf cluster, French Croix de Guerre and Belgium Medal of Honor. Colton raised cattle and horses and was a director of the Utah Cattlemen's Association and the National Cowboy Hall of Fame. He was active in regional and local water conservancy. He worked for many years on the Upper Colorado River Project, serving as chairman of a four-state committee that secured funding from Congress. He also was active in the Mormon Church. Colton is survived by his wife, Marguerite Maughan Colton, three sons, 13 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Funeral services were scheduled for Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Northeast Bancorp-Bank of New York Merger in Doubt
DOC.TEXT: A proposed merger between Bank of New York Co. and Northeast Bancorp Inc. is in jeopardy because the two sides cannot agree on how much Northeast is worth. In documents filed Monday with the Federal Reserve Board, Bank of New York placed the value of Northeast stock at $12.31 a share. Northeast, the parent of Union Trust Co. of New Haven, maintained its shares had a book value of $33.50 as of March 31. Bank of New York said it based its calculations on a thorough asessment of Northeast's loans. ``It's going to be difficult to reach a compromise,'' said Gerard Cassidy, a bank analyst with Tucker, Anthony Inc. He said a merger looks doubtful. The two banks agreed to merge in 1983, at which time Bank of New York said it would pay 1.85 times the book value. The deal, which expires Aug. 15, was amended in 1986 to 2.5 times book value. Northeast said it views the merger plans as a legal contract and would ``pursue all legal remedies'' to enforce the agreement. A new interstate banking law in Connecticut would have allowed the two to merge last month.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Slump Blamed on Falling Aluminum Prices
DOC.TEXT: Reynolds Metals Co. on Tuesday reported a 37.6 percent drop in its first quarter income reflecting a steep decline in prices for aluminum ingot and other aluminum products. The Richmond-based metals company said it earned $77.7 million, or $1.31 a share, in the three months ended March 31, down from $124.5 million, or $2.28 a share, in the same period a year ago. Revenue in the latest quarter fell about 4 percent to $1.39 billion from $1.45 billion in the corresponding 1989 quarter. William O. Bourke, Reynolds' chairman and chief executive officer, said a steep decline in the price of aluminum ingot and many aluminum fabricated products affected first-quarter earnings. ``Aluminum ingot prices today are approximately 40 percent below where they were at the beginning of 1989, and we have seen varying degrees of price erosion for many fabricated aluminum products as a result,'' Bourke said. However, Bourke said aluminum demand and prices have improved in recent weeks. The company's aluminum shipments in the first quarter were up 2 percent from first-quarter 1989 to 319,700 metric tons, compared with 312,900 tons a year ago. The company's annual shareholders' meeting will be held Wednesday in Richmond.

Prices moved broadly lower on Wall Street today after a double dose of bad economic news dashed trader hopes for an easing of interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 13.29 to 2,749.77 as of 11 a.m. EDT. Declining issues had a 3 to 1 lead over advancers, with 319 stocks rising, 967 falling and 488 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume came to 47 million shares at mid-morning. Prices took a series of hits from two March economic indicators and the bond market's reaction to them. The Labor Department said consumer prices soared an unexpectedly high 0.5 percent last month, pushing the inflation rate for the first three months of 1990 to its highest level in almost eight years. The stock market was most concerned by a 0.7 percent rise in prices excluding the volatile food and energy categories. The government also reported today that industrial production rose 0.7 percent last month due in large part to increases in the output of automobiles following a major cutback in January. Both reports wiped out hopes that the Federal Reserve might nudge interest rates lower anytime soon. The Fed has been trying to keep inflation in check and the economy from overheating by keeping keeping rates relatively high. Wall Street took its cue from the bond market, with skidded in response to the reports. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was off $12.50 per $1,000 face value early today. IBM, which shot up 3} after a rosy earnings report on Monday, was off } to 110[ and led the NYSE most active list today. NCR, which reported a 15 percent first-quarter earnings decline, tumbled 4\ to 110[. Philip Morris was up \ to 42|, Citicorp was off \ at 24, and Exxon was unchanged at 45|. The NYSE's index of all its listed common stocks was off 0.84 at 188.10. On the American Stock Exhcange, the market value index fell 1.99 to 354.99.

DOC.HEAD: Sony to Make Picture Tubes at Former Volkswagen Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with more details, comments from Sony official, Heinz; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Sony Corp. will manufacture picture tubes for large color television sets at a shuttered Volkswagen assembly plant outside Pittsburgh, creating about 1,000 jobs in the next three years, Gov. Robert Casey said today. Casey said at a news conference the Japanese electronics company plans to spend about $300 million to refurbish and equip a 600-acre parcel of the plant site near New Stanton, about 45 miles southeast of Pittsburgh. The company also will lease a 200-acre parcel nearby for ``the possible development within the next five years of an additional new manufacturing facility,'' according to an agreement signed today by Casey and Masaaki Morita, chairman of Sony Corp. of America. ``Sony's TV business in the United States is growing while at the same time the market trend is toward larger and larger screen sizes,'' Morita said. He said Sony decided to locate in Pennsylvania in order to be closer to key suppliers in central and eastern United States. The company already has a picture-tube plant in San Diego. ``We believe we must make the product in the market where we sell it,'' he said. Sony will lease the property from the state, which will provide $23.5 million dollars in loans and job training grants to the company, Casey said. About 2,500 auto workers lost their jobs two years ago when Volkswagen of America Inc. closed the assembly plant after 10 years of production. Since then, the 2.8 million-square-foot plant has been on the market. Sony confirmed in October it was looking at several sites in southwestern Pennsylvania for a possible location for a sixth U.S. plant. ``Our highest economic development priority these past two years has been bringing new jobs and new hope to the families of Westmoreland County and the entire region,'' Casey said. He said Sony's decision to invest in the plant marks a successful conclusion to those efforts. U.S. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., said the plant will help balance the United States' huge trade deficit with Japan. ``It means a great deal more than jobs and investment,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Grains, Soybeans Marginally Higher Despite Profit-taking
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were mostly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade despite profit-taking in the wake of Monday's sharp rise in prices. Corn prices opened steady to fractionally higher as traders consolidated Monday's gains. Analysts say continued foreign demand could boost prices. Wheat prices also were fractionally higher in early trading, on expectations the Soviet Union will make an additional bid for U.S. wheat under the export bonus program. Soybean futures were slightly higher despite profit taking at the open. In early trading, wheat was { cent higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.71 a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to } cent higher with May at $2.72 a bushel; oats were 2{ cents to 3\ cents higher with May at $1.55{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 1} cents higher with May at $5.91\ a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, with prices pressured by followthrough selling from Monday's weak close. Expectation that supplies will increase through the spring and into summer caused the selling of live cattle futures. Feeder cattle prics were pushed lower by live cattle's weakness. Lower cash prices put pressure on live hog futures, and frozen pork bellies were pushed lower by expectation of lower fresh belly prices. DOC.HEAD: Double-Digit Increase in GE's First-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co., buoyed by new orders in its aircraft engine and power systems divisions, on Tuesday reported a 12 percent profit gain for the first quarter. GE reported earnings of $950 million in the three months ended March 31, up from $849 million in the first quarter of 1989. Earnings per share were up 13 percent, to $1.06 from 94 cents. Revenue rose 6 percent to $12.6 billion in the first quarter of this year from $11.9 billion a year earlier. ``Very strong earnings improvements were reported by GE Capital, Power Systems and Aircraft Engines,'' said GE chairman John F. Welch Jr. Other divisions with higher earnings included lighting, medical systems, transportation systems, and electrical distribution and controls. He said new orders for power generation were up 60 percent from the first quarter of 1989, while orders from the company's medical systems division were 25 percent ahead of last year. The company reported a total backlog of $35 billion in the aircraft engine division, following new orders from Lufthansa and from Aeroflot, the Soviet national airline. GE said operating profit from its major appliances division was even with last year, while profit and revenue from its broadcasting arm, NBC, were ``somewhat below'' the first-quarter figures in 1989. Operating profit from its materials division was down considerably, which the company attributed to slower demand for cars, appliances and housing. GE said growth in earnings per share was slightly higher than net earnings because of a $10 billion share repurchase program announced last year. Under the program, the company bought back 11.6 million shares for $728 million in the first quarter, bringing total shares acquired to 15.3 million, for a total $963 million, since the program began in November 1989.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T And Two Unions Reach Tentative Agreement on Early Retirement
DOC.TEXT: About 34,000 union employees of American Telephone & Telegraph Co. would be eligible for early retirement under a tentative buyout agreement reached between unions and management, officials from both sides said Tuesday. Beginning May 1, the company would add at least three years to each worker's age and tenure and five years for those workers whose jobs are considered obsolete, said AT&T spokesmkan Burke Stinson. Workers in the latter category, including telephone operators, would also receive a 15 percent boost in monthly pension payments, Stinson said. The unions involved are the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. The proposal follows similar incentives offered last year to managers as AT&T seeks to trim its workforce and modernize operations in the wake of the 1984 breakup of the Bell System. Last year, 39 percent, or 12,535 of 32,121 managers, opted to retire early under a plan that added five years to each manager's age and tenure, and boosted pension payments by 15 percent. IBEW spokesman Joe Penna said the proposal on the table is an improvement over an offer rejected by the unions last month. AT&T offered to add five years to each worker's age, but did not increase the size of the pension payments, Stinson said. Penna said business managers plan to meet next week to discuss the proposal. About one-third of the eligible workers _ between 8,000 and 12,000 _ are expected to opt for early retirement, Penna said. Stinson said AT&T plans to trim 12,000 people from its payrolls this year. The plan is seen as a measure to ``soften the impact,'' Stinson said. Representatives of the Communications Workers of America did not immediately return telephone calls to their New York City headquarters. AT&T has 165,400 non-management workers.

DOC.HEAD: Drop in Earnings Depresses Stock
DOC.TEXT: NCR Corp. on Tuesday said its income fell 15 percent in the first quarter due to lower profit margins and the cost of a share repurchase program. The news hit NCR's stock hard. The stock tumbled $6.25 to $64.50 a share by noon on the New York Stock Exchange in heavy trading. The company earned $52 million, or 73 cents a share, in the first three months of 1990, down from $61 million, or 77 cents a share, a year earlier. Net income was negatively affected when the company repurchased 1.6 million common shares of stock this quarter. However, the stock buyback had a favorable impact on earnings per share. First-quarter revenue was $1.27 billion, up 1 percent over last year's $1.25 billion. And the company reported that first-quarter orders reached the highest level for any quarter in NCR's history. ``Orders in the United States showed a gain, while orders overseas achieved an all-time record with a substantial gain over the prior year,'' said NCR Chairman Charles Exley. NCR develops and manufactures business information processing systems.

DOC.HEAD: PaineWebber Reports 17 Percent Quarterly Gain
DOC.TEXT: PaineWebber Group Inc. on Tuesday reported a 17 percent increase in first-quarter earnings, but the gains came against a particularly weak quarter a year ago on Wall Street. PaineWebber, the nation's eighth-largest brokerage, said its core businesses including retail sales and asset management all showed improvement in the still-slumping securities industry. PaineWebber reported net income of $10.8 million, or 20 cents per share, in the three months ended March 30. That was up from $9.18 million, or 11 cents per share, in the same 1989 period. Revenue rose 7 percent to $426 million from $397 million a year earlier. Compared with the 1989 fourth quarter, overall earnings were down slightly from $10.9 million. ``PaineWebber's first-quarter results represent continued improved operating performance of our major businesses,'' PaineWebber Chairman Donald B. Marron said in a statement. He said retail sales, institutional equity, fixed income, asset management and international businesses all showed improvement over the first quarter of 1989, an extremely weak one during the securities industry recession. The quarterly increase was the second reported by a Wall Street firm despite the pronounced downturn in the securities industry since the 1987 stock market crash. Other firms are expected to report less positive results. PaineWebber said its first-quarter earnings were hurt by a weak investment banking environment and losses from risk arbitrage trading. PaineWebber's investment banking revenue was $67.6 million, a 12.7 percent gain, but sharply lower than $75.9 million in the 1989 fourth quarter. Brokerage commissions rose 8.5 percent to $162 million, but also were sharply lower than $179 million in the fourth quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Hallmark Accepts Tenders of Univision Junk Bonds
DOC.TEXT: Hallmark Cards Inc. said Tuesday it dropped a key condition of a tender offer for $270 million in junk bonds issued by the company's Univision Holdings Inc. unit, and had accepted $251.9 million of the bonds for payment. Hallmark, a privately held greetings card company based in Kansas City, Mo., also said it had reached an agreement with bank lenders on restructuring the cash-strapped Spanish-language television company's payments to the banks. Univision had been authorized to file for protection from creditors under terms of the federal bankruptcy laws if the tender offer was unsuccessful, and Hallmark's purchase averts that possibility. Hallmark had offered to pay $131 million for two series of junk bonds on which its 63.5 percent-owned Univision unit had missed interest payments. But Hallmark had set as a requirement of its tender offer that at least 90 percent of each issue must be tendered before it would be obligated to buy any of the securities. On Tuesday, Hallmark said it had dropped that requirement and accepted $162.7 million in subordinated discount notes and $89.2 million in subordinated debentures that were tendered under the offer. The securities tendered represented about 98.6 percent of the discount notes but only about 85 percent of the outstanding debentures. Hallmark also extended the tender offer, which was to have expired at 5 p.m. Tuesday, for another week until 5 p.m. April 24. The company has agreed to defer interest payments on the securities it purchases under the tender offer for five years. Univision Holdings, based in New York, operates an eight-station Spanish-language TV network that reaches an estimated 92 percent of Hispanic households in the United States. It was unable to make interest payments of about $10 million due on its bonds and bank debt in February because of what it called cash-flow problems. Hallmark offered to buy the bonds at a discount and defer interest payments on them. Its first buyback offer of $106 million failed to generate much interest, and it sweetened the offer to $131 million on March 30. It separately agreed with certain banks to reschedule Univision's bank loan repayments, provided it completed the tender offer for the bonds.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Up 12.3 Percent
DOC.TEXT: American Home Products Corp. on Tuesday reported a 12.3 percent gain in its first quarter earnings as the company benefited from a lower effective tax rate. Sales grew 3.8 percent for the diversified maker of consumer products including Woolite, Easy-Off oven cleaner and similarly well-known household names. The company earned $314.49 million, or $2.01 a share, in the three months ended March 31, up from $280.09 million, or $1.81 a share, in the corresponding 1989 quarter. Sales totaled $1.81 billion in the first quarter compared to $1.75 billion a year earlier. Results for 1989 were restated to reflect American Home Products' acquisition of A.H. Robins Co. Inc., the drug company that makes Robitussin cough syrup, Chap Stick lip balm and other products. Robins, facing numerous lawsuits stemming from its Dalkon Shield birth control device, entered bankruptcy court proceedings in 1985. American Home Products bought Robins last year. American Home Products said it had a lower effective tax rate in the first quarter because it used losses Robins previously had related to the funding of a trust to compensate victims of the Dalkon Shield.

DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose modestly Tuesday against all major currencies in light European trading following the long Easter weekend. Gold prices declined. The dollar started out stronger, then fell back after the release of data indicating continued strength in the U.S. economy, dealers said. ``It's a bit surprising that the dollar is coming down, because the figures were good and the U.S. interest rates are rising,'' said one dealer at a U.S. bank in Frankfurt. ``But before the trade figures are out, we don't expect anything to happen.'' The U.S. February trade report is scheduled for release on Wednesday. Traders said markets were quiet ahead of that data, which they expected to show a narrowing American trade deficit. On Tuesday, the U.S. government reported that industrial production rose 0.7 percent in March and consumer prices surged an unexpectedly sharp 0.5 percent last month. DOC.HEAD: Grains, Soybeans Futures Show Continued Strength
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures closed mostly higher Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as demand and cold wet weather in some crop-producing states affected the market. Soybean futures were higher on the strength of soybean oil, which posted contract highs from August outward. The bullish nature of soyoil is due to an expectation of tight domestic stocks for the remainder of the 1989-1990 marketing year. The National Oilseed Processor Association on Monday reported a drop in its March soyoil stocks, a period when inventories usually increase. Harvest delays in South America also proved to be a boost in soybean prices, said Jerry Zusel, an analyst with Balfour Maclaine Corp. in Chicago. Corn prices reached new contract highs due to concern over the cold and wet weather in the corn belt that has delayed planting. ``We could use a week to 10 days of dry weather to allow farmers to plant their crops,'' Zusel said, adding that the corn pit would turn bullish once the crop was in the ground and if the rain continued. Selling on the part of speculators sent old crop wheat futures down sharply. Analysts noted that old crop wheat has been selling at a premium because of demand. At the close, wheat was unchanged to 5{ cent lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.65 a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 3\ cents higher with May at $2.74 a bushel; oats were 4 cents to 5\ cents higher with May at $1.57} a bushel; soybeans were 4{ cents to 5} cents higher with May at $5.96 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: $263 Million Loss for 1989, More than Double Earlier Estimate
DOC.TEXT: Great American Bank lost a record $263.4 million last year _ more than double a previous estimate _ and may be taken over by federal regulators unless the thrift can raise $350 million by the end of the year, officials said Tuesday. Great American said in a statement that it may sell out or merge with another institution to raise the needed capital. The Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates savings and loans, has approved a plan requiring Great American to raise $350 million in capital by Dec. 31 to meet regulatory capital requirements. Great American reported in February that it lost $123.9 million in 1989, but a six-week audit revealed its losses actually totaled a record $263.4 million. It was one of the largest losses ever for a California thrift and exceeded the previous record by Imperial Savings, which federal regulators seized earlier this year after it posted a $259.1 million loss in 1989, the OTS said. Independent auditors who reviewed Great American's records found new problems stemming from loans Great American made in the Southwest, particularly in Arizona. The 1989 loss dropped Great American's capital level below all three of the new capital adequacy tests outlined in thrift bailout legislation approved by Congress last year. Much of Great American's problems have been attributed to its 1986 purchase of a Tucson thrift. Arizona has suffered an economic slowdown since then, however, which has left Great American with a portfolio of souring loans. In approving the institution's capital plan, regulators established growth limits and several operating conditions on the thrift that allow it to engage only in approved business activities like residential and consumer lending. Great American can't pay dividends or make other capital distributions without approval from regulators, who also have required the thrift's board of trustees to submit quarterly progress reports and meet quarterly capital targets. If it fails to meet any of the conditions, Great American faces strict operating limits and possible seizure by federal regulators, the thrift's statement said. Last month, Great American retained the investment banking firm of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. to help it raise capital. The bank and its advisers are exploring several alternatives, Great American said, including its possible sale or merger with another financial institution. Great American said it also is pursuing alternatives that would raise its capital levels, such as branch sales and other divestiture transactions. That strategy, however, probably would reduce the bank's earnings and leave it with a higher-level of low-quality assets. The thrift said it's not sure if regulators would approve those types of sales or, if they occurred, whether it would be sufficient to bring the bank into compliance with regulatory guidelines.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T and Two Unions Reach Tentative Agreement on Early Retirement
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. has reached a tentative agreement on an early retirement plan with two unions, part of the company's effort to cut costs. The plan, which would add three years of age and service to each worker's record on May 1, would nearly double the number of workers eligible for a pension to 34,000, said AT&T spokesman Burke Stinson. The plan allows some of AT&T's divisions to offer some workers greater retirement incentives _ five years added to age and seniority and a 15 percent boost in monthly pension payments _ in areas the company considers overstaffed, Stinson said. The unions affected are the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. IBEW spokesman Joe Penna said the special incentives are aimed at workers who would otherwise be laid off because their jobs have been made obsolete by technology. AT&T has 165,400 union workers worldwide. The proposal follows a similar package offered last year to managers as part of AT&T's six-year effort to reduce its workforce, consolidate operations and modernize equipment in the aftermath of the 1984 breakup of the Bell System. Last year 12,535 of 32,121 eligible managers opted to retire early under a plan that added five years to each manager's age and tenure, and boosted pension payments by 15 percent. There company has 116,000 managers. The management program cost AT&T $163 million and is expected to save $450 million annually, Stinson said. No one has estimated the savings from the latest proposal because it is not known how many workers and how many organizations with the company will participate in the early retirement plan, Stinson said. Penna said he expected about one-third of eligible union employees _ between 8,000 and 12,000 workers _ to opt for early retirement. He said the proposal was an improvement over an offer rejected last month by the unions. That plan would have added five years to each worker's age but would not have raised monthly pension payments. Penna said the new package is a victory for unions because it eliminates thousands of jobs through early retirement rather than layoffs. AT&T, with 280,400 employees worldwide, says it plans to cut 12,000 jobs this year. About 93,000 jobs have been eliminated since 1984, when a court order broke up the Bell Telephone monopoly into competitive regional companies.

DOC.HEAD: Value of Exports Doubled Last Decade
DOC.TEXT: Tobacco exports doubled in annual value in the 1980s, contributing nearly $25 billion to the U.S. trade ledger over the decade, an industry report said Tuesday. The study, released by the Tobacco Merchants Association of the United States, said exports increased to almost $5 billion in 1989 from $2.5 billion in 1980. ``Last year alone, while U.S. industry as a whole produced a merchandize trade deficit of about $109 billion, the U.S. tobacco industry contributed $4.2 billion to the positive side of the nation's trade ledger,'' the association said. The association, in its 75th year, said it represents all sectors of the tobacco industry, including growers, manufacturers, suppliers, dealers, distributors, securities firms and management consultants. Tobacco exports have come under fire from some U.S. health authorities and others who contend it is wrong to push sales overseas when Americans are being advised to quit smoking because of health risks. Before he retired Oct. 1, then-Surgeon General C. Everett Koop told Congress it was ``the height of hypocrisy to export tobacco.'' Koop had conducted a vigorous anti-smoking campaign while in office. Dean Kleckner, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, said American farmers and the U.S. economy benefit from the recent upswing in tobacco exports. Kleckner, in a statement, said that increased sales of tobacco leaf and products are a result of American farmers producing the type of product wanted by foreign customers. He also cited the removal of overseas trade barriers, primarily in Japan, Taiwan and South Korea.
