The Fed has been trying to keep inflation in check and the economy from overheating by keeping keeping rates relatively high. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was down more than $10 per $1,000 face value for much of the day, and the losses in the credit markets spilled over to stocks. But the blue chips, as they have done during a number of recent sessions when there is bad economic news, gradually regained ground, leaving the secondary stocks behind. This trend, known as a two-tier market, reflects trader caution. While investors are looking to buy, they want to stay with stocks perceived as the safest. Some analysts saw signs of strength in this pattern. ``The ability to come back shows we still have upside momentum,'' said Alfred E. Goldman, an analyst with A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis. ``There's still sideline cash that's willing to buy stocks after a modest price decline.'' Earnings reports influenced the performance of some stocks, most notably NCR, which fell 5] to 65] and topped the NYSE most active list after reporting a first-quarter profit decline. General Electric rose [ to 66~ after releasing results in line with the market's expectations. Among blue chip issues, AT&T was up [ to 42, IBM rose \ to 111[, and Philip Morris picked up | to close at 43. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market fell $688 million, or 0.02 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.03 to 188.91. Standard & Poor's industrial index slipped 0.13 to 400.29, while S&P's 500-stock composite index fell 0.06 to 344.68. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.28 to 435.42. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 354.72, down 2.26.

DOC.HEAD: Cocoa Prices Drop In Market Correction
DOC.TEXT: Cocoa futures fell sharply Tuesday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, reflecting what brokers called a market correction after a sharp runup in prices in recent months. On other markets, precious metals were mixed; grains and soybeans were mostly higher, energy futures were down, and livestock and pork futures were mostly lower. Cocoa settled $42 to $50 lower with the contract for delivery in May at $1,259. Cocoa futures had been rising because of concern over political unrest in the Ivory Coast _ the world's largest cocoa producer _ and lack of rain in other producing countries in West Africa, and in Brazil. Judith Ganes, an analyst with Merrill Lynch in New York, said Tuesday that emotions got ahead of facts in the runup of cocoa prices _ more than $300 a ton off last fall's 14-year low of $900. She said the export of cocoa from the Ivory Coast was complete when the unrest set in. Moreover, she said, recent rains have helped Brazil and West Africa. ``The rally wasn't justified in the short term,'' she said. ``It was time for a correction.'' Precious metals futures declined on New York's Commodity Exchange, as the dollar showed persistent strength against other major currencies. William O'Neill, an analyst with Elders Futures Inc. in New York, said higher than expected inflation rate of the Consumer Price Index released Tuesday had little effect on precious metals prices. Many investors historically have turned to gold and silver as a hedge against inflation. ``It (Tuesday's trading) showed that the only thing of importance (to precious metals) is the dollar,'' O'Neill said. Gold was unchanged to 10 cents lower with April at $375.20 a troy ounce; silver was 3.2 cents to 4.4 cents higher with May at $5.108 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures closed mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean futures were higher on the strength of soybean oil, which posted contract highs from August and beyond. The bullish nature of soyoil is due to an expectation of tight domestic stocks for the remainder of the 1989-1990 marketing year. The National Oilseed Processor Association on Monday reported a drop in its March soyoil stocks, a period when inventories usually increase. Corn prices reached new contract highs due to concern over the cold and wet weather in the corn belt that has delayed planting. Selling on the part of speculators sent old crop wheat futures down sharply. Wheat was a \ cent to 5} cent lower with May at $3.64} a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 3 cents higher with May at $2.74 a bushel; oats were 4 cents to 5\ cents higher with May at $1.57} a bushel; soybeans were 4{ cents to 6 cents higher with May at $5.96{ a bushel. Energy futures declined on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders continued to show concern about the abundant supplies of crude oil on the market. The price of crude was down despite Tuesday's meeting in Saudi Arabia of the oil ministers of that country, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. The ministers are meeting on how to best reduce oil production by 1 million barrels. Jerry Samuels, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York, said a meeting of OPEC ministers usually results in the firming of the energy market, but that was not the case Tuesday. He said there is scepticism the three oil ministers will come up a plan that would be acceptable to other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 41 cents lower to 6 cents higher with May at $17.44 a bushel; heating oil was 52 cent lower to .46 higher with May at 54.20 cents a gallon; unleaded gasolne was .15 cent lower to .23 cent higher with May at 60.44 cents a gallon. Livestock futures were lower and pork futures mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade. Livestock futures were .35 cent lower to .08 cent higher with April at 79.72 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to 53 cent lower with April at 83.95 cents a pound; live hogs were .63 cent lower to .30 cent higher with April at 56.45 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .60 cents lower to .20 cents higher with May at 59.20 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: New Bedford Fishing Fleet Snags Most Money
DOC.TEXT: New Bedford's fishing fleet pulled in the most money of any port's fleet in the nation, the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration in Washington said Tuesday. While the New England port only ranked 13th in pounds of catch, its fleet brought in $141 million worth of fish in 1989, said Barbara O'Banon, administration statistician. The high amount of scallops caught at an average price of $4.14 per pound contributed to New Bedford's top-earner status. The New Bedford port has been named the top port for its dollar catch four times in the last five years. Dutch Harbor, Alaska, brought in the most fish in 1989 with 504.3 million pounds. That port was also the second highest money maker at $107 million. Other top moneymaking ports and their 1989 dollar totals are: Kodiak, Alaska, $100.2 million; Petersburg, Alaska, $61.4 million, and Kenia, Alaska, $56.5 million. Other top ports and their hauls in pounds are: Cameron, La., 352.7 million; Pascagoola Moss Point, Miss., 282.1 million; Empire Venice, La., 272.7 million; and Kodiak, Alaska, 213.2 million pounds. New Bedford brought in 90.4 million pounds of fish in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: McGraw Hill's Profit Plunges; Gannett's Almost Flat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Belo earnings. Picks up 4th graf pvs, McGraw-Hill earned... ADDS 3 grafs detail on Belo earnings.
DOC.TEXT: McGraw-Hill Inc. Tuesday said its earnings tumbled 47 percent in the first quarter in part because it has become more vulnerable to seasonal swings in business since entering into a school publishing venture. The New York-based diversified publishing and information company reported revenue growth of 7.6 percent for the first three months of this year. The Gannett Company, meanwhile, reported a barely perceptible increase in first-quarter earnings. It said a sluggish consumer economy and restructuring in the retail industry combined to produce the poorest advertising environment in almost 20 years. Another media company, Dallas-based A.H. Belo Corporation, said its net income was up about 16 percent from last year as revenue rose due to higher classified advertising volume and a boost in broadcast revenue from state primary election campaigns. McGraw-Hill earned $16.49 million, or 34 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31, down sharply from $31.17 million, or 64 cents a share, a year earlier. Joseph L. Dionne, chairman and chief executive officer of McGraw-Hill, said the formation last year of a joint venture school publishing company, which was a major investment for the company, has increased business seasonality. The Macmillan_McGraw-Hill School Publishing Co. posted a loss in the first quarter, as expected. But Dionne said McGraw-Hill's share of the loss was smaller than expected and it is anticipated that full-year results will be fine. Last year's quarterly income was boosted by a one-time $8 million gain associated with a change in accounting procedures. There also was a lower tax rate in the first 1989 quarter than in this year's first quarter. One of McGraw-Hill's publications is Business Week magazine. It also has publications in various other specialized fields and broadcast interests. Gannett, headquartered in Arlington, Va., said earnings totaled $75 million, or 47 cents a share, in the quarter ended April 1, up slightly from $74.9 million, or 47 cents a share, the prior year. Revenue slipped less than 1 percentage point to $813.4 million from $817.6 million a year earlier. The company blamed the downturn on a loss in advertising revenue. Newspaper advertising revenue declined by 3 percent in the fist quarter. Gannett said broadcast revenue also was lower, but no figures were provided. Gannett, a nationwide news and information company, publishes 83 daily newspapers, and 52 non-daily publications. Besides publishing USA Today, the company operates 10 television stations, 16 radio stations and Gannett News Services. Belo posted a profit of $2.8 million, or 14 cents a share, in the first three months of the year compared with $2.4 million, or 12 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue rose to $56.3 million from $53.6 million reported in last year's first quarter. Belo owns and operates The Dallas Morning News, seven community newspapers in the Dallas-Fort Worth area and five televsion stations in several states.

DOC.HEAD: Restaurant Chain Battles McDonalds Over Texas Burger
DOC.TEXT: It could be called a case of Texas hamburglary. But to Lake Jackson restaurateur Richard Cox, the flap over McDonald's ``Texas Homestyle Burger'' is no laughing matter. ``We have been using the Texas burger concept for 17 years,'' said Cox, owner of the Red Top restaurant chain that features ``Texas Style Burgers.'' ``They copied everything we did,'' Cox, 45, said Monday. ``They thought it was a good idea and went ahead and used it, and they didn't think anyone would challenge them.'' Cox has sued and has obtained an injunction against McDonald's using the name in ads in his end of Brazoria County until June 4, when the case is to be tried. The man who heads the corporation that owns the six McDonald's in the county is doing some challenging of his own. ``He is trying to portray himself as a small independent businessman run over by a large corporation,'' said Robert D. Humason Sr. of Lake Jackson. ``He's fighting me. I'm down here struggling with six stores.'' Humason heads Dewey Corp., which owns the McDonald's restaurants in Brazoria County, south of Houston. Cox, who owns six Red Top restaurants in Brazoria County and one in Houston, said the McDonald's ad campaign for their burger is almost identical to his Texas Style Burger. In a petition, McDonald's denied using Cox's concept, saying its promotion relies on generic logos that don't belong to Cox. Humason said Cox didn't have the marketing concept registered and does not hold sole rights to the three words in contention. Cox said the McDonald's ads are so similar that confused customers have brought McDonald's coupons to Red Top. But Humason said of 174,000 coupons distributed during the marketing drive, only three were mistakenly taken to Red Top restaurants.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Record Quarterly Revenue and Big Jump in Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Microsoft Corp. on Tuesday reported record third-quarter revenues and a 83 percent increase in earnings from the same period a year earlier. The computer software giant said it earned $310.9 million for the quarter that ended March 31, a 58 percent increase over the $197 million for the same period a year earlier. Earnings totaled $75.2 million or 62 cents a share vs. $41.1 million or 36 cents a share. For the first nine months of the fiscal year, revenues were $846.5 million, 45 percent over the $583.3 million recorded one year earlier. Earnings for the three quarters of fiscal 1990 rose 59 percent to $199.2 million or $1.69 a share, compared with $125.2 million or $1.12 a share for the corresponding period of fiscal 1989. Jon Shirley, president and chief operating officer, said the record quarterly revenue was the result of continuing strength in all facets of Microsoft's operations. ``The international part of our business was strong and represented 58 percent of this quarter's revenue,'' he said. ``In the product area, the Microsoft Word family was particularly strong.'' Microsoft develops, markets and supports a wide range of computer software for business and professional use, including operating systems, language and application programs.

DOC.HEAD: Approve Name Change, Announce Purchase From GTE, Earnings Up 41 Pct
DOC.TEXT: United Telecommunications Inc. said Tuesday it will buy the remaining 19.9 percent of US Sprint and change its name to Sprint Corp. to cash in on the high profile of its long-distance subsidiary. United Telecom also reported a 41 percent rise in first quarter profits, but it said revenue growth was slower than expected at US Sprint and that competition was intensifying from rivals AT&T and MCI. US Sprint was formed in 1986 as a joint venture of United Telecom and GTE Corp. It is now the nation's No. 3 long-distance company with 8 percent of the market. United Telecom bought a controlling interest in 1988 and was given an option to buy the remaining 19.9 percent. The company will notify GTE by the end of May that it is ready to exercise the option and take full control, William Esrey, chairman and CEO, told Telecom shareholders at Tuesday's annual meeting in this Kansas City, Mo., suburb. The agreed selling price is about $500 million, Telecom spokesman Jerry Cosley said. Esrey said United Telecom's name would change July 1, when the transaction with GTE is expected to be completed. Shareholders approved the name change at the meeting. ``It's obviously not without some mixed emotions,'' retiring Chairman Paul Henson told shareholders. ``We think that Sprint Corporation tells the financial community more clearly what we are about. In addition, it has very high public recognition.'' The company also will shorten the long-distance subsidiary's name to Sprint, reflecting its attempts to expand overseas, Esrey said. Telecom's local telephone service subsidiaries, such as United Telephone of Kansas, will remain unchanged. Sprint's revenues were $1.2 billion in the first quarter vs. $984 million in the same quarter last year, an increase of 22 percent. But revenues increased only about 2 percent from the last quarter of 1989, less than the 4 percent to 6 percent forecast by company officials, Cosley said. ``This is an area that we are somewhat disappointed in, and that we are addressing,'' Esrey told stockholders. Cosley said some revenues from contracts already won by Sprint simply did not materialize during the quarter as expected because equipment wasn't installed. ``But those revenues will show up down the road,'' he said. Esrey told shareholders Sprint will introduce about 55 new products this year as competition in the long-distance market heats up. He noted that both American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and MCI Communications Inc. are developing fiber-optic telephone networks similar to the one Sprint built a few years ago and now touts in its advertising. ``Day-by-day, that advantage tends to shrink on us,'' Esrey said. ``We must now use our system to help us develop new products.'' He said the company would consider buying smaller long-distance companies as MCI did recently when it bought Telecom USA Inc. of Atlanta, the fourth-largest U.S. long-distance carrier. But Esrey said Telecom would proceed with caution. ``Certainly, if we can acquire customers by buying them, cheaper than we can through other ways, we will do it,'' he said. United Telecom said it earned $107.6 million or 51 cents a share on revenues of $2.02 billion in the first quarter, compared with $76.4 million or 36 cents a share on revenues of 1.77 billion a year earlier. The company's stock closed 25 cents lower at $39.87{ on the New York Stock Exchange. Also at the meeting, Henson, who had announced his retirement more than a year ago, officially stepped down after 31 years. He came to the company in 1959 as a vice president, was named president in 1964 and chairman in 1966. He is given much credit for helping to form Sprint in the mid-1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Inventor Seeks Damages in Windshield-Wiper Case
DOC.TEXT: Jurors who decided Ford Motor Co. stole the intermittent windshield-wiper design from its inventor now must consider how much the automaker should pay in damages. Maryland inventor Robert W. Kearns said he showed the windshield wiper to Ford engineers in 1962, detailing the system in an attempt to sell it to the company. Ford has sold about 20.5 million vehicles equipped with the Kearns-design wiper system. ``This phase of the trial is going to deal with two issues: damages and whether or not Ford's infringement was willful,'' U.S. District Judge Avern Cohn told jurors as the trial's damage phase opened Tuesday. Cohn instructed the jury to make its decision on an award amount based solely on the reasonable royalty due Kearns, disregarding any interest or legal fees incurred during his 12-year-old suit. In the opening arguments, attorneys for both Kearns and Ford presented different interpretations of how the jury should figure royalties. Kearns' attorney Paul Janicke told the eight-person jury that Kearns deserves 25 percent to 42 percent of Ford's profits from the device, or between $193 million and $325 million. ``But what is normally done when licensing patents in the auto industry is they tend to do things to the inventors rather than for them. There isn't reasonable compensation at all,'' Janicke said. Ford attorney Malcolm Wheeler denied that the automaker knowingly duped the inventor, saying its engineers believed they had developed the system themselves. ``When the jury returned the decision that Ford had infringed on the patents, that came as quite a blow,'' he said, referring to the Jan. 29 jury verdict. ``Ford's engineers did not act like people who thought they were stealing Mr. Kearns' designs.'' But the jury decided the Ford system was similar enough to Kearns' that it constituted patent violation. The Kearns system combines three elements _ an electric wiper motor, a driver switch and a control module _ all of which were included in the Ford version. Kearns also sued General Motors Corp., Chrysler Corp., Daimler-Benz, Honda, Toyota, Nissan and 21 other companies, claiming each has infringed on his patent. The Ford suit was the first to go trial. Kearns, a former resident of Detroit suburb River Rouge who now lives in Gaithersburg, Md., claimed the automakers violated patents he obtained between 1967-74.

DOC.HEAD: First-Quarter Profit Up 23 Percent; Sales Off
DOC.TEXT: Polaroid Corp. said Tuesday that first-quarter profit climbed 22.8 percent but sales declined slightly in a lackluster business environment. The photography giant reported net income of $31.8 million, or 43 cents per share, in the three months ended April 1, up from $25.9 million, or 29 cents per share, in the same 1989 quarter. Polaroid said last year's first-quarter earnings were depressed because of expenses related to fending off a hostile takeover attempt by Shamrock Holdings Inc. Polaroid said worldwide sales in the first quarter fell to $436 million from $442 million a year earlier. ``The general worldwide business environment has been slower than expected,'' Polaroid President and Chief Executive I. MacAllister Booth said in a statement. ``This, in combination with increased marketing expenses related to our long-term growth strategy, is reflected in our first-quarter results,'' he added. Booth said the company had lowered its expectations for 1990 but still believed it would show moderate growth in sales and operating profit for the year. Polaroid said first-quarter operating profits were $65.4 million, up from $34.9 million a year earlier. The year-ago figure reflected $38.5 million in expenses related to Shamrock's takeover bid. Polaroid supplies instant photography, cameras and films, as well as conventional films, videotapes and electronic visual communication products to family, business and technical and industrial markets.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Off Sharply
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 3 new grafs to indicate WTI at lowest level since February 1989. Picks up 4th graf pvs, The June ...
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures prices tumbled to their lowest levels in 14 months Tuesday as traders dumped futures contracts on the belief that sluggish short-term demand will do little to reduce abundant supplies. Refined petroleum products traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed mixed. The contract for May delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, slid 41 cents to $17.44 per 42-gallon barrel after inching up 7 cents on Monday. That was the lowest closing price for the near-month contract since West Texas Intermediate finished below $17 a barrel in February 1989, according to Elders Futures Inc. The June, July and August crude contracts posted smaller losses. The near-month contract took the hardest hit partly because traders assumed that any effort OPEC might make to cut world oil supplies would come too late to benefit the May contract, which expires Friday. The contract for May delivery of unleaded gasoline rebounded 0.23 cent to 60.44 cents a gallon after losing 1.66 cents on Monday. Contracts for delivery in June and July settled unchanged from Monday's closing levels while the August contract ended with a small drop. Among other refined petroleum products traed on the Merc, home heating oil for May delivery dropped 0.52 to 54.20 cents a gallon, wiping out much of Monday's gain of 0.89 cent. Later contracts were mixed. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery settled at $1.585 per million British thermal units, down from $1.598 on Monday. Most later contracts finished higher. Energy market analysts said the selloff in crude reflected a bearish supply and demand situation. A meeting of three OPEC ministers to discuss price weakness didn't produce any tangible results, analysts said. It is generally assumed that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will not undertake a radical production-cutting program to prop up world oil prcies. Andrew Lebow, a broker at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said oil prices also were weighed down by speculation that weekly statistics due late Tuesday after the markets closed would show another large buildup in crude inventory.

DOC.HEAD: First-Quarter Earnings Surge
DOC.TEXT: Honeywell Inc. said Tuesday that first-quarter earnings from continuing operations increased 63.5 percent, in part because of strong performances by its industrial and commercial flight systems divisions. Honeywell said net income rose to $83.4 million, or $2.12 per share, in the three months ended April 1 from $51 million, or $1.18 per share, in the 1989 first quarter. The earnings include an after-tax gain of $18.1 million, or 46 cents per share, from the sale of Yamatake-Honeywell shares, the company said in a statement. Earnings from discontinued operations totaled $6.7 million, or 17 cents per share, compared with $11.9 million, or 28 cents per share, in the first quarter of last year. Worldwide sales from continuing operations were $1.53 billion, up from $1.43 billion in the first quarter of 1989. Honeywell is provides products, systems and services for homes and buildings, industry, and aviation and space. The company had total 1989 sales of $6.1 billion. Honeywell said total company orders in first-quarter were flat. Excluding results from businesses sold in 1989, orders increased 4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Reports First-Quarter Earnings Increase
DOC.TEXT: Warner-Lambert Co. said Tuesday its first-quarter earnings rose 19 percent on an 8 percent sales increase. The health care and consumer products company said its earnings increased to $120 million, or $1.79 a share, from $101 million, or $1.49 a share, during the same period in 1989. Worldwide sales increased to $1.10 billion from $1.02 billion in the same period last year. Joseph D. Williams, chairman and chief executive, said all of the company's business segments contributed to Warner-Lambert's first-quarter growth. During the quarter, worldwide sales of the company's pharmaceutical products rose 10 percent to $359 million, while sales of non-prescription health care products increased 4 percent to $355 million. Chewing gum sales went up 9 percent to $250 million, while Warner-Lambert's other products grew 12 percent to $137 million in the first quarter.

DOC.HEAD: GTE Earnings Up 8 Percent
DOC.TEXT: GTE Corp. on Tuesday reported an 8 percent increase in first-quarter profit, citing strong performances by its telephone and other telecommunications businesses. Net income was $355 million, or $1.05 per share, up from $329 million, or 97 cents per share, in the first quarter of 1989, the company said. Revenue and sales were $4.5 billion in the three-months ending March 31, up 9 percent from $4.1 billion in the same period last year. GTE said revenue and sales from its telecommunications businesses rose 37 percent to $798 million. It attributed the increase to greater sales of government communications systems, cellular-mobile phone services and directory advertising. During the quarter, GTE received an $879 million contract for continued communications work for the U.S. Army. GTE said revenue from its telephone operations increased 5 percent to $3.2 billion. It said revenue rose despite a voluntary $101 million annual reduction in the rates charged certain carriers for access to GTE's local networks. The Jan. 1 reduction, along with a similar reduction last April, reduced revenue and operating income by $50 million. Sales of electrical products increased 3 percent, while operating income decreased 8 percent because of competitive pricing, lower results overseas and a softening in the automotive industry. ``I expect results from our lighting operations to improve as the benefits from the restructuring program initiated last year take hold,'' said James L. Johnson, GTE's chairman and chief executive officer. The restructuring will close two lighting plants and 17 warehouses and streamline the company's product delivery network.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's to Buy Recycled Goods to Build U.S. Restaurants
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp. said Tuesday it would seek to substitute recycled materials for at least 25 percent of the goods needed to build, remodel and equip its U.S. restaurants. The program _ dubbed McRecycle USA _ would create the nation's largest new market for recycled materials, the company said. ``We're the largest user of recycled paper products in the quick-service restaurant business,'' said Shelby Yastrow, McDonald's senior vice president of environmental affairs. ``Now, we're prepared to use our purchasing power to stimulate demand for a wide range of products made from recycled materials.'' Pressure has been building on fast-food and soft-drink companies in recent years to promote recycling because of the large quantity of trash they generate. McDonald's said its initial goal calls for spending $100 million a year on recycled products for its restaurants, or 25 percent of annual expenditures. Each year, McDonald's builds about 375 restaurants and remodels 1,000 in the United States. Products used include building insulation, timber, table tops, waste containers, wallboard and roofing materials. Ed Rensi, president of McDonald's USA, said in a statement that the $100 million target is in addition to more than $60 million the company already spends annually on recycled paper products such as napkins and drink carriers. Richard Denison, senior scientist for the non-profit Environmental Defense Fund in Washington, called McDonald's plan ``a significant step forward'' but said it should be ``just one step in a larger overhaul of their own operation.'' ``I think it demonstrates McDonald's willingness to take a leadership position on solid-waste issues,'' Denison said. ``I would hope that this is seen as something that would be emulated by other companies, not only fast-food companies but also other large chains in other areas _ for example retail stores and the like.'' In its announcement, McDonald's noted that last fall it began a recycling program for polystyrene food-packaging in 450 restaurants in New England. The company said it plans to expand the program to all its 8,200 U.S. restaurants ``as quickly as projected recycling facilities are opened.'' The announcement is intended to encourage companies to build more centers to recycle polystyrene, said Chuck Rubner, assistant vice president for McDonald's.

DOC.HEAD: Merc Members Vote on Dual Trading Restrictions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with vote approving proposed restrictions; picks up 10th graf pvs, `Congress also ...'
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange voted Tuesday to approve restrictions on the dual-trading of certain contracts as a proposed alternative to a federal crackdown on the practice. Dual trading, in which floor brokers trade for their own accounts and their customers' at the same time, is among practices the government investigated in a probe of suspected trading abuses at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade _ the nation's largest futures exchanges. It has long been considered a legitimate practice, but critics say it leads to the temptation of front-running, an illegal procedure in which traders try to make a profit trading for themselves ahead of their customers. The Merc and Board of Trade maintain that dual trading provides much of the market's liquidity. But the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the federal regulator of the futures markets, has proposed a partial ban on dual trading with an eye toward a possible total ban. The Merc's proposal would basically ban dual trading in the most heavily traded contract months, but would allow it in less active contract months for each commodity. The Merc said 76 percent of the 1,561 ballots cast favored the restrictions, which were drawn up by an exchange committee and approved recently by board of governors. The exchange has 2,500 active members. The Merc will ask the CFTC to accept the newly approved proposal in lieu of the agency's plan. The CFTC is expected to make a final determination on dual trading this summer, exchange spokesman Andrew Yemma said. Congress also is considering dual-trading restrictions that would potentially be more severe than those proposed by the Merc. The Merc's proposed restrictions were recommended by a committee that reviewed trading practices in light of the government probe, in which 48 people, mostly traders, have been indicted, Yemma said. The Merc's proposal would involve ``the most heavily traded contract months but it will not affect the lightly traded months which need the liquidity that dual trading provides,'' Yemma said. The exchange believes those contracts are more easily monitored because they are less active, he said. For example, in the Merc's pork belly futures pit, contracts are currently traded for delivery in May, July, August and February. Under the Merc's proposal, dual trading would be allowed for contracts in the more distant months, which tend to be less active. Even before the government probe was revealed last year, the Merc banned dual trading in 1987 for 90 percent of the trades in its Standard & Poor's 500 stock-index futures pit, Yemma said. ``There was a feeling among members in the pit that there were abuses of dual trading that needed to be addressed,'' he said. But Yemma said the Merc opposes the CFTC plan because it does ``not take into account the vital role that dual trading plays in fostering liquidity in back months and lightly traded contracts.'' The Chicago Board of Trade also believes the CFTC proposal goes too far, said Board of Trade spokesman Michael O'Connell. There currently are no restrictions on dual trading at the Board of Trade, and officials there want to keep it that way, O'Connell said.

DOC.HEAD: Ameritech Quarterly Earnings Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Ameritech said its earnings in the first quarter were nearly flat because of the cost of job cuts at the Midwest Baby Bell. American Information Technologies Corp. said earnings were $303.5 million, or $1.13 a share, compared with profits of $300.8 million, or $1.12 a share, in the first three months of 1989. Revenue increased 4.7 percent to $2.6 billion from $2.5 billion. The company, which provides telephone service in five Midwestern states, said earnings were affected by one-time expenses of about $54 million related to workforce cuts. Early retirement incentives were used to trim 1,265 jobs at Illinois Bell and Michigan Bell. Ameritech also is the parent of local Bell companies in Ohio, Indiana and Wisconsin.

DOC.HEAD: Del Monte Foods to Sell European Foods Business
DOC.TEXT: Del Monte Foods has agreed to sell its European processed foods division to an investor group for $355 million in cash and assumed debt. The group is led by affiliates of Charterhouse PLC of Britain and members of Del Monte's European division, known as DMFE, Del Monte said Tuesday. Del Monte has been selling assets to pay off debt acquired in January when the company was bought from RJR Nabisco for $1.47 billion by its managers and an investor group led by Merrill Lynch & Co. That sale, in turn, was designed to help RJR pay off debt incurred when the company was taken private in a record $24.53 billion buyout led by the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. The sale of the European operation and other recent divestitures ``were contemplated in the financing arrangements leading to the Jan. 9 acquisition,'' said Dr. Robert J. Carbonell, chairman and chief executive officer of Del Monte Foods. ``Our divestiture program is substantially ahead of the original timetable,'' he said. Proctor & Gamble Co. purchased Del Monte's Hawaiian Punch beverage business for $150 million in late January. Del Monte also has sold its Far East business, excluding the Philippines, to Kikkoman Corp. of Japan for $110 million.

DOC.HEAD: Scott Paper Reports Drop In Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Scott Paper Co. said its earnings dropped 31 percent in the first three months of 1990, in part because of the costs of expanding the company's printing and publishing papers business. Higher interest expenses and ``shortfalls'' in the company's food service business also contributed to the decline, the company said Tuesday. Net profit in the period totaled $60.1 million, or 82 cents a share, compared with $86.5 million, or $1.12, in the first quarter of 1989. Sales rose 2 percent to $1.3 billion from $1.27 billion. Sales at S.D. Warren's printing and publishing papers business were down 2 percent and income declined 31 percent in the first quarter, reflecting the costs of major capital projects at Muskegon, Mich., and Skowhegan, Maine. Scott Chairman and chief executive officer Philip E. Lippincott said those two projects ``are part of a very aggressive expansion program being undertaken around the world, where in 1989 and 1990 the company is starting up 10 new or rebuilt paper machines, nine this year.'' Increased capital spending and the purchase in 1989 of the company's common stock warrants boosted debt and led to higher interest expenses, the company said. Lippincott said overseas subsidiaries reported an 8 percent increase in sales and 18 percent gain in income in the quarter, primarily because of improvement in the Pacific region. Earnings from Scott's U.S. tissue business, its largest division, were up 7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Banker Gets 2 Years in Insider Trading Case
DOC.TEXT: A former junior bank official was sentenced to two years in prison and fined $25,000 for his conviction on 86 counts of wire and mail fraud in an insider trading scheme. Danny Omar Cherif, 35, a former assistant vice president at First National Bank of Chicago, also was sentenced to three years on special release and 300 hours of community service by U.S. District Judge James B. Moran. Federal prosecutors said Cherif returned to the bank after he was fired in 1987, gaining entry with an old bank key card he had tricked bank security officials into reactivating. Prosecutors charged Cherif copied documents from the bank's leveraged buyout division, acquiring non-public information on mergers and acquisitions in which the bank was involved. Cherif subsequently bought and sold stock in four companies, making $230,000 for himself and several thousand dollars for relatives and friends, prosecutors said. Cherif became a stockbroker for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. after he was fired from First National, but he lost that job after his indictment.
